questions.text: Which physiological change amongst the following isn't anticipated during laparoscopic surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Increased pH
 
  • Regarding pathophysiology of pneumoperitoneum - CO2 is rapidly absorbed across the peritoneal membrane into the circulation. In the circulation, CO2 creates a respiratory acidosis by the generation of carbonic acid.
  • Body buffers, the largest reserve of which lies in bone, absorb CO2 (up to 120 L) and minimize the development of hypercarbia or respiratory acidosis during brief endoscopic procedures.
  • Once the body buffers are saturated, respiratory acidosis develops rapidly, and the respiratory system assumes the burden of keeping up with the absorption of CO2 and its release from these buffers.

*[Extra Edge]: Pneumoperitoneum

The physiologic effects of CO2 pneumoperitoneum can be divided into two areas: (a) gas-specific effects and (b) pressure specific effects.


Fig: Carbon dioxide gas insufflated into the peritoneal cavity
  • Hypercarbia also causes tachycardia and increased systemic vascular resistance, which elevates blood pressure and increases myocardial oxygen demand.
  • The most common arrhythmia created by laparoscopy is bradycardia. A rapid stretch of the peritoneal membrane often causes a vagovagal response with bradycardia and, occasionally, hypotension.
  • The increased pressure of the pneumoperitoneum is transmitted directly across the paralyzed diaphragm to the thoracic cavity, creating increased central venous pressure and increased filling pressures of the right and left sides of the heart. If the intra-abdominal pressures are kept under 20 mmHg, the cardiac output usually is well maintained.
  • Increased intra-abdominal pressure decreases renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate, and urine output. These effects may be mediated by direct pressure on the kidney and the renal vein.
  • The direct effect of the pneumoperitoneum on increasing intrathoracic pressure increases peak inspiratory pressure, pressure across the chest wall, and also, the likelihood of barotrauma.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 455.

choices.text: Gives an immediate definitive diagnosis of tumor
Used for detecting positive margins after resection
Sentinel lymph node biopsy in breast carcinoma is an example

questions.text: Everything about intraoperative histopathological analysis is correct except the following statement:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Gives an immediate definitive diagnosis of tumor
 
  • Intraoperative frozen section may be helpful to determine the extent of surgery but cannot gives an immediate definitive diagnosis of tumor because the quality is inferior to that of routine material, resulting in a potential reduction in diagnostic accuracy and precision.
  • Pathologic confirmation of cancer is mandatory before initiating treatment, but this can be done by a biopsy with frozen section during the same anesthetic before a planned complete resection.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy in breast carcinoma is an example where Frozen can be done to determine the extent of surgery

Fig: Frozen section (FS) of a sentinel lymph node demonstrated the presence of a micrometastasis

* [Extra Edge]: Frozen section
 
  • Frozen section diagnosis is useful when a very rapid answer is necessary.
  • The surgeon supplies a small representative fresh tissue sample of the area of interest.
  • A BMS freezes the tissue quickly in the pathology laboratory and can produce sections for microscopic examination within several minutes. There are a few disadvantages in comparison with routine processing: fresh tissue carries a higher risk of infection; the quality is inferior to that of routine material, resulting in a potential reduction in diagnostic accuracy and precision; small but representative samples are necessary; certain types of tissue (e.g. fat) are difficult to process; and the process is time-consuming and disruptive.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 182.

questions.text: Which of these is the most dependable for monitoring fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Urine output

The easiest and most reliable method of assessing the adequacy of fluid resuscitation is by monitoring the urine output. 

The key to monitoring of resuscitation is urine output. Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour. If the urine output drops and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion (tachycardia, cool peripheries and a high lactate/metabolic acidosis), then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given. It is important that patients are not over-resuscitated; urine output in excess of 2 mL/kg body weight per hour should warrant a decrease in infusion.

Other measures of tissue perfusion such as lactate levels can be useful, particularly in larger burns. A persistent raised lactate/metabolic acidosis can indicate a missed systemic toxicity from cyanide or carbon monoxide. Patients with underlying comorbidities, particularly cardiac or renal, will require further intensive monitoring such as central venous pressure measurement in an intensive care setting.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 671.

questions.text: During surgery, a patient went into class 3 hemorrhagic shock due to an accidental injury to a critical vessel. Which cannula size should be used for immediate fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 16 Gauge

Amongst the given options - option (1) - 16 Gauge is the best answer.
In a patient with massive bleeding, there is always a risk of the patient going into shock and the widest bore cannula available showed be used for cannulation.
The ATLS guidelines recommend securing intravenous access with two large-bore cannulas (14-16G) in a patient needing resuscitation. 



Reference: ATLS® Advanced Trauma Life Support®, American College of Surgeons, 10th Edition, Page No 52.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the OPD with copious diarrhea and dehydration. Which cannula can be used to ensure the flow of large amounts of fluids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Grey

For quick fluid resuscitation in patients with dehydration, the grey cannula, which has a large bore (16 G) and a flow rate of 180 ml/min(maximum upto 240ml/min) , is the preferable cannula. 



Reference: ATLS® Advanced Trauma Life Support®, American College of Surgeons, 10th Edition, Page No 52.

questions.text: What colour is 16F Foley's catheter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Orange

It is a self-retaining urinary catheter made of latex. It has got a balloon near the tip into which distilled water is infused to make it self-retainable. Usually, Foley's catheter is kept for 7 days.
(F-French unit, Charriere unit, where each unit equals 0.33 mm). 16 F means circumference of the catheter is 16 mm. Diameter is one-third of circumference).

Fig: Catheter sizes are colored-coded at the balloon inflation site for easy identification

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 990.

questions.text: What is the modified shock index formula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Heart rate/Mean arterial pressure

Modified shock index (MSI) is defined as heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure.
  • Low systemic vascular resistance and a high MSI are indicators of hypodynamic circulation and a high stroke volume value, respectively. Low MSI, on the other hand, denotes a hyperdynamic condition. 
  • It is a better marker than Shock index for mortality rate prediction. SI is known as a hemodynamic stability indicator.
  • Whereas SI and MSI are statistically more accurate than one individual parameter, there is no substitute for the experienced clinician at the bedside. This may be the reason that SI and MSI have not been widely adopted.â€Š
* [Extra Edge]: Modified shock index
 
  • MSI is a more important clinical predictor than blood pressure and heart rate because MSI > 1.3 indicates a hypodynamic state.
  • Conversely, low MSI is also a predictor of increased mortality. This is commonly seen in patients with cerebrovascular diseases, chest pain and palpitations.
  • These patients often have increased ICP and arrhythmias, which can be easily identified.
 

SI = HR/SBP

MSI = HR/MAP

MAP = [(DBP × 2) + SBP]/3

(Where; HR = Heart rate; SBP = Systolic Blood pressure; DBP = Diastolic blood pressure; MAP = Mean arterial pressure)

the threshold values as HR at 120 beats per minute, SBP at less than 90 mmHg and SI at cut off 0.5-0.9 and MSI at less than 0.7 to more than 1.3. 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 51.

questions.text: What is the color of 22 Gauge IV cannula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Blue

The 22 Gauge IV cannula is blue in color. 
The higher the gauge number, the smaller the cannula.
Different sized cannulas move liquid through them at different rates, known as flow rates.



* [Extra Edge]: 
 

IV cannulas present minor risks to a person. Some potential risk include:

  • mild pain at the insertion site
  • blood clot formation
  • infection at the insertion site
  • bleeding
  • bruising
Mnemonic for Colour coding of Cannula-
Oh Great God Please Bless Your People
Oh- Orange- 14G
Great- Grey- 16G
God- Green- 18G
Please- Pink- 20G
Bless- Blue- 22G
Your- Yellow- 24G
People- Purple- 26G


Reference: Equipment in anesthesia and critical care, 1st Edition, Page No 294.

questions.text: What does the reference to French in Foley's catheter mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option 3 - Outer Diameter of catheter

#controversial


French or Fr scale is a scale that is used to determine the outer diameter of a catheter, not its circumference as commonly assumed.
1 Fr = 0.33mm in diameter
Outer diameter of a catheter = French(Fr) size/3 in mm
For eg, 6Fr Catheter - will have 6/3 = 2mm outer diameter. 

Note: It is a common misconception that it denotes outer circumference. For those who cleared NEET UG and did even elementary physics/maths and passed - will know that circumference of a circle is pi X diameter
Value of pi is 3.141 - not 3. So, a 6Fr catheter - will have a diameter of 6/3 = 2mm. But circumference would be pi X d(i.e 3.14 X 2mm) = 6.28mm - not 6mm. 
Hopefully, a little recap of Maths would have cleared the doubt - that Fr denotes outer diameter - not Circumference since pi is 3.14, not 3. 


Reference:
1. SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 990.
2. Catheters in vascular interventional radiology: an illustrated reviewhttps://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10679593/
3. NCERT Mathematics Class 7 Circles page 153

questions.text: Which of the following is not required on a preoperative patient surgical checklist?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Doctor's Signature

Doctor’s signature is not a part of 19 points Safety Checklist developed by WHO in 2009.

The WHO Surgical Safety Checklist is a simple tool designed to improve the safety of surgical procedures by bringing together the whole operating team (surgeons, anaesthesia providers and nurses) to perform key safety checks during vital phases of perioperative care: prior to the induction of anesthesia, prior to skin incision and before the team leaves the operating room.

+ Elements of the surgical safety checklist:
  1. Sign in: Patient's identity and consent
  2. Time out: Team confirms patient’s identity, surgical site and procedure.
  3. Sign out :Needle sponge and instrument counts are done.


Fig: Surgical Safety Checklist

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 241.

Online Reference: https://www.who.int/teams/integrated-health-services/patient-safety/research/safe-surgery/tool-and-resources

questions.text: Identify the muscle splitting incision.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lanz incision

A Lanz incision is a commonly performed abdominal incision for open appendicectomy.

  • The Lanz incision is an oblique incision made along Langer's lines and this is a muscle splitting incision.
  • It is also known as the Rockey-Davis incision and it is essentially a modification of the traditional Gridiron incision (also known as McBurney's incision).It is a transverse incision centred over McBurney's point (two-thirds from the umbilicus to the ASIS).
  • The incision extends medially to the lateral border of the rectus abdominis and laterally the same distance. It is commonly completed or open appendicectomy and is considered to have a better cosmetic result compared to the Gridiron incision.
The Kocher incision is a subcostal incision on the right side of the abdomen used for open exposure of the gallbladder and biliary tree.
  • This incision is just inferior and parallel to the subcostal margin. Unlike the midline incision, it is not an avascular plane.
  • The incision extends through the anterior rectus fascia, rectus muscle, internal oblique, transverse abdominis, transversalis fascia, and peritoneum.


The Rutherford-Morrison is an extension of the gridiron incision that is commonly performed for transplant surgery.

  • The Rutherford-Morrison incision is commonly completed for renal transplants.
  • It may be used on the left or right-hand side. The incision begins ~2 cm above the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and extends obliquely down and medially through the skin and deeper tissue cutting them along the line of the skin incision.


The Pfannenstiel incision is a commonly used transverse incision to perform pelvic surgery. 

  • Pfannenstiel's incision refers to a low transverse incision (10-15 cm) that is 2-5 cm above the pubic symphysis.
  • It provides excellent access into the intra-pelvic cavity.


Fig: Abdominal Incisions

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 98.

questions.text: You have been assigned to suture the incision following a midline laparotomy. Appropriate length of suture material should be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 4x incision length

+ Jenkins Rule: 
It is a rule for the mass closure of the abdominal wound. It states that for a continuous suture, the length of the suture used should be at least four times the length of the wound with sutures 1cm apart and with 1cm bites of the wound edge.


Fig: Jenkin’s rule – the amount of the suture should be at least four times the length of the wound

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 109.

choices.text: After partial expansion of lungs and <50 mL output from drain for 2 consecutive days
After complete expansion of lungs and <30 mL output from drain for 2 consecutive days
After complete expansion of lungs and <100 mL output from drain for 24 hours

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man who is a known case of myasthenia gravis underwent VATS thymectomy for thymoma. Intraoperatively, the surgeon inadvertently damaged the pleura and therefore decided to insert a chest drain in the pleural cavity. Which among the following parameters will help the surgeon decide on chest drain removal?

1. After partial expansion of lungs and <50 mL output from drain for 2 consecutive days
2. After complete expansion of lungs and <30 mL output from drain for 2 consecutive days
3. After complete expansion of lungs and <100 mL output from drain for 24 hours
4. On 4th day, irrespective of the output from the drain and lung expansion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3)  After complete expansion of lungs and <100 mL output from drain for 24 hours

Among the given options the most appropriate answer is  After complete expansion of lungs and <100 mL output from drain for 24 hours.

+Criteria for Chest Tube removal:
  • Stable clinical condition
  • Wide-open lung in X-ray of the tube thoracostomy
  • Discharge of less than 200 cc in twenty-four hours
  • No air leak

Fig: Chest tube with Underwater seal Drainage

* [Extra Edge]: ICD removal

Chest tubes may be safely removed following demonstrated pleural space evacuation, on underwater seal, with <300 mL output over prior 24 hours.
  • It is done once chest X-ray confirms that lung gas has expanded properly, pleural fluid drain becomes serous and less than 25 mU day for 3 consecutive days, water column movement becomes less than 1 cm.
  • It is removed under all aseptic precaution; suture is removed; patient is asked to take deep inspiration; often outer end of the tube may be connected to low volume suction.
  • At the summit of deep inspiration, tube is pulled out; wound is cleaned quickly and if sealing suture is present it should be tied firmly; sealed plaster dressing is placed to avoid re-entry of air into the plural cavity.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1107.

questions.text: Which of these scoring systems is used for research and monitoring and is useful in determining the degree of wound infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Southampton grading scale

* Audio Explanation:


Southampton grading scale and ASEPSIS wound score are used for research and monitoring and is useful in determining the degree of wound infection

+ The following options were given in the question:
  • Southampton grading is used for surgical site infections.
  • Glasgow score is a coma score to assess consciousness.
  • ASA classification is used to assess anaesthesia risk in a patient .
  • APGAR is a neonatal prognostic score.


Fig: The Southampton Wound Scoring System

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 27th Edition, Page No 48.

questions.text:
After receiving treatment for the infection following a laparotomy, a woman arrives with a ruptured abdomen. The doctor decides to suture again. What kind of suture material should be utilized out of the following?
1. 

2. 

3. 

4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 

The above Clinical Picture is of Acute Wound dehiscence or Brust Abdomen.

It is disruption of a laparotomy wound, occurring usually between 5th and 8th postoperative day.
At around 7–10 days postoperatively, leakage of clear or serosanguineous fluid from the wound is the first ominous sign of incipient dehiscence.


Fig: Abdominal wound dehiscence in a transverse incision with evisceration of bowel

* [Extra Edge]: Burst Abdomen

  • Usually sutures opposing the deep layers, i.e. peritoneum and rectus sheath tear through, causing burst abdomen-Acute wound failure.
  • It is a mechanical wound failure due to various factors causing separation of the closed abdominal wound often with evisceration of the contents.
  • Modified Smead-Jones closure mainly used to prevent burst abdomen-it is interrupted specialised suture used in the closure of abdomen as single layer excluding the skin. Number one polyethylene or PDS suture material is used. 
  • Nonabsorbable monofilament suture material is used for the closure even though evidence says that there is no difference between synthetic absorbable like polyglactic acid and nonabsorbable monofilament suture. Nonabsorbable suture causes prolonged wound pain but is preferred in risk category patients.
  • Suture bite interval should be 1 cm but not more; suture length and wound length ratio should be 4:1 or more but not less.

* Audio Explanation:

* [Extra Edge]: Management of Burst Abdomen
 
  • Primary deep fascial closure-deep tension/retention sutures
  • Delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or pack/opposite or Bogota bag 
  • Topical negative (vacuum) pressure closure
  • Delayed skin closure or skin graft over the dehiscence wound once it granulates well.
  • Component separation technique with primary fascial closure
  • Placing drain in subcutaneous plane
  • Suitable antibiotic therapy; fluid management
  • Prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome, hematoma or intra-abdominal abscess formation or sepsis
  • Blood or blood product transfusion; nutrition supplementation

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 732.

questions.text: The best way to treat a contaminated wound with necrotic material is to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Debridement

Best management of contaminated wound with necrotic material is debridement.

Exploration and debridement of wounds should be done to the limit of blood staining. With the obvious exception of nerves, arteries, and tendons, devitalized tissue must be removed till the bleeding occurs.

* [Extra Edge]:

Debridement plays a crucial part in the management of trauma. Wounds sustained in disasters are often heavily contaminated, containing foreign bodies and non-viable tissues. Debridement reduces the chances of anaerobic and necrotizing infections and can prevent systemic sepsis.
 
  1. After the administration of anasthesia, the injured area is copiously irrigated with normal saline. Lavage using a pressurised system is controversial, with concerns over tissue trauma and spread of debris. A waterjet based system that simultaneously clears the debris after debriding is very useful. The wound is palpated and all foreign matter removed. Dirt and debris enmeshed in soft tissues can only be removed by excision of those tissues. Open joints should be thoroughly irrigated and all foreign material removed.
  2. The next step is excision of all dead and devitalised tissue. At this stage the tourniquet is let down to check the vascularity of the tissues. Skin excision is kept to a minimum and only the margins of the wound need be trimmed back to healthy bleeding edges.


Fig: Gross contamination wounds in need of proper debridement

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 452.

choices.text: Minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definitive surgery later
Maximum possible surgical intervention is done immediately

questions.text: Which of these is true about damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definitive surgery later

Damage control surgery (DCS) is an approach of treating trauma patients with major injuries.

It can be divided into the following three phases: Initial laparotomy, Intensive Care Unit (ICU) resuscitation, and definitive reconstruction. 

Abbreviated laparotomy involves temporarily packing and closure of the abdomen to prevent further physiological complications caused by delayed shock and excessive hemorrhage.


Fig: Abdominal closure following damage control surgery

* [Extra Edge]: Damage Control Surgery
 
  • Damage control surgery aims to break the ‘vicious cycle’ of hypothermia, tissue hypoxia, coagulopathy and acidosis before later definitive repair. This is called " Trauma Triad of Death". Anatomy is restored when the physiology is optimised.
  • The principles are in sequence: (i) short operations aiming to control haemorrhage and limit contamination; (ii) ongoing correction of deranged physiology – acidosis, hypothermia, perfusion and organ function on intensive care; (iii) definitive surgical repair.
  • This is a key component of damage control resuscitation. The decision of whether damage control surgery is the appropriate course should be made early and allows the whole surgical and anaesthetic team to work together to limit the time in surgery and achieve the earliest possible admission of the patient to the ICU. Damage control is a staged process.

Fig: Trauma Triad Of Death
 
Stage Intervention
I Patient selection
II Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
III Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
IV Definitive surgery
V Abdominal closure
Fig: Stages of DCS


Fig: Criteria for Damage Control Surgery


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 385.

questions.text: Boiling water accidently splashes over the face and trunk of a 5-year-old child. Which of the following techniques is best for calculating the amount of body surface affected by burns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lund and Browder chart
 
  • When estimating burn size in young children, the head size must be taken into consideration as it has a larger relative surface area than other parts of the body.
  • The Lund and Browder chart can be used to get a more precise understanding of the actual burn size in children up to 5 yrs of age.
  • The body proportions of children necessitate adjustment of the above-mentioned scales. An infant’s head is proportionally larger than an adult’s and this adjustment is represented on the modified Lund and Browder chart for children, where at birth the head represents 18% and the lower limbs 13.5% each. For each year 1% is subtracted from the head, with 0.5% being added to each lower limb until the age of 10, when the body proportions are roughly equivalent to those of an adult.
  • The Lund and Browder chart can be completed at multiple points during a burn admission to document changes in burn size/depth and can also be used as an adjunct to surgical notes, when skin graft donor sites and grafted areas can be shaded.
* History:

Berkow reported the following proportions for adults, noting that they were not difficult for clinicians to remember: 1) lower extremities, 38 %; 2) trunk, 38 %; 3) upper extremities, 18 %; and 4) head, 6 %.
He concluded that 'if one bears these proportions in mind, estimating the extensiveness of a lesion is a very simple matter.
Furthermore, Berkow detailed why these adult proportions did not hold true for infants and children. Berkow's method for calculating surface area of various body parts in relation to TBSA was instrumental in later efforts by Doctors Lund and Browder (1944) in the development of the Lund-Browder Chart and by Wallace (1951) who simplified burn BSA assessment, resulting in the Rule of Nine or Wallace's rule of nines.



Fig: Modified Lund and Browder table and diagram

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: A three-year-old child has burns on their face and scalp with singeing of hairs , buttocks, and both thighs circumferentially. How much of the body's surface area is affected by burns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 37
 
  • For child below 5 years usually Modified Lund and Browder table is used, but for simplicity of calculations:
  • An infant’s head is proportionally larger than an adult’s and this adjustment is represented on the modified Lund and Browder chart for children, where at birth the head represents 18% and the lower limbs 13.5% each.
  • For each year 1% is subtracted from the head, with 0.5% being added to each lower limb until the age of 10, when the body proportions are roughly equivalent to those of an adult.
In the given question , closest answer is-37%
  • Circumferential burn of both thighs = 6 . 5 + 6.5 = 13
  • Buttocks= 2.5 +2.5 =5
  • Face and scalp with singeing of hairs = 17
  • Total burn area= 13+5+17= 35%

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 668.

questions.text:
After a laparoscopic hernia operation, the attending surgeon requests that you use 3-0 nylon to stitch the skin wound. Which set of tools are the ones you should use for suturing?


1. 


2. 


3.


 
4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 

A basic suturing kit includes the following:

  • A needle holder.
  • Toothed forceps, with a hook to handle tissue.
  • Fine suturing scissors.
  • The appropriate suturing material.

It’s very important to consider the suturing material that is used when performing the operation. In turn, choosing the right suturing material is made easy by considering the location and tension of the wound. Other equally important factors to consider about are the tensile and knot strength, handling of the wound, and tissue reactivity.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1150.

questions.text:
For a patient with breast cancer, a surgical attending has finished a modified radical mastectomy. Subcuticular sutures are required to be used to close the wound. Which suture will you pick from this list?
1. 

2. 


3. 

4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 

Monocryl Sutures 3-0 or 4-0 with cutting needle are used in closure of MRM wounds by subcuticular suturing.
Option 2 showing Vicryl is showing round bodied needle , hence not correct.

* [Extra Edge]: Subcuticular suture
 
  • This technique is used in skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily. The suture material used may be either absorbable or non-absorbable. For non-absorbable sutures, the ends may be secured using a collar and bead, or tied loosely over the wound. When absorbable sutures are used, the ends may be secured using a buried knot.
  • Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together, thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.
  • Monocryl Sutures 3-0 or 4-0 with cutting needle are mostly used in Subcuticular suture technique.
     

Fig: Subcuticular suture technique

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 108.

questions.text: How much ringer lactate could a 50 kg male with 2° burns expect to use in the first 8 hours with 40% burns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (3) -  2 litres

Ringer's lactate is the most commonly used crystalloid in burns as it most closely replicates the osmolality of plasma.

Fluid resuscitation is done as per the modified Parkland formula. 
Fluid required in 24 hours = 2ml/kg X TBSA(%)   (Body surface area involved in burn)
Note: 50% of calculated fluid is given over 8 hours, remaining 50% over 16 hours.

Inputing these values for the above scenario - 2ml/kg X 50kg X 40 = 4000ml (4L) in 24 hours. Therefore, 50% of 4L - i.e. 2L needs to be given in the first 8 hours. Hence, the correct option is Option (3) -  2 liters

Remember, Fluid requirement is different in
A.Children (<14y) =  [3ml/kg X Wt(kg)X TBSA(%)]
B.Electrical burns = [4ml/kg X Wt(kg)X TBSA %]



Reference: ATLS (Advanced trauma life support) 10th edition page 174

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the image's suture material is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Degraded by enzymatic degradation
 
  • Catgut suture undergoes enzymatic degradation by proteolytic enzymes present in the body, allowing for gradual absorption and breakdown of the suture material over time.
  • This degradation process is important for minimizing tissue reaction and promoting wound healing.
  • Catgut is made from sheep submucosa .
  • Frequent Use of Catgut is: To Ligate superficial vessels, suture subcutaneous tissues. Stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly.
* [Extra Edge]:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 106.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent layers undergoes a fasciotomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Skin+subcutaneous tissue+Superficial fascia+deep fascia
 
  • Fasciotomy is a surgical procedure performed to relieve compartment syndrome, a condition characterized by increased pressure within a closed muscle compartment.
  • During a fasciotomy, all subsequent layers, including the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia, are incised to release the pressure within the compartment and restore blood flow to the tissues.
* [Extra Edge]: 
 
  • Acute compartment syndrome occurs when there is increased interstitial pressure within a closed osteofascial compartment, which results in microvascular compromise.
  • It is a surgical emergency as delayed treatment may lead to irreversible muscle ischemia and significant long-term morbidity.
  • Compartment syndrome is generally a clinical diagnosis. It can be difficult to diagnose in the presence of impaired consciousness, in children and in patients with regional nerve blocks.
  • Monitoring intra compartment pressures (ICPs) can sometimes help to guide management. A pressure of ≤30 mmHg between the diastolic pressure and ICP has been recommended as the threshold for fasciotomy.
  • Fasciotomy involves incising the skin and deep fascia with long axial incisions. If the compartment pressure was high, the muscle will then be seen bulging out through the fasciotomy opening. The lower limb is reliably decompressed via two incisions. A medial longitudinal incision 1–2 cm posterior to the medial border of the tibia decompresses the superficial and deep posterior compartments. A lateral longitudinal incision 2 cm lateral to the anterior tibial border decompresses the peroneal and anterior compartments.

  • Late diagnosis of compartment syndrome is a management dilemma as a late fasciotomy may result in rhabdomyolysis, infection, need for amputation and even death.


    Fig: Fasciotomy of the leg

    Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 33.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS for a patient with a 25-year-old brain injury who has the following parameters: Disoriented, presence of eye opening in response to pain and ability to localize pain.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 11

Eye-opening in response to pain - E2
Disoriented (confused conversation) - V4
Localizing pain - M5
GCS, hence, would be 2+4+5 = 11

* [Extra Edge]: Glasgow Coma Scale and GCS-P score
 

The Glasgow Coma Scale provides a clinical index of the ‘overall’ acute impairment of brain function, or so called ‘conscious level’. When it was described, features of focal dysfunction such as brainstem signs were not incorporated and instead were intended to be assessed separately. Nevertheless, there have been views that indices or scores that combine an assessment of ‘conscious level’ and ‘brain stem’ function may have a useful place. In response, the GCS Pupils Score (GCS-P) was constructed to bring together information about a patient’s responsiveness as reflected in the GCS Score and the pupil reaction.

The GCS Score is derived by assigning notation to the level in each of the three subcomponents of the GCS and summing the results of a patient’s assessment. Further information on the GCS Score can be accessed. The Pupil Reactivity Score summarises Information about loss of pupil reactivity to light and is calculated as follows.

Pupils Unreactive to Light Pupil Reactivity Score
Both Pupils 2
One Pupil 1
Neither Pupil 0

The GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score:
* GCS-P = GCS - PRS


Fig: Revised Glasgow Coma Scale

GCS Score = (E[4] + V[5] + M[6]) = Best possible score 15; worst possible score 3

Reference: ATLS® Advanced Trauma Life Support®, American College of Surgeons, 10th Edition, Page No 110.

questions.text: Which one is not a part of ASEPSIS wound grading
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Induration

The ASEPSIS wound scoring method is an acronym for Additional treatment, Serous discharge, Erythema, Purulent exudate, Separation of deep tissues, Isolation of bacteria, and Stay as inpatient prolonged over 14 days.
This is a scoring system for the severity of wound infection, which are particularly useful in surveillance and research.


Fig: ASEPSIS wound scoring

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 48.

questions.text: How is the below pressure sore graded
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Grade 4

If underlying bone or muscle is visible as shown in this image, it becomes grade 4 bed sore.

* [Extra Edge]: Stages of Pressure Sores

+ Common sites for pressure injuries and ulcers-

Ischium, Greater trochanter, Sacrum, Heel, Malleolus, Occiput.


Fig: Stages of Pressure Sores

+ Management of Pressure Ulcers:
 

Non-operative management is generally considered for patients who have a stage 1 or 2 ulcer. No conservative treatment option has proved superior to other options.

This management is quite similar to preventative management and it involved:

  • Pressure Offloading
  • Enzymatic Wound debridement
  • Wound cover using adequate dressings. No dressings has been proven to be superior than other wound dressings
  • Antibiotic cover

Non-operative debridement includes autolytic, enzymatic, larval, mechanical. These types should be considered when there is no urgent clinical need for drainage or removal of devitalized tissue. The current evidence for this is mixed.

Patients with a stage 3 and stage 4 pressure ulcer should be considered for operative management.

Absolute indications for surgical debridement include necrosis, advancing cellulitis, crepitus, fluctuance, and/or sepsis secondary to ulcer-related infection. There should be a high index of suspicion of biofilm if present >4 weeks and lacks signs of any healing in the previous 2 weeks.

The choice of reconstruction depends on location, size, and depth of the pressure sore. Each choice has benefits and limitations, as discussed below.

  • Skin Grafting: often lack sufficient bulk and strength, which results in a high failure rate.
  • Fascio cutaneous Flaps: durable, well-vascularised but limited bulk may not be sufficient for deeper wounds. For example, a rotation flap or rhomboid flap.
  • Musculocutaneous flaps: provide more depth of coverage, higher bacterial resistance.
  • Free Tissue Transfer: This has been described by is less commonly utilised.

In these cases, patients may require a bladder and/or bowel diversion.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 35.

questions.text: In the image below, the patient is in the following position:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Reverse Trendelenburg position

The image given in the question is that of the Reverse Trendelenburg position as head is elevated.
Reverse Trendelenburg position: Used in Upper Abdominal surgeries like Lap Cholecystectomy, surgeries of head and neck. 

+ Objectives of correct surgical positioning:

â— Facilitate safe anaesthesia and surgery
â— Reduce adverse physiological insults
â— Optimise surgical exposure and ergonomics
â— Maintain patient’s dignity by avoiding unnecessary exposure

* [Extra Edge]: Supine position in OT table


This is the most common position for general surgical procedures. The patient’s arms may be placed by their side or extended to afford access to intravenous and arterial cannula. This is a versatile position and can be modified as follows:

â— Rose’s position: slight neck extension for head and neck surgery.
â— Shoulder and arm extended: to assist in axillary and breast surgery.
â— Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted down on an incline with the patient’s knees slightly flexed. This is often used in pelvic procedures and when resuscitating a patient in shock.
â— Reverse Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted up, thereby placing the head higher than the feet.

+ In advanced laparoscopic surgery, exaggerated and frequent position changes during the course of the operation are used to enhance surgical exposure. An excellent example would be in laparoscopic resection of the rectum, wherein the table is tilted to the right to aid in left colon mobilisation; a neutral or reverse Trendelenburg position is used to mobilise the transverse colon; and pelvic dissection is completed with a steep Trendelenburg position. This can only be achieved if the patient is well positioned and secured.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 96.

questions.text: A drain as shown in the given image was placed in operative bed post right sided modified radicle mastectomy. What type of drain is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Closed

A surgical drain is a tube used to remove pus, blood or other fluids from a wound. The given image shows a Romovac drain which is a closed type of drain. There are 3 types of drains :

Closed drains : Utilise suction action for drainage. 

Semi - Open drain : Utilise the principle of capillary action. 

Open drain : Utilise the effect of gravity for drainage.

* [Extra Edge]: Current role of drain placement in gastrointestinal surgery


+ Avoid routine drain placement following

â— Colonic surgery

â— Small bowel resections
â— Hepatic resections
â— Cholecystectomy

+ Consider routine drain placement following

â— Oesophageal surgery

â— Major pancreatic resection

+ Selective use of drains following


â— Rectal surgery
â— Gastric resections


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 115.

questions.text: When suturing, what is the angle between the skin and the needle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 900 
 
  1. In order to reduce the size of the entry incision and encourage eversion of the skin edges, the needle should always enter the skin at a 90° angle. 
  2. Depending on the thickness of the skin, the needle should be inserted 1–3 mm from the edge of the wound.
  3. The specific suturing technique determines the depth and angle of the suture.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 104.

questions.text: What is the most frequent reason for post-operative hospitalization in an outpatient (daycare-based) procedure/surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Nausea and vomiting

The most frequent causes of post-operative hospitalization are pain followed by Nausea and Vomiting (PONV) Followed by bleeding/Hemorrhage and urinary retention 
Since pain is not given in the options - Nausea and Vomiting (PONV) is the most appropriate answer. 

Reference: Kulkarni S, Harsoor SS, Chandrasekar M, Bhaskar SB, Bapat J, Ramdas EK, Valecha UK, Pradhan AS, Swami AC. Consensus statement on anaesthesia for day care surgeries. Indian J Anaesth. 2017 Feb;61(2):110-124. doi: 10.4103/ija.IJA_659_16. PMID: 28250479; PMCID: PMC5330067.

questions.text: How soon may an elective surgery be performed on a symptomatic COVID patient who doesn't need to be admitted to the hospital?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 6week
 
  1. After recovery following COVID-19, the scheduling of elective surgery is determined using both severity- and symptom-based categories. 
  2. 4 weeks for a patient who is asymptomatic or who only has minor, non-respiratory symptoms. 
  3. 6 weeks for a symptomatic patient (e.g., cough, dyspnea) who did not need hospitalization. 
  4. 8 to 10 weeks for a symptomatic diabetic, immunocompromised, or hospitalized patient.
  5. 12 weeks for a patient who was admitted to an intensive care unit as a result of contracting COVID-19.
Reference: Glasbey JC, Dobbs TD, Abbott TEF. Can patients with asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection safely undergo elective surgery? Br J Anaesth. 2022 Jun;128(6):909-911. doi: 10.1016/j.bja.2022.03.003. Epub 2022 Mar 10. PMID: 35369990; PMCID: PMC8907026.

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient who is a known case of peptic ulcer disease presented to emergency with pain in abdomen since 6 hours, RR- 24/min, BP readings of 90/50 mm of Hg and spO2 of 92% on 10 litres of air. A chest X-ray performed showed air under diaphragm.Which of the following step needs to be undertaken before shifting the patient to OT??
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: 2 to 3 liters of crystalloid infused
 
  • The patient's clinical presentation, including abdominal pain, hypotension, and gas under the diaphragm on the chest X-ray, suggests a perforated peptic ulcer with pneumoperitoneum.
  • Before shifting the patient to the operating theater (OT) for definitive surgical management, initial resuscitation is essential.
  • Infusing 2 to 3 liters of crystalloid helps stabilize the patient's hemodynamics and correct any hypovolemia before undergoing surgery.

Free gas under diaphragm 


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 671.

questions.text: Within 4-6 hours, a child starts dribbling saliva, has swallowing difficulties, and appears with a high-grade fever and inspiratory stridor. Which of the following needs to be administered in addition to airway management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) IV ceftriaxone
 
  • The symptoms described, including dribbling saliva, swallowing difficulties, high-grade fever, and inspiratory stridor, are consistent with acute epiglottitis.
  • Epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis. The most common causative organism is Haemophilus influenzae type B.
  • Airway management is a priority in these cases, and IV ceftriaxone is the antibiotic of choice to cover the likely pathogen.
  • Antibiotics like cefotaxime or ceftriaxone are used to treat HIB infection.



Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1107.

questions.text: Methylene blue is injected in the peritumoral area as seen in the provided image. Which of the following procedures is being carried out?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is a surgical procedure in which a single lymph node or a small group of lymph nodes are identified and removed to determine whether the cancer has spread beyond the primary tumor to involve regional lymph nodes. 

The procedure utilizes methylene blue, which is injected near the primary tumor. The dye reaches the sentinel node (the first node in the chain that receives the lymphatic drainage from the tumor) which can then be precisely identified and removed through lymphatic mapping.

The sentinel lymph node is then examined microscopically for the presence of cancer cells; if none are found, then it is assumed that the cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes and further surgery may not be necessary.


Fig: fluorescein dye – the fluorescent sentinel lymph node is seen with blue light


Fig: blue dye (methylene blue) – blue sentinel lymph nodes and lymphatics are seen in the axilla. Sentinel lymph nodes are marked with an arrow

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 937.

questions.text: What do we mean by Class 3 hemorrhagic shock?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A melanoma with a depth of 0.5 mm should have the following recommended margin for a wide local incision:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 1 cm
 
  • A melanoma with a depth of 0.5 mm requires a wide local incision.
  • The recommended margin for a wide local incision in this case is 1 cm.
  • The margin refers to the distance of healthy tissue that should be removed along with the melanoma to ensure complete excision and reduce the risk of recurrence.

questions.text: An elderly person, who is bed ridden for many years, was having a bedsore as shown in the figure. What is the grade of this bedsore?
questions.solution:
The given image is of Grade 4 pressure sore characterized by extensive tissue destruction extending up to the muscle layer. 

Grades of pressure sore:
 
  1. Stage 1- Erythema with no blanching or breach in the epidermis.
  2. Stage 2- Partial thickness skin loss with epidermal and dermal involvement.
  3. Stage 3- Full thickness skin loss with intact fascia but involvement of subcutaneous tissue. 
  4. Stage 4- Full thickness skin loss with involvement of muscle, bone, tendon or joint. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 29, 30.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about neurogenic shock?
questions.solution:
Neurogenic shock manifests as hypotension, bradyarrhythmia, and temperature dysregulation due to peripheral vasodilatation following an injury to the spinal cord.

Clinical features of different types of Shock:





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 402.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding split graft and full thickness skin graft? 
(i) Primary contraction more with split skin graft 
(ii) Secondary contraction more with split skin graft 
(iii) Primary contraction more with full thickness skin graft 
(iv) Secondary contraction more with full thickness skin graft
questions.solution:
The correct statements are:

(ii) Secondary contraction more with a split skin graft.
(iii) Primary contraction more with full-thickness skin graft.

Explanation:
Primary contraction refers to the immediate shrinkage that occurs after graft placement. Full-thickness skin grafts involve the transplantation of both the epidermis and the entire dermis. As a result, full-thickness grafts generally undergo more primary contraction compared to split-thickness grafts. Split skin grafts have more secondary contraction. 




Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page no 1917 .

questions.text: A patient planned for surgery is to be given neoadjuvant chemotherapy. What is meant by neoadjuvant chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
Preoperative, or “neoadjuvant,” treatment involves the administration of adjuvant systemic therapy, most commonly chemotherapy, before definitive surgery and radiation therapy.
The objective of neoadjuvant chemotherapy is to reduce the bulk of the tumor.
Treatment given as a first step to shrink a tumor before the main treatment, which is usually surgery, is given. Examples of neoadjuvant therapy include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. It is a type of induction therapy.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 208, 933.

questions.text: All of the following are advantages of laparoscopic surgery over open surgery except?
questions.solution:
Following are the advantages of laparoscopic surgery: 
  1. Less post-operative pain
  2. Better cosmesis
  3. Shorter hospital stay
  4. Early recovery
  5. less intraoperative adhesions
  6. Better anatomy perception (as image can be magnified)- early recognition of burns if any.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 103.

questions.text: The following finding was observed. Identify?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an ulcer with punched-out edges over a pressure point on the plantar surface, most likely that of a trophic ulcer/ neuropathic ulcer.
A neuropathic ulcer is a result of peripheral neuropathy due to lack of sensation over the pressure points leading to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that remain unnoticed but eventually develop into ulcers.
Features of a neuropathic ulcer include:
  • ï»¿ï»¿Painless (due to lack of sensation)
  • Margins: Regular; Punched-out appearance; Presence of calluses on the margin
  • Location: Plantar surface of foot
The following causes of leg ulceration are important differential diagnoses:
  • Arterial/ ischaemic ulcers (option A)
    • Pale/ necrotic
    • Skin changes: shiny, loss of hair
    • Over joints and bony prominences
  • Venous leg ulcer (option B)
    • Gently sloping edge
    • Floor: Granulation tissue
    • Location: Gaiter region (between muscles of calf and ankle)
  • Neuropathic ulcers/ trophic ulcers
  • Neoplastic ulcers/ malignant ulcers (option D)
    • Elevation of the ulcer edge (overturned edges)
    • Requires biopsy to exclude squamous cell carcinoma
  • Infections (example - tuberculosis)
  • Vasculitic ulcers
  • Traumatic ulcers

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 111.

questions.text: An adult diabetic patient complains of pain over the gluteal region on sitting and after 24 hours develops discharge from behind the scrotum and undergoes surgical debridement extending deep to the fascia. Black necrotic material was removed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This rapidly progressive fasciitis of the genitalia and perineum represents Fournier’s gangrene, a type of necrotizing fasciitis, a necrotizing soft tissue infection.
The infection is often polymicrobial and spreads along dartos, Scarpa’s, and Colles’ fascia.
Risk factors include:
  • Perirectal abscesses
  • Diabetes and obesity
  • Chronic alcoholism
Fournier gangrene is a necrotizing infection of the male genital and perineal skin and subcutaneous tissues, similar to other progressive fasciitis and necrotizing soft tissue infections. When the genitalia are involved, patients typically present with significant pain and tenderness, scrotal and genital swelling, discoloration or frank necrosis, crepitus, and, at times, foul-smelling discharge. Fournier gangrene is usually a polymicrobial infection with microaerobes, anaerobes, and gram-positive and gram-negative organisms.

Treatment requires urgent surgical drainage with aggressive debridement of the necrotic tissue, broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics, and intensive monitoring with supportive care. The magnitude of the debridement depends entirely on the degree of progression of the process.
It is rare for the process to involve the testicles or deep tissues of the penis deep to the tunica vaginalis and Buck fascia, respectively, so these structures should be preserved. It is uncommon for the urethra to be involved, although a defined urinary tract source may be evident, such as a urethral stricture, with perforation and local infection.



Fig: Fournier gangrene. Skin necrosis, purulence, and edema of the scrotum.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 2067.

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been doing this job for a long time, but the symptoms are recent in onset. What is the likely mechanism involved in this disease?
questions.solution:
Raynaud’s syndrome may follow the use of vibrating tools.
Thus, it is a recognised industrial disease and is known as ‘vibration white finger’ or vibration Raynaud syndrome/ hand-arm vibration syndrome.
  • Direct damage to vessels and neural dysfunction is implicated in vibration-induced RP.
  • Raynaud’s syndrome occurs due to peripheral vasospasm (abnormal thermoregulatory response by sympathetic nervous system) and is more common in the upper extremities.
It may occur due to exposure to the following:
  • Cold temperatures
  • Tobacco
  • Emotional stress
  • Occupation groups: Vibrating tools
  • Raynaud phenomenon: secondary to scleroderma, SLE, Sjogren’s and APLA
The characteristic changes are as follows:
  • Intense pallor (white attack)
  • Cyanosis (blue attack)
  • Reactive hyperemia
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 2112.

questions.text: A chemist sustained burns due to cylinder explosion to anterior region of chest and abdomen as well as burns to right upper limb and circumferential burn to his right thigh. What is the percentage of burns?
questions.solution:
9+9+9+9=36
  • Right Upper Limb 9%
  • circumferential right thigh 9%
  • anterior chest 9%
  • Anterior abdomen 9%

questions.text: What is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients?

Causes of hypercalcemia in malignancy are-
Increased bone breakdown, Pseudohyperparathyroidism -d/t release of PTH related Peptide, Dehydration ,Kidney injury, prolonged immobilsation.

questions.text: Identify the incision marked number 5?
questions.solution:
The Modified Gibson incision is a transverse incision above the pubis, frequently used in gynecological and urological surgeries.
This incision can be made on either side of the midline, but often on the left. It is started 3 cm above and parallel to the inguinal ligament and extended vertically 3 cm medial to the anterior superior iliac spine up to the umbilicus.




Reference: Jelinek LA, Marietta M, Jones MW. Surgical Access Incisions. [Updated 2024 Oct 5]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK541018/

questions.text: Open cardiac massage , what category of wound classification will it belong to?
questions.solution:
Open Cardiac massage is contaminated wound.
These include open accidental wounds, Gross spillage of GI tract, surgeries with major break in sterile technique. Eg- Penetrating abdominal trauma.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 225.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with painless, fleshy, exophytic lesions on the surface of the genitalia. She is 14-weeks pregnant. It is found to be caused by low-risk strains of HPV. Which of the following is the safest and can be used to manage this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has genital warts (condyloma acuminata) caused by low-risk HPV strains during pregnancy. Management must prioritize safety for both mother and fetus.

Key points:

  • Cryotherapy:

    • Safe in pregnancy

    • Non-systemic, can be applied directly to lesions

    • Minimal side effects, no teratogenic risk

  • Other options:

    • Imiquimod & Fluorouracil: Contraindicated in pregnancy due to systemic absorption and potential teratogenicity

    • Trichloroacetic acid (TCA): Also safe but cryotherapy is generally preferred because it is less caustic and easier to control

choices.text: Proliferative phase > Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Remodeling phase
Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase
Inflammatory phase > Hemostatic phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase
Remodeling phase > Proliferative phase > Destructive phase > Inflammatory phase

questions.text: What is the correct order of the normal phases of wound healing?
questions.solution:
The normal wound healing process occurs in a well-defined sequence of overlapping phases:

  1. Hemostatic phase: Immediately after injury → platelet aggregation, clot formation, and release of growth factors.

  2. Inflammatory phase: Hours to a few days → neutrophils and macrophages clear debris and pathogens; cytokines are released.

  3. Proliferative phase: Days to weeks → fibroblasts, angiogenesis, collagen deposition, and granulation tissue formation.

  4. Remodeling (maturation) phase: Weeks to months → collagen remodeling, tensile strength increases, scar formation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. Which of the following is seen in the lesion?
questions.solution:
The provided history, along with the image showing an ulcer on the face with pearly, rolled-out borders, suggests a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

Basal cell carcinoma is an epithelial tumor that originates from basal cells and is the most prevalent type of skin cancer. It typically appears on the face, particularly above the line connecting the corners of the mouth and the lobule of the ear.

Risk factors for developing BCC include:

Ultraviolet (UV) radiation (the strongest risk factor)
Age between 40 and 80 years, especially with a history of excessive sun exposure
Being light-skinned
Exposure to arsenic compounds, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and infrared light

Basal cell carcinoma is more common in males than in females and is associated with certain genetic syndromes, including xeroderma pigmentosum and Gorlin's syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form the boundary of Hesselbach's triangle?
questions.solution:
The vas deferens does not contribute to the boundary of Hesselbach's triangle.

Hesselbach's triangle, also known as the inguinal triangle, is a region on the deep surface of the anterior abdominal wall. The boundaries of

Hesselbach's triangle are as follows:

Medial boundary: Lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle.
Lateral boundary: Inferior epigastric vessels.
Inferior boundary: Inguinal ligament.
This triangle is clinically significant because direct inguinal hernias commonly occur through this area, particularly in cases of abdominal wall weakness.

questions.text: A patient complains of experiencing pain in the calf region after walking a certain distance. He reports that he needs to rest to relieve the pain. Which grade of Boyd's grading system does this symptom correspond to?
questions.solution:
The patient's pain subsides with rest, indicating a classification of Grade III according to Boyd's classification of claudication.

Boyd's classification is commonly used to assess the severity of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) based on the occurrence and intensity of symptoms. Grade III is characterized by intermittent claudication, where the patient experiences muscle pain, cramping, or weakness in the lower limbs (typically in the calves) after walking a specific distance or engaging in physical activity. The pain typically resolves with rest, indicating a moderate severity of PAD.

Boyd's classification of claudication:

Grade I: Pain occurs after walking but subsides with continued walking due to increased blood flow and collateral circulation washing away pain-inducing metabolites.
Grade II: Pain persists during walking, but the patient can continue walking with effort.
Grade III: Pain requires rest for relief.
Grade IV: Pain occurs even at rest.

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of chronic smoking is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip stage. Further investigations revealed that the lymph nodes are not involved. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
For early-stage (no lymph node involvement) squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lip, the treatment of choice is surgical excision with negative margins.

Key points:

  • SCC of the lip:

    • Most commonly affects the lower lip.

    • Early-stage (T1-T2, N0) lesions have excellent outcomes with surgery alone.

  • Margins:

    • Negative margins (typically 0.5–1 cm) are crucial to reduce local recurrence.

    • Frozen section can be used intraoperatively but is not mandatory in all cases.

  • Other treatments:

    • Radiotherapy: reserved for patients unfit for surgery or with positive margins.

    • Chemoradiotherapy: used in advanced disease with nodal involvement or unresectable tumors.

questions.text: In a triage system, highest priority patients are respectively colour coded by
questions.solution:
In triage systems, color coding is used to prioritize patients based on the urgency of their condition:

  • Red: Immediate / highest priority — life-threatening injuries, require urgent intervention to survive.

  • Yellow: Delayed — serious but not immediately life-threatening, can wait for a short period.

  • Green: Minor / minimal — walking wounded, can wait longer for care.

  • Black: Expectant / deceased — injuries incompatible with life or already dead.

questions.text: In a patient who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, what is the ideal urine output?
questions.solution:
The ideal urine output for a patient after laparoscopic cholecystectomy is 0.5-1.5 mL/kg/hour. In the postoperative period, normal urine output is expected, which in adults typically ranges from 0.5 to 1.5 mL/kg/hour, or approximately 1500 mL per day. To adequately eliminate the end products of protein metabolism, a minimum daily urine output of 400 mL is required. Normal urine output over a 24-hour period is calculated as 0.5-1.5 mL/kg/hour, resulting in a total of 12-36 mL/kg per day.

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 331 .

questions.text: In a patient presenting with rectal prolapse, which of the following procedures is not done via the perineal approach?
questions.solution:
The Ripstein operation is an abdominal approach for managing rectal prolapse.

Rectal prolapse can be treated using two main approaches:

Perineal approach: This method is easier to perform and has fewer complications, but it carries a higher recurrence rate. The surgeries performed using this approach include:

Thiersch's wiring

Delorme‘s mucosectomy

Altemeier‘s procedure (perineal rectosigmoidectomy)


Abdominal approach: This method is more complex, associated with higher complication rates, but it has a lower risk of recurrence. Surgeries in this category include:

Moschcowitz repair

Ripstein and Wells rectopexy

Ventral rectopexy (suture rectopexy)

Resection rectopexy



When a patient is fit for an abdominal procedure, it is generally preferred over the perineal approach due to the lower recurrence risk. However, the perineal approach is typically favored for elderly patients with comorbidities and young men, as the abdominal method can potentially damage the pelvic autonomic nerves, leading to sexual dysfunction.

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1399 .

choices.text: Rest pain is seen more in the night
The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction
Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking

questions.text: Which of the following statements about claudication pain is not true?
questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication pain, which arises during walking, does not typically start with the very first step.

Peripheral artery occlusion or stenosis is often caused by atherosclerosis, atheroma, or thromboembolic disease. Such occlusions or stenoses affect the organ supplied by the obstructed artery. In the lower limbs, this results in claudication pain, rest pain, and gangrene. Although claudication affects muscle groups located one anatomical level below the site of arterial obstruction, the clinical symptoms may not directly indicate the exact location of the peripheral arterial blockage.

Intermittent claudication pain, linked to arterial stenosis or occlusion, arises due to anaerobic metabolism in the muscle. This type of claudication pain can be categorized as follows:

Vascular (intermittent) claudication: Triggered by walking and relieved by rest within 5 minutes.

Claudication pain upon taking the first step: Typically associated with osteoarthritis.

Neurogenic claudication: Occurs with changes in back position, such as bending forward or straightening, and takes longer than 5 minutes to relieve. This can result from nerve compression due to lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or spinal stenosis.

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 997-999 .

questions.text:
A 73-year-old patient presents with painless rectal bleeding. Which of the below-mentioned investigations are done for this patient?
A. Colonoscopy
B. CECT
C. CEA
D.CA 19-9
questions.solution:
In an elderly patient presenting with painless rectal bleeding, a colonoscopy, contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT), and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) test may be considered. Serum CA 19-9, a biomarker for pancreatic cancer, is not relevant in this case.

Rectal bleeding typically indicates pathology in the lower gastrointestinal tract, below the ligament of Treitz. Potential causes of rectal bleeding include:

Colon cancer

Inflammatory bowel disease

Diverticular diseases

Hemorrhoids

Angiodysplasia


Colonoscopy with biopsy is crucial for diagnosing inflammatory bowel disease, distinguishing between ulcerative colitis and Crohn's colitis, and monitoring treatment response. It is also the preferred method for investigating suspected colorectal cancer, especially in older patients. Angiodysplasia, common in individuals over 50, can also be identified through colonoscopy.

CT colonography is effective in detecting polyps and is less invasive than colonoscopy. Spiral CT can be useful for diagnosing complicated diverticular disease.

CEA is a non-specific serum biomarker that can be elevated in colorectal cancer, so it may be useful in this case.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2469,2470,2474 .

questions.text: Feeding is done through the given method. Which of the following is not a complication of this?
questions.solution:
The provided image illustrates a central line. Patients receiving total parenteral nutrition via a central line may face complications such as pneumothorax, osteoporosis, and refeeding syndrome. Aspiration pneumonia, which is more commonly associated with enteral feeding, can be mitigated by positioning the patient in a semi-recumbent posture during feeding.

Enteral nutrition complications can be categorized as follows:

1. Tube-related (most common): These include malposition, displacement, blockage, breakage or leakage, and local issues such as skin or mucosal erosion.


2. Gastrointestinal: Issues may consist of diarrhea, bloating, nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, aspiration, and constipation.


3. Metabolic/biochemical: Complications in this category include electrolyte imbalances, deficiencies in vitamins, minerals, and trace elements, and drug interactions.


4. Infective: These can be exogenous, related to handling contamination, or endogenous, stemming from the patient‘s own conditions.


 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 338-340 .

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard treatment for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The gold standard treatment for varicose veins is endothermal ablation. This technique uses heat, typically from radiofrequency or laser energy, to close off and collapse the affected veins, effectively treating the condition.

The given image depicts tortuous, dilated veins, characteristic of varicose veins, which are a common vascular condition often seen in the legs due to malfunctioning valves in the veins.

New Treatment Modalities for Varicose Veins:
1. Foam sclerotherapy:
A popular method for this is the Tessari method, where foam is prepared by mixing the sclerosant with air in a 1:3 or 1:4 ratio. The foam is injected into the veins to induce closure.
2. Endovenous glue therapy:
This involves the endoluminal application of cyanoacrylate adhesive, which seals the veins and leads to eventual collapse and absorption of the varicose vein.
3. Transilluminated powered phlebectomy:
A technique that uses transillumination (light-guided visualization) to assist in the removal of varicose veins through small incisions.
These modern treatment options are less invasive and often result in quicker recovery times compared to traditional surgical methods.

questions.text: Which of the following is the class of shock where urine output is first decreased?
questions.solution:
Urine Output and Shock: In moderate shock, urine output is typically the first parameter to decrease.

Classification of Shock:
Shock can be categorized into three stages:
1. Initial Non-Progressive Stage
2. Progressive Stage
3. Irreversible Stage


Monitoring Shock: Urine output serves as the most reliable clinical indicator to assess the effectiveness of therapy in patients experiencing shock.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in all kinds of shock?
questions.solution:
Shock is defined as a systemic condition marked by inadequate tissue perfusion, which fails to support normal cellular respiration.

Hypovolemic Shock results from a decrease in circulating blood volume. Common causes include:
Hemorrhage
Dehydration
Vomiting
Third-spacing (fluid accumulation in the interstitial space)

Obstructive Shock occurs when there is a mechanical obstruction that reduces preload, impairing cardiac filling. Causes include:
Cardiac tamponade
Tension pneumothorax
Massive pulmonary embolism
Air embolism

Cardiogenic Shock is characterized by the heart's inability to effectively pump blood to the tissues. Causes include:
Myocardial infarction
Cardiac dysrhythmias
Valvular heart disease
Blunt myocardial injury
Cardiomyopathy

Distributive Shock is a condition where there is a decrease in oxygen delivery primarily due to reduced systemic vascular resistance, leading to vasodilation. This type of shock is distinctive because it often involves a compensatory increase in cardiac output. Causes include:
Spinal shock
Anaphylaxis
Septic shock

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
Lactate dehydrogenase is not included in the qSOFA score.

qSOFA Scoring Overview
The qSOFA (quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) is a simplified version of the SOFA score designed for bedside assessment, particularly useful in non-ICU settings, as it does not rely on laboratory values.

The qSOFA assigns one point for each of the following parameters, indicating a potentially life-threatening sepsis when at least two are met:



SOFA Scoring Overview
SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system, particularly effective in the ICU setting. It evaluates the following organ systems:

Circulation: Systolic blood pressure and need for vasopressors, as well as platelet count.
Respiration: PaO2/FiO2 ratio and need for mechanical ventilation.
Mentation: Glasgow Coma Scale score.
Hepatic function: Bilirubin levels.
Renal function: Creatinine levels.
Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ? 2.

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman with no comorbidities presents with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no history of smoking or history of other illnesses. She mentions the episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image, along with the history of no previous illness in a young female, is most indicative of Raynaud's phenomenon.

Raynaud's Phenomenon:
It is characterized by episodic digital ischemia caused by the vasospasm of digital arteries.
Cold exposure or emotional stress can trigger these episodes.
During the blanching/ischemic phase, symptoms such as pallor or cyanosis occur, often accompanied by numbness and paresthesia.
Capillaries and venules dilate, leading to cyanosis due to the presence of deoxygenated blood in these vessels.
The color changes are usually well-defined and confined to the fingers or toes.
In the rewarming phase, the digital vasospasm resolves, and blood flow into the dilated arterioles and capillaries increases dramatically, causing reactive hyperemia, which imparts a bright red color to the digits.
Some individuals may experience only pallor and cyanosis, while others may exhibit both.

questions.text: A 30 year old female presented with burns involving both her upper limbs and front of chest. Calculate the percentage of burn according to the rule of nine.
questions.solution:
Burns on both upper limbs would add to 18% (9% for each limb).
Burns on the front of her chest would add to 9%. Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 18%+ 9%=27%.
Ref: Schwartz's Principles of Surgery - 11th edition • Page no: 252, 253

choices.text: It can progress to squamous cell cancer
Long duration antibiotics will improve the condition
It can be prevented by early excision and grafting of burn wounds
The prognosis is poor with high recurrence rate

questions.text: A 75 year old female presented with a non healing ulcer over the leg as shown below.She gives history of electrocution a few years ago.Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image is suggestive of Marjolin's ulcer. Marjolin ulcers most commonly arise from burn scars. The most common cell type identified is squamous cell carcinoma. All suspicious lesions should be biopsied. Confirmed cases of Marjolin ulcers should be excised with clear margins. Marjolin ulcers can be prevented with early excision and grafting of burn wounds. The prognosis is poor with a high rate of recurrence. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities include cautery ablation, cryotherapy, drug therapy including imiquimod. Chronic antibiotics are not used for the treatment of Marjolin's ulcer.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition • Page no 747

choices.text: X-ray can be used in case of suspicion of a metallic foreign body

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with severe pain and swelling in her right hand which is increasing in size and severity. She had a prick injury while in the garden 5 days back. On examination, she cries out in pain when you try to extend the hand and palpate the palmar aspect passively. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
questions.solution: The given image and history is suggestive of deep palmar abscess. Collar button abscess is an abscess that occurs in the web space between fingers. Mainstay of treatment for deep palmar abscess includes: incision and drainage, exploration under anaesthesia to remove the foreign object, IV antibiotics and analgesics. Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics, 13th edition • Page no 3814

questions.text: The most common source of bleeding during laparoscopic repair of bilateral direct inguinal hernia is ?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic hernia repair is particularly indicated in bilateral hernias, recurrent hernias after open repair, and in patients who prefer a minimally invasive approach. Techniques include transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) repair and totally extraperitoneal (TEP) repair.
During a laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair, the dissection is carried out near the myopectineal orifice of Fruchaud, where the inferior epigastric artery runs medially, branching off from the external iliac artery. This artery is of particular concern because it is located near the internal inguinal ring, a key anatomical landmark in hernia surgery. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 20th Edition • Page no 1127

choices.text: Excision can be done if the patient makes a request
The tumor is not fluctuant in nature

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with a painless swelling over the right shoulder. On examination the swelling was non pulsating and slip sign was positive. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image is suggestive of a lipoma. Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose tissue. It can occur anywhere and at any depth. It can be encapsulated or diffuse, superficial or deep.
On examination, they are nontender and non-pulsatile. Because of the soft consistency, they may appear to be fluctuant but they are not. The slip sign is positive.
Diagnosis is mostly clinical. Biopsy/FNAC is rarely indicated in case of clinical doubt of malignant transformation. All lipomas need not be excised. Excision can be done on request for cosmetic purposes or in case of suspicion of malignancy.
SRB Manual of surgery, 6th edition • Page no 69

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis in a male who presents with unilateral testicular swelling which is transilluminant . The examiner could not get above the swelling. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, there is a unilateral scrotal swelling in which the examiner cannot get above the swelling, and is transilluminant points towards a diagnosis of hydrocele.
Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis.
Hydrocele can be congenital or acquired. Congenital hydrocele is seen in children due to patent processes vaginalis. Acquired hydrocele can be secondary to inflammation or infection of the epididymis or testes.
