It is translucent on transillumination test and testes will not be separately palpable due to tense fluid collection. Ref - Schwartz principle of surgery 11th edition Page 1635

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with a complaint of dilated and tortuous veins in the left leg and mild pain while walking. On palpation, the vein is pulsatile. He had a history of road traffic accident, including a left leg fracture 10 years ago. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of trauma and a recently developed pulsatile swelling of the same side has a traumatic arteriovenous fistula.
An arteriovenous fistula is an abnormal communication between an artery and a vein and tends to occur when two structures are in proximity. Traumatic AV can occur secondary to penetrating and blunt trauma. The most common traumatic AV fistula is a carotid-cavernous fistula secondary to the base of the skull fracture.
Clinical features: pulsatile swelling and in chronic cases- limb lengthening, arterialisation of veins and heart failure. Large extremity fistula may present with skin warmth in contrast to cool extremity and signs of venous hypertension which is usually seen in varicosities.
Diagnosis: Ultrasonography can detect flow anomalies. CT angiography can provide anatomic delineation. Ref- Bailey and Love 28th edition Page 1027

choices.text: Donor site heals rapidly and can be reused

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the graft used in the given image
questions.solution:
The given image shows a split skin graft also known as Thiersch graft.

Split-thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft): consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts. Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:
• Large grafts can be harvested
• In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
• Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft takeup.
• Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Reference Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 27th Edition • Page no 639

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the pathophysiology of Hypovolemic shock?
questions.solution:
Following are features of Hypovolemic shock- Low cardiac output, increased systemic vascular resistance, reduced preload, low mixed venous saturation and high base deficit.


Bailey and Love 28th edition Page 13-14

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulceration?
questions.solution:
• Gastroduodenoscopy (endoscopy): The investigation of choice for suspected peptic ulcer disease. It allows direct visualization of the ulcer, biopsy for H. pylori or to rule out malignancy, and assessment of complications like bleeding or perforation. 

  • CECT: Usually reserved for complications (perforation, obstruction) or suspected malignancy, not first-line. 

  • Barium meal: Can detect ulcers but cannot provide biopsy; less sensitive for small or subtle lesions. 

  • Barium swallow: Mainly used for esophageal lesions, not for peptic ulcers. 

    Punched out defect in a case of peptic ulcer on Gastroduodenoscopy 



Reference: Bailey's and love short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1119

questions.text: What nutrient deficiency is commonly associated with delayed wound healing following minor surgery?
questions.solution:
Zinc is essential for wound healing as it plays a key role in:

  • Collagen synthesis
  • Cell proliferation and immune function
  • Epithelialization and tissue repair

Why Zinc Deficiency Delays Wound Healing?

  • Impaired fibroblast function → Poor collagen production
  • Reduced immune response → Higher risk of infection
  • Delayed keratinocyte migration → Slower re-epithelialization

Reference: Harper's illustrative biochemistry 31st edition page no 583

questions.text: An elderly male patient presents with persistent fatigue and anemia. Given his clinical profile, what is the recommended screening protocol for colon cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Colonoscopy: Recommended as the primary screening test for colorectal cancer in average-risk adults aged ≥50 years. If normal, it is repeated every 10 years. It allows direct visualization and biopsy. 

  • Fecal occult blood testing (FOBT): Can be used, but usually annually, not every 2 years, and is less sensitive. 

  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy: Examines only the distal colon; screening is usually every 5 years, not annually. 

  • Barium enema: Older modality, rarely used today due to lower sensitivity and inability to perform biopsy. 

Key point: Colonoscopy is the gold standard for screening, diagnosis, and prevention by allowing polyp removal.


Reference
1.Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 20th Edition - Page no 1233
2.Schwartz's Principles Of Surgery - 10th Edition - Page no. 1567

questions.text: A male patient presented with swelling in his lower limb. The clinical image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with swelling of the lower limb, which is chronic and symmetric. If the swelling is associated with thickened skin, peau d’orange appearance, and non-pitting edema, it is characteristic of lymphedema due to lymphatic filariasis.

Key points:

  • Lymphatic filariasis: Caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, or Brugia timori. Leads to chronic lymphatic obstruction, elephantiasis, and thickened skin.

  • DVT: Usually presents acutely with unilateral swelling, pain, warmth, and tenderness. Pitting edema is common early.

  • Edema: General term; can be pitting or non-pitting. Not specific to filariasis.

  • Mansonelliasis: A filarial infection but rarely causes limb swelling; mostly mild, transient, or subclinical manifestations.

Hence, the most likely diagnosis is lymphatic filariasis.



Reference:Panikers textbook of medical parasitology 8th edition page no 215-216

choices.text: Yellow - Significant injuries, hemodynamically stable patients, required monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about triage, according to the internationally accepted four-color-coded system?
questions.solution:
Patients that require monitoring and have substantial injuries but are hemodynamically stable are assigned a yellow color tag. They are patients with a middling priority.

Treatment priorities are categorized through the use of triage. Determining which patients need emergency medical assistance, transportation, or hospital admission is done on the scene of the accident.

Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 26th edition page no 857

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with halitosis, dysphagia, and regurgitation of food. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The triad of halitosis (foul breath), dysphagia, and regurgitation of undigested food is classic for Zenker’s diverticulum, also known as a pharyngoesophageal or pulsion pseudodiverticulum.

Key Features:

  • Site: Just above the upper esophageal sphincter (Killian’s dehiscence).

  • Type: Pulsion pseudodiverticulum — mucosa and submucosa herniate through the muscular layer.

  • Symptoms:

    • Dysphagia (initially to solids, later to liquids)

    • Regurgitation of undigested food

    • Halitosis due to food stasis

    • Aspiration and cough (especially at night)

    • Gurgling sound in the neck on swallowing


Other options:

  • Achalasia cardia: Causes dysphagia to both solids and liquids from the start, with regurgitation of saliva or food but no halitosis or nocturnal aspiration.

  • GERD: Presents with heartburn and acid regurgitation, not undigested food; halitosis is uncommon.

  • Esophageal carcinoma: Causes progressive dysphagia (first solids, then liquids) and weight loss, but no regurgitation of undigested food.



Reference:Sabistons textbook of Surgery 21st edition Page no 1025-1026,1028-1029

choices.text: Consume small, frequent meals with increased protein.
Consider reversing the surgical procedure to Billroth II

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with loose stools occurring  15-20 minutes post meals. She recently underwent a Billroth I gastrectomy operation. What is the most appropriate initial management for him?
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with early dumping syndrome, a known complication following Billroth I (and II) gastrectomy.

It occurs 15–30 minutes after meals due to rapid gastric emptying of hyperosmolar food into the small intestine, leading to fluid shifts and gut hormone release.

Symptoms:

  • Cramping, diarrhea

  • Palpitations, sweating

  • Dizziness, weakness

Initial management:
Dietary modification is the first-line approach —

  • Eat small, frequent meals

  • Increase protein and fat content (slows gastric emptying)

  • Avoid simple carbohydrates

  • Lie down for 20–30 minutes after eating to delay gastric emptying

Other options:

  • Omeprazole + amoxicillin: for peptic ulcer/H. pylori, not dumping syndrome.

  • Insulin: for diabetes, not indicated here.

  • Reversal to Billroth II: reserved for refractory severe cases, not initial management.

questions.text: Which of the following should be used for pre-operative management in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
n patients with pheochromocytoma, excess catecholamine secretion (epinephrine, norepinephrine) leads to severe hypertension and tachyarrhythmias.

The pre-operative goal is to control blood pressure and expand plasma volume before tumor manipulation.

Stepwise management:

  1. Alpha-blockade first (essential):

    • Drug of choice: Phenoxybenzamine (non-selective, irreversible α-blocker)

    • Alternatives: Prazosin, Doxazosin (selective α1-blockers)

    • Started 10–14 days before surgery to normalize BP and reduce vasoconstriction.

  2. Beta-blockade (only after adequate α-blockade):

    • Used to control tachycardia.

    • Never started before α-blockade — as unopposed α-stimulation can cause hypertensive crisis.

Other options:

  • Nitroprusside: Used for intraoperative BP control, not preoperative preparation.

  • Calcium channel blockers: May be used as adjuncts but not as first-line for pre-op control.

Mnemonic:
“A before B” — Alpha before Beta.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 2739-2745

choices.text: What is the next appropriate step in management?

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room after a road traffic accident in an unconscious state. He has a head injury. On examination, he has bradycardia and hypertension. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was 6. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient has a GCS score of 6, which indicates severe traumatic brain injury.

Key points:

  • GCS ≤ 8 is a standard indication for airway protection via endotracheal intubation.

  • The patient is unconscious, making him unable to maintain airway or protect against aspiration.

  • Bradycardia and hypertension suggest Cushing's triad, indicating increased intracranial pressure (ICP).

Management priorities:

  1. Airway: Intubate and ventilate to maintain oxygenation and normocapnia.

  2. Breathing: Ensure adequate oxygen delivery.

  3. Circulation: Maintain adequate blood pressure to ensure cerebral perfusion.

  4. Imaging: Once the airway is secured, urgent CT head is warranted to identify the type and location of injury.

Other options:

  • Administer IV fluids: Supportive but secondary; airway takes priority.

  • Thrombolysis: Contraindicated in trauma.

  • Urgent CT head: Necessary, but airway must be secured first in an unconscious patient with GCS ≤8.

In severe head injury with GCS ≤8, airway protection via intubation is the immediate next step, followed by imaging and other supportive measures.


Reference
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 27th Edition - Page no 1349

questions.text: Management of an appendicular mass in appendicitis is ___
questions.solution:
The Ochsner–Sherren regimen is the standard conservative management for an appendicular mass. It involves bed rest, antibiotics, and careful observation, allowing the mass (formed by the inflamed appendix walled off by omentum and bowel loops) to resolve. An interval appendectomy may be considered later once inflammation has subsided.

Other options:

  • Incision and drainage: Considered if there is a fluctuant abscess.

  • Laparoscopic appendicectomy: Not the first choice in a well-formed appendicular mass.

  • Alvarado regime: Refers to a diagnostic scoring system for appendicitis, not its management.


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1312

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presents with extreme pain in the right side of his trunk. On examination, blisters and a woody surface are noted. The image of his trunk is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient is elderly and diabetic, which are key risk factors for necrotizing soft tissue infections.

  • Clinical features supporting necrotizing fasciitis:

    • Severe pain disproportionate to physical findings.

    • Blisters/bullae and a woody, firm indurated surface.

    • Rapid progression of symptoms.

  • Other options:

    • Gas gangrene: Usually associated with trauma, crepitus, and gas on imaging.

    • Cellulitis: Less severe pain, diffuse erythema, no woody induration.

    • Erysipelas: Superficial infection, well-demarcated redness, usually not necrotic or blistered.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 978,1192

questions.text: A male patient with a history of burns in his left lower limb presented to the OPD with the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Marjolin's ulcer is a malignant transformation (usually squamous cell carcinoma) that arises in chronic wounds, scars, or old burn sites.

  • Key features: non-healing ulcer, raised edges, bleeding, foul discharge, often many years after the initial burn.

  • Other options:

    • Infected burn wound: Usually presents acutely, with redness, warmth, pus, and pain; develops shortly after injury.

    • Venous ulcer: Typically occurs over the medial malleolus, associated with chronic venous insufficiency, not old burn scars.

    • Arterial ulcer: Occurs over pressure points, often painful, with pale base and associated with peripheral arterial disease.

Clue: Chronicity and prior burn history are classic indicators for Marjolin’s ulcer.


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 605,984,997

questions.text: A male patient comes to the outpatient clinic with dilated tortuous veins in his lower limb. Varicose veins is suspected. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Duplex ultrasonography is the investigation of choice for varicose veins. It allows:

    • Visualization of venous anatomy

    • Assessment of venous reflux

    • Evaluation of deep and superficial venous systems

  • Other options:

    • Plethysmography: Can assess venous function but is not first-line for diagnosis.

    • MRI/CT scan: Rarely used; only for complex or atypical cases.

Clue: Non-invasive, widely available, and provides both anatomic and functional information—makes Duplex scan the standard choice.



Reference: Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 28th edition page no 1030-1039

questions.text: A patient with a direct hernia is posted for Lichtenstein repair. Which of the following is used in the mesh?
questions.solution:
• Lichtenstein repair is a tension-free mesh repair for inguinal hernia.

  • The mesh used is usually polypropylene, a non-absorbable, synthetic material that provides long-term reinforcement of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

  • Other options:

    • Polyacrylamide: Not used in hernia repair; more for cosmetic or soft tissue applications.

    • Polyglycolic acid & Polyglactin: Absorbable materials; would not provide permanent support, so not used for Lichtenstein mesh.

Key point: Permanent, non-absorbable polypropylene mesh is the standard for tension-free inguinal hernia repair.



Reference:Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition Page no 1092,1099-1101

questions.text: A female patient was provisionally diagnosed with intestinal obstruction. An emergency laparotomy was done, and the following specimen was removed. Identify the following specimen.
questions.solution:
• A trichobezoar is a mass of ingested hair that accumulates in the stomach and sometimes extends into the small intestine (Rapunzel syndrome).

  • Commonly seen in young females with a history of trichophagia (hair-eating) or psychiatric disorders.

  • Grossly, it appears as a dark, compact, hairball-like mass that conforms to the shape of the stomach.

  • Other options:

    • Phytobezoar: Composed of indigestible plant fibers; usually brownish and softer.

    • Gangrene of stomach: Would show necrotic tissue, not a compact mass.

    • Lactobezoar: Seen in premature infants from inspissated milk, not adults.

Key point: In young females with intestinal obstruction and a gastric mass, trichobezoar is the classic diagnosis.



Reference:Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry 11th edition Page no 433

questions.text: A male patient complains of loss of appetite and dysphagia. He lost around 6 kgs of weight in the last 3 months. He was diagnosed with esophageal cancer a few years back and was treated for it. Which of the following could be the reason of his current presentation?
questions.solution:
• The patient has a history of esophageal cancer and now presents with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and anorexia.

  • These are classic red-flag signs suggestive of tumor recurrence or obstruction.

  • Other options:

    • Achalasia cardia: Typically presents earlier in life, with gradually progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids, not necessarily rapid weight loss post-esophageal cancer.

    • Fibrosis/stricture: Could cause dysphagia but usually post-radiotherapy or surgery, and weight loss is often less severe.

    • GERD: Causes heartburn and mild dysphagia, rarely severe weight loss.

Key point: In a patient with prior esophageal cancer, new-onset dysphagia and weight loss should always raise suspicion for recurrence, and endoscopic evaluation with biopsy is warranted.


Reference:Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology 6th edition page no 615

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in case of esophageal varices in a patient with liver cirrhosis:
questions.solution:
Type of Shock Cause CVP Cardiac Output SVR Skin Temp Key Features
Hypovolemic Blood/fluid loss (e.g., trauma, burns, diarrhea) ↓ ↓ ↑ Cold, clammy Tachycardia, hypotension, flat neck veins
Cardiogenic Pump failure (e.g., MI, cardiomyopathy) ↑ ↓ ↑ Cold, clammy Pulmonary edema, S3 gallop, raised JVP
Obstructive Physical obstruction (e.g., tamponade, PE, tension pneumothorax) ↑ ↓ ↑ Cold, clammy Muffled heart sounds, JVP ↑, pulsus paradoxus
Distributive (Septic) Sepsis/infection ↓ or normal ↑ (early), ↓ (late) ↓ Warm (early), cold (late) Bounding pulse, fever, warm peripheries early
Distributive (Anaphylactic) Allergy (IgE-mediated) ↓ ↑ ↓ Warm Urticaria, wheezing, stridor, hypotension
Distributive (Neurogenic) Spinal cord injury, anesthesia ↓ ↓ ↓ Warm, dry Bradycardia, hypotension, loss of sympathetic tone

Hypovolemic shock from variceal hemorrhage or bleed is the most frequent cause of death in esophageal varices in patients with liver cirrhosis.

The most prevalent kind of shock is hypovolemic shock, which is a component of all other types of shock to some extent.

A systemic state of poor tissue perfusion that is insufficient for regular cellular respiration is known as shock.

Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 13

questions.text: A 32-year-old male chronic smoker presents with pain in the fingers for a few months. On examination, gangrenous ulcers were present in the fingers as shown below. Investigations showed blood glucose and lipid profile within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 32-year-old chronic smoker with finger pain for several months and gangrenous ulcers on examination, with normal blood glucose and lipid profile, points strongly toward Buerger's disease.

Key Features of Buerger's Disease:

  • Young male smoker → classic demographic

  • Distal extremity involvement → small- and medium-sized arteries & veins

  • Claudication in feet, calves, or hands → progresses to rest pain

  • Superficial thrombophlebitis → migratory, recurrent

  • Raynaud’s phenomenon → common association

  • Distal ischemic ulcers/gangrene → especially toes and fingers

  • Strong association with tobacco use → disease progresses unless smoking stops

Other options: 

  • Diabetic ulcers: Usually occur on the sole or pressure points, and associated with high glucose.

  • Acute paronychia: A localized infection near the nail, not extensive ulcers/gangrene.

  • Raynaud's phenomenon: Causes color changes (white-blue-red) in fingers with cold, reversible ischemia, not ulcers/gangrene unless it progresses severely.

    Take-home Message:

A young male smoker with finger gangrene and normal glucose/lipid levels → think Buerger’s disease.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1925

questions.text: An 80-year-old man developed right-sided calf muscle pain and swelling. He was bedridden following a right inter-trochanteric fracture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This elderly man presents with right calf pain and swelling following a period of immobilization (bedridden after an inter-trochanteric fracture). These are classic features suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).

Why DVT is most likely:

  • Risk Factors:

    • Age > 60 years

    • Immobilization/bedridden

    • Recent fracture/surgery (especially orthopedic)

  • Clinical Features:

    • Unilateral leg swelling

    • Calf pain or tenderness

    • Possibly warmth, erythema

    • Positive Homan’s sign (pain on dorsiflexion of foot, although not specific)

      Why the other options are less likely:

  • Chronic osteomyelitis: Presents with chronic pain, possibly discharging sinus; not acute swelling/pain.

  • Compartment syndrome: Usually presents with severe pain out of proportion, tense compartment, and neurovascular compromise — more common in trauma with vascular injury.

  • Arterial claudication: Causes exercise-induced leg pain relieved by rest; not acute swelling, and typically bilateral.

    Bottom Line:

In a bedridden elderly patient with unilateral calf swelling and pain, DVT is the most likely diagnosis and must be promptly evaluated to prevent complications like pulmonary embolism.


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 985-992

questions.text: What is the preferred management of the condition given in the image below?
questions.solution:
A dermoid cyst over the eyelid (also known as a periorbital dermoid cyst) is a benign congenital lesion formed due to sequestration of skin and dermal elements along embryonic lines of closure, commonly at the lateral eyebrow.
Key Points:

  • Age at Presentation → Often seen in infants and young children

  • Location → Superotemporal quadrant (lateral brow)

  • Consistency → Firm, non-tender, mobile mass

  • Complications → May grow, erode bone, or rupture → inflammation

  • Treatment of Choice → Surgical excision



Other options: 

  • Radiotherapy: Not used for benign dermoid cysts.

  • Intralesional steroids: Used in chalazion, hemangiomas—not dermoid cysts.

  • Antibiotics: No role unless there’s secondary infection (rare).


Reference: Bailey's and love short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 673

questions.text: What is the minimum external pressure that leads to the formation of pressure sores?
questions.solution:
Pressure sores (decubitus ulcers) develop when prolonged pressure on the skin exceeds the capillary filling pressure, leading to ischemia and tissue necrosis.

  • Normal capillary pressure: approximately 25–32 mmHg

  • Minimum external pressure causing pressure sores: ≥ 30 mmHg

    • Sustained pressure above this level impedes capillary blood flow → ischemia → necrosis.

      Clinical Relevance:

  • High-risk areas: Over bony prominences like sacrum, heels, elbows, and ischial tuberosities

  • At-risk patients: Bedridden, paralyzed, elderly, spinal cord injuries

    Timeline:

  • Pressure sores can begin to form within 2 hours of unrelieved pressure over a vulnerable area.

    Mnemonic:

"30 minutes of 30 mmHg = Trouble"
– Think of 30 mmHg as the critical cutoff for capillary perfusion pressure.

Commonly Affected Sites (Most to Least Frequent):

  1. Ischial tuberosities

  2. Greater trochanters

  3. Sacral region

  4. Heels

  5. Lateral and medial malleoli

  6. Occiput


    Prevention Strategies:

  • Maintain skin hygiene and hydration.

  • Use pressure-redistribution surfaces (e.g., air-fluidized beds or specialized mattresses).

  • Turn and reposition immobile patients every 2 hours.

  • Encourage wheelchair users to shift weight every 10 minutes for at least 10 seconds.
     


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 29,30

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer in her family arrives with blood-stained discharge from her nipple. What would be the ideal next move for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sono mammogram
 
  • The ideal next step would be to perform a Sono mammogram (Ultrasound Mammography). This imaging technique is useful for evaluating breast tissue and identifying potential underlying causes of the discharge, such as ductal carcinoma in situ or invasive breast cancer.
  • There is current interest in the use of MRI to screen the breasts of high-risk women and of women with newly diagnosed breast cancer.
  • Women who have a strong family history of breast cancer or who carry known genetic mutations require screening at an early age, but the mammographic evaluation is limited because of the increased breast density in younger women.

Fig: Bloody Nipple Discharge

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 929.

questions.text:
A woman who is 9 weeks pregnant presents with a 2.5 cm lump in the left breast's upper outer quadrant. The ultrasound did not detect any abnormality.
What will be the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Finger guided core biopsy

Most breast lesions in pregnancy are benign but a biopsy should be done to rule out malignancy. Core-needle biopsy with or without ultrasound guidance is a safe and reliable method for obtaining tissue.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: Which patients with breast cancer undergo an oncotype DX test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chemotherapy in hormone receptor positive patients

Oncotype Dx may be used to guide chemotherapy decisions among certain women with :

i)  Node negative
ii) Hormone receptor-positive 
iii) Her 2 negative breast cancer

Oncotype Dx® is the most widely used ROR score and measures the expression of 16 cancer-related genes and fve reference genes on paraffin-embedded tumour tissue. The assay classifies the ROR score as low (<18), moderate (19–30) or high (>30). In patients with a low ROR score, chemotherapy can be avoided.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 940.

choices.text: Dyscohesive ductal epithelial cells without cellular fragments
Tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei
Polymorphism with single or arranged ductal epithelial cells

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman who had a firm, non-tender breast lump underwent Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC). Which of the following traits would lead one to believe a benign breast tumour has been discovered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei
 
  • In FNAC, the traits suggesting a benign breast tumor include tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei (Option B).
  • In benign breast tumors, the cells tend to maintain their architectural organization, resulting in tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells.
  • These cells are usually uniform and show minimal variation in size, shape, and nuclear features.
  • The nuclei of these cells may appear dyscohesive or not tightly adhered to each other, meaning there is a lack of cohesive cellular clustering.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 918.

questions.text: What is molecular classification of breast cancer based on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Gene expression profiling
 
  • The molecular classification of breast cancer is based on gene expression profiling (Option D).
  • Gene expression profiling involves analyzing the activity of thousands of genes in a tumor sample to classify breast cancer into distinct molecular subtypes.
  • This classification system helps guide treatment decisions and predict prognosis.
  • The most commonly used molecular classification is the PAM50 gene panel, which identifies subtypes such as Luminal A, Luminal B, HER2-enriched, and Basal-like (Triple-negative) breast cancer.

Fig: Molecular classification of breast cancer

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 931.

questions.text: What percentage of axillary metastases can be detected by axillary ultrasonography in clinically node-negative breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 55-60%

This means that axillary ultrasonography can identify metastases in approximately 55-60% of patients who are clinically node-negative based on physical examination alone. 

* The percentage of axillary metastases that can be detected by axillary ultrasonography in clinically node-negative breast cancer depends on a number of factors, including the size of the primary tumor: 
  • cT1 tumors
    The sensitivity of axillary ultrasound to detect axillary metastases is 37.9%. 
  • cT2 tumors
    The sensitivity of axillary ultrasound to detect axillary metastases is 49.0%. 
  • cT3 tumors
    The sensitivity of axillary ultrasound to detect axillary metastases is 52.6%. 
  • Clinically significant disease
    The sensitivity of axillary ultrasound to detect clinically significant disease (> 2.0 mm) is 76%. 
Lymph node involvement is assessed by Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy. 



Reference: Tucker NS, Cyr AE, Ademuyiwa FO, Tabchy A, George K, Sharma PK, Jin LX, Sanati S, Aft R, Gao F, Margenthaler JA, Gillanders WE. Axillary Ultrasound Accurately Excludes Clinically Significant Lymph Node Disease in Patients With Early Stage Breast Cancer. Ann Surg. 2016 Dec;264(6):1098-1102. doi: 10.1097/SLA.0000000000001549. PMID: 26779976; PMCID: PMC4947031.

choices.text: 5 cm ER-positive breast carcinoma with one positive axillary lymph node, a 36-year-old woman underwent breast conservation therapy as well as
Routine clinical examination 3 monthly in 1st year with annual mammogram
Routine clinical examination 3 monthly and 6 monthly liver function tests

questions.text:
For a 1.5 cm ER-positive breast carcinoma with one positive axillary lymph node, a 36-year-old woman underwent breast conservation therapy as well as
chemotherapy. Now she is taking tamoxifen. How will you monitor the patient's progress?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Routine clinical examination 3 monthly in 1st year with annual mammogram
 
  • After breast conservation therapy and completion of chemotherapy, routine monitoring is necessary to assess the patient's progress and detect any potential recurrence or new lesions.
  • In this scenario, the recommended monitoring approach would be routine clinical examination 3 monthly in the 1st year with an annual mammogram (Option C).
  • The combination of clinical examination and mammography allows for regular assessment of the breast tissue and detection of any changes or abnormalities that may require further evaluation.
* Other options:
 
  • Assessment of tumor markers (Option B) is not typically used as a routine monitoring tool for breast cancer.
  • Annual bone scan (Option A) is not necessary unless there are specific indications such as symptoms or findings suggesting bone involvement.
  • Liver function tests every 6 months (Option D) are not routinely performed for breast cancer surveillance unless there are specific clinical indications.

* Guidelines of mammogram follow up:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 917.

questions.text: 45-year-old woman arrived with a history of a painless breast mass in the left upper quadrant measuring 6 cm by 5 cm with no axillary lymph nodes. A true-cut biopsy was indicative of ductal carcinoma in situ . After undergoing surgery, all tumor tissue was removed with sufficient margins, and a postoperative HPE revealed DCIS with high grade tumor and necrosis and 14 mm of margin clearance. Which of the following is subsequently required?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Adjuvant radiotherapy


The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is used to guide treatment decisions for Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS) based on four factors:  (1)Patient Age, (2) Tumor Size, (3)Histologic Grade (including necrosis) and (4)Surgical Margin Width. 

Each factor is scored from 1 to 3, with higher scores indicating a greater risk of recurrence. The total score ranges from 4 to 12, categorizing patients into low, intermediate, or high-risk groups. Low risk group requires excision, intermediate group requires excision+ Radiotherapy while high risk group requires mastectomy. 

Van Nuys prognostic index:





In the current scenario as given in the question - 

Age: 45 years → Score: 2 (Age 40–60 years)
Tumor Size: 6 cm (60 mm) × 5 cm (50 mm) → Score: 3 (Size >40 mm)
Histologic Grade: High-grade with necrosis → Score: 3
Margin Width: 14 mm → Score: 1(Margins >10 mm)
Total Score = 2+3+3+1 = 9

Hence, patient needs to be given adjuvant Radiotherapy i.e option 3 as per VNPI (Van Nuys Prognostic Index)

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 844.

questions.text: What causes Peau d'Orange in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Obstruction of sub-dermal lymphatics
 
  • The phenomenon known as "peau d' orange" is brought on by lymphatic blockage in locally advanced breast cancer. It indicates that the skin is involved (T4b Stage).
  • The reason for "peau d' orange" is cutaneous lymphatic edema.
  • The infiltrated skin cannot swell where the sweat ducts are attached, giving the area an orange-like appearance. A similar phenomenon can occasionally be observed over a chronic abscess.


Fig: Peau d’orange (skin of the orange) or edema of the skin of the breast.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 815.

questions.text: What kind of breast examination technique is done if the physician palpated with the tips of all fingers save the thumb starting at 2 o'clock posterior palpated at three locations on line joining periphery to nipple. Then moved directly to 3 o'clock and returned centripetally while palpating at 3 locations on the line connecting periphery and nipple?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dial of Clock method

The described method of breast examination is known as "Dial of Clock" method.
In dial of clock method, palpation is performed in segmental manner until entire breast is examined with “pads of middle three fingers” (index, middle, and ring) with hand held in slightly bowed position.




Fig: Clinical breast examination

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 916.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most conspicuous  indicator of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Peau d’orange

Peau d'orange is the most conspicuous sign in breast cancer.

Peau d'orange (French for orange peel) is characterized by edema and pitting and results from blockage of lymphatic drainage with or without associated stromal infiltration. The most common cause of breast peau d'orange is inflammatory breast cancer. It makes the cancer a T4B disease. 





Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 815.

questions.text: What is the technique illustrated in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

The technique depicted in the image is sentinel lymph node biopsy using methylene blue dye technique. 

Sentinel LN: First LN which receives lymph directly from tumor.

Sentinel node biopsy identifies the first few lymph nodes into which a tumor drains. The surgeon uses a harmless dye as in this image.  The nodes are removed and tested for signs of cancer. Sentinel node biopsy is a procedure to see if cancer has spread.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 936.

questions.text: Which of the following scores requires additional FISH research when there is Her-2/neu immunohistochemistry staining in cases of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) 2+

A score of 2+ is required for further FISH study.

About 20% to 25% of breast cancers have an overexpressed HER-2 protein or HER-2 gene. Protein overexpression brought on by amplification is clinically assessed by immunohistochemistry and graded on a scale of 0 to 3+. As an alternative, fluorescent in situ hybridization directly measures the two normal copies of the HER-2 gene.

Her-2neu IHC interprtation-

1+ Negative

2+ Equivocal- FISH is done to confirm the amplification

3+ Positive Her2neu

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 191.

questions.text: Which of the following does not constitute Ca breast stage T4b ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nipple Retraction

T4b -- Ulceration and/or ipsilateral macroscopic satellite nodules and/or oedema (including peau d’orange) of the skin that does not meet the criteria for inflammatory carcinoma.







Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 934.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lactating mother appeared with a bothersome breast lump. What is the best way to begin an investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) USG

Since the lady is a lactating mother with a painful breast lump, Most appropriate initial investigations would be USG to r/o Breast milk retention. The age is not a criteria in this question.

Indications of breast USG:
 
  • Symptomatic breast lump in women <35 years.
  • Breast lump during lactation and pregnancy.
  • Assessment of mammographic abnormality .
  • Assessment of MRI .
  • Breast mass along with a negative mammogram.
  • Breast inflammation.
  • Breast lumps in males along with MRI Needle biopsy for localisation.
  • Follow-up of breast carcinoma.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: A lactating woman complains of painful breasts. What should be the first investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) USG

A lactating female presents with painful breast. First investigation to be done in this case is USG.

Indications of breast USG:

  • Symptomatic breast lump in women <35 years.
  • Breast lump during lactation and pregnancy.
  • Assessment of mammographic abnormality .
  • Assessment of MRI .
  • Breast mass along with a negative mammogram .
  • Breast inflammation.
  • Breast lumps in males along with MRI
  • Needle biopsy for localisation.
  • Follow-up of breast carcinoma.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: Which of the following does not use neo-adjuvant chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Breast cancer stage 1

There is no role of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in Stage 1 Breast CA.
Currently, neoadjuvant chemotherapy is offered to patients with locally advanced breast cancer and also those breast cancer patients who may benefit from size reduction before conservation therapy.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 940.

choices.text: Dyscohesive ductal epithelial cells without cellular fragments
Tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei
Polymorphism with single or arranged ductal epithelial cells

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl who had a firm, non-tender breast lump underwent fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC). Which of the following traits would lead one to believe a benign breast illness has been discovered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2)  Tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei

A non-tender, firm and mobile breast lump in a female age 17 years is suggestive of fibroadenoma, in which tightly arranged ductal epithelial cells with dyscohesive bare nuclei are seen on FNAC.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 918.

questions.text: To treat breast cancer, a patient had sentinel lymph node biopsy. Which nerve is most likely to sustain damage during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Intercostobrachial nerve
 
  • Sentinel node biopsy for breast cancer often causes injury to the intercostobrachial nerve during axillary dissection to clear the lymph nodes, while taking care to preserve the nerve of serratus anterior, thoracodorsal vessels, nerve of latissimus dorsi, and medial/lateral pectoral nerves.
  • Intercostobrachial nerve is often sacrificed during the operation, resulting in loss of sensation on the upper medial border of the arm. ALND is more likely than SLND to lead to axillary paresthesias, because of disruption to the intercostobrachial nerves.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 937.

questions.text: You were contacted by a 56-year-old woman who had been diagnosed with breast cancer. The immunohistochemical staining of her tissue revealed the following. Her2 Neu is negative. What can you say about the patient's prognosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Poor prognosis
 
  • The IHC profile depicts a triple negative breast cancer, i.e. a Basal like profile as ER,PR and Her 2 are all negative.
  • Positive staining is seen as brownish dots over the slide.
  • These negative results mean that the growth of the cancer is not supported by the hormones estrogen and progesterone, nor by the presence of too many HER2 receptors.
  • Therefore, triple-negative breast cancer does not respond to hormonal therapy (such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors) or therapies that target HER2 receptors, such as Herceptin (trastuzumab). In general, survival rates tend to be lower with TNBC compared to other forms of breast cancer.

Fig: Molecular classification of breast cancer

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 931.

questions.text: The Van Nuys Prognostic Index does not depend on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) ER status
 
  • The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a scoring system used to assess the prognosis of patients with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast.
  • The VNPI takes into account several factors, including age, tumor size, nuclear grade, and presence of comedo necrosis.
  • ER status (estrogen receptor status) is not included in the VNPI and, therefore, does not impact the calculation of the index.
  • The VNPI is based on Micro SWAG i.e, microcalcification, size of lesion, width of surgical margin, age of the patient and DCIS Nuclear grade.


Fig: Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI)

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 844.

choices.text: TRAM flap base on superior epigastric vessels
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
TRAM free flap based on superior and inferior epigastric vessels
Lower Abdominal Fat based inferior epigastric vessels

questions.text: What flap is used in breast reconstruction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery



When comparing satisfaction rates among different autologous techniques, deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap reconstruction seems to provide the highest rates of well-being.
Cost-effective analyses have been performed to compare autologous and implant-based techniques.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 858.

choices.text: EGFR is positive in Small cell cancer
Her 2 Neu amplification is seen in fraction of breast cancer
N-myc gene is a tumor suppressor gene

questions.text: Of the following statements, which one is true
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) Her 2 Neu amplification is seen in fraction of breast cancer
 
  • BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene.
  • M-myc is an oncogene.
  • EGFR is positive in adenocarcinoma of lung and breast carcinoma.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 194.

questions.text: Tamoxifen used to treat breast cancer won't help in preventing:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Endometrial Carcinoma
 
  • Tamoxifen given for Breast cancer will not prevent endometrial carcinoma.
  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator used for the treatment and prevention of estrogen receptor (ER) positive breast cancer.
  • Tamoxifen characteristically causes cystic endometrial hyperplasia due to its agonistic action on endometrium, thereby increasing the risk of endometrial cancer (EC) by about 2–7 fold.
  • More aggressive types of EC with poor prognoses are observed in tamoxifen users.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 941.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female complained of a lump and edema in the left breast for the last 15 days. Upon inspection, it was mobile over the chest wall and was associated with the increased temperature of the local site. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Inflammatory Ca

The left breast's recent 15-day swelling and the increase in local temperature are signs of inflammatory breast cancer.
Inflammatory breast cancer:
i. A short-lived, rapidly progressing tumour
ii. Warm, painful, and diffuse
iii. Involving the entire breast tissue and extending to the skin of the chest wall with the appearance of peau d' orange.
iv. The affected area covers more than 1/3 of the breast skin.
v. Widespread lymphedema brought on by tumour emboli in cutaneous lymphatics.

According to AJCC 8th Edition 
T4d Inflammatory carcinoma; peau d’orange and redness involving >1/3rd of the surface of the breast with or without a breast lump




Fig: Diffuse redness (erythema) and skin oedema involving more than one-third of the breast, with an enlarged left breast – features of inflammatory carcinoma.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 932.

questions.text:
A 4 cm by 3 cm irregular mass that is neither fixed to the skin nor the chest wall is seen in the right upper quadrant of the right breast in a 50-year-old woman's patient. A 2 cm lymph node is felt in the right axilla. The opposite breast felt completely normal. Which of the subsequent exams would you have this patient undergo?
A. Bilateral mammography
B. PET scan
C. Biopsy of the breast mass
D. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) A, C & D

The given clinical scenario is s/o breast malignancy with locoregional spread without distant metastasis. 

Therefore for further evaluation, mammography, breast biopsy and biopsy of the lymph node should be performed. 

PET scan is usually performed in advanced cases of breast cancer and not routinely done in assessment of locoregional disease. 



Fig: Triple Assessment in Breast Investigation

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

questions.text:
Match the following.
A. Breast surgery 1. Long thoracic nerve
B. Thyroid surgery 2. External laryngeal nerve
C.  Submandibular excision 3. Hypoglossal nerve
D. Video assisted thymectomy 4. Phrenic nerve
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 1) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

The correct matching is:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 937.

questions.text:
After 3 months, the patient's upper limbs were still swollen from the mastectomy for cancer breast.
What exactly is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Upper limb lymphedema
 
  • In this case upper limb lymphedema develops after 3 months post mastectomy.
  • Upper limb lymphangiosarcoma develops in a chronically edematous limb which usually takes around 10 years to develop. It is known as stewart-treves syndrome.
  • Lymphedema-associated angiosarcoma (Stewart-Treves) develops on an extremity ipsilateral to an axillary lymphadenectomy. It appears on the upper, medial arm as a violaceous plaque in an individual with nonpitting edema and has a poor survival.
  • Radiation-induced angiosarcoma occurs 4 to 25 years after radiation therapy for benign and malignant conditions.

Fig: Stewartâ€Treves Syndrome Involving Chronic Lymphedema after Mastectomy of Breast Cancer

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 535.

questions.text: A female patient presents with a 4 x 3 cm lump in the right upper outer quadrant of the breast. Axillary nodes are negative, and mammography suggests BIRADS. 4. The patient underwent conservative breast surgery with HPE of high grade DCIS. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) Adjuvant RT

* Radiotherapy :
  • In some patients with significant local recurrence risks (I.e Younger women, those with high-grade tumours, and those with involved resection margins are more likely to experience local recurrence) following mastectomy, radiotherapy to the chest wall is recommended. 
  • This includes patients with large tumours, numerous nodes that are positive, or significant lymphovascular invasion. 
  • In women with node-positive breast cancer, there is some evidence that postoperative chest wall radiation increases survival. 
  • Combining conservative surgery with radiation to the residual breast tissue is common.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 845.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate initial investigation for a 35-year-old lactating mother who presents with a painful breast lump?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) USG

Most appropriate initial investigation should be USG
 
  1. Following are some of the indications of breast USG
  2. ï¿²symptomatic breast lump in women <35 years of age
  3. ï¿²breast lump during lactation and pregnancy
  4. ï¿²clinical breast mass with negative mammogram
  5. ï¿²breast inflammation
  6. ï¿²guidance of needle biopsy or localization.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: A female patient in her 60s complains of burning & itching in one breast. The following image is visible following a clinical evaluation. The following statements about the ailment are all accurate, with the exception of which one:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) S-100 antigen positive on immunostaining
 
  • The clinical evaluation and the image suggest Paget's disease of the breast, a rare form of breast cancer that affects the nipple and areola.
  • While Paget's disease of the breast is associated with underlying invasive breast cancer in most cases, immunostaining for S-100 antigen is typically negative in Paget's cells. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.
  • Other accurate statements include external signs if underlying invasive cancer, presentation with a mass in more than 50% of cases.
  • Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy.

Fig: Nipple erosion in early Paget’s disease

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 924.

questions.text: Breast cancer is more common in women with the following personality type:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 3) Type C
 
  • According to the research conducted by Dr. R. Grossarth-Maticek, breast cancer is more common in women with Type C personality.
  • Type C personality is characterized by introversion, passivity, and a tendency to suppress emotions.
  • These individuals often have difficulty expressing their emotions and tend to internalize their stress, which can lead to chronic stress and weakened immune system.
  • Chronic stress can lead to the development of cancer by suppressing the immune system's ability to detect and destroy cancer cells. Therefore, Type C personality is considered a risk factor for breast cancer.
  • On the other hand, Type A personality is characterized by competitiveness, time urgency, and high levels of stress.
  • Type B personality is characterized by a laid-back attitude and low levels of stress.
  • Type D personality is characterized by negative emotions such as anxiety, depression, and social inhibition. While these personality types may have their own set of health risks, they are not specifically associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.
Online Resources: Pelosi AJ. Personality and fatal diseases: Revisiting a scientific scandal. J Health Psychol. 2019 Mar;24(4):421-439. doi: 10.1177/1359105318822045. Epub 2019 Feb 22. PMID: 30791726; PMCID: PMC6712909.

questions.text: Which of the following nodes receives the majority of lymph from the malignant breast?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Anterior (pectoral) nodes
 
  • The majority of lymph from the malignant breast is received by the anterior (pectoral) nodes, which are located in the axilla.
  • The anterior nodes are the first regional lymph nodes to receive lymphatic drainage from the breast.
  • They are an important site for the evaluation of lymph node involvement in breast cancer.
Other options:
  • Apical nodes primarily receive lymph drainage from the upper limb, head, and neck.
  • Parasternal (internal thoracic) nodes receive some lymph from the breast, but not the majority.
  • Supraclavicular nodes receive lymph drainage from various regions, including the upper limb, head, neck, and thorax.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 938.

questions.text: Starting at what age do new mammogram screening recommendations suggest mammography should be routinely provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 40 years
 
  • New mammogram screening recommendations suggest routine mammography should be provided starting at the age of 40 years.
  • A mammography is a screening tool used for the early detection of breast cancer.
  • However, in certain cases, ultrasound (USG) can be used before the age of 40 for breast evaluation.
  • USG is particularly useful in younger women with specific risk factors or clinical indications.
* Advantages of USG over Mammography:
  • Preferred in pregnant, lactating, and young women with dense breast tissue
  • Differentiation between solid and cystic breast lesions
  • Detection of abnormal axillary lymph nodes
  • Assists in guided breast biopsy procedures
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 916.

questions.text: Mainstay of treatment of for Zuska's Disease is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Antibiotics, Incision and Drainage

Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses. 
  • Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition
  • It is managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage if necessary
  • The initial management usually involves a combination of antibiotics to treat the underlying infection and surgical intervention in the form of incision and drainage of the abscess.

Fig: Zuska's Disease

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 550.

questions.text: Which of the following approaches is recommended for treating cystosarcoma phyllodes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Wide local excision
 
  • The recommended approach for treating cystosarcoma phyllodes is a wide local incision.
  • Cystosarcoma phyllodes (phyllodes tumour) is a rare breast tumor that has both benign and malignant characteristics.
  • A wide local excision involves removing the tumor along with a margin of normal surrounding tissue to ensure complete removal.
  • This approach allows for preservation of breast tissue and avoids more extensive procedures like mastectomy.




Fig: Malignant phyllodes tumor (cystosarcomaphyllodes)

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 600.

questions.text: What is most likely to be the source of tingling and numbness across the posteromedial portion of the upper arm following a modified radical mastectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Intercostobrachial nerve
 
The given case scenario is suggestive of iatrogenic injury to the intercostobrachial nerve.
  • It is a branch of the 2nd intercostal nerve.
  • It is the lateral cutaneous branch of the 2nd intercostal nerve and supplies the skin of the axilla and upper part of the medial aspect of the arm. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 931.

questions.text: A 40 years old female presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaint of lump in the breast. Clinical image of the breast is shown below. Such an appearance is because of :
questions.solution:
• The image shown above is of peau d'orange appearance.
  • It occurs due to infiltration of subdermal lymphatics by cancer cells.
  • Peau d'orange makes it a T4b disease (Skin involvement).

Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Involvement of Cooper's ligament results in dimpling and puckering. 
  • Option 3- Involvement of lactiferous ducts causes nipple retraction
  • Option 4- Involvement of chest wall makes it a T4a disease.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 860.

questions.text: All of the following are relative contraindication for BCS except?
questions.solution:
Relative Contraindication for BCS :
  • Tumor size greater than 5cm.
  • Recurrence in a previously conserved breasts.
  • Focally positive margins.
  • History of previous irradiation to breast.
  • Active collagen vascular disease.
  • Multiple tumors in the same quadrant.



Reference: Jordan RM, Oxenberg J. Breast Cancer Conservation Therapy. [Updated 2022 Sep 19]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK547708/

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Basal type of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Basal type, also referred as Triple Negative Breast Ca or TNBC is negative for ER, PR and HER2neu.

MOLECULAR CLASSIFICATION OF BREAST CANCER /LUMINAL CRITERIA:
  1. Luminal A [Double positive]: ER(+), PR(+), HER-2-NEU (-) : Best prognosis
  2. Luminal B [Triple positive]: ER(+), PR(+), HER-2-NEU (+)
  3. Basal cell type: ER(-), PR(-), HER-2-NEU (-), Positive for EGFR, myoepithelial markers, cytokeratin 5 and 6.
  4. HER-2-NEU Type: ER(-), PR(-), HR-2-NEU (+)  worst prognosis









Reference: DeVita, Hellman, and Rosenberg's Cancer: Principles and Practice of Oncology, 10th edition, Page no 1139, 1140.

questions.text: A 34 year old female with Right breast lump<4cms, on examination. No nipple retraction no skin color change. On mammography, calcified fibro-adenoma is seen. What is the BIRADS score in this?
questions.solution:
Based on the given information, the BIRADS score for the breast lump in the 34-year-old female would be 2.
  • BIRADS : Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System score of 2 means that the breast lump is benign (non-cancerous) and has a very low suspicion for malignancy.
  • In this case, the calcified fibro-adenoma seen on mammography is a common benign breast tumor.
  • The absence of nipple retraction and skin color change also suggests a low suspicion for malignancy.
  • BIRADS score is as follows:





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 917, 922.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for diagnosis of breast Ca?
questions.solution:
• Triple assessment method used for diagnosis of Breast CA.
 
  • It includes—
  1. Clinical Symptoms
  2. Imaging (Mammography/ USG).
  3. Tissue sampling— biopsy or FNAC.
PPV of triple assessment= 99.90%.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 863, 873, 874.

questions.text: A 35 year old women was on tamoxifen therapy for 5 years now after breast cancer surgery. When should she discontinue the drug if she wants to conceive?
questions.solution:
• Tamoxifen can be started either after surgery (adjuvant therapy) or before surgery (neoadjuvant therapy).
  • When given after surgery, it is usually taken in the dose of 10mg BD for 5 years. It's the DOC for hormonal therapy in premenopausal women. It is teratogenic in nature.
  • Ideally, it should be stopped 2 months before conception which is the washout time of the drug in order to prevent its teratogenic effects.

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 812 .

questions.text: What does Luminal type A breast Cancer mean?
questions.solution:
luminal A means ER + PR+ and HER2 -


* Extra edge: 

In patients with endocrine-responsive breast cancer, those with luminal A tumours may avoid chemotherapy if they have a low-risk score on Oncotype Dx® and/or clinical risk assessment online tools (e.g. https://breast.predict.nhs.uk/ tool); however, patients with a high clinical and genomic risk should be considered for chemotherapy with an anthracycline (epirubicin) or taxane-based therapy. Patients with luminal B tumours should receive an anthracycline and/or taxane-based therapy because of the greater risk of relapse. Those with HER2/neu-positive tumours should receive trastuzumab+pertuzumab along with chemotherapy (taxane + anthracycline), while those with triple negative tumours should receive chemotherapy (taxane + anthracycline). Carboplatin-based regimens may be benefcial for tumours with aggressive biology.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 931, 940.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor of Breast Carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Axillary Lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor in patient with Non Metastatic breast Cancer.
Hormone receptor status is the most important prognostic factor in Metastatic Breast Cancer.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 20st Edition, Page. No: 848.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and accompanying image suggest post-mastectomy lymphedema in the upper limb.

Lymphedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to impaired lymphatic drainage, often a complication of breast cancer treatments such as axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) significantly reduces the risk of developing lymphedema.

Clinical Signs and Symptoms: The affected arm exhibits noticeable swelling, leading to a significant increase in limb size. Patients may also experience feelings of heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and decreased mobility.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on the observation of arm swelling. Additional diagnostic criteria include a girth measurement where the affected arm is more than 2 centimeters larger than the unaffected limb, a volume increase of 200 mL or more, or a change in limb volume of 5% or greater.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of treatment. Biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Almost half of the women receiving cyclosporin A following renal transplantation develop multiple and bilateral fibroadenomas, which tend to regress after stopping the treatment. Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumors of the female breast, often occurring in women under 30 years of age. They are sometimes referred to as "breast mouse" due to their high mobility within the breast.

Complex fibroadenomas fall under the category of "proliferative changes without atypia" and are associated with a 1.5 to 2 times increased risk of developing subsequent breast cancer. These complex fibroadenomas contain features such as cysts larger than 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine changes.

The histological image of a fibroadenoma shows proliferation of ducts arranged in both intracanalicular (compressed) and pericanalicular patterns, surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma.

questions.text: What is the benefit of ER screening in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
• Estrogen receptor (ER) is used as a prognostic marker.
  • Prognostic marker generally is used to describe molecular markers that predict disease-free survival, disease- specific survival, and overall survival.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 1047-1051.

questions.text: A woman presented with breast lump on examination skin changes such as brawny induration, erythema and peaud' d orange was present over 2/3 of the breast and immunohistology shows e-Cadherin overexpression. According to 8th edition of AJCC classification the patient can be classified under which stage?
questions.solution:
As the patient has brawny induration/eczema - suggesting inflammatory skin signs being present along with e- Cadherin expression - it is suggestive of inflammatory breast carcinoma- T4d. 

TNM Staging of Breast Carcinoma







Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 934.

questions.text:
Smoking increases the risk of which of the following diseases?
A. Duct ectasia
B. Fibroadenoma
C. Mondor's disease
D. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution:
Smoking increases the risk of breast carcinoma.

Duct ectasia, characterized by dilated major milk ducts and considered a disorder of involution as part of ANDI, involves ducts filled with debris that can cause irritation, leading to periductal inflammation and fibrosis, resulting in nipple retraction. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

Mondor‘s disease refers to thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall, presenting as a tender thrombosed subcutaneous cord. A narrow, shallow groove alongside the cord becomes visible when the skin is stretched by raising the arm. Smoking may contribute to the development of Mondor‘s disease, with other risk factors including breast surgery, biopsy, inflammatory processes, breast cancer, and trauma.

Breast cancer risk factors can be categorized into modifiable and nonmodifiable types. Factors that increase oestrogenic exposure—such as early menarche, late menopause, nulliparity, late first pregnancy, and hormone replacement with high estrogen therapy—are associated with increased risk. Smoking is a modifiable risk factor, with a relative risk (RR) of 1.14 for smoking 25 or more cigarettes per day and an RR of 1.07 for smoking for 20 years or more.

Fibroadenoma, the most common cause of a breast lump in women aged 15-25 years, arises from lobular hyperplasia and is surrounded by a well-defined capsule. Smoking is not a risk factor for fibroadenomas.

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 922,929-931 .

questions.text:
Which of the following are done in Breast Conservation Surgery?
A. Wide local excision
B. Axillary node dissection
C. Frozen section (biopsy) to be doneduring surgery
D.Post-operative radiotherapy optional
questions.solution:
Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS) involves procedures such as wide local excision, axillary node dissection, and frozen section biopsy during surgery. When BCS is followed by radiotherapy, the combined approach is known as Breast Conservation Therapy (BCT) (Statement 4).

The goal of breast conservation surgery is to remove the tumor with a 1mm margin of normal breast tissue, a procedure also referred to as lumpectomy, tylectomy, partial mastectomy, or wide local excision (Statement 1). During surgery, an intraoperative frozen section (Statement 3) is performed to check for clear margins. If positive margins are detected, a procedure known as ‘cavity shave‘ is used to revise the margins. Additionally, regional lymph node assessment is performed through a separate incision in the axilla (Statement 2).

Absolute contraindications for BCT include:

First trimester of pregnancy (BCT may be an option for some second-trimester and many third-trimester patients who can receive radiation after delivery)

Persistently positive margins after two microscopic evaluations

Multicentrictumors

Diffuse microcalcifications

Extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)

Inflammatory breast cancer


Relative contraindications for BCT include:

Active systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or scleroderma

Large tumor-to-breast ratio (lump > 5 cm)

Known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2 mutations) or Li-Fraumeni syndrome (p53 mutation)

Multifocal disease

Previous radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast


 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 877 .

questions.text: Involvement of which of the following structures leads to the clinical presentation as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows - The peau d'orange appearance of the breast. It is caused by the blockade of superficial lymphatics.



This blockage leads to dermal lymphatic obstruction, resulting in edema within the breast tissue. As a consequence, the sweat glands and hair follicles become buried under the edema, producing the characteristic orange peel appearance. Additionally, infiltration of Cooper's ligaments can cause dimpling of the skin, while infiltration of the lactiferous glands may lead to nipple retraction. If the spread extends into the chest wall, it can result in fixation of the breast to the wall, restricting the breast's mobility.

Furthermore, spread to the axillary lymph nodes can result in lymphedema, while venous edema of the upper limb may develop due to compression of the axillary vein by the swollen lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 51-year-old lady presents with complaints of a mass in the right breast. On examination, the mass was larger than 2cm and ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were present. What is the staging, considering the mass is malignant?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario involving a 51-year-old woman with a breast mass larger than 2 cm, lymph node involvement (N1), and an image depicting an ulcerative mass near the nipple of the right breast (classified as T4) is indicative of inflammatory breast carcinoma. Its likely staging is cT4N1M0.

Inflammatory breast carcinoma (staged as T4) is a particularly aggressive type of locally advanced breast cancer (LABC), associated with the poorest prognosis among breast cancer subtypes, accounting for less than 3% of all breast cancer cases. It is characterized by significant skin changes, including brawny induration, erythema, and edema, often described as peau d'orange, which refers to the orange-peel appearance of the skin due to edema and dimpling around hair follicles.


Diagnostic Criteria for Inflammatory Breast Cancer:
1. Rapid onset of breast symptoms: This may include erythema, edema, and/or peau d'orange, with or without a palpable mass.
2. History duration: Symptoms should have a duration of no more than six months.
3. Erythema involvement: Erythema should cover at least one-third of the breast.
4. Pathologic confirmation: There should be pathologic evidence of invasive carcinoma.
The key pathological feature is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics observed in skin biopsy specimens, although this is not a strict requirement for diagnosis.

Mammography may appear normal or show signs of skin thickening. A PET-CT scan is recommended at diagnosis to exclude the possibility of concurrent metastatic disease.

Axillary nodal metastases are common in this condition, and there is a substantial risk for distant metastases.

choices.text: Breast cancer diagnosed in a post menopausal female >50 years of age

questions.text: Genetic testing for BRCA 1/BRCA 2 is indicated for all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Genetic Testing: It is generally not recommended for post-menopausal females over 50 years of age unless specific high-risk criteria are met.

Genetic Counseling: This involves discussions about genetic testing options, including BRCA testing and multi-gene panel testing, to assess the risk of genetic mutations associated with breast cancer.

Recommended Genetic Counseling and Testing Criteria for High-Risk Women:
Breast cancer diagnosed before age 50.
Triple-negative breast cancer.
Bilateral breast cancer.
Breast and ovarian cancer in the same individual.
Breast cancer in men.
Family history of two or more individuals with breast and ovarian cancer (either maternal or paternal).
A close male relative with breast cancer.
A close relative with early-onset (<50 years) breast or ovarian cancer.
Known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations in the family.
These criteria help identify individuals who may benefit from genetic testing to guide management and preventive strategies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old mother presents with pain in her left breast. Which of the following is the most likely cause of acute mastitis?
questions.solution:
Acute mastitis is a local bacterial infection that typically occurs when the breast is particularly vulnerable due to cracks and fissures in the nipples.

Causes and Pathophysiology:
The condition arises from a combination of inadequate milk drainage and the introduction of bacteria, which are often present on the skin. The cracks in the nipple serve as entry points for infection.
The most common causative organism of acute mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus.
Timing:
Acute bacterial mastitis is most frequently seen during the first month of breastfeeding, often referred to as a lactational breast abscess.

Symptoms:
Staphylococcal acute mastitis usually leads to localized abscesses. Symptoms may include:
Fever and malaise
Localized pain and tenderness
Redness and swelling of the affected breast
A positive fluctuation test, indicating the presence of pus within the abscess (this is considered a late sign).

Management:
Treatment typically includes:
Analgesics for pain relief
Continued breast milk expression to ensure drainage
Antibiotics, commonly amoxiclav
Repeated aspiration of pus if an abscess forms
If there is a failure of aspiration and antibiotics, surgical intervention such as incision and drainage may be necessary.

questions.text: A female patient presented with a 4 x 3 cm lump over the right breast. On examination, Peau d'orange appearance can be noted. What is the tumor staging in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has a breast lump of 4 x 3 cm, but the key finding is Peau d’orange (skin edema due to lymphatic invasion). According to the AJCC TNM staging for breast cancer:

  • T1: Tumor ≤2 cm in greatest dimension

  • T2: Tumor >2 cm but ≤5 cm

  • T3: Tumor >5 cm

  • T4: Tumor of any size with direct extension to chest wall or skin

    • T4a: Extension to chest wall

    • T4b: Ulceration or skin edema, including Peau d’orange or satellite skin nodules

    • T4c: Both T4a and T4b

    • T4d: Inflammatory carcinoma

Here, Peau d’orange corresponds to T4b, regardless of tumor size.

Other options:

  • T2: Only based on size (2–5 cm), without skin involvement.

  • T3: Tumor >5 cm, no skin involvement.

  • T4a: Extension to chest wall, not skin.


Reference:Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition Page no 843

questions.text: A female patient presents with a hard and irregular lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. The histopathological slide of the mass sample is given below. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) is the second most common type of invasive breast cancer after ductal carcinoma.

Key histopathological feature:

  • The slide typically shows small, uniform, discohesive cells arranged in single-file (Indian file) pattern infiltrating the stroma.

  • Sometimes, the cells encircle normal ducts in a targetoid (bull’s-eye) pattern.

  • The discohesion occurs due to loss of E-cadherin expression, a hallmark of lobular carcinoma.

Clinical features:

  • Usually presents as a hard, irregular lump (often in the upper outer quadrant).

  • More likely to be bilateral or multicentric compared to ductal carcinoma.

  • May have poorly defined margins on palpation and imaging because of its infiltrative growth pattern.

Differentiation from other options:

  • Papillary carcinoma: Shows papillary fronds with fibrovascular cores.

  • Colloidal (mucinous) carcinoma: Abundant extracellular mucin with floating tumor cells.

  • Medullary carcinoma: Sheets of large pleomorphic cells with prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate.

The Indian file pattern and loss of cohesion of tumor cells on histology are diagnostic of invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast.


Reference:Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease,9e,page no 1065-1066

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, point tenderness, fluctuation test is positive.
