There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the contralateral breast is normal. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover done were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. What is the management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is incision and drainage.

The patient is a lactating mother presenting with localized breast pain, erythema, warmth, fever, and a positive fluctuation test, which suggests a breast abscess.

Unsuccessful aspirations indicate that the abscess is not resolving with needle drainage. Ultrasound showing fluid collection confirms the diagnosis.

Management involves incision and drainage for persistent or large abscesses that do not respond to aspiration. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are given post-procedure. Continued breastfeeding or milk expression should be encouraged to prevent milk stasis.

Other options
Option 1 - Broad-spectrum antibiotics alone are insufficient if a well-formed abscess does not resolve with aspiration.
Option 3 - Punch biopsy is not needed unless there is suspicion of inflammatory breast cancer or a non-healing chronic abscess.
Option 4 - Breast conservation surgery is a treatment for breast cancer and is not appropriate for abscess management




Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 866

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the surgery out-patient with a left-sided breast lump which she noticed on self breast examination 3weeks ago. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump seems to be mobile and firm. Mammogram revealed a benign lesion. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
A young woman (23 years old) with a mobile, firm, non-tender breast lump, and a benign lesion on mammogram, most likely has a fibroadenoma — the most common benign breast tumor in young women.

Why Reassurance and follow-up is the best option:

  • Fibroadenomas are:

    • Common in women <30 years

    • Typically mobile, painless, and firm

    • Often <2–3 cm and non-progressive

  • Imaging (Mammogram or Ultrasound):

    • If features are clearly benign, no immediate biopsy or surgery is needed.

    • In young women, ultrasound is preferred over mammogram, but the key here is the lesion is benign radiologically.

  • Management:

    • If the lump is small (<2–3 cm), stable, and benign on imaging:
      → Reassurance and 6-month follow-up

    • Biopsy is only needed if:

      • Features are suspicious

      • Lump grows

      • Patient is anxious or >30 years

        Why others are incorrect:

  • Biopsy – Not required for radiologically benign lesions in a young woman.

  • Tamoxifen – Used in ER+ breast cancer or gynecomastia, not for benign fibroadenomas.

  • Surgical excision – Reserved for:

    • Rapid growth

    • Size >5 cm (giant fibroadenoma)

    • Symptomatic

    • Patient request


Reference: Bailey's and love short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 870

questions.text: Best prognosis among the following breast cancer subtypes is for
questions.solution:
Subtype ER/PR HER2 Ki-67 Prognosis
Luminal A + − Low (<14–20%) Best prognosis
Luminal B + − or + High (>20%) Worse than Luminal A
HER2-enriched − + High Poor (better now with trastuzumab)
Basal-like (Triple negative) − − Very high Worst prognosis
ER-negative − ± Variable Generally poor prognosis
 

Why Luminal A has best prognosis: 

  • Hormone receptor-positive (ER/PR positive)

  • HER2-negative

  • Low proliferation rate (low Ki-67)

  • Good response to hormonal therapy

  • Slow-growing, low-grade tumor



Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 872

questions.text: Which of the following is FNAC unable to detect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Follicular carcinoma
 
  • FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology) is unable to detect follicular carcinoma (Option A).
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid cannot be reliably distinguished from follicular adenoma by FNAC alone because it requires histopathological examination of the tumor capsule to confirm invasion.
  • FNAC is useful in detecting other thyroid pathologies such as papillary carcinoma, colloid goiter, and Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 858.

questions.text:
A thyroid nodule on the right side was observed in a 27-year-old woman who was 20 weeks pregnant. The nodule's FNAC indicated that papillary cancer might
be present. Which of the following should not be used in her management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Radioactive iodine ablation
 
  • In a pregnant woman with a thyroid nodule suspected of papillary cancer, radioactive iodine ablation (Option C) is contraindicated during pregnancy.
  • Radioactive iodine therapy is commonly used in the management of papillary thyroid cancer to ablate residual thyroid tissue after total thyroidectomy or to treat distant metastases.
  • However, it is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the potential harm to the developing fetus.
  • The other options, total thyroidectomy plus neck node dissection (Option A), right lobectomy (Option B), and total thyroidectomy (Option D), may be considered in the management of papillary thyroid cancer in non-pregnant individuals.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 869.

questions.text: A young woman came in with a bulge in the middle of her neck, as can be seen below, which movements with swallowing and tongue protrusion. Its size has remained unchanged throughout the last year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thyroglossal cyst

Thyroglossal cyst is the only cause of midline neck swelling which moves with both swallowing and tongue protrusion.

Thyroglossal Cyst
It is a fibrous cyst that presents as a regular neck mass or a lump.
They are the most common cause of midline neck masses and are generally Subhyoid in location.
The mass on the neck moves during swallowing or on protrusion of the tongue because of its attachment to the tongue (foramen of cecum) via the tract of thyroid descent.

* [Extra Edge]: Treatment Of Thyroglossal Cyst

Treatment must include excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, which involves removal of the body of the hyoid bone and the suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum, together with a core of tissue on either side. This operation is known as Sistrunk’s operation and minimises recurrence, most notably from small side branches of the thyroglossal tract.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 806.

questions.text:
A young female with history of renal calculi complains of bone pain and abdominal cramps.
Multiple fractures were identified during the study, and serum calcium and PTH levels were elevated. Which of the following will be the best inquiry to arrive at a conclusive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sestamibi scan
 
  • The clinical presentation of bone pain, abdominal cramps, elevated serum calcium, and elevated PTH levels suggests the possibility of hyperparathyroidism.
  • Sestamibi scan is the imaging of choice for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • It is also known as a parathyroid scan, & is the best inquiry to localize the source of abnormal parathyroid activity.
  • The scan involves injecting a radioactive tracer that is selectively taken up by hyperactive parathyroid glands, allowing for their identification.
Other options:
 
  • CECT neck and ultrasound neck can provide additional information, but they are not the primary diagnostic modalities for hyperparathyroidism.
  • Radioiodine scan is used to evaluate thyroid function and is not directly relevant to the diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 877.

questions.text: A thyroidectomy was performed on a patient who had hyperthyroidism. He appeared with thyroid storm symptoms two days later. What is most likely to be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Inadequate preoperative preparation

Thyrotoxic crisis (storm) is an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism.
It most commonly occurs if a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy. 
During thyroid storm, an individual's heart rate, blood pressure, and body temperature can soar to dangerously high levels.

* [Extra Edge]: preoperative preparation
 
  • Traditional preparation aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid at operation.
  • Preparation is as an outpatient and only rarely is admission to hospital necessary on account of severe symptoms at presentation, failure to control the hyperthyroidism or non-compliance with medication. Care should be coordinated with endocrinology input.
  • Carbimazole 30–40 mg/day is the drug of choice for preparation. When euthyroid (after 8–12 weeks), the dose may be reduced to 5 mg 8-hourly or a ‘block and replace’ regime used.
  • In this case, the high dose of carbimazole is continued to inhibit T3 and T4 production and a maintenance dose of 0.1–0.15 mg thyroxine is given daily. The last dose of carbimazole may be given on the evening before surgery. Iodides are not used alone because, if the patient needs preoperative treatment, a more effective drug should be given.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 862.

questions.text: Which of these is not seen in MEN-1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Posterior pituitary tumors

Posterior pituitary tumors are not seen in case of MEN-1 syndrome because in MEN disorders, only anterior pituitary tumours develop.
Since the posterior pituitary contains neural components, endocrine neoplasias cannot develop there.




Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 912.

questions.text: Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) cannot by itself diagnose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Follicular carcinoma of thyroid

FNAC is not enough to diagnose Follicular Carcinoma of Thyroid Gland:

Only a core tissue biopsy can show evidence of basement membrane and capsular invasion, which are crucial to distinguish between follicular adenomas and follicular carcinoma of the thyroid.

Simply observing atypical malignant cells in the fine needle aspirate material can detect papillary carcinomas, breast cancer, and lung cancer.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 858.

choices.text: 99 m-Tc scan should be performed to determine whether the nodules are hypo-functioning or hyperfunctioning
All nodules >1 cm should be resected irrespective of cytology
FNAC ideally should be performed for all nodules >2 cm in diameter

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is diagnosed with a nodular goiter. Which of the following statements regarding her evaluation and management is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) All nodules >1 cm should be resected irrespective of cytology 

Subjects with a benign cytology are considered true negative if they are followed up for a period of at least 2 years – this will allow identification of those with changing symptoms for a repeat FNAB, and true negativity is confirmed if a diagnosis of thyroid neoplasia has not been made after a 2-year follow-up.

Surgery is required if malignant or suspicious cytology is reported. Rapid growth and increasing pressure effects (breathing difficulty) will signal the need for surgery. Some patients may undergo surgery for pressure effects like dysphagia, and other patients may opt for surgery because of cosmetic reasons due to the size of the goiter.
It has been suggested that in subjects with a suspicious FNAB report, the rate of surgery may be reduced further by subjecting patients to radio nuclide scanning and performing surgery on those nodules that are cold or warm, and simply following up those with hot nodules without surgery as the risk of malignancy in these nodules is very low.



Online Reference: Unnikrishnan AG, Kalra S, Baruah M, Nair G, Nair V, Bantwal G, Sahay RK. Endocrine Society of India management guidelines for patients with thyroid nodules: A position statement. Indian J Endocrinol Metab. 2011 Jan;15(1):2-8. doi: 10.4103/2230-8210.77566. PMID: 21584159; PMCID: PMC3079862.

choices.text: 50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
50% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal
25% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
25% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal

questions.text: How is removal of the correct gland after surgery confirmed in parathyroid adenoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal

The Miami Criteria are used to assess the effectiveness of removing a single adenoma in a patient with hyperparathyroidism.

  • The criteria measure the drop in the circulating plasma PTH (parathyroid hormone) level 10 minutes after resection.
  • A drop in the PTH level to less than half its maximum preoperative levels and to the normal range indicates successful resection and single-gland disease.
  • If the drop in PTH is not detected or is insufficient, multiple gland disease is suspected and further treatment or exploration may be necessary. The half life of PTH is 3-5 minutes, allowing for a significant drop to be detected in the plasma following resection of a single adenoma.

Fig: Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement. Drop of PTH into the normal range and less than half the maximum value at 10 minutes postresection.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 880.

choices.text: Operated even if the patient is asymptomatic
Majority of the goiters derive their blood supply from mediastinal vessels
Majority of the Retrosternal goiter can be removed by a neck incision

questions.text: Which is true with respect to Retrosternal goiter ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Majority of the Retrosternal goiter can be removed by a neck incision

  • Patients with retrosternal goiter should be carefully assessed to determine whether they may require surgery.
  • In most cases, minimal symptoms and elderly age suggest observation only. However, if there is significant airway compression, symptoms present or the patient is young, the benefits of surgery should be weighed against the risks.
  • Most retrosternal goiter can be managed safely via transcervical approach, but may require conversion to an open sternotomy if diagnosis reveals malignancy, extension into posterior mediastinum or large size. In these cases, joint efforts from both thoracic and neck surgery may be beneficial.

Fig: Chest radiograph showing a retrosternal goiter with calcification and tracheal displacement

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 860.

questions.text: Name the common site of gastrinoma in MEN1 syndrome.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Duodenum

  • The above statement is referring to Gastrinomas, which are tumors that enhances the secretion of gastrin, a hormone which increases the hydrochloric acid production of the stomach, causing ulcers and other acid-related conditions.
  • It is associated with MEN 1 syndrome, which is a genetic disorder that affects among other things, the exocrine glands of the pancreas. 
  • More than 70% of the gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome are commonly located in the first and second part of the duodenum.
  • This section of the duodenum is also known as the 'gastrinoma triangle'.
  • Therefore, due to the high likelihood of tumors being located in this particular section, it is recommended that all patients with gastrinomas should be tested for MEN 1 syndrome and undergo surgical exploration if there is no evidence of diffuse metastases.

Fig: The gastrinoma triangle

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 907.

questions.text: Which hormone will not have to be additionally supplied in case of a 56 years old female who underwent trans sphenoid hypophysectomy for pituitary tumor and now has low ACTH, TSH, FSH and LH
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Mineralocorticoids
 
  • Mineralocorticoids are not required in this patient's treatment plan because, following hypophysectomy, basal levels of mineralocorticoids—primarily aldosterone—remain normal because the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone feedback is not regulated by the levels of ACTH.
  • Rather, it is primarily regulated by serum potassium levels.
  • Since the lady has low FSH and LH, estradiol has to be supplemented in hormone replacement therapy
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 898.

questions.text: The method for thyroid examination is shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lahey's method

Lahey's technique for palpating the thyroid is demonstrated in the image above.
The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation according to Lahey's method. The left hand should be used to push the left lobe laterally while the right hand is used to palpate the lobe.
CRILE'S METHOD- This method involves placing the thumb on the thyroid gland and asking the patient to swallow. Small thyroid nodules within the thyroid gland can be palpated by this method.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 454.

choices.text: Level 1 to Level 5 nodes of ipsilateral side

questions.text: Which among the following structures is removed in modified radicle neck dissection
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Level 1 to Level 5 nodes of ipsilateral side 

Modified radical neck dissection
This term denotes a procedure in which one or more of the non-lymphatic structures are preserved (the accessory nerve, the sternocleidomastoid muscle or the internal jugular vein) with clearance of all nodal levels (I–V).



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 811.

questions.text: After undergoing B/L adrenalectomy due to B/L pheochromocytoma, the patient experienced  lethargy, exhaustion, low blood pressure, and normal pulse 1 day later. There are no indications of volume deficiency, what is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Addisonian Crisis

  • Pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas are tumors which are derived from the sympathetic or parasympathetic nervous system and produce catecholamines.
  • The ultimate treatment goal for these tumors is complete removal of the tumors, which can be done through partial or total adrenalectomy. However, it is important that the normal adrenal cortex is still there, in order to prevent Addison's disease and to make sure that bilateral pheochromocytomas are most likely to be present.
  • Nitroprusside infusion is used for any intraoperative hypertension and hypotension can be solved with a volume infusion. Postoperatively, the catecholamine levels should be checked to make sure they are normalized.
  • An ACTH test should be done to check for cortisol deficiency when bilateral adrenal cortex-sparing surgery is done. The risks of surgery for pheochromocytoma include severe preoperative hypertension, high secretion tumors and recurrence.
  • Additionally, the absence of adrenal glands can lead to a sharp drop in cortisol which requires lifelong glucocorticoid replacement therapy which leads to a 15-25% risk of developing Nelson syndrome.
  • Nelson syndrome is characterized by the enlargement of the pituitary gland and the development of pituitary gland tumors.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 898.

questions.text: The nerve that will sustain the least damage during thyroid surgery is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Marginal mandibular

Among the given options, marginal mandibular nerve is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery as it is situated higher up among the given nerves. Therefore, it is least likely to be encountered in dissection involved in thyroid surgery. Note- The most common nerve injured in thyroid surgery is ELN ( not RLN ).

The fascia above the facial vessels is palpated in the midportion of the body of the mandible. The nerve is usually identified in the fascia above the vessels and is dissected along its path horizontally to expose it as it exits the parotid and traverses onto the muscles anteriorly.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 843.

questions.text:
A patient with a midline neck enlargement that shifts with deglutition arrives to the OPD. He also has exophthalmos and tachycardia. What specific investigations are necessary in this situation?
(i) Thyroid scan
(ii) FNAC
(iii) Thyroid function tests
(iv) USG neck
(v) Anti-thyroid antibodies
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) i, iii, iv, v

The given clinical history is suggestive of Grave’s disease. Antibodies Involved are TSH receptor antibodies.

Investigations—

Thyroid function tests : Increase in TSH, T3, T4. 

USG Neck : Diffuse midline neck swelling. 

Anti - Thyroid Antibodies present.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 860.

questions.text: A thyroidectomy patient was being extubated. The anesthesiologist discovered that the patient starts to experience recurring cyanotic spells when the tube is removed. Which of the subsequent might be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B/L RLN palsy
 
  • Recurring cyanotic spells after extubation suggest bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy.
  • RLN palsy can occur as a complication of thyroidectomy.
  • It leads to vocal cord dysfunction and can result in airway compromise.
  • Immediate intervention may be required to secure the airway and ensure adequate oxygenation.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 864.

choices.text: 3 follicular cell clusters with each 10 - 15 cells
6 follicular cell clusters with each 10 - 15 cells

questions.text: The appropriate samples for FNAC thyroid will contain:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 6 follicular cell clusters with each 10 - 15 cells

Adequate specimen in case of FNAC thyroid will be having 6 follicular cell clusters with each 10-15 cells.

* Criteria for adequacy of a specimen:
A specimen must show at least six groups of follicular cells, each of which should have at least ten cells, ideally on a single slide.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 855.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not removed in a type-2 modified radical dissection of the neck?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Spinal Accessary Nerve



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 811.

questions.text: Which of these is least likely to have lymph node metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Follicular Ca Thyroid

Anaplastic Ca Thyroid > Papillary Ca Thyroid > Medullary Ca Thyroid > Follicular Ca Thyroid.
 
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is more commonly seen in iodine-deficient areas.
  • They present as solitary thyroid nodules and are associated with a rapid increase in size. 
  • Pain is not common but can be seen if hemorrhage occurs into the nodule.
  • Metastasis is bloodborne and lymph node involvement is not seen.
  • FNAC cannot differentiate benign and malignant follicular lesions.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 868.

choices.text: Lining of tall columnar and cuboidal cells

questions.text: What is the difference between a well differentiated follicular carcinoma of thyroid and a follicular adenoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vascular invasion

The key difference between a well-differentiated follicular carcinoma of the thyroid and a follicular adenoma is the presence of vascular invasion.
  • A follicular adenoma is a benign tumor of the thyroid gland that is usually encapsulated and does not invade the surrounding tissues.
  • In contrast, a well-differentiated follicular carcinoma of the thyroid has the potential to invade the surrounding tissues, including blood vessels, which is known as vascular invasion.
  • Vascular invasion is an important diagnostic feature that helps to distinguish between a benign follicular adenoma and a malignant follicular carcinoma.
  • The presence of vascular invasion indicates that the tumor has the potential to spread to other parts of the body, and therefore, it requires aggressive treatment such as surgery, radioactive iodine therapy, and/or external beam radiation therapy.
  • Other features such as Hurtle cell change, lining of tall columnar and cuboidal cells, and nuclear features may also be helpful in distinguishing between a follicular adenoma and a follicular carcinoma, but they are not as reliable as vascular invasion.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 868.

questions.text: A 40 years old patient with thyroid carcinoma underwent thyroidectomy but on 4th post-operative day, he developed perioral tingling and carpo-pedal spasm. How to investigate this patient?
questions.solution:
• Hypoparathyroidism is a common complication following thyroid surgery. Usually, its a temporary phenomenon and lasts for 4-6 weeks. 
  • It can be diagnosed when there is decreased serum calcium and PTH levels.
  • Hypocalcemia is a common complication following thyroidectomy, often due to damage or removal of the parathyroid glands, which are responsible for regulating calcium levels in the body.
  • Estimation of calcium levels will help identify hypocalcemia, which can present with symptoms like tingling, muscle spasms, and seizures.
  • Parathormone (PTH) levels are crucial in differentiating whether the hypocalcemia is due to primary hypoparathyroidism (low PTH levels) or due to functional hypoparathyroidism (normal or high PTH levels in response to low calcium).
  • Phosphate levels may also be elevated in hypocalcemia as a result of impaired renal excretion due to low calcium.

Other options:
 
  1. Estimation of T3 and T4: While thyroid function tests are important in monitoring the thyroid status after thyroidectomy, they are less relevant to the acute issue of hypocalcemia and the symptoms of tingling and muscle spasms.
  2. Radioisotope iodine scan: This is used for detecting thyroid tissue or metastasis after thyroidectomy in thyroid cancer patients, but it is not relevant to the current symptoms of hypocalcemia.
  3. Thyroglobulin estimation: This is a tumor marker used to assess for recurrence of thyroid cancer after thyroidectomy, but it does not help in evaluating the cause of hypocalcemia.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 915.

questions.text: Which drug is used in goiter patients to reduce bleeding before thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
• Lugol's iodine is used in goiter patients before thyroidectomy to reduce vascularity and bleeding during surgery.
  • It works by inhibiting the release of thyroid hormones (Wolff-Chaikoff effect) and reducing the gland's blood flow, making it less vascular and easier to operate on. This is especially beneficial in cases of hyperthyroid goiter.
  • Lugol's Iodine is started 1-10 days prior to surgery to decrease vascularity of gland and thus chances of intraoperative thyroid storm.


Pre-operative preparation of a hyperthyroid patient

1. Antithyroid medication:
  • Drugs: Propylthiouracil (PTU) or Methimazole.
  • Purpose: To inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis and control hyperthyroid symptoms.
  • Duration: Typically started weeks before surgery to achieve a euthyroid state.
  • Monitoring: Regular checks of thyroid hormone levels (T3, T4, TSH) to ensure normalization.

2. Beta blockers:
  • Drug: Propranolol (commonly used).
  • Purpose: To control symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia, palpitations, and tremors.
  • Dose: Adjusted based on symptom control.

3. Iodine therapy:
  • Drug: Lugol's iodine or potassium iodide.
  • Purpose: To reduce thyroid vascularity, gland size, and hormone release (Wolff-Chaikoff effect).
  • Timing: Typically given 7–10 days before surgery.

4. Corticosteroids:
  • Drug: Hydrocortisone or Betamethasone.
  • Purpose:
    • To reduce the risk of adrenal insufficiency if hyperthyroidism is severe or prolonged.
    • To stabilize thyroid function and decrease inflammation.

5. Co-morbidities:
  • Address any underlying cardiovascular issues, such as atrial fibrillation.
  • Optimize nutritional status and hydration.

6. Anxiolytics:
  • Drug: Benzodiazepines.
  • Purpose: To alleviate anxiety, which can exacerbate hyperthyroid symptoms.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 813.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with a sudden onset of scrotal pain and discharge. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario of an elderly male patient with sudden-onset scrotal pain and discharge, along with blackish discoloration of the scrotum, is most likely indicative of Fournier's gangrene.

Fournier's gangrene is a rare polymicrobial infection that affects the perineal soft tissue, external genitalia, and perianal region. It involves inflammation of the subcutaneous tissue, leading to obliterative arteritis and gangrene. The condition often follows minor injuries or procedures in the perineal area, with common causes including urethral dilatation or hemorrhoid injections.

Clinically, patients present with sudden scrotal pain, accompanied by prostration, pallor, fever, and potentially crepitus or foul-smelling discharge.

The management requires immediate surgical debridement following initial stabilization with fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics. Urinary diversion and other supportive measures are also important in the treatment.

choices.text: Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limits of normal

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for parathyroidectomy in a patient?
questions.solution:
Parathyroidectomy is indicated in primary hyperparathyroidism based on the guidelines (NIH 2014):

  1. Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above normal → surgical indication 

  2. 24-hour urinary calcium >400 mg/d → indicates risk of nephrolithiasis, surgical indication 

  3. Age <50 years → younger patients are recommended for surgery due to long-term risk 

Creatinine clearance <90 ml/min is not an established indication for surgery. Surgery may be indicated if renal function is significantly compromised (e.g., GFR <60 ml/min), but <90 ml/min alone is insufficient.

Other options explained:

  • High serum calcium, elevated urinary calcium, or younger age → recognized criteria for surgery to prevent complications.

  • Creatinine clearance <90 ml/min → normal or mildly reduced; does not alone warrant parathyroidectomy.

High-yield point:
Parathyroidectomy indications focus on calcium levels, renal stones, bone involvement, age, or symptoms — not mild reduction in creatinine clearance.

questions.text: A patient who underwent thyroidectomy developed Hoarseness of voice following surgery. Which of the following steps in surgery could not have resulted in this complication?
questions.solution:
• Hoarseness of voice post thyroidectomy can be due to injury to external laryngeal nerve or unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • Division of strap muscles during thyroidectomy is a step where its least likely for the nerve injury to take place.
  • During thyroidectomy external laryngeal nerve injury is more common than recurrent laryngeal nerve and presents with hoarseness of voice.
  • At times bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury can occur causing dyspnea needing emergency tracheostomy however voice remains normal.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 851-852.

questions.text: A diabetic patient developed DVT with a necrolytic migratory rash. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Glucagonoma is a rare α-cell tumor of the pancreas.

  • Key features (4D’s):

    1. Dermatitis → Necrolytic migratory erythema (classic rash, painful, erythematous, migratory, blistering, especially perioral, perineal, intertriginous areas).

    2. Diabetes mellitus → due to excess glucagon (insulin antagonist).

    3. DVT (deep vein thrombosis) → strong association.

    4. Depression (neuropsychiatric symptoms).

  • Other findings: anemia, weight loss, glossitis, diarrhea.



    Other options

  • VIPoma: Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome).

  • Gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison): Refractory peptic ulcers, diarrhea.

  • Insulinoma: Hypoglycemia, Whipple’s triad.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman after thyroidectomy comes to you for 2nd opinion for further treatment of papillary thyroid cancer. What would you recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
A radioiodine scan is recommended for this patient post-thyroidectomy to check for any residual or metastatic disease.

Incidence: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most prevalent form of thyroid cancer, frequently diagnosed in women aged 30 to 50.
Etiology: Common risk factors include radiation exposure and a family history of thyroid cancers. Genetic mutations in the RET or BRAF genes are often associated with this type of carcinoma.

Clinical Features:
Presentation: Patients typically present with an asymptomatic thyroid swelling, often accompanied by enlargement of cervical lymph nodes.
Advanced Disease Symptoms: In more advanced stages, symptoms may include hoarseness, dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), cough, or dyspnea (difficulty breathing).

Diagnostic Evaluation:
Ultrasound Scan: This imaging modality is effective for assessing the size and number of thyroid nodules, as well as categorizing them as benign, indeterminate, or malignant.
Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC): FNAC is a valuable diagnostic tool, particularly for evaluating indeterminate or malignant lesions, aiding in the diagnosis and management of thyroid conditions.

Other options:

  • Chemotherapy → very limited role, not used in papillary carcinoma.

  • External beam radiotherapy → reserved only for unresectable or non–radioiodine-avid disease.

  • Wait and watch → not recommended, as further staging/ablation is necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best imaging modality to diagnose neuroendocrine tumours (NETs)?
questions.solution:
Positron emission tomography (PET) is considered the best modality for diagnosing neuroendocrine tumors (NETs).

The initial imaging investigation typically involves cross-sectional imaging using computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). For patients suspected of having NETs, CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis are performed for staging purposes. An MRI may be considered for further definition of lesions in the liver or pancreas when necessary.

PET scans using 111In (indium) labeled pentetreotide or 68Ga (gallium) linked somatostatin analogues are particularly effective due to the overexpression of somatostatin receptors often found in NETs. These radiolabeled somatostatin analogues help localize NETs, making PET scans the most effective imaging modality for these tumors.

questions.text: A female patient with a known case of thyroid malignancy was found to show high levels of serum calcitonin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical situation presented is suggestive with thyroid cancer in the medullary region (MTC). Amyloid deposits are evident in histopathology, and these deposits are a result of changed calcitonin molecules.

A tumor of the thyroid gland's parafollicular or C cells is known as medullary thyroid cancer. They originate from the ultimobranchial bodies' neural crest cells.

The majority of MTCs happen seldom. However, familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B are linked to about 25% of the malignancies.

Individuals with familial MTC typically present at a younger age than those with sporadic MTC, who typically present at an older age. Among MTC's features are:

* Neck tumor that hurts and has cervical lymphadenopathy

* If locally invaded, dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea

* Diarrhea brought on by serotonin-induced increased intestinal motility

Cushingoid behavior as a result of ectopic ACTH

Reference:Robbins basic pathology 10e page no 768

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with abdominal pain, proptosis, features of ataxia, and abnormal bursts of unusual eye movements as shown below. The child is found to have an intra-abdominal mass. What is the most likely diagnosis in this boy?
questions.solution:
This 2-year-old boy presents with:

  • Abdominal pain with a mass

  • Proptosis (eye bulging)

  • Ataxia (gait imbalance)

  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus (chaotic eye movements + myoclonic jerks)

These classic features are highly suggestive of neuroblastoma.

Key Points about Neuroblastoma:

Feature Details
Tumor origin Neural crest cells (sympathetic nervous system); commonly from the adrenal medulla
Age group Most common <5 years; median ~18 months
Common sites Adrenal gland (most common), paraspinal ganglia, mediastinum
Crosses midline Yes, often crosses midline (vs Wilms' tumor which doesn't)
Metastasis Common at presentation: bones, bone marrow, liver, skin
Characteristic findings - Proptosis & periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes) due to orbital metastases
- Abdominal mass
- Opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMS) due to paraneoplastic encephalopathy
- Blueberry muffin lesions due to skin mets
Biochemical markers ↑ Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) in urine
Diagnosis - USG/CT/MRI to locate tumor
- Urine catecholamines
- Tissue biopsy
Histology Small round blue cell tumor; Homer Wright rosettes may be seen
Prognosis Depends on stage, MYCN amplification (worse), age (<18 months better)


 

Differential diagnosis: 
Option Reason
Rhabdomyosarcoma Can cause orbital proptosis but not typically associated with abdominal mass and OMS
Hepatoblastoma Presents with abdominal mass, but proptosis & OMS are not seen
Wilms’ tumor Abdominal mass usually does not cross midline, no proptosis or OMS
 

Because of the triad of abdominal mass, periorbital metastasis, and paraneoplastic OMS.


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 847

questions.text: From where does the bleeding from a Mallory-Weiss tear usually occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Left gastric artery
 
  • Mallory-Weiss tears are related to forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining.
  • Most Mallory-Weiss tears stop bleeding spontaneously and supportive treatment is all that is required. If bleeding continues, infusion of vasoactive substances into the celiac artery into the left gastric artery often obviates the need for operation.
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome is characterized by longitudinal mucosal lacerations (intramural dissection) in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, which are usually associated with forceful or prolonged vomiting or retching. The lacerations often lead to bleeding from submucosal arterial plexus.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1167.

questions.text: An infant of six months woke up in the middle of the night sobbing from stomach ache that was eased by passing red faeces. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Intussusception
 
  • The most likely diagnosis for an infant waking up with stomach ache and passing red feces is intussusception (Option B).
  • Intussusception occurs when one portion of the intestine telescopes into another, leading to obstruction and compromised blood supply.
  • The classic presentation includes sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, inconsolable crying, and passing of "currant jelly" stools, which are reddish due to blood mixed with mucus.
  • Prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bowel necrosis.

* [Extra Edge]: Intussusception



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 260.

questions.text: A woman in her twenties is experiencing vomiting, nausea, and stomach pain. She exhibited baldness and an epigastric crepitus, following an examination. What has been found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Trichobezoar

* Audio Explanation:


Fig: Trichobezoar of the stomach in a girl aged 15 years

  • Trichobezoar (hair balls) are unusual and are virtually exclusively found in young psychiatric patients.
  • It is caused by the ingestion of hair, which remains undigested in the stomach. The hair ball can lead to ulceration and gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation or obstruction.
  • The diagnosis is made easily at endoscopy. A preoperative diagnosis is difficult even with high-resolution computed tomography (CT) scanning.
  • Treatment consists of removal of the bezoar, which may require open surgical treatment. Phytobezoars are made of vegetable matter and are found principally in patients who have gastric stasis, usually following gastric surgery.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1180.

choices.text: Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon

questions.text: A 65 year old man presented with history of syncope. He also complains of feeling lightheadedness and excessive bleeding and pain during defecation. Stool occult blood test for routine screening of colon cancer came back negative. There is no recent weight loss history. What is the most likely colonoscopic finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon
 
  • The most likely colonoscopic finding in this patient is dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon, known as colonic angiodysplasia.
  • This condition is commonly seen in older individuals and can cause lower gastrointestinal bleeding (LGIB), lightheadedness, and syncope.It can be associated with Aortic Stenosis.
* Other options:
 
  • Early stage carcinoma colon: Less likely due to negative stool occult blood test and absence of weight loss.
  • Sigmoid diverticulitis: Less likely due to the absence of recent weight loss history.
  • Microscopic colitis: Less likely as it doesn't typically present with syncope, lightheadedness, or excessive bleeding and pain during defecation.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1370.

questions.text: All of the following pathological lesions given below are premalignant with the exception of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crohn's disease
 
  • Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory condition that primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract, but it is not typically associated with premalignant changes.
  • It can lead to complications such as strictures and fistulas but does not have a direct premalignant potential like the other conditions listed.
  • The other conditions—ulcerative colitis, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, and Barrett’s esophagus—are associated with an increased risk of developing malignancies such as colorectal cancer and esophageal adenocarcinoma, respectively.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 671, 1268.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman has right iliac fossa pain that is dull and painful. Upon examination, a tumour (mass) in the right iliac fossa could be felt and there was a noticeable gross pallor. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Carcinoma ascending colon
 
  • In a 58-year-old woman with right iliac fossa pain, a tumor palpable in the region, and noticeable gross pallor, the most likely diagnosis is carcinoma of the ascending colon (Option D).
  • Right-sided colonic tumors, particularly in the ascending colon, can present with nonspecific symptoms such as abdominal pain and weight loss. This patient
  • The palpable mass and gross pallor could be indicative of an advanced stage of colon cancer.
  • Further investigations, such as colonoscopy and imaging studies, would be required to confirm the diagnosis.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1358.

questions.text: What is the preferred investigation for "acute appendicitis"  in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ultrasound
 
  • The preferred investigation for acute appendicitis in children is an ultrasound (Option B).
  • Ultrasound is non-invasive, readily available, and does not involve ionizing radiation, making it the imaging modality of choice for pediatric patients.
  • It is highly accurate in diagnosing acute appendicitis, with sensitivity and specificity approaching or even exceeding that of CT scan.
  • Ultrasound findings of acute appendicitis:
    • Non-compressible, dilated appendix
    • Thickened appendix wall
    • Presence of appendicolith (fecalith)
    • Peri-appendiceal fluid collection
    • Hypoechoic (dark) appearance of the appendix
* Signs seen in acute appendicitis:


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1339.

questions.text: What condition of the following is does not results in evisceration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Congenital umbilical hernia
  • Evisceration typically involves the protrusion of internal organs through an opening, and while the other conditions (urachal fistula, gastroschisis, and patent vitellointestinal duct) are associated with such abnormalities.
  • A congenital umbilical hernia generally involves a defect in the abdominal wall but does not necessarily imply evisceration.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 202.

questions.text:
A young boy who had been experiencing stomach pain, vomiting, and a fever arrived at the emergency room. On examination, he was febrile with a pulse rate
of 104 beats per minute. The resident was eliciting the sign shown below. Can you identify the sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) McBurney’s point tenderness

The point over the right side of the abdomen that is one-third of the way between the anterior superior iliac spine and the umbilicus is known as McBurney's point. This is close to where the appendix is most frequently found.

* Audio Explanation:
 


1- Mcburney Point
2- Umblicus
3- ASIS



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1339.

questions.text: Following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a patient was released from the hospital the same day. He arrived at the hospital on the third postoperative day with a fever. A 5 X 5 cm collection was detected by ultrasonography in the right subdiaphragmatic area. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Pigtail insertion and drainage

The given clinical scenario is of Subdiaphragmatic fluid collection and later development of abscess.
 
  • Pigtail insertion and drainage involves percutaneous placement of a catheter (pigtail) into the collection to facilitate drainage. This is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for effective drainage of the collection without the need for re-exploration or more invasive interventions.
  • By inserting the pigtail catheter, the accumulated fluid in the subdiaphragmatic area can be drained, reducing the risk of infection and promoting the patient's recovery.
  • This approach is often preferred as it carries a lower risk compared to re-exploration of the wound or more invasive procedures, while still effectively addressing the collection.
  • Observe with antibiotic cover may not be sufficient to resolve the collection, and re-exploration of the wound with T-tube insertion or ERCP may not be necessary or appropriate in this case.

Fig: Percutaneous cholecystostomy. A pigtail catheter has been placed through the abdominal wall, the right lobe of the liver, and into the gallbladder.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1410.

questions.text: Progressive jaundice, pruritus, and clay-colored feces had been observed in a 60-year-old habitual smoker for two months. There was a history of jaundice rising and waning. The major pancreatic duct and common bile duct were shown to be dilated by a CT scan. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Periampullary Carcinoma.

Historically, evaluation and management of cholangiocarcinoma required arbitrary division of the bile duct into thirds based on the location of obstruction. Lesions of the middle third, however, are decidedly rare, so investigations have recently focused on perihilar and intrahepatic lesions, known as proximal lesions, versus those involving the periampullary region, known as distal disease. More than two thirds of all cholangiocarcinomas involve the proximal biliary tree near the bifurcation, known as a Klatskin tumor.

It often presents with obstructive jaundice due to obstruction of the bile ducts, leading to symptoms such as Waxing and wanning Jaundice( periampullary cancer causes obstruction, later by the fluid pressure of bile a part of tumor is released causing waning of jaundice and the cycle repeats), itching (pruritus), and pale stools (acholic stools).

With hilar cholangio-carcinomas, the gallbladder and visualized extrahepatic biliary tree are usually decompressed, whereas distal lesions will have extrahepatic biliary ductal dilation and gallbladder distention.

Frequently, dilatation of both the bile and pancreatic ducts (“double-duct sign”) On CT scan.


Fig: Double duct sign of Periampullary CA.

Reference: Sleisenger and Fordtran’s Gastrointestinal and Liver Disease, 10th Edition, Page No 1197.

choices.text: Remnant of proximal part of vitellointestinal duct

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Meckel's diverticulum is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Present in 3% of the population

Meckel's diverticulum is present in 2% of people rather than 3% of the population.

* [Extra Edge]: Features of Meckel’s diverticulum:

  • Remnant of vitellointestinal duct.
  • Occurs in 2% of patients, 5 cm (2 inches) long, 60 cm (2 feet) from the ileocaecal valve, 20% heterotopic epithelium
  • Should be looked for when a normal appendix is found at surgery for suspected appendicitis
  • If a Meckel’s diverticulum is found incidentally at surgery, it can be left provided it has a wide mouth and is not thickened
  • Can be a source of gastrointestinal bleeding if it contains ectopic gastric mucosa

Fig: Meckel’s diverticulum

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1311.

questions.text: A patient with abdominal pain for 2 hours arrives to the casualty, and the following X-ray is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pneumoperitoneum
 
  • The X-ray shows air under the diaphragm, which indicates the presence of free air within the peritoneal cavity, known as the pneumoperitoneum.
  • Pneumoperitoneum is most commonly caused by a perforated viscus, such as a ruptured hollow organ (e.g., stomach, intestine) or iatrogenic injury during surgery.

Fig: Pneumoperitoneum on upright chest X-ray in patient with perforated ulcer



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1127.

questions.text: Which organ should be examined first during an emergency laparotomy for an intestinal obstruction to determine whether it is a small bowel or large colon obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cecum

While doing emergency laparotomy for an intestinal obstruction, cecum should be visualized first to confirm ,whether it's a small bowel or large bowel obstruction.

If caecum is collapsed, it is likely to be small bowel obstruction whereas it will be distended in large bowel obstruction. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1311.

questions.text: What kind of flap-based technique is applied during pilonidal sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rhomboid flap 

Rhomboid flap-based procedure is used for pilonidal sinus surgery. The skin and subcutaneous fat to be removed is excised down to deep fascia, and a rhomboid area of specimen including pilonidal sinus and its all extensions are removed

Then flap is raised so that it includes skin, subcutaneous fat, and the fascia overlying gluteus maximus, rotated to cover midline rhomboid defect.


Fig: Rhomboid-Limberg flap for pilonidal sinus

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 960.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis of the given gross specimen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Polyps in gallbladder

The diagnosis of the given gross specimen is gallbladder polyp.

Polypoid lesions of the gallbladder include:
 
  1. Cholesterol polyps : Have a characteristic echogenic pedunculated appearance on USG.
  1. Adenomatous polyp : May lead to malignancy. Lack of transmural invasion on USG.

Cholesterosis of GB

Strawberry gallbladder 



Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 650.

questions.text: Which is the most common presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Abdominal mass

Most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor is abdominal mass.
 
  • Desmoid tumor is MC malignant mesentery neoplasm.
  • Develops from musculoaponeurotic abdominal wall structures, particularly below the level of the umbilicus.
  • It is an entirely unencapsulated fibroma and is so solid that cutting through it causes it to creak.
  • MRI is investigation of choice, Biopsy may be done to establish diagnosis.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1557.

choices.text: Do conservative management and leave it for spontaneous resolution
Perform Laparotomy and check for leakage site and healthy margins
Perform Laparotomy and completely exteriorize the fistula
Perform Laparotomy and place lateral drains and leave

questions.text: A resection anastomosis was performed on a patient with Crohn's disease. The patient exhibits a fistula-related anastomotic site leak on the seventh postoperative day. The total amount of daily leakage is 150–200 ml. The patient is stable and uncomplaining; there is no intra-abdominal collection. What level of management will come after that?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Do conservative management and leave it for spontaneous resolution.

The likely diagnosis is a very low output enterocutaneous fistula. Daily output less than 500 ml is low output fistula. 
The patient is stable with no collection of fluid in the abdomen, indicating that the fistula is not actively leaking.

The ideal management in this case is conservative management which includes nutritional support, wound care, and regular follow-up. 

* Principles of management of enterocutaneous fistulae (SNAP):

â— S, elimination of Sepsis and skin protection
â— N, Nutrition – a period of parenteral nutrition may well be required
â— A, Anatomical assessment
â— P, definitive Planned surgery

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1315.

questions.text: What is the treatment for a patient who has dysphagia and sporadic epigastric discomfort during endoscopy whose oesophagus is dilated proximally and narrowed distally?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Heller’s Cardiomyotomy.

Achalasia is a rare and very specific type of esophageal disorder that affects both the muscles and nerves of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). This leads to difficulty in swallowing, chest pain and sometimes vomiting.

It is usually diagnosed after a physical exam and radiologic imaging studies, such as barium swallow and CT scan which reveal dilation of the esophageal lumen with narrowing of its distal end.

Heller’s cardiomyotomy is the treatment of choice for achalasia cardia, which involves surgically dividing the lower esophageal sphincter muscle and the inner muscle layer of the esophageal wall. This helps with opening up the esophageal lumen, and prevents the episodes of chest pain and dysphagia that are seen in achalasia.


Fig: Completion of the myotomy; the light of the endoscope can be seen shining through the thin mucosa

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1315.

questions.text: What's the early complication of ileostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Necrosis

Ileostomy is a surgical procedure where a stoma (or hole) is created in the abdominal wall, allowing the small intestine to enter into an artificial external opening.

Among the given options, necrosis is an early complication ( < 30 days ) of ileostomy. Rest of the given options are delayed complications. 

* Stoma complications:

â— Skin irritation
â— Prolapse
â— Retraction
â— Ischemia
â— Stenosis
â— Parastomal hernia
â— Bleeding
â— Fistulation


Fig: Spouted ileostomy in the right iliac fossa

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1315.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a toddler who has a few drops of blood coming out of his rectum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Juvenile Rectal Polyp
 
  • Juvenile rectal polyps are the most common cause of passage of a few drops of blood per rectum in a toddler.
  • They are benign, mushroom-like growths that occur in the lining of the rectum.
  • They typically cause mild rectal bleeding but can also cause discomfort, pain, and bright red blood in the stool or on toilet paper. Other causes of rectal bleeding in toddlers include infections, anal fissures, certain medications, or even foreign bodies in the rectum.
  • This is a bright red, glistening pedunculated sphere (‘cherry tumor’) that is found in infants and children that may persist into adult life.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1403.

questions.text: Choose the true diverticulum of esophagus.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Parabronchial diverticulum

All of the diverticula except the Parabronchial diverticula seen in the middle Esophagus are false diverticula.

* Esophageal diverticula are either:

  • True diverticula: Include all esophageal layers
  • False diverticula: Contain only mucosa and submucosa herniating through the muscular layer (e.g. Zenker's diverticulum)

Fig: Barium esophagram demonstrating a giant midesophageal diverticulum

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1029.

questions.text: What incision from the list below is used for diaphragmatic surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Circumferential

Circumferential incisions in diaphragm are the safest incisions as they result in little loss of function. These circumferential incisions, however, must be at least 5 cm lateral to the edge of the central tendon to avoid the posterolateral and anterolateral branches of the phrenic nerve.

Reference: Filosso PL, Guerrera F, Sandri A, Lausi PO, Lyberis P, Bora G, Roffinella M, Ruffini E. Surgical management of chronic diaphragmatic hernias. J Thorac Dis. 2019 Feb;11(Suppl 2):S177-S185. doi: 10.21037/jtd.2019.01.54. PMID: 30906583; PMCID: PMC6389560.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient arrives with massive bowel diarrhea and rectal bleeding. A growth that resembles a cauliflower is visible on sigmoidoscopy in the rectum. Histopathological analysis of a colectomy specimen reveals cancer. Which of the following prognostic studies is not necessary?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is ( Option 3) EGFR mutations
 
  • Kras and Cmyc have been found to have prognostic value in advanced colonic cancers (stage 4), where genotyping for Kras mutations is now standard practice.
  • ErbB2 amplification is associated with advanced disease stage and poor survival outcomes, however it is only amplified in less than 5% of subjects.
  • MSI has well-established prognostic value in colonic cancers and is often tested regularly. While all these options have some prognostic value, in a scenario where a patient has early stage cancer (no more than a symptom of diarrhoea and a tumor excised during sigmoidoscopy), EGFR may have no prognostic value.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 195.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an admission criterion for upper GI bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Hematocrit > 40%
 
  • Hematocrit > 40% is not a criteria for admission in upper GI bleed as this is non specific and can be managed conservatively.
  • The indications for hospital admission and resuscitation in upper GI bleed are: Shock index >1.5 Frank blood in nasogastric aspirate BP <100 mm Hg.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1217.

questions.text: The doctor was searching for curling ulcers in a burn patient. Which area should be examined?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. 1st part of duodenum
 
  • In a burn patient, the doctor was looking for curling ulcer and 1st part of duodenum must be examined for the same as the closest to stomach is 1st part of duodenum. 
  • Curling ulcers are Characterized by multiple, superficial erosions after a burn injury that begin in the proximal acid releasing portion of stomach and invade distally and is rare in antrum and duodenum.
  • They are acute ulcers which develop after major burns, presenting as pain in epigastric region, vomiting or hematemesis. Treatment is conservative-IV ranitidine. IV pantoprazole 80 mg in 100 ml DNS-slow, later 40 mg IV maintenance.
  • Curling's ulcer occurs when burn injury is more than 35%. It is observed in the body and fundus not in antrum and duodenum.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 813.

questions.text: A young healthy male patient appeared with stomach pain and a 6-month history of changed bowel habits. On CT, there was a dilated distal ileum, a thickened ileocecal junction, a thickened cecum, and sacculations on the antimesenteric boundary. The vascularity of the adjacent mesentery is likewise enlarged, and there is fat around the mesentery. Which of the following does not constitute a distinct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4. Ischemic bowel disease
 
  • Ischemic bowel disease can’t be the differential diagnosis as in Ischemic bowel disease or mesenteric ischemia, vascularity of adjoining mesentery is decreased.
  • History of abdominal pain and altered bowel habit with thickened cecum and ileocecal junction and increased vascularity of surrounding mesentery can be observed in Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease and tuberculosis.
  • Signs and symptoms of ischemic colitis reflect the extent of bowel ischemia. In mild cases, patients may have diarrhea (usually bloody) without abdominal pain.
  • With more severe ischemia, intense abdominal pain (often out of proportion to the clinical examination), tenderness, fever, and leukocytosis are present. In CT scan Thumb Print sign is seen. 
  • Peritonitis and/or systemic toxicity are signs of full thickness necrosis and perforation.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1309.

questions.text: Which of the following is required to establish the diagnosis of H-type trachea-esophageal fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Tracheo-esophagoscopy
 
  • To establish the diagnosis of H-type trachea-esophageal fistula in difficult cases, Tracheo-esophagoscopy is required. TEF is an abnormal communication (fistula) between the esophagus and trachea.
  • It can be of different types based on the defect. Congenital isolated TEF (H-type) is a rare disorder and this leads to difficulties in its diagnosis and management.
  • If there is any uncertainty regarding the radiograph during initial diagnosis, a bronchoscopy with simultaneous injection of methylene blue should be performed for diagnosis of H-type TEF.





Fig: Tracheoesophageal fistula/Esophageal atresia with gastric perforation in a 28-week gestation, 1000-g baby

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 264.

questions.text: A four-year-old girl complained of an abdominal lump. In which of the following diagnosis for the above lump is a bone scan required?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Neuroblastomaâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹
 
  • In Neuroblastoma, a bone scan is required since metastases is evident in 60-70% of patients at the time of diagnosis and the most common site of metastasis in older children is bones.
  • Most (40%) present under the age of 1 year, 35% between ages 1 and 2 years and 25% older than 2 years.
  • Many present with signs and symptoms related to tumour growth or they may be incidental ultrasonographic fndings. Presenting symptoms include malaise and/or pain or obstruction of veins or lymphatics or hydronephrosis.
  • Acute or subacute paraplegia can develop from spinal cord or nerve root involvement. Many children (70%) have metastases at the time of presentation. Rarely the tumor secretes VIP, which results in diarrhoea, dehydration and hypokalemia.
  • NBs may secrete catecholamines, leading to elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrines. Serum lactate dehydrogenase is a useful tumour marker.
  • An unequivocal diagnosis is from histology of either the tumour or bone marrow aspirate. Imaging is undertaken to stage the disease using CT or MRI and MIBG. In children with regional or metastatic disease, biopsy is necessary for diagnosis and prognostication.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 902.

questions.text: The incidence of which of the following has been reduced due to the revolutionized in food preservation brought on by the advent of refrigeration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Stomach
 
  • Since the early 20th century, countries that have substituted refrigeration for traditional food-preserving methods such as salting, smoking, and pickling have seen a remarkable decrease in stomach cancer cases.
  • Conversely, countries that still rely heavily on these old practices still have high incidences of stomach cancer.
  • Stomach cancer increases with consumption of nitrites, preserved food, etc also. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 204.

questions.text: Where does osteoblastic metastasis commonly originate?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. Prostate
 
  • Sclerotic or osteoblastic bone metastases are distant tumor deposits of a primary tumor within bone characterized by new bone deposition or new bone formation.
  • Sclerotic bone metastases can arise from several different primary malignancies including- prostate carcinoma (most common) breast carcinoma (may be mixed) transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) carcinoid medulloblastoma neuroblastoma mucinous adenocarcinoma of the gastrointestinal tract lymphoma (e.g. ivory vertebra).

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 516.

choices.text: Located retroperitoneally at the level of L3
Useful for the painful conditions of lower abdomen
Most common side effects are diarrhea and hypotension

questions.text: Pick the option that is true about coeliac plexus block.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4. Most common side effects are diarrhea and hypotension

Celiac Plexus Block is performed retroperitoneally at the level of L1 and is usually done bilaterally for  painful conditions of upper abdomen like pancreatic cancer or pancreatitis.
Most common side effects are diarrhea and hypotension.
 
  • Celiac plexus neurolysis with alcohol injection has been an effective form of analgesic treatment in patients with pancreatic carcinoma.
  • However, the use of radiologically or endoscopically guided celiac plexus blockade in chronic pancreatitis has been disappointing.
  • Due to the risk of alcohol injury and the need for repeated injections, celiac plexus blockade in chronic pancreatitis has used short-acting analgesics or other drugs rather than 50% alcohol.
  • A trial of EUS-guided celiac plexus blockade revealed successful pain relief in 55% of patients, but the benefit lasted beyond 6 months in only 10% of patients. The procedure therefore appears safe, but the effect is short lived in those patients who obtain pain relief.
Other options-
  • Coeliac plexus is located L1
  • It is done bilaterally
  • It is used for painful conditions of upper abdomen 

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1469.

questions.text: Pick the option that is an early complication of ileostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Necrosis

Stoma necrosis may occur in the early post-operative period and usually is caused by skeletonizing the distal small bowel and/or creating an overly tight fascial defect.
Rest of the given options are delayed complications of ileostomy. 

* Stoma complications:

â— Skin irritation
â— Prolapse
â— Retraction
â— Ischemia
â— Stenosis
â— Parastomal hernia
â— Bleeding
â— Fistulation

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1314.

choices.text: Clean and drape from the level of nipple to mid-thigh
Clean and drape from chin to knee
Clean and drape from umbilicus to mid-thigh
Clean and drape from rib cage to inguinal regions

questions.text: Using a midline laparotomy method, a surgeon chooses to operate on a patient with cancer cecum and execute a right hemicolectomy. To prepare the patient's body parts for surgery, you have been given instructions. How will you proceed?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Clean and drape from the level of nipple to mid thigh.

  • For cancers located in the cecum and ascending colon, the procedure of choice is right hemicolectomy.
  • The procedure includes division of the ileocecal pedicle at its origin from the superior mesenteric vessels and division of the right colic vessels; the lymphatic tissue that surrounds the superior mesenteric vein can be removed en bloc in order to perform a complete lymph node dissection.
  • The right branch of the middle colic vessels is divided.
     
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1376.

questions.text: What use does Heller's myotomy serve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Achalasia cardia
 
  • Heller's myotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat achalasia cardia, a motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter.
  • During Heller's myotomy, the muscle fibers of the lower esophageal sphincter are cut to relieve the obstruction and improve esophageal emptying.
  1. This involves cutting the muscle of the lower esophagus and gastric cardia.
  2. Typically, anterior myotomy is performed for at least 6 cm proximally at the esophageal side and 2–3 cm distally into the gastric cardia.
  3. Transabdominal or transthoracic approaches have been advocated. Currently, the standard procedure is a laparoscopic approach. The major complication is GORD, which can occur in up to 40% of patients. The addition of a partial fundoplication (anterior Dor or posterior Toupet) has been shown to be effective in reducing the incidence of GORD.
  4. A complete 360° fundoplication (Nissen) is considered contraindicated because the increase in outflow resistance against an a peristaltic esophageal body will probably result in postoperative dysphagia. Laparoscopic myotomy is superior to single pneumatic dilatation in efficacy and durability.
  5. The surgical outcome is better in types I and II achalasia than in type III. For the latter, a longer extended proximal myotomy is often needed for adequate treatment.
* Achalasia cardia:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1123.

questions.text: A woman presented with only solid dysphagia that had not progressed. An esophageal barium examination revealed proximal dilatation and distal constriction. The following is the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Lower esophageal ring
 
  • Schatzki ring is a thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.
  • Most patients are asymptomatic, although intermittent dysphagia may occur when the ring diameter is quite narrow. The dysphagia is usually to solid foods only.
  • Diagnosis of a Schatzki's ring is made with a barium study.


Fig: Schatzki’s ring found on endoscopy. Note there is also esophagitis

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1147.

questions.text: A senior patient describes a protracted history of weakness and sluggishness. He is discovered to be anaemic upon examination, and occult blood has been detected in his stool. Which of the following should be the focus of your investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Colonoscopy 
 
  • Given the patient's age, and symptoms of weakness, sluggishness, anemia, and occult blood in the stool, the focus of the investigation should be a colonoscopy.
  • Colonoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing and evaluating various gastrointestinal conditions, including colorectal cancer, which can present with anemia and occult blood in the stool.
* Difference between Right and left sided Colon cancers:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 156.

choices.text: Small intestine and appendix account for almost 60% of all gastrointestinal carcinoid
5 year survival for carcinoid tumors is >60%
Appendiceal carcinoids are more common in females than males

questions.text: The following statement about Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Rectum is usually spared 
 
  • Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the small intestine, appendix, rectum, and other locations.
  • The statement is false because the rectum is not usually spared in gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors.
  • Rectal involvement can occur in carcinoid tumors, although the small intestine and appendix account for a higher percentage of these tumors.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 910.

questions.text: Complete rectal prolapse has been reported by a young male patient. The ideal procedure is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Abdominal rectopexy
 
  • Abdominal rectopexy is considered the ideal procedure for complete rectal prolapse.
  • Abdominal rectopexy involves securing the rectum to the sacrum, providing support and preventing further prolapse.
  • Delorme's procedure (option B) is a technique used for partial rectal prolapse.
  • Anterior resection (option C) is typically performed for conditions such as rectal cancer, not for rectal prolapse.
  • Goodsall's procedure (option D) refers to a technique used in the treatment of anal fistulas.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1400.

questions.text: Primary restrictive procedures for morbid obesity include all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Switch duodenal operations 
 
  • Primary restrictive procedures for morbid obesity include vertical band gastroplasty (option A), Roux-en-Y operation (option C), and laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding (option D).
  • Switch duodenal operations (option B), such as duodenal switch or biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch, are primarily malabsorptive procedures rather than restrictive procedures.
* Types of bariatric surgery:



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1189.

choices.text: Should be done by continuous layers as it takes less time
Should be Done by single layer serosal sutures
Should be done using single layer extramucosal technique

questions.text:
A 6-year-old kid who was in life-threatening shock had a CT scan that revealed significant ascites, thickening of the gut wall,
and poor or no enhancement of the strangulated bowel segment, which on surgical exploration revealed a gangrenous intestine.
What is accurate about anastomosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Should be done using single layer extra mucosal technique
 
  • When performing an anastomosis for a gangrenous intestine, it is important to ensure a secure and watertight connection.
  • The preferred technique is to perform a single-layer anastomosis taking the submucosa.
  • This technique allows for proper alignment of the intestinal layers, ensuring adequate blood supply and reducing the risk of complications.
  • Additionally, using absorbable sutures made of materials like polyglactin or polydioxanone is commonly preferred over catgut (option C), as these materials provide better tensile strength and reduce the risk of suture-related complications.
  • Continuous layers (option A) are not necessary and can be time-consuming, while using absorbable sutures like catgut (option B) is not ideal for an anastomosis.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1306.

questions.text: Which among the following investigations will help in arriving at a definitive diagnosis of carcinoma of pancreatic head?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Guided biopsy
 
  • Guided biopsy techniques, such as endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) or percutaneous biopsy, provide tissue samples for histopathological examination.
  • These techniques allow for direct sampling of the pancreatic tissue, providing a definitive diagnosis of carcinoma of the pancreatic head.
  • Histopathological examination helps in assessing the tumor type, grade, and stage, which is crucial for planning appropriate treatment strategies.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1282.

questions.text: Mention the diagnosis of the following Barium X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. CA esophagus
 
  • The barium swallow has shown an irregular filling defect and narrowing with shouldered margins which may indicate the presence of either squamous cell carcinoma in the upper two-thirds of the esophagus, or adenocarcinoma in the lower third.
  • A further upper GI endoscopy and biopsy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. If found to be suitable for potentially curative therapies, staging investigations should be done to ensure that the cancer has not spread to other parts of the body (CT scan).
