  • If the cancer is localized, further staging tests should be performed to assess the loco-regional stage (endoscopic ultrasonography, endoscopic ultrasound +/- laparoscopy). These tests will allow for appropriate treatment planning and management of the cancer.
  • In Achalasia cardia- Bird's beak deformity is seen. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1136.

questions.text: Pick the Hinchey's stage for a patient with peritonitis and during surgery diverticular perforation is seen with purulent contamination.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3. 3.

Hinchey classification is a system used to classify the severity of patients with peritonitis.
Peritonitis is an inflammation of the peritoneum, a membrane that lines the inner wall of the abdomen and covers the abdominal organs.

The Hinchey classification is divided into four stages (I-IV), with each stage representing a varying degree of peritonitis severity.
  • Stage I: This stage is the least severe and includes patients with localized peritonitis and mild abdominal pain. Symptoms may also include tenderness, rebound tenderness and guarding.
  • Stage II: This stage includes patients with diffuse peritonitis and more severe abdominal pain. In addition, there may be systemic signs of infection such as fever and tachycardia.
  • Stage III: This stage includes patients with diffuse peritonitis and more severe systemic signs of infection, such as hypotension and hypothermia. Patients may also have abdominal distension, widespread ileus (restricted peristalsis of the intestine), and abscesses.
  • Stage IV: This is the most severe stage characterized by  generalized fecal peritonitis, and includes patients with peritonitis-related organ failure. Organs may include the heart, lungs, kidneys and/or liver. In addition, these patients may have multi-organ dysfunction, sepsis, and require a high level of supportive care.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1368.

questions.text: A 44 year old man presented to OPD with complaints of dysphagia to both solid and liquids. Esophageal manometry was performed and it showed an abnormally elevated lower esophageal pressure of > 450 mm along with premature contractions with > 20% of swallows? What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Type 3 achalasia

Achalasia is a type of esophageal motility disorder that is characterized by a failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax, resulting in difficulty swallowing.

* According to Chicago classification: 

Type I achalasia (classic)
Median IRP >15 mm Hg, 100% failed peristalsis (DCI <100 mm Hg-s-cm); premature contractions with DCI <450 mm Hg-s•cm satisfy criteria for failed peristalsis

Type Il achalasia (with esophageal compression) -Median IRP >15 mm Hg; 100% failed peristalsis, panesophageal pressurization with ≥20% of swallows

Type Ill achalasia (spastic achalasia) - Median IRP >15 mm Hg; no normal peristalsis, spastic contractions with DCI >450 mm Hg-s•cm with ≥20% of swallows

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1122.

questions.text: After a large meal, a middle-aged guy complains of upper stomach ache. There is discomfort in the upper abdomen, and an X-ray reveals pneumomediastinum and a widening of the mediastinum. Name the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. spontaneous perforation of the esophagus
 
  • Boerhaave's Syndrome is an acute and potentially life-threatening condition caused by spontaneous perforation of the esophagus.
  • It usually occurs after a bout of vomiting against a closed glottis, causing a rapid increase in pressure within the esophagus, leading to rupture at its weakest point.
  • Symptoms include severe pain in the chest or upper abdomen, shortness of breath and may be accompanied by air in the mediastinum, pleura or peritoneum.
  • Chest X-ray and contrast swallow or CT are required for management and treatment is generally supportive.
  • Barotrauma can also be caused by other events such as defecation, labour and weight-lifting.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1127.

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented to ED with complaints of abdominal colic and features of obstructive jaundice. His WBC counts and liver enzymes were elevated. Ultrasound revealed a scleroatrophic gallbladder with impacted stones in CBD and IHBR dilatation. What is the most appropriate next step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3. MRCP

The above scenario is a case of Obstructive Jaundice/Surgical Jaundice - Elevated LFT, with a rise in Alkaline phosphatase and an enlarged CBD on radiology.
  • The standard treatment for this type of situation is an Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatogram (ERCP) to cut the sphincterotomy and the retrieval of stones in the common bile duct (CBD).
  • After the procedure, a stent can be placed to alleviate the obstruction, followed by a laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
  • Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatogram (MRCP) is a very sensitive and specific diagnostic study that can be used to detect hepatobiliary pathologies.
  • CT scan- Not well suited for detecting uncomplicated stones but excellent for detecting complications such as abscess, perforation of gallbladder or BD, and pancreatitis, Spiral CT may prove useful as a noninvasive means of excluding BD stones; some studies suggest improved diagnostic accuracy when CT is combined with an oral cholecystographic contrast agent.
     
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1196.

questions.text: The patient underwent LSCS. Following surgery, the patient experienced constipation, abdominal distention with a soft and silent bowel. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Paralytic Ileus

Paralytic ileus occurs from prolonged hypomotility of the gastrointestinal tract secondary to inflammation of intestinal smooth muscle.
  • Ileus, also known as paralytic ileus or functional ileus, occurs when there is a non-mechanical decrease or stoppage of the flow of intestinal contents.
  • Ileus is an often unavoidable consequence of abdominal or retroperitoneal surgery, but can also be found in severely ill patients with septic shock or mechanical ventilation.
  • Moderate to severe cases have been documented in 10-20% of post-cesarean patients. Paralytic ileus refers to abdominal distension, intolerance of oral intake and an inability to pass flatus persisting for more than 3 - 5 days postoperatively.
  • Examination typically reveals a hyper-resonant and distended abdomen, generalized tenderness and reduced to absent bowel sounds.
 Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 325.

questions.text: Which cancer  is likely to present with inguinal lymph node enlargement?
questions.solution:
The inguinal lymph nodes primarily drain the lower limb, perineum, external genitalia (penis or vagina), anal canal (below the pectinate line), and lower abdominal wall. Penile cancer on metastasis will drain into superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes.

Other options
  • Colorectal cancer drains into mesenteric and iliac lymph nodes.
  • Prostate cancer drains into internal iliac and obturator lymph nodes.
  • Testicular cancer drains into para-aortic (retroperitoneal) lymph nodes.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1444.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is admitted with intussusception and stomach pain. Intestinal polyps were discovered during the endoscopy. Below is a histopathological image from a biopsy that was collected. What kind of polyp is that
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Hamartomatous
 
  • The most common type of polyp in children is a hamartoma or juvenile polyp accounting for more than 95% of polyps found.
  • Juvenile polyps are typically found in 2 to 6 year old boys and girls but can be found in younger and older children up to about 10 years of age.
  • Hammartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract are rare compared to other types of GI polyps, yet they are the most common type of polyp in children.
  • The symptoms are usually rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, obstipation, anaemia, and/or small bowel obstruction.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1310.

questions.text: An abdominal ache had been present for several days in a 45-year-old patient with known peptic ulcer disease. He has been complaining of abdominal distension and escalating pain for the past two hours. This image was obtained using an X-ray. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. IV fluids and emergency laparotomy
 
  • The given history along with the presence of air under the diaphragm as seen in the X-Ray are suggestive of perforation causing pneumoperitoneum which might have occurred as a complication of peptic ulcer causing perforation in the gastric wall.
  • The next step in management should be iv fluids and emergency laparotomy.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 137.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who is having increasing trouble swallowing both food and liquids is put through a barium study. The image is seen here. What is the next stage in the patient's care?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  is 1. Upper G.I Endoscopy + Manometry

Taking into consideration the age, symptoms, history and the X-ray which shows Bird-Beak appearance, the most probable diagnosis is Achalasia Cardia.

It is characterized by failure of organized esophageal peristalsis, which results in food stasis and frequently noticeable esophageal dilatation and poor relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter due to damage to the Auerbach plexus and vagus nerve. 

To look for constrictions and other causes of Achalasia cardia plus for confirming the diagnosis, we do upper GI endoscopy with Manometry (which shows pressure at the level of Gastro-esophageal junction).

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1122.

choices.text: Mass is mobile perpendicular to mesentery attachment line
Mass is felt in the periumbilical region
Transverse band of resonance is felt on percussion

questions.text: Which statement regarding the Tillaux sign is correct
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Mass is mobile perpendicular to mesentery attachment line

The Tillaux triad is :
  • a. Periumbilical lump
  • b. Mass moves along perpendicular to attachment of mesentery- Tillaux sign
  • c. Transverse band of resonance is felt on percussion.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1560.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old IHD patient presents with abrupt, severe, generalised stomach discomfort and frequent vomiting attacks.
His heartbeat is 118 bpm, his rhythm is abnormally erratic, and his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Bowel noises are not present, and the abdomen appears mushy. In this situation, which of the following could be a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3. Acute mesenteric ischemia

Acute mesenteric ischemia is a potential diagnosis when the rhythm is erratic, the belly is soft (guarding is not seen in this picture), and vomiting episodes are frequent.
 
  • Acute pancreatitis -> No features suggestive of pancreatitis. No history of pain abdomen radiating to back.
  • Ruptured aortic aneurysm -> Pulsation abdominal lump as a feature not present
  • Peptic ulcer perforation ->No history suggestive of Peritonitis or history of analgesic intake or guarding and rigidity
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 928.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true when a child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
A. Bilious vomiting
B. Visible peristalsis
C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia
D. Palpable abdominal mass
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4. B, C & Dâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹

Metabolic abnormality with palpable abdominal mass, visible peristalsis from left to right is seen in hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Clinical features of pyloric stenosis
  • Seen during the third and sixth weeks of life.
  • Forceful, projectile, and non-bilious vomiting
  • Presence of visible gastric peristalsis (VGP) from left to rifgt
  • Palpable lump of hypertrophied pylorus- from the left side, a movable, smooth, firm, olive-like mass with all borders well defined, moves with respiration, and has poor resonance on percussion.
  • Constipation
  • Dehydration and weight loss
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and electrolyte imbalance.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 259.

questions.text:
In order to stop esophageal varicose haemorrhage, which of the following is used?
A.
B.
C.
D.
questions.solution:
The given tubes are :
  • Sengstaken Blakemore Tube
  • Minnesota Tube
  • OGD Scope
  • Gastro Fiber Endoscope
All of the above are used for controlling variceal bleed.
Sengstaken blake more tube has 2 ballons and 3 channels 1 for gastric aspiration &other for for inflating balloons, Minnesota has 4 channels one for gastric and esophageal aspiration, through scope we can ligate the vessel and stop the bleeding.


Fig: Oesophageal and gastric balloon tamponade with a Sengstaken–Blakemore or Minnesota tube.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1205.

questions.text:
Which of the following symptoms is present in a child who has hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
i. Non-bilious vomiting
ii. Visible peristalsis from Left to Right in Abdomen
iii. Palpable mass in abdomen
iv. Hypochlorimia, Hypokalemia,Metabolic acidosis
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. i, ii, iii

All of the following can be seen in cases of Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Clinical features of pyloric stenosis-
  • Seen during the third and sixth weeks of life.
  • Forceful, projectile, and non-bilious vomiting
  • Presence of visible gastric peristalsis (VGP) from left to right 
  • Palpable lump of hypertrophied pylorus- from the left side, a movable, smooth, firm, olive-like mass with all borders well defined, moves with respiration, and has poor resonance on percussion.
  • Constipation
  • Dehydration and weight loss
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and electrolyte imbalance.
 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 259.

questions.text:
A lap cholecystectomy was being performed on an obese ASA-2 patient. His ETCO2, spO2, blood pressure, and peak airway pressure all unexpectedly plummeted to 8mm Hg, 90%, and 80/50mm Hg, respectively. What might be the potential reason?
(i) CO2 embolism
(ii) Severe bronchospasm
(iii) Endobronchial intubation
(iv) Pneumothorax
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4. i only

The given clinical history gives evidence of hypoxemia, hypotension, sudden drop in EtCO2 with normal peak airway pressure which is suggestive of CO2 embolism.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 108.

questions.text:
Which statement concerning colon cancer is correct?
(i) Metformin reduces the risk of Colon Cancer
(ii) Right and Left Colon cancers have different clinical presentation
(iii) Colon cancers frequently metastasise to liver
(iv) Colon cancers can be hereditary
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. i, ii, iii, iv
 
  • Colon cancer is the cancer of the Large intestine & Rectum. They may be hereditary in form of syndromes like peutz-jegher or cowden syndrome. Clinical features depend on the site of cancer and are different in left and right sided cancer.
  • MC site of distant metastasis : Liver.
  • MC death in colon cancer : Liver Mets.
  • Metformin is beneficial in reducing the risk of colon cancer.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1360.

questions.text:
A gridiron incision was initially made on a patient who had undergone appendicectomy; this was later changed to a Rutherford Morrison incision. What structures are eliminated during this conversion?
(i) External oblique
(ii) Internal oblique
(iii) Transversus abdominis
(iv) Rectus abdominis
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1.  i, ii, iii

Gridiron incision : A muscle splitting incision involving external oblique and internal oblique. 

Rutherford Morrison Incision : It is a muscle cutting incision that cuts through external oblique, internal oblique and transverse abdominis.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1306.

questions.text: A 56 year old female who underwent open hysterectomy two years back presented with abdominal pain, vomiting and obstipation. Increased bowel sounds could be heard on auscultation. On erect abdominal Xray, air in the biliary tree along with dilated bowel loops were visible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Gallstone ileus

Small bowel obstruction, a gallstone outside the gallbladder, and air in the bile ducts make up the Rigler's triad.
 
  • An rare reason for a mechanical small intestinal obstruction is gallstone ileus.
  • A gallstone can get impacted at the ileocecal valve by passing via a fistula between the small intestine and gallbladder, which is an uncommon consequence of chronic cholecystitis.
  • The buildup of gas in the biliary tree is referred to as pneumobilia or aerobilia.
  • It's critical to distinguish between pneumobilia and the other branching hepatic gas type, portal venous gas.
  • There are numerous causes of pneumobilia, and the clinical setting is frequently crucial for separating them.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1247.

questions.text: Which surgery is depicted in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Thiersch wiring

The Thiersch surgery (anal encirclement) is usually carried out on individuals who are elderly or who are at high risk for rectal prolapse.
It is a straightforward operation that narrows the Anus using a suture or prosthetic.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1399.

choices.text: Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection is seen

questions.text: The image depicts a male patient. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection is seen
 
  • This is a case of Necrotizing fasciitis which involves the perineal region.
  • Synergistic gangrene (aerobic + anaerobic) is seen
  • Testes are not involved in this condition due to the presence of dual blood supply.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1416.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with severe stomach pain and distension arrives at the emergency room.
In the epigastric region, there is a fluid-filled lesion. Which of the following investigation may not be useful?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: GGT
 
  • GGT (gamma-glutamyl transferase) is an enzyme primarily associated with liver function and bile duct pathology.
  • It is not typically used as an investigation for evaluating a fluid-filled lesion in the epigastric region, probably a pancreatic cyst.
  • Other investigations, such as imaging studies (ultrasound, CT scan), may be more appropriate to determine the cause of the symptoms.
  • GGT levels may be elevated in liver diseases, but it is not specific to this particular clinical presentation.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1194.

questions.text: A patient has been exhibiting signs/symptoms of a gastric outlet obstruction. He has several liver mets in the right lobe of his liver, as well as a tumour that has invaded his stomach, pancreas, and duodenum. What is the best course of action for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Palliative gastro jejunostomy is often used to bypass a gastric outlet obstruction and improve symptoms, especially when the obstruction is caused by a locally advanced malignancy.
It would offer symptomatic relief for the patient, helping with the obstruction and improving their ability to eat and digest food
About 15% of the time, the duodenum is blocked.
If this happens early in the disease's progression, a gastrojejunostomy is performed as a surgical bypass.
Rest of the procedures are radical given the advanced stage of the disease, a palliative procedure would be the best option.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1161.

choices.text: Absent Bowel sounds with normal passage of flatus

questions.text: What trait characterises a large bowel obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. Dilated large Bowel with haustrations.

A key feature of large bowel obstruction is dilated large bowel with haustrations.
Dilated large bowel with incomplete haustrations is seen in large bowel obstruction while complete valvulae are seen in jejunal obstruction.
 
* Differences between small bowel and large bowel obstruction can be made based on the following features: 

 

 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1381.

choices.text: Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by second part of duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment
Superior mesenteric artery has a normal angle between 38-65 degree in relation to duodenum
Strong's procedure is corrective surgery in which ligament of Treitz divided.
Superior mesenteric artery syndrome is characterized by an angle less than 25 degree due to loss of intervening mesenteric pad of fat

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about superior mesenteric artery syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by second part of duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment


Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome: It is a cause of UGI obstruction from the compression of the third portion of the duodenum between the aorta and SMA leading to duodenal obstruction. It is seen in patients with sudden weight loss like in celebrities, AIDS, metastasis. 


Fig: Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome. 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1257.

questions.text: Resection of which of the following segment would result in vitamin B12 absorption defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Ileum
 
  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the distal part of the small intestine, specifically the terminal ileum.
  • Resection or removal of the terminal ileum, such as in cases of Crohn's disease or surgical resection, can lead to impaired absorption of vitamin B12.
  • This can result in vitamin B12 deficiency and subsequent manifestations, such as megaloblastic anemia and neurological complications.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1316.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels has the lowest risk of suffering a serious injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option Is 3. Inferior mesenteric artery
 
  • Injury to inferior mesenteric artery is least likely to result in significant damage among the given options.
  • Occlusion of the inferior mesenteric artery does not always result in irreversible ischemia of the descending and sigmoid colon, because the marginal artery of the colon usually receives an adequate supply from the left branch of the middle colic artery.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1375.

questions.text: What is the most common postoperative complication of ileoanal pouch anastomosis in ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 1. Pouchitis

Most common post-operative complication of ileoanal pouch anastomosis in ulcerative colitis is pouchitis.
Inflammation of the mucosa of the ileal pouch, or pouchitis, occurs in 7-33% of patients with UC treated by IPAA.( ileal pouch-anal anastomosis).
The cause is unknown but may be related to bacterial overgrowth, mucosa, ischemia, or other local factors.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1324.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ultrasound feature of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. High gastric residue

Ultrasonography is the investigation of choice to confirm diagnose of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis with accuracy> 95% (approaching almost 100%).
USG visualizes thickened and elongated pyloric canal.
USG criteria for diagnosis include >16 mm pyloric length and > 4 mm pyloric muscle wall thickness. Gastric residues are low because of recurrent emesis.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 259.

questions.text: What is the preferred investigation for the diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Barium swallow

Investigation of choice for diagnosis of Zenker’s diverticulum is barium swallow.
It is a mucosal outpouching (pulsion diverticulum) occurring through the triangular bare area (Kilian's triangle) between the upper oblique fibers (thyropharyngeus muscle) and lower horizontal fibers (cricopharyngeus muscle) of the inferior constrictor muscle.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1126.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of acute anal pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Fistula in ano
 
  • Fistula in ano is not a cause of acute anal pain.
  • These patients do not cause acute anal pain.
  • Instead patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain.
  • Rest all other options given cause pain 
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1408.

questions.text: A tumor was detected on histopathological examination of a child who underwent resection and anastomosis for an insusceptible small intestinal mass. Which among the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 3. Lymphoma

Most likely tumor associated is lymphoma
M/c tumor of small bowel in children is lymphoma and it can lead to intussusception.

Carcinoid tumors generally present with more chronic symptoms, like diarrhea, flushing, and, in rare cases, carcinoid syndrome.
Villous adenomas are rare in children and typically affect the colon rather than the small intestine.
Sarcomas can also affect the small intestine, but they are less common than lymphoma in pediatric patients. They may present as a mass, and while they can be aggressive, lymphoma is still the more common diagnosis in this clinical context.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 260.

choices.text: Absence of air fluid level in straight X-ray rules out any obstruction
Volvulus and mesenteric ischemia has a specific feature
Proximal bowel diameter > 5 cm and distal bowel diameter > 9 cm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the radiological features of the intestinal obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Proximal bowel diameter > 5 cm and distal bowel diameter > 9 cm

All are true about radiological features of the intestinal obstruction except:
d) proximal bowel diameter > 5cm and distal bowel diameter > 9cm

The cut-off diameter for obstruction in the proximal (small intestine) and distal (large intestine) bowels is 3 cm (not 5 cm) and 6cm (not 9 cm) respectively.

Mesenteric ischemia has thumb print sign. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1377.

questions.text: Which of the following describes an indirect appendicitis indication on a USG?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Mesenteric lymphadenopathy
 
  • Indirect findings on ultrasound (USG) can sometimes suggest the presence of appendicitis.
  • Mesenteric lymphadenopathy, or enlargement of lymph nodes in the mesentery near the appendix, can be observed on USG and may indicate an inflammatory process in the appendix.
  • Other direct findings, such as increased wall thickness or an appendicolith, are more specific for diagnosing appendicitis.
  • Ultrasound findings of acute appendicits:
    • Non-compressible, dilated appendix
    • Thickened appendix wall
    • Presence of appendicolith (fecalith)
    • Peri-appendiceal fluid collection
    • Hypoechoic (dark) appearance of the appendix
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 88.

choices.text: Patey's surgery is done for the treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with a slowly expanding, painless swelling above the mandibular angle. Swelling moves about and has variable consistency. Regarding the swelling, all of the following are accurate, except :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Has uniphasic cellular pattern
 
  • The given clinical scenario and image depict a likely case of parotid tumor (option A), likely to be a pleomorphic adenoma.
  • The parotid tail is the most common site (Option B) for parotid gland tumors to occur. It is the portion of the parotid gland that extends backward and wraps around the mandible.
  • However, the swelling in this case does not exhibit a uniphasic cellular pattern.
  • A uniphasic cellular pattern refers to the appearance of cells in the tumor, and it is not observed in this scenario.
  • Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation) (option C).
  • Radiotherapy is considered in high-grade malignancies demonstrating extra-glandular disease, perineural invasion, direct invasion of surrounding tissue, or regional metastases.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: How does one classify gall bladder carcinoma extending to the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: T3
 
  • The correct classification for gall bladder carcinoma extending to the liver is T3. T3 indicates that the tumor has invaded nearby structures, such as the liver or any other extrahepatic organ.
  • T1 indicates a small tumor confined to the gall bladder without invasion into surrounding structures.
  • T2 classification indicates involvement of the serosa, which is the outermost layer of the gall bladder.
  • T4 classification indicates invasion into adjacent structures beyond the liver.

* Gall bladder TNM staging:



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1517.

choices.text: Distorted folds reach up to the edge of ulcer

questions.text: Which of the following does not distinguishes between benign and malignant gastric ulcers?
questions.solution:
Correct option 4:Presence on lesser curvature
 
  • Option 1 is correct because it describes a characteristic feature of malignant gastric ulcers. Malignant gastric ulcers are more likely to have irregular, distorted folds that extend up to the edge of the ulcer. This is because the cancerous cells in the ulcer disrupt the normal architecture of the stomach lining. In contrast, benign ulcers usually have smooth, regular folds around the edges of the ulcer.
  • Option 2, Carman's meniscus sign is seen in malignant gastric ulcers
  • Option 3, Kirklin complex is a radiological feature seen in malignant gastric ulcers.  Malignant gastric ulcers are more commonly present at the greater curvature of the stomach and show a presence of kirklin complex with a positive carmen meniscus sign.
    The Kirklin complex is a combination of the Carman meniscus sign associated with a radiolucent semicircular zone surrounding the elevated ridge of the ulcer.
  • This complex is seen in cases of gastric adenocarcinoma on barium studies.
    The Carman meniscus sign describes the lenticular shape of barium in cases of large and flat gastric ulcers, in which the inner margin is convex toward the lumen. It usually indicates a malignant ulcerated neoplasm.
  • Option 4, presence on lesser curvature, is not specific to either benign or malignant gastric ulcers and does not distinguish between the two.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1165.

questions.text: Which of the following is represented by the colon's appearance on the barium study, as seen in the illustration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ulcerative colitis
 
  • The barium enema shows the lead pipe appearance seen in ulcerative colitis.
  • Ulcerative colitis diffusely involves the mucosa and submucosa of the colon.
  • There is a complete loss of haustral markings in the diseased section of the colon, and the organ appears smooth-walled and cylindrical; giving it the appearance of a lead pipe.

* Barium Enema Appearance: 


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1163.

questions.text: What is the most common location for splenunculi?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hilum of spleen
 
  • Splenunculi, also known as accessory spleens, are most commonly found in the hilum of the spleen. The hilum is the area where blood vessels enter and exit the spleen.
  • Splenunculi can occasionally be found in other locations, such as the greater omentum, but the hilum of the spleen is the most frequent site.
  • Other locations:
      • Splenic Hilum
      • Tail of the Pancreas
      • Gastrosplenic Ligaments
      • Lienorenal Ligaments
      • Wall of the Stomach
      • Wall of the Intestines
      • Greater Omentum
      • Mesentery
      • Pelvis or Scrotum (rarely observed)
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1221.

questions.text: Which office-based treatment for internal hemorrhoids has the lowest recurrence rates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Rubber band ligation (RBL)
 
  • Rubber band ligation (RBL) is the office-based treatment for internal hemorrhoids with the lowest recurrence rates.
  • RBL involves placing a rubber band around the base of the hemorrhoid, cutting off its blood supply, and causing it to shrink and fall off within a few days.
  • Injection sclerotherapy, another office-based treatment option, involves injecting a sclerosing agent into the hemorrhoid to shrink it. It may have a higher recurrence rate compared to RBL.
  • Photocoagulation and electrocoagulation use heat to destroy the hemorrhoidal tissue. They may be effective in some cases but may have higher recurrence rates compared to RBL.
* Grades of Hemorrhoids:


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1431.

questions.text: Which among the following surgeries would be performed in a case of rectal cancer which is within 5 cm from the anal verge
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Abdominal perineal resection
 
  • Abdominoperineal resection (APR) is the surgery performed for rectal cancer within 5 cm from the anal verge.
  • Abdominoperineal resection is the complete excision of the rectum, anal canal, and sphincter apparatus.
  • This is done with the creation of a permanent colostomy. This is commonly preferred in elderly patients with distal rectal cancer with poor sphincter function.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1413.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely symptom of High Small Bowel Obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Distension
 
  • Distension is the least likely symptom of high small bowel obstruction.
  • High small bowel obstruction refers to a blockage in the upper part of the small intestine.
  • Common symptoms of high small bowel obstruction include pain, vomiting, abdominal distension, dehydration  and obstipation.
  • Distension is more commonly associated with lower bowel obstruction, where the blockage occurs in the large intestine.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1381.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about delayed or late dumping syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Diarrhea
 
  • Delayed or late dumping syndrome is a condition that occurs after a meal, typically 2-3 hours later, in individuals who have undergone gastric surgery, such as gastric bypass or gastrectomy.
  • The symptoms can include reactive hypoglycemia (sudden drop in blood sugar levels after a meal, causing symptoms like weakness, sweating, and palpitations), vasomotor symptoms (such as flushing, palpitations, and sweating), and gastrointestinal symptoms such as bloating, nausea, and abdominal discomfort.


Management of dumping syndrome-
1. Frequent little meals
2. low glycemic index meals
3. Octreotide in resistant cases

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1163.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis if  a thirty year old male presents to the Emergency Department with symptoms of epigastric pain radiating to back that wakes him up at night and is relieved by consuming food. He gives history of similar pain in the past which was diagnosed as perforated duodenal ulcer and treated with omental patch surgery on two occasions. Pain before and after surgery has been controlled with proton pump inhibitors and analgesics.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Duodenal Ulcer 
 
  • The patient's symptoms of epigastric pain that radiates to the back, worsens at night, and is relieved by consuming food suggest a duodenal ulcer.
  • The history of previous perforated duodenal ulcer and omental patch surgery supports the diagnosis of duodenal ulcer.
  • Duodenal ulcers are commonly caused by Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use.
  • The characteristic pain associated with duodenal ulcers occurs when the stomach is empty, such as between meals or during the night.
  • Eating food helps neutralize gastric acid and temporarily relieves the pain.
  • The successful control of pain with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and analgesics further supports the diagnosis of duodenal ulcer.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1157.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histological subtype
Occult blood in stool is not seen

questions.text: All of the following statements about Gastric carcinoma are false except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Often associated with Hypochlorhydria/Achlorhydria 
 
  • Gastric carcinoma is often associated with hypochlorhydria (reduced stomach acid production) or achlorhydria (absence of stomach acid production).
  • This can be due to chronic inflammation or atrophy of the gastric mucosa.
  • The decrease in acid production can be detected through diagnostic tests such as gastric pH measurement or serum gastrin levels.
Other options:
  • The most common histological subtype is adenocarcinoma, which accounts for the majority of gastric cancer cases.
  • Occult blood in the stool can be a sign of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can occur in gastric carcinoma.
  • Gastric carcinoma is not highly radiosensitive.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1219.

choices.text: Typically presents between postoperative day 3 and day 5
Suture length should be 4 times of wound length
High incidence if Catgut is used for closure

questions.text: Which of the following statements about "Burst Abdomen" is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Typically presents between postoperative day 3 and day 5
 
  • Burst abdomen is the mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound associated with abdominal content evisceration.
  • It commonly occurs within the first few days after surgery, usually between postoperative day 5 and day 8.
  • Other factors such as wound tension, inadequate suturing technique, or compromised tissue healing can contribute to the development of Burst Abdomen.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 732.

questions.text: What is most frequently related with the obturator sign in acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pelvic Appendix
 
  • The obturator sign is a clinical finding in which the patient experiences pain upon internal rotation of the flexed right hip. It is suggestive of inflammation in the region of the obturator muscle.
  • The pelvic appendix, which is located in the pelvis near the obturator muscle, is most frequently associated with the obturator sign.
  • The proximity of the pelvic appendix to the obturator muscle can cause irritation and inflammation, leading to the positive obturator sign.
* Signs seen in acute appendicitis:



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1332.

questions.text: What is the recommended course of action for a 0.5 mm carcinoid tumour at the appendix's tip?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Appendectomy
 
  • The recommended course of action for a 0.5 mm carcinoid tumor at the tip of the appendix is appendectomy.
  • The small size of the tumor and its location at the tip of the appendix suggest a low risk of metastasis or invasion into surrounding tissues.
  • Therefore, a less extensive procedure such as appendectomy is sufficient to remove the tumor and prevent any potential complications. 
Other options:
  • Right hemicolectomy, colectomy, and hepatic wedge resection are more extensive procedures and are typically reserved for larger or more advanced tumors that have invaded nearby structures or have a higher risk of metastasis.
Guideline for Appendicular Carcinoid- 
  • Tumor < 2 cm and >2cm from base- Appendectomy
  • Tumor>2cm and <2cm from base- Right Hemicolectomy 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1344.

questions.text: What is the cut-off for severe acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: APACHE II Score > 8

The cut-off for severe acute pancreatitis is an APACHE II score greater than 8.
  • The APACHE II (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II) score is a widely used scoring system to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis.
  • It takes into account several physiological parameters such as vital signs, laboratory values, and age to determine the severity of the condition.
  • A score greater than 8 indicates a higher likelihood of severe pancreatitis, which is associated with increased morbidity and mortality.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 295.

questions.text: A midline painful fluctuant lump between the gluteal folds is found in a young guy. A rectal examination is painless. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pilonidal abscess
 
  • The most likely diagnosis for a midline painful fluctuant lump between the gluteal folds in a young guy is a pilonidal abscess.
  • Pilonidal abscess is a common condition characterized by the formation of an abscess or cyst in the natal cleft (the area between the buttocks).
  • It typically occurs in young individuals and is more common in males.
  • The abscess is often painful and may be associated with redness, swelling, and fluctuance.
  • Unlike perianal and perirectal abscesses, which are usually located near the anus, a pilonidal abscess is typically found in the midline between the gluteal folds.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1423.

questions.text: An 8 months old male child presented with sudden onset of abdominal pain with distension and vomiting. Per abdomen examination revealed a mass in right lumbar region. Attending surgeon ordered for Barium enema, which is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given image shows classical claw sign/ coiled spring sign on barium enema. 
  • It is seen in resolving intussusception. 





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 129.

Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1863, 1864.

questions.text: Amongst the following which is the most common site of intra-abdominal abscess:
questions.solution:
• Area marked as (1) represents the right sub-hepatic space which is the most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess. 
  • CT with intravenous contrast is the imaging method of choice for intra abdominal abscess. 
 
  • The right subhepatic space is a deep cavity located in Rutherford Morison's pouch.
  • It lies beneath the liver and above the transverse colon and hepatic flexure.

The boundaries of the right subhepatic space include:
  • the right lobe of the liver and diaphragm on the right side,
  • the foramen of Winslow on the left, the duodenum below,
  • the liver and gall bladder in the front, and
  • the right kidney and diaphragm at the back.

Abscesses in this area typically result from conditions like appendicitis, cholecystitis, perforated duodenal ulcers, or complications from upper abdominal surgeries. Intraperitoneal abscesses can also form due to intraperitoneal infections in specific abdominal sites (intra-abdominal abscess) or the pelvis (pelvic abscess). These abscesses may develop in subphrenic spaces or subhepatic spaces, on either the right or left side.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1055-1057.

questions.text: A young adult male presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of recurrent perianal openings over the buttock region. There is history of seropurulent discharge through those openings. Clinical picture of the patient is given below. Most likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of recurrent pain and discharge through perianal openings goes in favor of fistula-in-ano. 
 
  • Goodsall's rule is used to determine the location of the internal opening of the fistula. Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening with a short radial tract.
  • Fistulas with external opening located posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.
  • Exception- Fistulas with anterior external opening grater than 3 cm from the anal margin track to posterior midline. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1363-1367.

Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1408-1410.

questions.text: A young male presented with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. He was sweating and have tachycardia. Per-abdominal examination revealed a tender and rigid abdomen. Attending surgeon ordered a plain X-ray abdomen in erect posture, which is shown below. What is the best way to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given X-ray is a erect chest radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm.
  • It is indicative of hollow viscus perforation. 
  • The next best step in management among the given options is Resuscitation (with intravenous fluids) followed by emergency laparotomy. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1048, 1050-1052.

questions.text: Identify the focal lesion on NCCT Abdomen:
questions.solution:
Hydatid cyst as Calcification seen only in hydatid cyst in later stages.( Ring like).

Radiological Classification of Hydatid disease:








Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1460.

Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 613, 616, 628.

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic, right branch of middle colic artery
Ileocolic, right colic, trunk of middle colic artery

questions.text: A 32 year old female diagnosed with tumor in proximal Transverse colon. What are the vessels ligated while doing extended right Hemicolectomy?
questions.solution:
In extended right hemicolectomy : Terminal Ileum, Caecum, Ascending colon, Hepatic flexure and  proximal 2/3rd of Transverse colon are removed.
  • Vessels Removed : lleocolic , Right Colic and Middle colic artery at its base.





Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1377.

questions.text: After appendectomy, exploration was done for bleeding, ligation of which artery is beneficial?
questions.solution:
• In an appendectomy, bleeding typically arises from vessels supplying the appendix. The appendicular artery, a branch of the ileocolic artery (which itself is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery), is the primary blood supply to the appendix.
 
  • If there is significant bleeding post-appendectomy, ligation of the ileocolic artery would be beneficial as it controls blood flow to the appendicular artery and the surrounding region.

Arterial supply of Appendix:
 




Other options:

  1. Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA):
    Ligation of the SMA would lead to catastrophic ischemia of large portions of the intestine. It is not specific to the appendix.

  2. Right Colic Artery:
    The right colic artery supplies the ascending colon, not the appendix directly. Ligation would not effectively control bleeding from the appendicular region.

  3. Middle Colic Artery:
    The middle colic artery supplies the transverse colon and is unrelated to the appendicular vasculature.




Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1300, 1301.

choices.text: Small Bowel obstruction due to Bowel perforation

questions.text: In the given below X-ray obstruction is seen in which of the following part?
questions.solution:
Image shows a typical coffee bean sign seen in sigmoid volvulus.


Imaging findings of Sigmoid volvulus:
 
  • Abdominal X-ray:
    • Coffee bean sign (dilated, twisted sigmoid colon).
 
  • CT scan:
    • Whirl sign (twisted mesenteric vessels).
    • Determines ischemia or perforation.
 
  • Barium enema (rarely used):
    • Bird’s beak appearance at the point of torsion.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 464, 468, 472, 473, 544, 545.

questions.text: What is the least useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis in a patient with the following condition as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bird beak appearance suggestive of achalasia.
24-hour pH monitoring is an investigation used to detect gastroesophageal reflux, post achalasia cardia treatment- not for diagnosis of achalasia.

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1121 .

questions.text: A patient came with a complaint of a mass in the right hypochondrium and severe itching and jaundice which was waxing and waning. He also had a history of 2 episodes of black stools. Surgery was done as shown in the image. Which among the following condition was operated here?
questions.solution:
• The most likely condition operated in this case is periampullary carcinoma. The location of the mass in the right hypochondrium, along with symptoms such as severe itching, jaundice (waxing and waning), and episodes of black stools, are suggestive of a periampullary tumor.
  • The term "periampullary carcinoma" refers to tumors that arise in the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater, which is where the common bile duct and pancreatic duct join and empty into the small intestine. Periampullary carcinomas can include tumors arising from the ampulla of Vater itself, the distal common bile duct, the head of the pancreas, or the duodenum.
  • Whipple surgery, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy is depicted in the image. It is a surgical procedure commonly performed to treat periampullary carcinomas. 
 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1284 .

questions.text: Nutritional complications are more with which of the following fistula?
questions.solution:
• Fistulas allow intestinal contents to leave the body, and the distal intestine/colon is not included in the absorption process.
  • Patients lose macronutrients, hydration, and electrolytes as a result of proximal small intestine fistula and hence are at much higher risk of nutritional complications. 
 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1315 .

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient presented with Rectal prolapse. Which among the following is not a perineal approach management for the condition?
questions.solution:
• Ripstein procedure is not a perineal approach; it is an abdominal surgical technique used for the treatment of rectal prolapse. In the Ripstein procedure, the rectum is permanently fixed to the presacral fascia using polypropylene mesh. This eliminates intussusception and prolapse while restoring the rectum's natural posterior curve.
  • On the other hand, the other options mentioned, Altmeier, Thiersch, and Delorme, are perineal approaches for the management of rectal prolapse.
 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1399 .

questions.text: A patient with chronic pancreatitis presents with recurrent attacks of pain in the abdomen. The main duct diameter is found to be 10 mm with intraductal calculi. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient with chronic pancreatitis with intractable abdominal pain not relieved by first-line medical management is a candidate for surgical management.
  • The patients with a dilated MPD have obstructive pancreatopathy and the pain is attributed to the ductal hypertension, thus, these patients would benefit from a drainage procedure - in this patient the lateral or longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LPJ) called the modified Puestow procedure.
  • Pancreatic duct dilation is defined as a main pancreatic duct measuring at least 7 mm in diameter. Pancreatic duct dilation can be secondary to a single stone or stricture; however, it is often caused by multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. The pancreatic duct dilation observed on pancreatography for chronic pancreatitis is classically described as a chain of lakes, which reflects the presence of multiple dilations and stenoses. When it is accompanied by intractable pain, this condition is best treated with side-to-side Rouxen-Y pancreaticojejunostomy, also known as the modified Puestow procedure or lateral pancreaticojejunostomy.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1545.

questions.text: A patient complains of diarrhea 1 week back followed by right upper quadrant pain and fever. Imaging reveals a 75 cc liver abscess. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The patient with a liver abscess with clinical symptoms of RUQ pain and fever with an antecedent history of diarrhea likely has amebic liver abscess.
Medical treatment is very effective and should be the first choice in the elective situation.
Metronidazole 750 mg three times a day for 7 to 10 days is the treatment of choice.
Patients respond dramatically within 72 hours.

Aspiration (percutaneous needle aspiration) or percutaneous (catheter) drainage (also done under metronidazole cover) are indicated in cases where there is: (option D)
  • Diagnostic uncertainty: to rule out pyogenic abscess
  • Lack of response in 3-5 days to medical management
  • Imminent rupture
  • Prevent rupture of left-lobe abscesses into the pericardium. (Percutaneous drainage may be successful even if the liver abscess has already ruptured)
  • There is no evidence that aspiration, even of large abscesses (up to 10 cm), accelerates healing.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1456, 1457.

questions.text: A patient consumed a liquid containing 90% NaOH and has absolute dysphagia. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Nasogastric/duodenal tube is placed under endoscopic guidance for alimentary nutritional support in patients with chemical injury to esophagus.
However, in this patient with ingestion of 90% alkali, there is likely transmural necrosis of esophagus and stomach both, thus this patient will require a feeding jejunostomy for nutrition.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 411.

questions.text: A patient presented with vague RUQ pain, fever, chills and icterus. Radiology reveals the following. Which is correct about the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with fever, chills, RUQ pain and icterus likely has an infectious pathology of the liver.
Cross-sectional slice on CT reveals hypodense lesions with a distinct wall.
  • Laminated, serpentine, linear membranes are visible inside the larger pericyst. This is called the serpent sign or snake sign, indicating hydatid disease of the liver.
  • Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly called the dog (definitive host) tapeworm.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1460.

choices.text: It is a case of Meleney’s gangrene
Hyperbaric O2 therapy does not reduce mortality

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect regarding the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
This likely represents synergistic spreading gangrene, also termed subdermal gangrene or necrotizing fasciitis.
  • Abdominal wall infections are known as Meleney’s synergistic gangrene and scrotal infections as Fournier’s gangrene. (option A)
  • Recently, the role of hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) has become more established with a reduction in mortality in patients treated with HBO (9–20%) compared with patients who did not receive HBO (30–50%).
  • This lesion harbors Staphylococcus aureus and an anaerobic streptococcus, and is thus a polymicrobial pattern of infection with aerobes and anaerobes. (option B)
  • Surgical debridement of the necrotic tissue is the cornerstone of management. This process is repeated daily as the necrosis is prone to spread beyond the edges of the excised wound. (option D)
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 140.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with complaints of dull pain over the right lower abdomen for the past 2 months. CT scan revealed a pseudomyxoma peritonei. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare condition characterized by diffuse accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity.

Key points:

  • Most commonly arises from mucinous tumors of the appendix or ovary.

  • Ovarian association:

    • Mucinous cystadenoma or cystadenocarcinoma

    • Tumor produces mucin that spreads in the peritoneum, leading to “jelly belly” appearance.

  • Other tumors:

    • Embryonal cell carcinoma: Germ cell tumor, usually testicular/ovarian, not typical for PMP.

    • Serous cystadenoma: Produces serous fluid, not mucin.

    • Teratoma: Contains multiple tissue types, usually not mucin-producing.

questions.text: What is the best management approach for gastroschisis in a neonate?
questions.solution:
A newborn with gastroschisis requires an immediate primary closure of the defect. Parenteral nutrition is often necessary for several weeks to support the recovery of the intestines.

Gastroschisis is an abdominal wall defect usually located to the right of the umbilicus, allowing the bowel loops, bladder, ovary or undescended testes to protrude. Unlike Omphalocoele, the exposed bowel loops are not covered by amnion. 

GASTROCHISIS (no covering)




OMPHALOCELE (Sac or covering present)

questions.text: A patient was undergoing the ERCP for the removal of gallstones. However, it required multiple attempts to retrieve the stone. What is the commonest complication expected in such cases after the procedure?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a procedure used for diagnosis and treatment of biliary and pancreatic duct disorders, including gallstone removal.

Key points:

  • Most common complication: Post-ERCP pancreatitis (PEP)

    • Incidence: ~3–10% (higher with difficult cannulation or multiple attempts)

    • Mechanism: Mechanical trauma, hydrostatic injury, or enzymatic activation of the pancreas

  • Other complications:

    • Perforation (~0.1–0.6%)

    • Bleeding

    • Infection (cholangitis)

  • Risk factors for pancreatitis:

    • Multiple attempts at cannulation

    • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

    • Pre-existing pancreatitis

Clinical features:

  • Abdominal pain (epigastric)

  • Nausea, vomiting

  • Elevated serum amylase/lipase

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region even after multiple drainage attempts.Examination of the perianal region is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of fistula-in-ano. The most definitive management for this condition is a laying open fistulotomy, which effectively eradicates the disease.

Fistula-in-Ano Overview
A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity lined with granulation tissue that connects a primary opening within the anal canal to a secondary opening on the perianal skin.

Common Causes:
Perianal Abscess: The most prevalent cause of fistula-in-ano.
Other Conditions: Such as tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.
Symptoms:
Perianal Pain: Discomfort in the anal region.
Discharge: Intermittent purulent discharge, which may sometimes be bloody.
Goodsall's Rule
Goodsall's rule helps to determine the location of the internal opening of the fistula based on the position of the external opening:

Anterior Openings: Fistulas with an external opening located anteriorly connect to the internal opening via a short, radial tract.
Posterior Openings: Fistulas with an external opening located posteriorly follow a curvilinear path to the posterior midline.
This understanding of fistula-in-ano is crucial for proper diagnosis and effective treatment planning.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female undergoes emergency laparotomy. Which of the following is the surest sign of wound dehiscence?
questions.solution:
Wound dehiscence refers to the partial or complete separation of a surgical wound before complete healing.

  • Surest sign: Copious sero-sanguinous discharge from the wound — often preceded by “giving way” of sutures or visible separation of wound edges. 

  • Other signs: Local tenderness, mild fever, but these are less specific.

  • Rebound tenderness → peritonitis, not specific to dehiscence.

  • Hemorrhage → indicates bleeding, not wound separation.

  • Hypotension → may occur if severe bleeding or sepsis develops, not an early or specific sign.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with gynecomastia Ultrasonography (USG) reveals a 1-cm solid mass within the body of the testis. His serum testosterone is 600 ng/dl. and estradiol is 35 pg/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Leydig cell tumors are the most common hormone-secreting testicular tumors in adult men.

  • They often produce testosterone and sometimes estradiol, leading to gynecomastia.

  • Typically present as a small (<5â€¯cm), unilateral, solid testicular mass in men aged 20–60.

  • Serum testosterone may be normal or elevated; estradiol is often mildly elevated, explaining the gynecomastia. 

Other options:

  • Sertoli cell tumor: Can produce estrogen → gynecomastia, usually larger mass, less common.

  • Granulosa cell tumor: Extremely rare in adult males; feminization possible.

  • Spermatocytic tumor: Occurs in older men (>50), non-functional hormonally.

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have MEN-1 syndrome. Which of the following is the most common gastro-entero-pancreatic tumor seen in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
In MEN-1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1), the classical triad involves tumors of the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells. Among the pancreatic/gastro-entero-pancreatic tumors, the most common is:

  • Gastrinoma – usually located in the duodenum or pancreas, leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) with peptic ulcers and diarrhea.

  • Insulinoma – also seen, but less common than gastrinoma.

  • VIPoma – rare in MEN-1.

  • Lipoma – not part of MEN-1 endocrine tumors.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with severe respiratory distress soon after birth. A chest X-ray was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario and the X-ray revealing herniation of bowel loops into the chest is congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

CDH is a structural defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal contents to move into the thoracic cavity, which can lead to pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension. The most common type of CDH is the Bochdalek hernia, typically occurring on the left side. Affected patients may also present with a scaphoid abdomen.
 

  • Chest X-ray findings:

    • Bowel loops or stomach in the thoracic cavity

    • Mediastinal shift to the opposite side

    • Underdeveloped lung fields on the affected side

  • Pathophysiology: A defect in the diaphragm (usually posterolateral, Bochdalek type) allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thorax, impairing lung development.

  • Other options:

    • Congenital pulmonary airway malformation: Usually presents with cystic lung lesions, may not cause severe immediate distress.

    • Congenital lobar hyperinflation: Overinflated lobe, hyperlucency on X-ray; less acute distress.

    • Hyaline membrane disease (RDS): Usually in preterm infants, shows diffuse reticulogranular (ground-glass) pattern, not bowel in thorax.

High-yield point: Respiratory distress at birth + chest X-ray showing bowel loops in thorax → congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

questions.text: 74 year old gentleman presents to the OPD with history of significant unintentional weight loss, loss of appetite and iron deficiency anemia. A chest x-ray was done and is given below What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests that the patient may have colon carcinoma, with the X-ray showing a "cannonball" appearance typical of lung metastases.

Pulmonary metastases usually present as peripheral, rounded nodules of varying sizes, dispersed throughout both lungs. The most common primary cancers that lead to pulmonary metastases in adults include:

Breast carcinoma
Colorectal carcinoma
Renal cell carcinoma
Uterine leiomyosarcoma
Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not an extra-esophageal complication of GERD?
questions.solution:
• Extra esophageal complications of GERD include -laryngitis dental, erosions, pharyngitis, pulmonary fibrosis, asthma chronic cough, recurrent otitis media.
  • Mechanism of extraesophageal complications of GERD -
  1. Proximal esophageal reflux and micro aspiration of duodenal contents causing injury to larynx and lower respiratory tract;
  2. Second mechanism includes distal esophageal acid exposure causing a reflex vagal reflex leading to bronchospasm and cough.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 1114.

questions.text: Identify the following image
questions.solution:
1.
Achalasia Cardia		 2.
 Feline Esophagus
3.
DES		 4.
Leiomyoma
  • The given image has a cock and screw appearance, which is typical of diffuse esophageal spasm.
  • Diffuse esophageal spasm is a disorder of peristalsis characterised by non-peristaltic contractions or premature contractions with a distal contractile integral >450mmhg . Nutcracker esophagus is  characterised by increased duration of peristalsis with distal contractile integral of >8000mmhg.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 1121-23.

choices.text: Percutaneous endoscopic gastronomy (PEG) used for gastric outlet obstruction
Percutaneous endoscopic gastronomy used as a first step in the treatment of complex orofacial malignancies for nutrition of the patient.
Flatus tube for the treatment of sigmoid volvulus

questions.text: Name the following instrument and its use
questions.solution:
The given image shows percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy.
  • The insertion of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube improves nutritional and functional outcomes in patients who cannot maintain oral nutritional intake.
  • PEG insertion is often a preliminary step in the treatment of complex orofacial malignancies and can also be used to support nutrition in patients with various malignant, degenerative, or inflammatory diseases.
  • Contraindications to percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement, include coagulation disorders, bowel obstruction, infection, severe ascites, peritoneal carcinomatosis.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 151.

questions.text: Which is the most common hernia in females?
questions.solution:
The most common hernia in females is an indirect inguinal hernia.
Inguinal hernia is the most common hernia in men and women. It is classified into :
â— Indirect hernia - protrusion of the contents occurs through the deep inguinal ring, along with the spermatic cord, lateral to the inferior epigastric artery. It is the most common subtype of groin hernia in both males and females.
â— Direct inguinal hernia - Occurs through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal through the Hasselbach's triangle. The sac is medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

Reference: Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th edition, Page No 1599 .

questions.text:
Match the following positions of the appendix to their descriptions:

a. Subcaecal
b. Retrocaecal
c. Inside the pelvis
d. Paracaecal
questions.solution:
Ans-
The correctly matched positions of the appendix are as follows:

1 - b: Retrocaecal - the most common position, found in 14% of cases.

2 - d: Paracaecal - found in 2% of cases.

3 - a: Subcaecal - found in 1.5% of cases.

4 - c: Pelvic - found in 21% of cases.

The appendix is initially a short, broad, blind muscular tube. As the caecum undergoes differential growth, the appendix becomes tubular. This growth and rotation of the caecum typically position the appendix in a retrocaecal but intraperitoneal location. However, when this rotation does not occur, the appendix may be located in pelvic, subcaecal, or paracaecal positions. If the caecum fails to migrate to its typical position in the right lower quadrant, the appendix can sometimes be situated near the gallbladder. In cases of intestinal malrotation, the appendix might be found in the left iliac fossa.

Various positions of the appendix are illustrated in the image below.

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1335 .

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has the highest risk to cause the recurrence of duodenal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Highly Selective Vagotomy (HSV) is associated with the highest risk of recurrence of duodenal ulcers among the surgical options for treating peptic ulcer disease.

Overview of Highly Selective Vagotomy:

Mechanism: HSV preserves vagal innervation to the antrum, pylorus, and the remaining abdominal viscera, while cutting the vagal supply to the proximal two-thirds of the stomach, which contains most of the parietal cells responsible for gastric acid secretion.
Effect on Acid Secretion: By targeting the parietal cells, HSV reduces gastric acid secretion by approximately 75%, leading to a significant reduction in acid-related damage to the duodenum.
Advantages: The procedure spares important vagal innervation to the antrum and pylorus, reducing the risk of gastrointestinal side effects like delayed gastric emptying and dumping syndrome that are more common with other vagotomy techniques.
Limitations: HSV has limited effectiveness in treating type II (gastric and duodenal ulcers) and type III (prepyloric ulcers). These limitations may arise due to the risk of hypergastrinemia, caused by prolonged antral stasis and gastric outlet obstruction, which can contribute to the recurrence of ulcers.

Despite its benefits in reducing acid secretion and minimizing side effects, the risk of ulcer recurrence remains a challenge with HSV, particularly in more complex ulcer cases.

Other options:

  • Truncal vagotomy + drainage: Acid suppression good, recurrence ≈ 5–10%

  • Gastrectomy (antrectomy, Billroth I/II): Removes gastrin-producing antrum + parietal cells → lowest recurrence.

  • Gastrojejunostomy (without vagotomy/gastrectomy): Merely bypass; doesn’t reduce acid. It can lead to marginal ulcers, but when asked about “recurrence of duodenal ulcers” specifically, standard surgical literature considers HSV has the highest recurrence rate compared to other definitive anti-ulcer procedures.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female undergoes emergency laparotomy for perforation peritonitis. Which of the following is the surest sign of wound dehiscence?
questions.solution:
The most definitive indication of wound dehiscence is the presence of copious serosanguinous discharge.

Burst abdomen, or acute wound dehiscence, refers to the mechanical failure of a closed abdominal wound, leading to the separation of the wound edges and potential evisceration of abdominal contents. This condition typically occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.

Patients may experience a sudden sensation of the wound "giving way," often triggered by coughing, and they may notice pinkish serosanguinous discharge. This can result in the omentum or loops of intestine protruding through the wound.

Management strategies include:

Delayed closure with an initial mesh wrap or Bogota bag
Placement of a subcutaneous drain
Appropriate antibiotic therapy
Prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome, as previously described.

questions.text: A homosexual man complains of painful defecation and mass protruding from the anal canal. Biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma of anus. Correct management for this patient is
questions.solution:
Management of Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Anal Canal
The preferred treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is combined chemotherapy and radiation therapy, commonly referred to as the Nigro regimen.
Treatment Approach:
Chemoradiotherapy (Nigro Regimen): The primary treatment involves a regimen that combines 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with either mitomycin C or cisplatin, followed by external beam radiation to the pelvis, delivering a minimum dose of 45 Gy.

Metastasis: Metastatic disease is uncommon at diagnosis, occurring in approximately 5% of cases, thus the focus of treatment is on achieving local control.

For patients with T2 lesions and residual disease after receiving 45 Gy, or those with T3 or T4 tumors, or node-positive disease, an additional dose of 9 to 14 Gy is typically administered, culminating in a total radiation dose of 54 to 59 Gy.

Patients exhibiting persistent disease up to 6 months post-treatment generally require abdominoperineal resection (APR). Additionally, those experiencing local recurrence are also advised to undergo APR.

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. A diagnosis of fistula-in-ano is made. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the evaluation of fistula-in-ano, MRI is considered the gold standard for investigation.



A fistula-in-ano refers to an abnormal connection between the anal canal and the perianal skin, which is typically lined with granulation tissue. This condition may arise following the drainage of a perianal abscess or can be associated with diseases such as tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Clinical features include perianal pain, swelling, and intermittent purulent discharge, which may sometimes be blood-stained. Upon examination, one or more external openings may be visible.

Goodsall's rule serves as a helpful guideline for determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula. According to this rule, fistulas with an anterior external opening connect to the internal opening via a short, radial tract, while those with a posterior external opening typically follow a curvilinear path to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to Goodsall's rule are common. For instance, fistulas with an anterior external opening located more than 3 cm from the anal margin often track to the posterior midline instead.

So,

  • MRI pelvis (with contrast) → Gold standard for fistula-in-ano.

    • Accurately delineates primary tract, internal opening, secondary extensions, and abscesses.

    • Sensitivity >90%, superior to other imaging modalities.

  • USG (Endoanal ultrasound) → Useful, but operator-dependent and less accurate for complex/high fistulas.

  • CECT → Poor for soft tissue detail, not preferred.

  • Fistulogram → Obsolete; cannot delineate sphincter involvement accurately.

questions.text: All of the following are true about nephroblastoma except:
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma, rather than nephroblastoma, is the most prevalent intra-abdominal malignancy in children.

Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is an embryonal renal neoplasm typically diagnosed in children under the age of five. It arises from abnormal development of the kidneys, leading to the proliferation of the metanephric blastema.

Clinical Presentation:
Children with Wilms tumor may exhibit:
Abdominal mass
Fever
Hematuria (which indicates tumor extension into the renal pelvis)
Hypertension (noted in a significant number of cases)

Prognostic Factors for Wilms Tumor:
Several factors influence the prognosis of Wilms tumor, including:
Histological type
Stage of the disease
Age of the patient at diagnosis
Tumor weight
Response to therapy
Loss of heterozygosity at chromosome regions 1p and 16q

questions.text: While doing an endoscopy, constriction is felt at the oesophageal junction at 25 cm from the incisor. This is due to?
questions.solution:
The arch of the aorta and left bronchus cross the esophagus at approximately 25 cm from the upper incisor teeth.

Normal Constrictions of the Esophagus:
The esophagus typically exhibits three constrictions at specific levels, measured from the upper incisors:

1. Junction of the esophagus with cricopharynx:
Located 15 cm from the incisor teeth.
2. Crossed by the arch of aorta and left bronchus:
Located 25 cm from the incisor teeth.
3. Piercing the diaphragm:
Located 40 cm from the incisor teeth.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with hematuria and a neovascular mass in bilateral kidney on a CT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The CT scan displays renal lesions with hypo-attenuating features indicative of macroscopic fat, which strongly suggests the presence of renal angiomyolipoma.



• Angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that can occur sporadically or in conjunction with tuberous sclerosis. These tumors typically present at a mean age of 43 years and have a higher incidence in females. Larger tumors may lead to spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Patients may exhibit symptoms such as flank pain, a palpable mass, hematuria, urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure.

Imaging Findings in Renal Angiomyolipoma:
The identification of macroscopic fat is crucial for diagnosis.
