Ultrasound (USG): May reveal hyperechoic lesions in the renal cortex accompanied by posterior acoustic shadowing. In cases associated with tuberous sclerosis, the entire kidney may appear echogenic, losing the normal corticomedullary junction.
CT Findings:
Cortical lesions that show macroscopic fat (less than -20 HU)
No evidence of ossification or calcification
The presence of macroscopic fat is highly indicative of this condition, though it is not exclusively diagnostic, as renal cell carcinoma (RCC) may occasionally exhibit macroscopic fat as well.
Approximately 5% of angiomyolipomas may be fat-poor.
MRI:
An effective modality for visualizing intramural fat components, utilizing two sequences:
Fat-saturated techniques
Phase-in and phase-out imaging, which reveals India ink artifacts at the interface between fat and non-fat areas.
Digital Subtraction Angiography:
These lesions are hypervascular, presenting a 'sunburst appearance' during the arterial phase and an 'onion peel appearance' in the venous phase.

• Generally, angiomyolipomas do not necessitate intervention. However, mTOR inhibitors such as everolimus can be utilized to reduce the size of the lesions.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who is a chronic tobacco chewer presents with a whitish lesion on the gingivobuccal sulcus for 7 months. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this scenario is leukoplakia, and the next best step in management is local excision and biopsy.

Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition affecting the oral cavity, characterized by well-defined whitish patches or plaques that can cover large areas of the oral mucosa. Several risk factors include smoking, chronic candidiasis, chewing tobacco, alcohol consumption, spices, and sepsis.

Presentation:
Lesions appear as small, well-defined patches but may extensively involve significant portions of the oral mucosa.

Variants of Leukoplakia:
1. Homogeneous Leukoplakia: This is the most common type, presenting as uniform white patches.
2. Nodular Leukoplakia: Characterized by fine nodules on the surface, this variant has a higher potential for malignancy.
3. Speckled Leukoplakia: Presents as whitish lesions on an erythematous base and carries the highest risk of malignant transformation.
4. Proliferative Verrucous Leukoplakia: A rare form with a significant risk for malignant progression.
Hairy Leukoplakia:
Hairy leukoplakia is often seen in patients with AIDS, marked by severe hyperkeratosis and acanthosis. The primary cause of this condition is the Epstein-Barr virus.

Risk of Malignancy:
Leukoplakia occurring in elderly individuals and lasting for an extended duration poses a greater risk of progression to malignancy. Therefore, an excisional biopsy is essential not only to confirm the diagnosis but also to exclude carcinoma.
Management:
Management strategies include smoking cessation and reduction of alcohol intake.

questions.text: Which of the following structures cause a constrictions in the esophagus 25 cm from the incisors?
questions.solution:
Constrictions of the esophagus occur at the following levels
• Junction of the esophagus with cricopharynx (15 cm from the incisor teeth)
• At the level of crossing by the arch of aorta and left bronchus (25 cm from the incisor teeth)
• It pierces the diaphragm (40 cm from the incisor teeth).
Ref: Bailey and Love's short practice of Surgery - 28th Edition • Page no: 1107

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for splenectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common indication for splenectomy are :
• Elective splenectomy - Haematological disorders such as hereditary spherocytosis, Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), etc.
• Emergency splenectomy - Trauma
• Splenectomy (overall) - Trauma.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 27th Edition • Pg 1185

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is not seen in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Hperchloremia is not seen in Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis have persistent vomiting secondary to gastric outlet obstruction, resulting in loss of hydrochloric acid and development of metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia. Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na* and HCO3.
However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway which reabsorbs sodium in exchange for pottasium causing hypokalemia. Ref- Bailey and Love 27th edition Page 128

questions.text: An alcoholic male patient diagnosed with hollow viscus perforation is taken up for laparotomy. Intraoperatively, a 2 cm-sized perforation is seen in the gastric region. How can this patient be managed?
questions.solution: Gastroduodenal perforations are a common surgical emergency caused due to Peptic ulcer disease (PUD), Smoking, alcohol, chronic analgesic use. Patients present with hypotension and signs and symptoms of peritonitis- tenderness, guarding and rigidity. Management depends on the location and size of perforation. Small subcentric perforations with healthy margins can undergo primary repair and buttressed with an omental patch. (Graham's repair). Larger perforations and ulcers with fibrotic edges can be managed by an omental pedicle flap repair. A tongue of omentum is brought up to cover the ulcer defect and secured with a series of interrupted sutures. (Modified Graham's patch). Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition • Page no 1212- 1213

questions.text: Following a bout of vomiting a young female presented with chest pain radiating to the neck and breathlessness . On evaluation she had tachycardia with BP of 100/70 auscultation reavealed a crunchy noise synchronous with the heart beat and her X-ray is as shown below. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Oesophageal perforation is a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs through the transmural perforation of the esophageal wall. It can occur secondary to trauma, endoscopic instrumentation, corrosive ingestion, or severe repetitive vomiting against a closed GE junction. It can present with various symptoms such as neck pain, chest pain, Mediastinal crackles (Hamman sign), features of sepsis, hypotension. The initial investigation that is performed in this condition is a contrast esophagogram (gastrograffin) which will show the extravasation of the contrast. Water-soluble contrast (iohexol) should be used instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum if there is perforation. If the esophagogram is normal, contrast-enhanced CT is useful in identifying the injury.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition • Page 1034, 1035

questions.text:
A 30 year old male following binge drinking presented with acute abdomen. On per abdominal examination patient had guarding and rigidity. His X-ray revealed the following findings.



What could be the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• The given X-ray shows air under the diaphragm sign which is suggestive of a hollow viscous perforation.
  • Acute abdomen is a common surgical emergency. Common causes include appendicitis, hollow viscus perforation, cholecystitis, and pancreatitis.
  • An erect abdominal X-ray is commonly done as the first investigation which in case of a perforation will show air under the diaphragm. Clinical features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation. Fever may be present.
  • Features of septic shock can be seen at later stages.
  • Treatment of hollow viscous perforation mainly includes resuscitation, analgesics, intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, and emergency exploratory laparotomy.
Reference Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Editon • Page 650, 1296, 1455

questions.text: A middle aged woman presents with difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. Her barium swallow is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario along with barium swallow showing a bird beak appearence is suggestive of Achalasia Cardia.
It is a primary esophageal motility disorder.
It is charecterised by the absence of peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES in response to swallowing.
Patient presents with dysphagia, regurgitation and weight loss.
Ref- Grainer and Allison 6th edition page 624.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is likely to get during an open hernioplasty with mesh repair ?
questions.solution:
The ilioinguinal nerve is most commonly injured within open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury. The ilioinguinal nerve provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.
Schwartz's Principles of Surgery - 11th edition • Page nos 1497, 1498 and 1499

choices.text: Urgent surgical exploration with Omental patch closure

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with diffuse abdominal pain. Physical examination revealed rigidity and guarding. Abdominal X-ray demonstrated free air under the diaphragm. Intraoperatively, duodenal perforation was noted with gross contamination of the abdomen with enteric and purulent content. What is the appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Duodenal perforation is managed by omental patch repair without resection. Omental patch repair is preferred as it reduced the chances of duodenal fistula at the site of repair.
Resection is considered in a patient with multiple perforation, suspected gangrene or malignancy.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition • page 1335

questions.text: Among the following labelled incisions identify "Lanz incision"
questions.solution:
Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular-mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer's lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition • Page no:86 (Figure: 7.4),1309 (Figure: 72.12)

questions.text: What type of flap is done in a patient with recurrent pilonidal sinus as shown in the image ?
questions.solution:
Image shows a rhomboid flap done in pilonidal sinus surgery. Pilonidal sinus is blind track lined by granulation tissue leading from an epitheilal surface to surrounding tissue. It is also known as Jeep driver's bottom seen in the natal cleft more in men after puberty.
Treatment-
Surgery- Bascom procedure, Z plasty, Transposition flap- Rhomboid flap.

Ref- Sabiston textbook of Surgery 20th edition page 1969.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with a midline swelling at the site of previous abdominal surgery through a midline incision. He undergoes fascial closure augmented with a mesh as depicted below. Identify the type of repair with respect to the placement of the mesh
questions.solution:
The given patient is suffering from an incisional hernia. incisional hernia refers to a ventral abdominal wall hernia at the site of a previous surgical incision. incisional hernias are repaired by fascial closure augmented with a mesh. There are different options for mesh placement:
• Onlay (above the anterior fascia, over the defect)
• Inlay (between the fascial edges without overlap)
• Sublay (below the fascial components) - this includes retrorectus, preperitoneal, and intraperitoneal (IPOM) mesh placements.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition • Page no 1111.

questions.text: A patient presents with repetitive episodes of heartburn and chest pain. What is the most common condition that causes these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of repetitive episodes of heartburn and chest pain is esophagitis, most frequently due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). GERD occurs when stomach acid refluxes into the esophagus, leading to irritation and inflammation (reflux esophagitis).

Other options

  • Pneumonia (Option 2) – Typically presents with fever, cough, dyspnea, and pleuritic chest pain rather than heartburn.

  • Achalasia (Option 3) – A motility disorder causing dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) rather than heartburn.

  • Barrett’s Esophagus (Option 4) – A complication of chronic GERD but not the most common initial cause of heartburn and chest pain. It is diagnosed in patients with long-standing GERD and carries a risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Reference: Robbin's and cotran pathologic basis of Disease 9e page no 755.

questions.text: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours. The X-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Foreign body in the esophagus is most common in children, with typical symptoms like dysphagia and refusal to feed. Diagnosis is usually confirmed on AP and lateral X-rays.

Common Foreign Bodies:

Population Commonly Ingested Objects
Children Coins, disc batteries, toys
Adults Food boluses (e.g., meat), dentures

X-RAY FINDINGS
View Esophageal Coin Tracheal Coin
AP View Coin appears flat (coronal) Coin appears on edge
Lateral View Coin edge on side Coin appears flat (sagittal)


Clinical presentation: 

  • Early signs: Choking, gagging, coughing.

  • Later signs:

    • Esophageal: Drooling, dysphagia, vomiting, neck pain.

    • Airway compromise: Stridor, wheeze, cyanosis (if airway involved).

      Imaging:

  • Initial: AP and lateral X-ray of neck, chest, and abdomen.

  • If complications suspected: Contrast studies or CT scan (e.g., for perforation or mediastinitis).

    Management:

    Asymptomatic Child (e.g., swallowed coin in esophagus):

  • Observe up to 24 hours for spontaneous passage.

  • If it remains lodged or symptoms develop → endoscopic removal.

    Symptomatic Child:

  • Immediate endoscopic removal with flexible endoscope + grasping forceps.

    Tracheal Foreign Body:

    • AP view: Edge seen

    • Lateral view: Flat surface seen (sagittal orientation)

  • Pulmonary Foreign Body:

    • May be seen in intercostal spaces

    • CT Chest if not visible on X-ray
       

Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1072

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic small bowel diarrhoea.Duodenal biopsy shows villous atrophy. Anti endomysial antibodies and IgA TTG antibodies are positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation — chronic small bowel diarrhea, villous atrophy on duodenal biopsy, and positive anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA) and IgA tissue transglutaminase (tTG) — is classic for Celiac disease (Celiac sprue).

Differential Diagnosis 

      Celiac Sprue (Celiac Disease)

  • Cause: Autoimmune reaction to gluten (gliadin) in genetically predisposed individuals.

  • Histology: Villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, intraepithelial lymphocytosis.

  • Serology: Positive IgA anti-tTG and anti-endomysial antibodies.

  • Clinical: Steatorrhea, weight loss, iron deficiency anemia, dermatitis herpetiformis.

  • Treatment: Lifelong gluten-free diet.

    Tropical Sprue

  • Cause: Likely infectious in origin; affects people in tropical regions.

  • Histology: Similar to celiac (villous atrophy) but often with more inflammation in jejunum and ileum.

  • Serology: Negative celiac antibodies (tTG, EMA).

  • Clinical: Chronic diarrhea, megaloblastic anemia due to B12 and folate deficiency.

  • Treatment: Tetracycline + folic acid for 3–6 months.

    Whipple's Disease

  • Cause: Infection with Tropheryma whipplei.

  • Histology: PAS-positive macrophages in lamina propria containing bacilli.

  • Serology: No specific antibody test.

  • Clinical: Diarrhea, arthralgia, neurologic symptoms, hyperpigmentation, cardiac signs.

  • Treatment: Ceftriaxone IV then oral TMP-SMX for 1 year.

    Short Bowel Syndrome

  • Cause: Malabsorption due to surgical resection of large parts of small intestine.

  • Histology: No intrinsic mucosal disease; rather loss of surface area.

  • Serology: Normal.

  • Clinical: Diarrhea, steatorrhea, nutrient deficiencies depending on section lost.

  • Treatment: Nutritional support, sometimes TPN, tailored to extent of loss.



Reference:Sleisenger and Fordtran's Gastrointestinal and Liver Disease: Pathophysiology, Diagnosis, Management 10th edition - Page no 1890

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a known history of Crohn's disease . Physical examination reveals rigidity and guarding. On imaging lleal Perforation is diagnosed. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient with Crohn's disease presenting with:

  • Diffuse abdominal pain

  • Rigidity and guarding (suggestive of peritonitis)

  • Imaging showing ileal perforation

This is a surgical emergency

Management:

  • Perforation of the small intestine (especially in Crohn’s disease) with signs of peritonitis requires urgent laparotomy or laparoscopy.

  • In Crohn's disease, due to poor healing and high recurrence, primary anastomosis is often avoided in emergency settings.

  • Hence, a diverting ileostomy with resection is commonly done.

    Why not the other options?

  1. Upper GI endoscopy – Not appropriate in acute peritonitis or perforation; contraindicated.

  2. CT abdomen – Diagnosis already made (ileal perforation), and the patient is unstable. Further imaging delays definitive care.

  3. Antibiotics and NPO – Supportive but not definitive. Surgery is needed.

 Reference: Online Resource - https://www.uptodate.com/contents/overview-of-gastrointestinal-tract-perforationsectionName=CLINICAL%20FEATURES&search=peptic%20ulcer%20perforation& topicRef=24&anchor=H5020509&source=see_link #H12750226

choices.text: 6 o'clock and crypt of the dentate line
12 o'clock and at external anal spinchter
11 o'clock and at internal anal spinchter

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with purulent discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. The patient is put ina lithotomy position and the opening is located at the 11 o'clock position, 4 cm from the anal margin. What will be the likely position of the internal opening and where does the internal opening start?
questions.solution:
In most cases, the internal opening is located at the 6 o’clock position (posterior midline) within the anal canal, typically originating from a crypt at the dentate line.

In this scenario, a patient presents with a perianal external opening at the 11 o’clock position, situated 4 cm from the anal verge. This placement prompts evaluation using Goodsall’s Rule.

Goodsall’s Rule Explained

External Opening Location Fistula Tract Pattern Internal Opening Site
Anterior (within 3 cm) Straight, radial tract Corresponding to external position
Posterior (any distance) Curved tract Posterior midline (6 o’clock)
Anterior (beyond 3 cm) May follow a curved tract (exception to the rule) Posterior midline (6 o’clock)
 

In this case: The anterior external opening is >3 cm from the anal verge, so the internal opening is most likely at the 6 o’clock position, per the exception.

 

Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1364-1365

questions.text: An elderly male on digital rectal examination was found to have a rectal mass raising the suspicion of rectal carcinoma. His bowel habits are normal and he visited the outpatient department for a routine check-up. Which of the following should be recommended as the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the setting of a suspected rectal carcinoma on digital rectal examination (DRE), the next best step in evaluation and management is a full colonoscopy with biopsy.

Rationale:

  • Digital rectal exam (DRE): Can detect low rectal tumors but has limited reach.

  • Colonoscopy:

    • Visualizes the entire colon and rectum.

    • Allows biopsy of any suspicious lesion.

    • Essential to rule out synchronous lesions, which are seen in 3–5% of colorectal cancer cases.

  • Barium enema: Less sensitive and does not allow biopsy. It is now largely obsolete for initial diagnosis.

  • CT scan: Helpful for staging, not for initial diagnosis or confirmation.

  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy may miss proximal lesions.

    Next Step Summary:

  • Full colonoscopy + biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis.

  • After histopathological confirmation, further staging with CT/MRI follows.

    Key Point:

Even in asymptomatic patients with a suspicious rectal mass, colonoscopy with biopsy is the most definitive and appropriate initial diagnostic step.

Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1320,1331

questions.text: What is the most frequently used and accepted form of bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  is 4. Roux-en-Y gastric bypass
 
  • Most commonly performed and acceptable method of bariatric surgery among given options is Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
  • However, the better answer to this question will be sleeve gastrectomy.
  • Since it is not there in the given options, we should mark the second best answer which is roux-en-Y gastric bypass.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1181.

questions.text:
Hepatojejunal anastomosis was used in surgery for biliary stricture in a child. After two weeks, the postoperative bilirubin level dropped from 12 mg/dL to 6 mg/dL.
What could be the reason for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Delta bilirubin
 
  • Delta Bilirubin: Part of the direct-reacting Bilirubin fraction includes conjugated bilirubin that is covalently linked to albumin. This albumin-linked bilirubin fraction (delta fraction, or biliprotein) represents an important fraction of total serum bilirubin in patients with cholestasis and hepatobiliary disorders.
  • By virtue of its tight binding to albumin, the clearance rate of albumin-bound bilirubin from serum approximates the half-life of albumin, 12-14 days, rather than the short half-life of bilirubin, about 4 hours.
  • Significance of delta bilirubin in patients with obstructive jaundice: It has been observed that there is an inverse correlation between delta-bilirubin and total bilirubin concentration.
  • In patients with good drainage, the percentage of delta-bilirubin increase within 7 days after biliary drainage procedure, but it did not reach 60% by 28 days in the patients with poor drainage.
  • The increase in the percentage of serum delta-bilirubin indicates effectiveness of biliary drainage.

Reference: Kozaki N, Shimizu S, Higashijima H, Kuroki S, Yamashita H, Yamaguchi K, Chijiiwa K, Tanaka M. Significance of serum delta-bilirubin in patients with obstructive jaundice. J Surg Res. 1998 Sep;79(1):61-5. doi: 10.1006/jsre.1998.5357. PMID: 9735241.

questions.text: What is the possible explanation for a bilirubin level of 40 mg/dL in a patient with obstructive jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Renal failure
 
  • All causes of cholestatic jaundice, such as malignant blockage and total CBD obstruction, can result in high jaundice, but concurrent renal failure causes bilirubin levels to rise over 30 mg/dL.
  • Conjugated bilirubin may be eliminated in urine and is soluble. However, this process is not present in renal failure, and the serum bilirubin can increase to extremely high levels.
 

* Audio Explanation: 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1377.

questions.text: Non-visualization of gallbladder in hepatic scintigraphy indicates which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Acute cholecystitis due to gallstones

Non-visualization of gallbladder in hepatic scintigraphy is suggestive of Acute cholecystitis.
 
  • Ultrasonography is the most useful radiologic test for diagnosing acute cholecystitis. It has a sensitivity and specificity of 95%. In addition to being a sensitive test for documenting the presence or absence of stones, it will show the thickening of the gallbladder wall and the pericholecystic fluid.
  • Focal tenderness over the gallbladder when compressed by the sonographic probe (sonographic Murphy’s sign) also is suggestive of acute cholecystitis. Biliary radionuclide scanning (HIDA scan) may be of help in the atypical case.
  • Lack of filling of the gallbladder after 4 hours indicates an obstructed cystic duct and, in the clinical setting of acute cholecystitis, is highly sensitive and specific for acute cholecystitis. A normal HIDA scan excludes acute cholecystitis.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1405.

questions.text: The patient started wheezing intra-op during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Which of the following is applied during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Deepen the plane of anesthesia
 
  • If the patient develops wheezing while performing laparoscopic cholecystectomy, he should be treated by deepening of the plane of anesthesia.
  • The most frequent reason for asthma attacks during surgery is insufficient depth of anesthesia.
  • First, deepen anesthetic level and raise FiO2. Keep in mind that the patient is undergoing surgery and is sedated.
  • A deeper level of anesthesia can relax the airway muscles and reduce the likelihood of airway reflexes, such as bronchospasm or wheezing. Additionally, deepening anesthesia can reduce intra-abdominal pressure and minimize other mechanical triggers of wheezing.
  • Consequently, the use of medical intervention such as the administration of beta-agonists/Ketamine cane be given

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 415.

questions.text: The term "cystic blow out" is classified as follows under the Bismuth/Strasberg classification:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Type A
  • The Bismuth/Strasberg classification is used for bile duct injuries.
  • "Cystic blowout" refers to a bile duct injury involving the cystic duct.
  • It is classified as Type A according to the Bismuth/Strasberg classification.

Fig: Bismuth–Corlette classification of cholangiocarcinoma

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1257.

choices.text: Donor bile duct with recipient bile duct or Roux-en-Y choledochojejunostomy
Donor bile duct with duodenum of recipient
Donor bile duct with jejunum of receipt
External drainage for few days followed by choledochojejunostomy

questions.text: Which method for obtaining bile drainage in the donor liver during orthotropic liver transplantation is ideal?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Donor bile duct with recipient bile duct or Roux-en-Y choledochojejunostomy 
 
  • The ideal method for bile drainage in the donor liver during orthotopic liver transplantation is to connect the donor bile duct with the recipient bile duct or perform a Roux-en-Y choledochojejunostomy.
  • This allows for the drainage of bile from the donor liver into the recipient's intestine, maintaining biliary continuity.
  • Donor bile duct with the duodenum of the recipient (option B) or jejunum of the recipient (option C) are not the preferred methods.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1610.

questions.text: Select the vessel affected by tumor of the uncinate process of pancreas.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Superior mesenteric artery
 
  • The uncinate process is a thin, curved projection at the lower and medial aspect of the head of the pancreas that passes between the superior mesenteric artery and the abdominal aorta.
  • This structure divides the superior mesenteric vessels anteriorly and the abdomen posteriorly and can be seen on sagittal cross-sectional imaging.
  • The uncinate process can potentially be compressed by a tumor at this site and may lead to compression of the superior mesenteric vessels with resulting effects on blood flow.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1286.

questions.text: A patient undergoes MRCP showing dilated biliary radicles, gall stones, and CBD stones. What management will you do next
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. ERCP
 
  • The standard treatment for this type of situation is an Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio pancreatogram (ERCP) to cut the sphincterotomy and the retrieval of stones in the common bile duct (CBD).
  • After the procedure, a stent can be placed to alleviate the obstruction, followed by a laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
  • Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatogram (MRCP) is a very sensitive and specific diagnostic study that can be used to detect hepatobiliary pathologies.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1199.

questions.text: All among the following conditions require ERCP as an indication except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Acute pancreatitis without Choledocholithiasis

ERCP is endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography.
It is an invasive procedure helps in diagnosis and management of Biliary- pancreatic duct system. 

Among the given options, ERCP will be least useful in the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis. 

The common indications for ECRP are as follows-
  • Recurrent pancreatitis
  • Unexplained Jaundice
  • Periampullary mass
  • Biliary stenting for strictures or leakage
  • Sphincterotomy 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1199.

questions.text: A 40 year patient presented with recurrent abdominal pain post cholecystectomy. On USG examination, no significant findings were present. He was discovered to have biliary dyskinesia after additional evaluation by other investigations. Which among the following investigations would not be helpful for diagnosing biliary dyskinesia
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. USG
 
  • Among given options, USG is not done for the diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia as the findings are seen to be normal.
  • The diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia can be made by a HIDA scan (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan) and ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography). Also post surgery follow up will help in identifying these patients as they will present with persistent right upper quadrant pain after cholecystectomy.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1503.

questions.text: 5 days after having a lap cholecystectomy, a patient complained of pain in right upper quadrant. On USG, a 5 cm collection is visible in Morrison's pouch. Biliary leakage may be a possibility. What kind of investigation is most accurate at finding the leak
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. ERCP
 

After a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the presence of a fluid collection in Morrison's pouch (the space between the liver and the right kidney) along with pain suggests the possibility of a biliary leak. A biliary leak can occur due to injury to the bile ducts during the surgery, and this requires accurate diagnosis and management.

Here's a breakdown of the options:

  1. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography):
    ERCP is the most accurate investigation for diagnosing a biliary leak. It allows for direct visualization of the bile ducts and can identify the location and cause of a leak. Additionally, ERCP has the advantage of being therapeutic: if a leak is found, it can be treated simultaneously by placing a biliary stent to divert bile flow and allow the leak to heal.

  2. HIDA (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan):
    HIDA is a nuclear medicine scan that is used to assess the function of the gallbladder and bile ducts. It is helpful for detecting biliary leaks but is not as specific as ERCP for locating the exact site of the leak. It works by tracing the flow of a radiolabeled bile acid, and if a leak is present, the radiotracer will appear in abnormal locations (such as the peritoneal cavity). While useful, it is not as definitive as ERCP.

  3. MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography):
    MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that uses MRI to visualize the biliary tree. It is very effective at detecting bile duct injuries and can provide clear images of the biliary system. While it is an excellent diagnostic tool, ERCP is more commonly used for both diagnosing and treating a biliary leak, as MRCP cannot provide the same level of therapeutic intervention.

  4. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):
    CECT is useful for identifying collections or abscesses and can help detect fluid collections like those in Morrison's pouch. However, it is not the most accurate for identifying biliary leaks. CECT can suggest a leak if it shows a bile-containing collection, but it cannot definitively demonstrate the leak's source. Therefore, it is not as specific as ERCP or MRCP.

Conclusion:

ERCP (option 1) is the most accurate investigation for diagnosing a biliary leak and also has therapeutic value, making it the best choice for managing a potential biliary leak after laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

questions.text: Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak, according to Strasberg's categorization of bile duct injury, is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Type C

Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak is Type C.
Strasberg classification Bile Duct injury
A Cystic duct leak or leaks from small ducts in liver bed
B Occlusion of an aberrant Right Hepatic Duct
C Leak from an aberrant RHD
D Lateral injury to CBD (< 50% circumference)
E1 CHD stricture, stump > 2 cm
E2 CHD stricture, stump < 2 cm
E3 Hilar structure with preserved biliary confluence
E4 Hilar stricture with involvement of confluence
E5 Stricture to an aberrant RHD and to CHD


Fig: Strasberg classification of postoperative bile duct strictures

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1511.

questions.text: A patient arrived with symptoms including clay-colored feces, generalized itching, and jaundice. His CBD was also dilated, and his ultrasonogram revealed a swollen gall bladder without any signs of stones. Which of the following investigations comes next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Endoscopic ultrasound

The given clinical history (jaundice, generalized itching, clay-colored stools) is suggestive of obstructive jaundice.

  • His USG shows evidence of a distended gall bladder and dilated CBD which implies that the obstruction must be distal to the CBD and most likely at the periampullary region.
  • The best imaging modality to check for obstruction at the peri-ampullary region is endoscopic ultrasound as it offers the benefit of taking a biopsy in case of peri-ampullary carcinoma.
Other options-
  • x ray and PET scan are of no use. 
  • Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography is an invasive procedure so it is not the next line investigation. 


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1496.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the components of Reynolds' Pentad?
(i) Fever
(ii) Hypotension
(iii) Altered Mental Status
(iv) Malena
(v) Vomiting
(vi) Pain
(vii) Jaundice
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. i,ii,iii,vi,vii

Reynold’s Pentad is a collection of signs and symptoms involved in Ascending cholangitis.

* It includes-

1. Intermittent fever 

2. Intermittent Pain 

3. Intermittent Jaundice 

4. Septic Shock

5. Altered Mental Status.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1408.

questions.text:
Which one of the following statements about HCC is true?
(i) Global incidence of HCC is rising
(ii) NASH & NAFLD are risk factors
(iii) LENVATINIB is used in tumors of size < 3.5 cm
(iv) TACE is done for multi-modular tumor
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. i, ii, iv

Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of liver. Global incidence of HCC is rising. Liver Cirrhosis, NASH and NAFLD are some of the risk factors.

* Management of HCC:

1. Localised disease—Small tumors are resected by maintaining functional liver reserve (>25%) .In case of low functional liver reserve, liver transplant is done . FLR can be increased by Nimura’s technique or ALPP’s procedure ( Associating Liver Partition and Portal vein ligation for Staged Hepatectomy ) in some cases.

2. Advanced disease—SUNITINIB, LENVATINIB, SORATENIB , TACE (Trans arterial chemo embolization ),TARE (Trans arterial radio embolization) and Radio frequency ablation.

Lenvatinib is a systemic treatment for advanced HCC, often used when surgical options like liver transplantation or resection are not feasible. It is typically used for patients with advanced-stage HCC or those who cannot undergo resection or liver transplantation.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1214.

questions.text:
Two years after undergoing a cholecystectomy, the patient was readmitted to the hospital with bile duct stones.
What is the name of these stones?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Primary stone
 
  • Stones that form in the Bile Duct can cause primary choledocholithiasis, or they can move from the gallbladder to the Bile Duct, causing secondary choledocholithiasis.
  • Primary choledocholithiasis was defined as those that appeared two years after cholecystectomy, whereas residual or secondary choledocholithiasis was defined as those that appeared in the first two years following cholecystectomy.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 642.

questions.text: Three days after having a cholecystectomy, the patient came with tachycardia and stomach pain. He has an 11,000/mm3 WBC count. A 5 x 5 cm collection in the right hypochondrium was observed on USG. What is the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. USG guided pig tail drainage

The given scenario is of Bile leak followed by development of abscess. 
 
* Pigtail drainage:
 
  • In image-guided percutaneous drainage, an abscess or other collection of fluid or air is drained using a catheter (a small tube). 
  • Abscess development is the most frequent complication of leftover gallstones following cholecystectomy. 
  • The intraperitoneal and extraperitoneal spaces are where the abscess is located. 
  • Pigtail catheters are a safe and non-invasive alternative to tube thoracostomy that provide effective treatment for minor effusions and pneumothorax.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 68.

questions.text: A patient has several gallstones, each measuring 12 mm in diameter, and their S. Bilirubin, ALP, and GGT levels are all increased five times above the recommended level. What is the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. ERCP
 
  • Magnetic repulsion Cholangiopancreatography is used to determine the obstruction's source. 
  • ERCP is the best choice if the patient had jaundice. MRCP is performed because the serum bilirubin level is within normal limits. 
  • MRCP is an excellent imaging of the gallbladder and biliary system using a non-invasive method. 
  • The accuracy of MRCP's non-invasive biliary tract imaging is comparable to that of direct cholangiography performed using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC). 
  • The biliary tree can be photographed to show ductal obstruction, strictures, or other intraductal abnormalities.
MRCP- 
A rapid, noninvasive modality that provides detailed bile duct and pancreatic duct images equal to those of ERCP Sensitivity ≈93% and specificity ≈94%, comparable with those for ERCP Useful for examining nondilated ducts, particularly at the distal portion, which often is not well visualized by US Adjacent structures such as the liver and pancreas can be examined at the same time
Recommended for patients with low to moderate clinical probability of choledocholithiasis.

ERCP- 
ERCP is the standard diagnostic test for stones in the BD, with sensitivity and specificity of ≈95%Use of ERCP to extract stones (or at least drain infected bile) is life-saving in severe cholangitis and reduces the need for BD exploration at the time of cholecystectomy Recommended for patients with a high clinical probability of choledocholithiasis
When contrast agent flows retrograde into the gallbladder, stones appear as filling defects and can be detected with a sensitivity rate of ≈80%, but US remains the mainstay for confirming cholelithiasis



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1236.

choices.text: Laparoscopic exploration of CBD and removal of stone
Laparoscopic CBD extraction through the cystic duct

questions.text: While performing a laparoscopic surgery, a surgeon with little experience in laparoscopic cholecystectomy discovered some stones in the common bile duct. What should he do, ideally?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Open CBD exploration
 
  • The surgeon should consider his or her limitations and be able to determine when degree of difficulty or uncertainty necessitates conversion of laparoscopic to open cholecystectomy.
  • Lap CBD exploration is an advanced surgery and if surgeon is not trained for this then he should convert the case and do open cholecystectomy and open CBD exploration.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1251.

questions.text: Where does cholangiocarcinoma typically occur?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. Hilum

Most common site of cholangiocarcinoma is hilum.
  • They are divided into 3 types based  on pathogenesis-
    Sclerosing, Nodular, Papillary.
  • Clinical Features-
    Painless jaundice is MC symptom of cholangiocarcinoma, followed by pruritus, abdominal pain, weight loss ,fever.
  • Cholangio carcinomas are tumors arising from bile duct epithelium, most commonly adenocarcinomas.
  • MC gene mutation: K-ras >p16.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1216.

questions.text: Which of the following does not appear to be raised in a youngster with jaundice, icterus, pruritus, and clay-colored stools?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3. Glutamate dehydrogenase

Glutamate dehydrogenase is not elevated in obstructive jaundice. Increase in serum levels of this enzyme are indicative of hepatocellular necrosis.
Enzymes Elevated in Cholestasis/Obstructive Jaundice-
•â€‹ALP
•â€‹5'-Nucleotidase
•â€‹Gamma glutamyl transpeptidase

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1194.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be determined by a USG in a patient with a surgical cause of obstructive jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Peritoneal deposits

In this patient, USG can tell all of the following except peritoneal deposits.
 
  • Peritoneal deposits are not detected by ultrasound. Even CECT can miss the peritoneal deposits.
  • ï¿²Best investigation for diagnosis of peritoneal deposits is diagnostic laparoscopy.
  • ï¿²Ultrasound does not reveal peritoneal deposits. The peritoneal deposits may even be missed by CECT.
  • ï¿²Diagnostic laparoscopy is the best test to diagnose peritoneal deposits.ï¿²
Other options- 
  • USG easily detects GB stones and minimal ascites
  • It can also detect biliary obstruction by Intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation. 
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1141.

questions.text: What are the organisms associated with fish consumption that also cause carcinoma of the gallbladder called?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Clonorchis sinesis
 
  • Organism associated with fish consumption that also cause carcinoma gall bladder is clonorchis sinensis.
  • Clonorchis sinensis is a liver fluke acquired by ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked freshwater fishes.
  • And it is a well known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 680.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of biliary obstruction symptoms in a patient who has eaten fish while on vacation?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Clonorchis sinesis

Clonorchis sinensis is the most probable etiology.

Clonorchis sinensis is a liver fluke acquired by ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked freshwater fishes.
And it is a well known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 680.

choices.text: Amoebic liver abscess in the right lobe

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses is not a possible cause for an elevated right hemidiaphragm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Acute cholecystitis

All of the following are possible diagnoses except acute cholecystitis as a cause for elevated right hemidiaphragm.

* Causes of elevated hemidiaphragm: 
ï¿²1. Atelectasis
ï¿²2. Lobectomy
ï¿²3. Pulmonary hypoplasia
ï¿²4. Phrenic nerve palsy
ï¿²5. subphrenic abscess
ï¿²6. Amoebic and pyogenic liver abscess

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1499.

questions.text: What would be the investigation of choice for obstructive jaundice due to gallstone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: MRI
 
  • MRI provides detailed images of the biliary system, including the bile ducts, gallbladder, and liver, allowing for the visualization of any obstructions or abnormalities.
  • MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) is a specific MRI technique used to evaluate the biliary system.
  • Other imaging modalities, such as ultrasound or CT scan, may also be used in the evaluation of obstructive jaundice, but MRI with MRCP is considered the most comprehensive and accurate imaging technique for this condition.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1495.

questions.text: According to the AAST scale for grading liver injuries, what grade are hepatic avulsions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Grade VI
 
  • Grade VI liver injuries are defined as hepatic avulsions, which involve complete disruption or detachment of the liver from its blood supply and surrounding structures.
  • This type of injury is highly critical and requires immediate surgical intervention. It is associated with extensive damage to the liver and significant hemorrhage.
  • Grade VI injuries are often associated with high mortality rates and necessitate complex surgical procedures to control bleeding, repair the liver, and restore vascular supply.

* AAST (American Association for the Surgery of Trauma) scale for grading liver injuries:



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 417.

questions.text: Which segments have been resected where a surgeon excises a portion of liver to the left of the attachment of the falciform ligament?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Segment 2 and 3 
 
  • When a portion of the liver is excised to the left of the attachment of the falciform ligament, it involves the resection of segments 2 and 3.
  • Segment 2 is located in the left lateral lobe of the liver, while segment 3 is located in the left medial lobe.
  • The falciform ligament separates the liver into left and right lobes, and resecting to the left of its attachment specifically involves segments 2 and 3.
  • Segment 1 refers to the caudate lobe, and segment 4 is located in the right lobe of the liver, so they are not involved in this particular resection.
* Segmental Classification of Liver Lobes:


* Surgical procedures: 





Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1192.

questions.text: Which of the following is a term used for pain in the right upper quadrant due to adhesions and inflammation between the liver and the diaphragm is
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome 
 
  • Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome is a sequela of chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which refers to the inflammation of the liver capsule without the involvement of liver parenchyma.
  • Laparoscopy reveals adhesive bands extending from the fallopian tube on the right side to the undersurface of the liver accounting for the right upper quadrant pain.

* PID pain differentials:



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1406.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for congenital biliary atresia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Kasai procedure
 
  • The preferred treatment for congenital biliary atresia is the Kasai procedure.
  • The Kasai procedure (Hepatoportoenterostomy) involves creating a surgical connection between the liver and the small intestine to bypass the obstructed bile ducts.
  • This procedure aims to restore bile flow and prevent further damage to the liver.
  • Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.
* Types of Biliary Atresia: 



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 382.

questions.text: 1. Except for_______  , all of the following bind the gastrinoma triangle.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Spleen vein and inferior mesenteric vein

Except for the spleen vein and inferior mesenteric vein (option D), all of the following structures bind the gastrinoma triangle.
  • The gastrinoma triangle is an anatomical region in the upper abdomen that is commonly associated with the presence of gastrinomas, tumors that produce excessive amounts of gastrin.
  • Gastrinoma is most commonly located in the gastrinoma triangle (Passaro's triangle) bounded by the lines connecting the:
  • Cystic duct
  • Junction between the second and third parts of the duodenum
  • Junction between the neck and body of the pancreas


Fig: Gastrinoma triangle

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1139.

questions.text: A young patient presented with jaundice. Laboratory test revealed a bilirubin of 21 mg/dl, conjugated bilirubin is 9.6 mg/dl and alkaline phosphatase is 450 IU/I. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of elevated levels of ALP with bilirubin- conjugated and unconjugated elevated are indicative of obstructive jaundice. 

Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Hemolytic anemia will result in isolated elevation of unconjugated bilirubin. 
  • Option 2 and 3- Hepatic cause of jaundice will result in elevated levels of AST and ALT out of proportion to ALP. Increase in bilirubin is also seen. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 315-319.

Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 135.

choices.text: Preferential visualization of GB on HIDA scan.

questions.text: Which of the following is false in case of acute cholecystitis?
questions.solution:
HIDA Scan is Gold standard for diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. (Finding: Non-visualization of GB in acute cholecystitis).
 
  • Triad of acute cholecystitis: Right upper quadrant pain, Fever, Leucocytosis.
  • Murphy's sign is elicited in patients with acute cholecystitis by asking the patient to take in and hold a deep breath while palpating the right subcostal area. If pain occurs when the inflamed gallbladder comes into contact with the examiner's hand, Murphy's sign is positive.
  • It is positive in acute cholecystitis
 
  • Imaging:
    • Ultrasound: Gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm), pericholecystic fluid, and sonographic Murphy's sign.
    • HIDA scan: Non-visualization of the gallbladder due to obstruction of the cystic duct.
 
  • Lab findings: Leukocytosis, elevated inflammatory markers (CRP), and sometimes mild liver enzyme elevation.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 212, 213, 1199, 1200.

questions.text: All of the following are correct about Type I choledochal cyst, except?
questions.solution:
Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilatation of intra and extra hepatic biliary tree.
The usual presentation is triad of Jaundice, abdominal pain and mass.
Todani Classification is used to classify Choledochal cysts.

Type I choledochal cysts has increased risk of malignancy, hence complete resection is advised.
Type V choledochal cyst is also called Caroli disease for which the TOC is Liver transplantation.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 27th Edition, Page. No- 1197.

questions.text: 55y old female treated with Lap Cholecystectomy for Cholelithiasis with Biopsy revealing GB carcinoma infiltrating the muscularis layer. What is the Management?
questions.solution:
Stage Ia and Ib- Standard Cholecystectomy
Stage Ib with perineural and lymphovascular invasion and II- Extended Cholecystectomy .
Radiation has no role. Chemotherapy not advised in early GB cancer.
* Extra Edge: 
Survival of patients diagnosed with gallbladder cancer is dependent on the stage of disease at presentation and whether surgical resection is performed. Independent factors affecting survival include T status, N status, histologic differentiation, CBD involvement, and R0 resection. Advances in surgical management and extent of resection have led to improvements in survival in surgical patients, although most patients present with late-stage disease and are not candidates for resection. Patients with T1a lesions, limited to the mucosa and lamina propria, have an excellent prognosis. Complete resection of T1b lesions to negative margins also affords an excellent prognosis.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1519.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for Gall Bladder Cancer?
questions.solution:
Risk Factors for GB carcinoma-
  • Gall stone >3cm
  • Porcelain GB
  • Obesity
  • Primary sclerosing Cholangitis
  • GB polyp >1cm
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Salmonella typhi infection.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 20th Edition, Page. No- 1538.

questions.text: What is the classification used to classify bile duct injuries based on vascular supply and location of the injury?
questions.solution:
Hannover classification - Bile duct injuries based on vascular and location of injury
Strasberg- Anatomically classify bile duct injury
Todani- Classification of Choledochal cyst
Mcmahon- Classify based on width of bile duct injury.

* Extra edge: 
Type Description
A Peripheral bile leakage
B Stricture of the common hepatic duct (CHD) or common bile duct (CBD) without injury
C Lateral CHD or CBD injury, including vascular injuries
D Total transaction of the CHD, including vascular injuries
E Late bile duct stenosis of the main bile duct

Reference: Bektas H, Kleine M, Tamac A, Klempnauer J, Schrem H. Clinical application of the hanover classification for iatrogenic bile duct lesions. HPB Surg. 2011;2011:612384. doi: 10.1155/2011/612384. Epub 2012 Jan 5. PMID: 22271972; PMCID: PMC3261461.

questions.text: Management of grade 2 splenic injury with no active bleeding in an 8-year-old child is
questions.solution:
Splenic injuries in children are commonly graded from I to V based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) classification.

Grade II splenic injury:

  • Laceration 1–3 cm in depth or subcapsular hematoma 10–50% of surface area

  • No active bleeding on imaging

Management principles in children:

  • Non-operative (conservative) management is preferred for hemodynamically stable children without active bleeding.

  • Monitoring: Vital signs, serial hemoglobin, abdominal exams, and imaging if needed

  • Indications for surgery: Hemodynamic instability, ongoing bleeding, or higher-grade injuries

Other options:

  • Splenectomy: Reserved for grade IV–V injuries or uncontrolled bleeding

  • Splenorrhaphy: Surgical repair if bleeding is significant but spleen can be preserved

  • Embolization: Considered in select cases with active bleeding but stable hemodynamics

questions.text: A newborn presents with jaundice. Biliary atresia is suspected when jaundice is persistent and exceeds:
questions.solution:
Biliary atresia is a progressive fibro-obliterative disease of the extrahepatic bile ducts in neonates.

Key points:

  • Normal neonatal jaundice: Usually resolves within 1–2 weeks.

  • Suspicion for biliary atresia:

    • Jaundice persisting beyond 2 weeks in full-term infants

    • Acholic (pale) stools

    • Dark urine

    • Hepatomegaly may be present

  • Early diagnosis is critical because Kasai portoenterostomy performed before 8 weeks offers the best prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma:
â— Chronic inflammatory conditions- PSC, Oriental cholangiohepatitis, Hepatitis C infection
â— Parasitic infections- Opisthorchis viverrini, C. sinensis
â— Congenital - Choledochal cysts, Caroli's disease
â— Chemical agents- Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast), Vinyl chloride,
Dioxin, Asbestos

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 1256.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with fever and weight loss. He gives a history of blood in the stools and vomiting 2 weeks ago. On examination, there is right hypochondriac tenderness and hepatomegaly. Abdominal CT a lesion in the right lobe of the liver with ragged edges, multiple septations, and heterogenous densities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of fever, hepatomegaly, and tenderness in the hypochondrium suggests a liver abscess. In a patient with a history of blood in the stools and vomiting, this points toward an amoebic liver abscess.

Amoebic liver abscesses are more common in males aged 20–40, particularly those with a history of travel to endemic regions. The condition is caused by the ingestion of Entamoebahistolytica cysts, initially leading to diarrhea. The trophozoites then reach the liver via the portal venous system, resulting in an abscess, with 80% of cases affecting the right lobe. Clinical features include right upper quadrant pain, tenderness, fever, hepatomegaly, and diarrhea.

Enzyme immunoassays, which detect antibodies against the parasite, have high sensitivity and specificity. Ultrasonography and CT scans can visualize the liver abscess, typically without a peripheral rim of enhancement.

The primary treatment for amoebic abscesses is metronidazole, which is curative in over 90% of cases. Luminal agents, such as diloxanidefuroate, are used to treat the carrier state. Abscess aspiration is recommended in cases where there is a high risk of rupture.
 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 66-69 .

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumor marker for pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution: Carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is a cell surface glycoprotein complex most commonly associated with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). Another common application of CA 19-9 in the biliary tract includes its use as an adjunct in diagnosing cholangiocarcinoma. Ref-Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • Page 668

questions.text: Identify the following structure seen in Calot's triangle during laparoscopic surgery
questions.solution:
In the given intra-op image during laparoscopic cholecystectomy the structure marked is a cystic artery. Hepatocystic triangle is defined as the triangle formed by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior edge of the liver.
Gray's anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice - 42nd edition • Page 1219

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image:
questions.solution:
ERCP is an abbreviation for a medical procedure called Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography that combines upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy and x-rays to to study the bile ducts, pancreatic duct and gallbladder and to treat problems of the bile and pancreatic ducts. Ampulla of Vater is cannulated and then a contrast-filled dye is injected for evaluation of the biliary and pancreatic tree. After a pathology has been diagnosed in CBD, a CBD stent can be placed.
Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology 6th edition • Page no: 780, 804

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day two, the patient came back to the hospital with complaints of increasing abdominal pain and was febrile on examination. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5cmcollection in the subhepatic space. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Post-laparoscopic cholecystectomy complications include:

Complication Presentation Timing
Bile leak Abdominal pain, fever, localized collection on imaging 1–7 days postop
Infection/abscess Fever, leukocytosis, collection—but typically later >3–5 days postop
Retained stones May present with jaundice, cholangitis Variable (usually late)
Surgical site pain No fever or collection on imaging Early postop day 1–2

In this case,

  • Fever + abdominal pain on post-op day 2

  • Ultrasound shows subhepatic collection

  • Drain removed on day 1, but new collection appears after

→ Most likely diagnosis: Bile leak, typically from a cystic duct stump or accessory duct injury.

Next Step:

  • Confirm with CT/MRCP or HIDA scan

  • Percutaneous drainage + ERCP with stenting if required


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1204

questions.text: A 40-year old lady is found to have a gall bladder polyp of size 5 mm on abdominal USG with no associated gall bladder stones. She appears to be healthy and is asymptomatic. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
In a 40-year-old asymptomatic woman with a 5 mm gallbladder (GB) polyp and no gallstones, the recommended management is surveillance with regular follow-up — typically by serial ultrasonography.

Guidelines for Management of Gallbladder Polyps:

Polyp Size Associated Gallstones Age >50 years Suspicious Features Management
<5 mm Absent No No No action or annual USG
5–9 mm Absent No No 6-monthly or annual USG
≥10 mm Irrespective Irrelevant Irrelevant Cholecystectomy
Any size Present >50 or symptoms Sessile, vascular, rapid growth Consider surgery

Key Points for This Case:

  • Polyp is <10 mm.

  • Patient is <50 years, asymptomatic, no gallstones, and no high-risk features.

  • Hence, serial USG follow-up every 6 to 12 months is sufficient.

  • No surgery needed unless the polyp increases in size or other risk factors develop.



Reference: Sabiston textbook of Surgery 20th edition Page no 1514

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common side effect after cholecystectomy is steatorrhea (fatty stools), especially shortly after surgery.

Why?

  • The gallbladder stores and releases bile, which is essential for fat digestion.

  • After cholecystectomy, bile is released continuously but in small amounts, not in a regulated, bolus fashion in response to meals.

  • This impaired fat digestion can lead to:

    • Steatorrhea (fatty, foul-smelling stools)

    • Bloating and diarrhea (sometimes called post-cholecystectomy syndrome)

      Other Options:

Option Why Incorrect
1. Osteoporosis Not a recognized complication of cholecystectomy.
3. Acute kidney injury Not directly related unless due to perioperative complications, which are rare.
4. Colorectal cancer Some weak associations exist in literature, but not a common or direct side effect.

questions.text: A 3 year old child is diagnosed to have hernia with hydrocele. What is the line of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Management of hydrocele of the hernia sac (congenital hydrocele) in a 3 years old child is herniotomy.
 
  • A patent processus vaginalis may allow only peritoneal fluid to track down around the testis to form a hydrocoele.
  • Hydrocele are unilateral or bilateral, asymptomatic, tender scrotal swellings.
  • They may be tense or lax, but typically transilluminate.
  • The majority resolve spontaneously as the processus continues to obliterate, but surgical ligation is recommended in boys older than three years of age.

Fig: Hydrocele

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 256.

questions.text: Unintentionally, a staple was positioned below and lateral to the iliopubic tract during laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery. The patient reported thigh pain and soreness following the surgery. Which nerve is involved in this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of inadvertent placement of surgical stapler in the triangle of pain during laparoscopic mesh repair of inguinal hernia involving lateral cutaneous of thigh causing thigh pain.
 

Fig: Mesh fixation with tacks. 1. above the pubic bone; 2. medial to epigastric vessels; 3. lateral to inferior epigastric vessels, 4. Two centimeters above iliopubic tract

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1074.

questions.text: Which incision is the most effective for diaphragmatic surgery?
questions.solution:
Circumferential incisions in diaphragm are the safest incisions as they result in little loss of function. These circumferential incisions, however, must be at least 5 cm lateral to the edge of the central tendon to avoid the posterolateral and anterolateral branches of the phrenic nerve




Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 163.

choices.text: The hernia lies above and medial to pubic tubercle
This type of hernia is most common in children

questions.text: A child came in with a swelling in the right groin area. A gurgling sound appeared when the swelling subsided. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The incorrect statement in this scenario is:

1. The sac contains omentum only.

Given that the child has a swelling in the right groin area, and a gurgling sound is heard when the swelling subsides, the most likely diagnosis is an indirect inguinal hernia
Hernia sac in an indirect inguinal hernia can contain not just omentum but also bowel loops (usually small intestine). While the sac may contain omentum, it more commonly contains loops of the intestine, and in some cases, both omentum and bowel

An inguinal hernia can be differentiated from a femoral hernia by ascertaining the relation of the neck of the sac to the medial end of the inguinal ligament and the pubic tubercle, i.e. in the case of an inguinal hernia the neck is above and medial, whereas that of a femoral hernia is below and lateral.
Whereas the neck of the indirect hernia is lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, the direct hernia usually emerges medial to this except in the saddle bag or pantaloon type, which has both a lateral and a medial component.
An indirect hernia travels down the canal on the outer (lateral and anterior) side of the spermatic cord.
A direct hernia comes out directly forward through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1060.

questions.text:
Accidentally, a stapler was positioned below and lateral to the iliopubic tract during laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery.
Following surgery, the patient reported thigh pain and soreness. This is due to the involvement of:
questions.solution:
The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is located below and lateral to the iliopubic tract and is highly likely to be injured during laparoscopic hernia repair.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1070.

choices.text: Located below the umbilicus and always in the midline
Located above the umbilicus and always in the midline
Located above the umbilicus and on either side

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about an epigastric hernia?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 2. Located above the umbilicus and always in the midline.

Explanation:

An epigastric hernia is a type of abdominal wall hernia that occurs in the epigastric region, which is the area of the abdomen above the umbilicus and typically between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus. It occurs in the midline of the abdomen, along the linea alba (the fibrous structure that runs vertically in the midline of the abdomen).

Let's review the options:

  1. Located below the umbilicus and always in the midline:
    This is incorrect. An epigastric hernia is located above the umbilicus, not below it. Hernias located below the umbilicus are typically umbilical hernias.

  2. Located above the umbilicus and always in the midline:
    This is correct. Epigastric hernias occur in the epigastric region, which is located above the umbilicus, and they typically occur in the midline of the abdomen along the linea alba.

  3. Located above the umbilicus and on either side:
    This is incorrect. Epigastric hernias occur in the midline, not on either side of the umbilicus. Hernias on either side of the umbilicus are more likely to be inguinal or ventral hernias.

  4. Can be seen anywhere on the abdomen:
    This is incorrect. Epigastric hernias are specifically located above the umbilicus and in the midline. Other types of hernias (e.g., umbilical, inguinal, femoral, incisional) can occur in different locations on the abdomen.

Conclusion:

An epigastric hernia is typically located above the umbilicus and in the midline, making option 2 the correct statement.



Fig: Epigastric hernia

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1074.

questions.text: Identify the appropriate mesh used in Hernia surgery:
questions.solution:
Most appropriate mesh used in hernia surgery is light weight and with large pores.

The light weight mesh have the benefit of lower postoperative pain and lower inflammation as compared to other types.
Large pores are important because they allow for better tissue integration and reduced risk of infection. Larger pores also enable better fluid drainage, which helps to avoid complications such as seroma or abscess formation


Fig: Lichtenstein’s repair


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1068.

questions.text: Which of the following are examples of M3 incisional hernias, as defined by the European Hernia Society:
questions.solution:
M3 incisional hernia as per EHS classification is Umbilical hernia.

* EHS Classification:


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1073.

questions.text:
Hernia surgery is currently taking place in the operating room. Near the inferior epigastric artery, the sac is located medially.
What exactly is a hernia and how is it treated?
questions.solution:
• Surgery of Choice for direct inguinal hernia is Lichtenstein tension free mesh hernioplasty.
  • It has the least recurrence rate.
  • A Lichtenstein repair of a direct hernia is a tension-free mesh repair.
  • The direct hernia is isolated from the cord structures, and then invaginated back into the abdominal cavity. The defect in the wall is then closed by suture, after which the mesh is fixed to bridge the defect.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1068.

questions.text: Lumbar puncture is being performed by you. Which structure will you encounter last?
questions.solution:
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous and interspinous ligaments, ligamentum flavum, epidural space containing the internal spinal venous plexus, dura, arachnoid, and lastly the subarachnoid space are all punctured by the lumbar puncture needle in that order.



Reference: Jane LA, Wray AA. Lumbar Puncture. [Updated 2023 Jul 24]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557553/

questions.text: A femoral hernia is discovered in a patient. Which of the following structures is directly lateral to the hernia sac?
questions.solution:
• Femoral vein lies immediately lateral to the sac of hernia.
  • The upper opening of the most medial compartment of the femoral sheath (femoral canal), also known as the femoral ring, contains lymphatics and Cloquet or Rossenmuller lymph nodes.
  • The lateral compartment is inhabited by the femoral artery, which is separated from the femoral ring by the femoral vein in an intermediate compartment.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1059.

choices.text: Surgery should not be done unless patient becomes symptomatic
Hernia in children is treated with herniotomy
Absorbable mesh should not be used for surgery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about hernia surgery?
questions.solution:
All are true about hernia surgery except surgery should not be done unless patient becomes symptomatic.
  • The basic operation is inguinal herniotomy, which entails dissecting out and opening the hernial sac, reducing any content and then transfixing the neck of the sac and removing the remainder.
  • It is employed either by itself or as the first step in a repair procedure (herniorrhaphy).
  • By itself, it is sufficient for the treatment of hernia in infants, adolescents and young adults.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1062.

choices.text: Watchful waiting and follow up if symptomatic
Surgical repair on the next elective list
Emergency surgical repair with exploration of the bowel

questions.text: A reducible hernia beneath the inguinal ligament is discovered in an asymptomatic healthy patient. Which of the following management strategies should be considered?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Surgical repair on the next elective list
 
  • In an asymptomatic healthy patient with a reducible hernia beneath the inguinal ligament, surgical repair on the next elective list is the recommended management strategy.
  • Surgical repair aims to reinforce the weakened area and prevent the hernia from becoming incarcerated or strangulated in the future.
  • Elective repair allows for proper planning and preparation, minimizing the risk of complications and ensuring optimal outcomes.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1062.

questions.text: What nerve is most susceptible to damage during laparoscopic hernia surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct answer 4. Lateral Femoral cutaneous nerve 

Lateral Femoral cutaneous nerve is the most commonly injured nerve in laparoscopic hernia repair. Ilioinguinal is most common nerve injured during open hernia repair. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1070.

questions.text: All of the following surround the "Triangle of Doom," except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Inguinal ligament

* The triangle of doom:


Fig: The triangle of doom

* Contents of the Space:
  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1605.

questions.text: Open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Stoppa operation
 
  • The open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia is known as the Stoppa operation.
  • It involves creating a pre-peritoneal space and placing a large mesh in this space to provide support and reinforcement to the weakened abdominal wall.
  • The mesh is positioned behind the transversalis fascia, covering the potential spaces where hernias can occur.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1125.

questions.text: Fibres of Internal Oblique and tranverse abdominus muscle contribute to which walls of Inguinal Canal?
questions.solution:
Anterior wall- External Oblique Aponeurosis
Posterior wall- Transversalis fascia and Conjoint tendon[Transverse abdominis and Internal oblique]
Roof- Transverse abdominis and Internal oblique.
Floor- Inguinal ligament.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 1065.

questions.text: What is the type of hernia in which the internal organ composes a portion of the wall of the hernia sac?
questions.solution:
A sliding hernia is a type of hernia in which part of the wall of the hernia sac is formed by a retroperitoneal organ, commonly:

  • Sigmoid colon (left side)

  • Cecum (right side)

  • Urinary bladder

  • Lumbar hernia: Herniation through the posterolateral abdominal wall (lumbar triangles); organ does not form the sac wall.

  • Spigelian hernia: Hernia through the Spigelian fascia (lateral abdominal wall); sac wall is normal peritoneum.

  • Richter’s hernia: Only part of the circumference of the bowel wall herniates, not the sac wall itself.

choices.text: 5 years. He has a history of penetrating stab injury at the same site. On examination, the swelling was >12 cm and was partially reducible with a palpable cough impulse. Which of the following is the best way to manage this patient's condition?

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling over his abdomen for 1.5 years. He has a history of penetrating stab injury at the same site. On examination, the swelling was >12 cm and was partially reducible with a palpable cough impulse. Which of the following is the best way to manage this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has a large incisional hernia (>12 cm) developing at the site of a previous penetrating abdominal injury. Such hernias occur due to weakness of the abdominal wall following surgery or trauma.

  • Wait and monitor: Not appropriate, as the hernia is large and progressive.

  • Primary suture repair: Suitable only for small defects (<2–3 cm). For large hernias, it has a high recurrence rate.

  • Fascial closure with a mesh: Best option. For large (>10 cm) or recurrent incisional hernias, tension-free mesh repair (onlay, sublay, or underlay) provides strength and minimizes recurrence.

  • Mayo’s repair: Used for small umbilical hernias, not for large incisional hernias.

Large incisional hernia → Mesh repair is the treatment of choice.

questions.text:
A patient presents with dull aching pain in both legs. He gives a history of prolonged standing and tortuous veins in the legs. Which of the following tests are done for saphenofemoral incompetence?
A. Brodie Trendelenburg Test
B. Morrissey's test
C. Fegan's test
D. Modified Perthes test
questions.solution:
