questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. Skin grafting was done wherein the graft was taken from the same person. Which type of graft is it?
questions.solution:
The image illustrates a split skin graft that has been harvested from the same individual, qualifying it as an autograft.

Overview:
Skin grafting involves transferring skin from a donor site to a recipient site. The preferred donor site, particularly in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children, is the buttocks, while the thigh is the most commonly utilized donor site.

Autograft Definition:
An autograft refers to the transfer of tissue from one area of the body to another on the same patient.

Types of Skin Grafts:
Skin grafts can be broadly classified into two categories:

1. Split-Thickness Skin Graft (Thiersch Graft):

This type consists of partial-thickness skin, including the epidermis and a portion of the dermis.
A lesser amount of dermis in a split-thickness graft results in reduced primary contraction (the degree of graft shrinkage in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and increased secondary contraction (the degree of graft shrinkage during the healing process).
2. Full-Thickness Skin Graft (Wolfe Graft):

This graft includes the entire epidermis and dermis, along with portions of sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles.
A greater amount of dermis in a full-thickness skin graft leads to increased primary contraction and reduced secondary contraction.

questions.text: Following a crush injury to both legs in a road traffic accident, a patient was urgently taken for below knee amputation. What is the rationale behind the procedure ?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario below knee amputation is carried out following a crush injury as it is a life saving procedure. Major amputations can be done for,
• Dead limb -Gangrene
• Deadly limb- Wet gangrene, spreading infection (gas gangrene), malignancy
• Dead loss limb- Severe critical rest pain which cannot be revascularized paralvsis. trauma etc.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition • Page no 952

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the following clinical finding seen?
questions.solution:
The “raccoon eyes” or periorbital ecchymosis (bruising around both eyes) is a classic clinical sign of anterior cranial fossa fractures.

Key points:

  • Occurs due to blood tracking from the anterior cranial fossa into the periorbital tissues through the orbital septum and soft tissue planes.

  • Often accompanied by CSF rhinorrhea if the fracture involves the cribriform plate.

  • Middle cranial fossa fracture: May show Battle’s sign (mastoid ecchymosis) and CSF otorrhea.

  • Posterior cranial fossa fracture: Rare; may also have occipital swelling but not typical raccoon eyes.

  • Epidural hematoma: Usually presents with lucid interval and neurological deterioration, not periorbital ecchymosis.

Hence, raccoon eyes are seen in anterior cranial fossa fractures.

choices.text: The ER doctor decides to intubate him. What is the preferred method of securing airway for this patient?

questions.text: A patient is brought in to the casualty with maxillofacial trauma after an RTA. He is unconscious with a dropping SpO2. The ER doctor decides to intubate him. What is the preferred method of securing airway for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has maxillofacial trauma, is unconscious, and has falling oxygen saturation, indicating a compromised airway.

  • In such cases, orotracheal or nasotracheal intubation may be difficult or dangerous due to facial fractures, bleeding, or distorted anatomy.

  • Tracheostomy (or an emergency surgical airway) is the preferred and definitive method to secure the airway in severe maxillofacial trauma.

  • Other options:

    • Mask ventilation: Temporary measure, may be ineffective in severe facial trauma.

    • Nasotracheal intubation: Contraindicated in basal skull fractures or midface fractures.

    • Laryngeal mask airway (LMA): Useful as a bridge but not definitive, especially if long-term airway control is needed.



Reference: Millers anesthesia 8th edition page no 2535

questions.text: A patient was rushed to the emergency department after being hit in the head in a road traffic accident The patient was unconscious. CT-scan revealed an extradural hematoma. Which of the following is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
• Extradural (epidural) hematoma is most commonly caused by laceration of the middle meningeal artery.

  • The pterion is the thinnest part of the lateral skull, where the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones meet. It lies directly over the middle meningeal artery, making it highly susceptible to trauma.

  • Other options:

    • Angle of mandible: Not related to epidural hematoma.

    • Lambdoid suture: More commonly associated with posterior skull fractures; less likely for EDH.

    • Suprameatal triangle: Relevant in mastoid or posterior cranial fossa approaches, not typical for EDH.

Key point: Trauma to the pterion → middle meningeal artery injury → epidural hematoma.



Reference: Pages 419 and 432 of Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice, 41st edition.

Reference:Grays Anatomy:The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no 419 and 432

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to the ER after he was hit by a motorbike while he was crossing the road. He sustained injuries over his abdomen with visible bruising. His blood pressure is 88/60 and IV fluids are immediately instituted. A FAST was done and it was positive. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient? FAST: (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma)
questions.solution:
This patient is hemodynamically unstable (BP 88/60 mmHg) following blunt abdominal trauma and has a positive FAST scan, indicating free fluid (likely blood) in the peritoneal cavity.

Key Management Algorithm for Blunt Abdominal Trauma:

Clinical Status FAST Result Next Step
Unstable Positive Exploratory laparotomy
Unstable Negative Search for other bleeding sources (e.g., chest, pelvis)
Stable Positive CT abdomen with contrast
Stable Negative Observation or further imaging

Other options: 

  • Abdominal MRI: Not used in acute trauma — too slow and not practical in emergencies.

  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL): Used when FAST is equivocal or not available — here, FAST is already positive.

  • CT scan: Only done if the patient is hemodynamically stable. This patient is unstable.

    Summary:

In blunt abdominal trauma with hypotension and a positive FAST scan → immediate exploratory laparotomy is indicated.


Reference Online Resource - https://www.uptodate.com/contents/initial-evaluation-and-management-of-blunt-abdominal-trauma-in-adults?search=blunt%20abdominal%20trauma&source=search_result&selectedTitle=1~150&usage_type=default&display_rank=1 #H11

questions.text: A woman had a vaginal hysterectomy because she had cervix cancer. Her urethral catheter was removed during surgery, and she later complained of urine incontinence. She was found to be incontinent continuously, as well as voiding normally. Through her urethra, methylene blue dye was injected into her bladder, and phenazopyridine dye was administered orally. When her pads were checked later, the topmost pad had a yellow stain, but neither the middle nor the bottom pads did. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient methylene blue dye was instilled in the bladder and was given oral phenazopyridine dye. Pad showed yellow staining at the top portion, but not the middle or bottom portions. She is likely to have Ureterovaginal fistula.



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1791.

questions.text: Select the drug that is useful for treatment of advanced prostate cancer.
questions.solution:
Goserelin
A synthetic analog of a  gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH).
Given in non-pulsatile manner(non-physiological) - it decreases testosterone production and is hence used for treating Prostate cancer.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 598.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a fever has a history of recurrent ureteric calculi. The right side of the kidney was removed. Histology shows 
  • Tubular thyroidization (filled with colloid casts), tubular atrophy
  • Interstitial fibrosis and inflammation (intense diffuse lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory infiltrate with germinal centers).
What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Recurrent ureteric stones may cause recurrent pyelonephritis.
Tubular hybridization, tubular atrophy, Interstitial fibrosis and inflammation all point toward Chronic pyelonephritis. 
The given image below shows the above mentioned histopathology features of chronic pyelonephritis


Fig: HPE of Chronic Pyelonephritis

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1470.

questions.text: A female patient aged 28, who also had dysmenorrhea, appeared with lower abdomen pain. Laparoscopic examination revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Chocolate cyst
  • It is brought on by endometriosis and develops when a microscopic patch of endometrial tissue, which is the mucous membrane that lines the interior of the uterine wall, bleeds, sheds, gets transplanted, and grows and enlarges inside the ovaries.
  • Over the course of months and years, the blood thickens and turns brown. When it ruptures, the substance leaks onto the surface of the uterus, bladder, intestine, and the corresponding gaps between them, as well as into the pelvis.
  • In other cases given in option there would be bulky ovaries. 

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1802.

questions.text: A patient's complex kidney cyst was unintentionally discovered on ultrasound, and as a result, he received a CT for an insurance workup. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Because most angiomyolipomas contain substantial amounts of adipose tissue, therefore it appears hypodense in the CECT image.

US shows a bright echogenic mass lesion on account of the high fat content. CT scan shows an intralesional fat density of –15 to –20 Hounsfield units (HU) within the mass, which is the hallmark of an angiomyolipoma radiological diagnosis. Management depends upon the size of the tumour, the risk of haemorrhage (Wonderlich syndrome) and the symptoms.

Angiomyolipomas are seen in Tuberous Sclerosis complex. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1481.

questions.text: An ultrasound was requested by a 65-year-old male banker in order to renew his health insurance. A complicated cyst was discovered in the right kidney, and hence underwent a CT. The CT scan image is shown below. The most likely possibility is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Renal cell carcinoma
 
  • The CT scan image shows a solid mass with irregular borders in the right kidney, which is highly suspicious for renal cell carcinoma.
  • Renal cell carcinoma is the most common type of kidney cancer, accounting for approximately 85% of all cases.
  • Contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for RCC. On CT, small lesions enhance homogeneously, whereas larger lesions have irregular enhancement due to areas of necrosis.
  • The clear cell subtype may show much stronger enhancement is a differential for angiomyolipoma. Below is the CT of Angiomyolipoma.




Other options:
 
  • Oncocytoma and angiomyolipoma are benign renal tumors that usually have well-defined borders and a characteristic appearance on imaging.
  • Perinephric cysts are fluid-filled sacs located adjacent to the kidney and appear as simple cystic lesions on imaging.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1482.

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most beneficial in the following situations:
questions.solution:
Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful for carcinoma vulva among the given options.

Sentinel lymph node biopsy was discovered by Cavana. It is useful in vulva cancer, Melanoma and breast cancer. 

The inguinal lymph node status has been identified as the single most important factor in predicting mortality attributable to vulval cancer.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1576.

questions.text:
A patient developed a renal laceration and urinoma as a result of a blunt trauma to the abdomen. Urinoma persisted even after 12 days, but the patient was
stable and there was no fever. What will be the next course of action?
questions.solution:
• The patient in the given clinical scenario is suffering from grade 4 renal trauma characterized by renal laceration and formation of urinoma. 
  • The most appropriate management of urinoma is to perform an internal ureteral stenting. 
  • Non responders can be treated with percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drainage. 
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 234.

questions.text: How is a 4 cm renal staghorn calculus treated?
questions.solution:
Management of 4cm size renal staghorn calculus is PCNL.

Renal Stones Treatment:

Size < 2cm : ESWL
Size > 2cm : PCNL
Staghorn calculi : PCNL + ESWL (Initial approach is PCNL followed by ESWL)

In PCNL kidney stones are removed via a 'track' developed between the surface of skin & collecting system of kidney.


Fig: Struvite (infectious) stones are evident on a plain radiograph of the abdomen.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1762.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate management for a patient who has tenderness in the left iliac fossa with a 3-cm stone in the renal pelvis and no hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is an ideal management for a female patient with a 3 cm left renal pelvic stone with no hydroureteronephrosis or distal obstruction, and normal functioning kidneys on both sides.
  • PCNL is minimally invasive, and can successfully treat stones of any size and location.
  • It also reduces the risk of urine leakage and stone fragments, and allows for quick stone clearance and shorter recovery times.
  • The procedure involves a small incision in the back through which a tiny telescope is inserted to view the stone, a laser to break up the stone and enable removal, and nephrostomy tubes to flush out the fragments.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1477.

questions.text: A testicular biopsy is successfully completed by the surgical registrar, who then gives the attending nurse the specimen. The sister asks you how to send the pathologist the sample. Which liquid will you have the sister place the specimen in?
questions.solution:
Testicular biopsy is usually sent in Bouin's solution for histopathological examination.
Bouin solution is composed of picric acid, acetic acid and formaldehyde in an aqueous solution.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1068.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is effective in treating advanced prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
• Goserelin is used as a depot formulation. 
  • Goserelin  is a synthetic decapeptide analogue of gonadotropin releasing hormone that acts as a partial agonist of the gonadotropin receptors in the pituitary that regulate luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion
  • The continued receptor occupancy by goserelin, however, ultimately causes a down-regulation of production of LH and FSH and a resultant decrease in testosterone and estrogen levels.
  • They produce effects similar to that of orchiectomy and are approved in the treatment of advanced prostatic cancer.
  • Goserelin and the other GnRH analogues cause a profound hypogonadism ("chemical castration") and its common side effects are typical of androgen deprivation, including hot flashes, loss of libido, erectile dysfunction, depression, nausea, diarrhea, weight gain and fluid retention
Memorizing trick for GnRH- 
relix- relax- GnRH antagonist
relin- GnRH agonist 

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 598.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to confirm anorchia?
questions.solution:
• Diagnostic laparoscopy is a definitive investigation for anorchia.
  • Inguinoscrotal USG and MRI are not helpful in the diagnosis of nonpalpable testis.
  • Diagnostic laparoscopy followed by laparoscopic orchidopexy if the testis is in the abdomen is the preferred approach.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1870.

choices.text: Per-rectal examination to check ejaculatory duct obstruction

questions.text: "Female partner is normal in a couple undergoing infertility treatment for the last four years. On two repeated samples, the male partner has 0.8 mL semen volume per ejaculate, no fructose, and no sperms when examined under a microscope. What is the next level of investigation?"
questions.solution:
• In a couple for treatment of infertility from the last four years, the female partner is normal.
  • Male partner has 0.8ml semen volume per ejaculate on two repeated samples and absent fructose, with no sperms on examination under microscope.
  • The next line of management would be Transrectal ultrasound to detect duct obstruction.
  • Absence of fructose and the absence of sperm in the ejaculate point to vas deferens blockage with seminal vesicle agenesis or occlusion.
  • Surgical vasography has been substituted by TRUS in the diagnosis of obstructive lesions that result in infertility.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1455.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. Patient was admitted in an emergency room for 5 days. The PSA level was 7.4. Which of the following is the best next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A 60 years old male presented with fever, chills and dysuria. Patient was hospitalized in an emergency for 5 days. PSA level was 7.4. This patient is most probably suffering from acute bacterial prostatitis and is treated by antibiotics.

Acute Bacterial Prostatitis :

  • Patients present with sudden onset high grade fever with chills and rigors, severe irritative symptoms and enlarged, tender and boggy prostate
  • Catheterisation and prostatic massage is contraindicated.
  • Treatment:-TMO-SMX and Ciprofloxacin.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 2067.

choices.text: Peak incidence in 3 years old children in India
Most common type in ammonium urate or calcium oxalate

questions.text: Which of the following statements about endemic bladder stones is incorrect?
questions.solution:
False regarding endemic bladder stones is that it always associated with recurrence. The prevalence of primary bladder calculi is higher in children who consume low-protein, low-phosphate diets.
  • After therapy, primary bladder calculi seldom reoccur. Stones are often solitary and don’t usually reappear after being removed.
  • The most frequent elements of primary bladder calculi are uric acid, calcium oxalate, ammonium acid urate, and calcium phosphate.
  • Children in endemic areas frequently eat a diet high in cereal that is low in animal protein and low in phosphate.
  • Low dietary phosphate intake causes both hyperammonuria and hypophosphaturia, which encourages the precipitation of calcium oxalate and ammonium acid urate.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1509.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male with 35 pack years appeared with a microscopic hematuria and a painless lump in the left scrotal sac. Alpha- fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase tests in the lab came out negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The features provided of a 55-year old man with history of 35 pack years of smoking and painless swelling in the left scrotal sac (may be metastatic mass) and microscopic hematuria (suggestive of RCC), laboratory investigations of negative Alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase levels (ruling out any testicular tumor) points towards a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. This may result in a varicocele formation which may present as a lump in the scrotum

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 2090.

questions.text: A 48-year- old female presents with pain in left flank, recurrent gross hematuria, and seizure. A CT scan of the abdomen showed several right sided renal angiomyolipomas measuring 1.5 to 6.5 cm and a left perinephric hematoma with a 3 cm angiomyolipoma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tuberous sclerosis (TS), also known as tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) or Bourneville disease, is a phakomatosis (neurocutaneous disorder) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system).
 

Spontaneous mutations account for 50-86% of cases, with the remainder inherited as an autosomal dominant condition. In the majority of such cases (80%) the mutation has been narrowed down to two tumor suppressor genes, both part of the mTOR pathway.

  • TSC1: encoding hamartin, on chromosome 9q32-34

  • TSC2: encoding tuberin, on chromosome 16p13.3 (accounts for most cases)

    * Tuberous sclerosis has a significant number of manifestations, involving many organ systems. The most common radiographic manifestations are:

 

  • cortical or subependymal tubers and white matter abnormalities

  • renal angiomyolipomas

  • cardiac rhabdomyoma(s)

    Tuberous Sclerosis also has dermatological manifestations like adenoma sebaceum and Shagreen's patch. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1481.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with psychological disorder is facing left-sided flank discomfort. Right kidney hyperechoic lesion and many liver lesions are seen on ultrasonography. These lesions had a -50 to -80 HU density, according to an abdominal CT scan. The following is the most likely reason:
questions.solution:
The lesions described in the question are s/o angiomyolipoma which appear hyperechoic on ultrasound and fat density hypoattenuating lesion ( black in appearance with HU of -60 to -80 ) on CT scan.
  • Tuberous sclerosis (TS), also known as tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) or Bourneville disease, is a phakomatosis (neurocutaneous disorder) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system).
  • Spontaneous mutations account for 50-86% of cases, with the remainder inherited as an autosomal dominant condition. In the majority of such cases (80%) the mutation has been narrowed down to two tumor suppressor genes, both part of the mTOR pathway.
  • TSC1: encoding hamartin, on chromosome 9q32-34
  • TSC2: encoding tuberin, on chromosome 16p13.3 (accounts for most cases) Tuberous sclerosis has a significant number of manifestations, involving many organ systems.
  • The most common radiographic manifestations are: cortical or subependymal tubers and white matter abnormalities renal angiomyolipomas cardiac rhabdomyoma(s)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1481.

choices.text: Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
Inject water to over distend the balloon until it bursts and Foley’s can be removed
Use ultrasound guidance to locate and prick the balloon and then remove the catheter

questions.text: The surgeon instructed the intern to remove the Foley's catheter following surgery, but the intern was unable to do so. In spite of his best efforts, the surgeon was unable to remove the Foley's catheter. What action is necessary now?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Use ultrasound guidance to locate and prick the balloon and then remove the catheter
 
  • When unable to remove a Foley's catheter, the next step would be to use ultrasound guidance to locate and puncture the balloon, allowing for deflation and subsequent removal of the catheter.
  • Injecting ether (option B) or water (option C) to dissolve or over-distend the balloon is not recommended as it may cause potential complications or damage to the urethra or bladder. CT-guided rupture (option A) is an invasive and unnecessary procedure that should be avoided.



Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 991.

questions.text: Which metal ion is the component of struvite?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) both (a) & (b)

Struvite stones are made up of Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate (struvite) along with Calcium-Carbonate/Phosphate/Apatite.
Struvite(mineral) by itself refers to only Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate but in the human body, the struvite stones formation usually involves both Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate(struvite) along with Calcium-Carbonate/Phosphate/Apatite.

* Struvite Stones:

They are also known as triple phosphate(due to three cations - Mg2+/Ca2+ and NH4+ ) and Infection stones since they are commonly seen in UTIs by urease-producing organisms (eg Proteus mirabilis).
Urease splits urea into Ammonia and H2O and the increased ammonia production causes the urine pH to get elevated, which decreases the solubility of phosphate and leads to the precipitation of Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1762.

questions.text: Lord's plication is done to treat:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hydrocele
  • Lord's plication is a surgical technique used to treat hydrocele.
  • It involves the excision of excess hydrocele sac and plication (folding) of the remaining sac to reduce its size and prevent re-accumulation of fluid.
  • Surgery is rarely indicated before 2 years because a majority resolve.
  • Teenage boys may have a non-communicating hydrocele with fluid arising from the tunica vaginalis; a plication (Lord’s procedure) or excision/eversion of the tunica vaginalis (Jaboulay procedure) are needed.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 257.

questions.text: Anuria and stomach discomfort are present in a 50-year-old female patient. According to radiological examinations, the patient had hydronephrosis and bilaterally impacted ureteric stones. RBCs with pus cells were discovered in the urine after investigation. What should be the first line of treatment if the serum creatinine level was 16 mg/dl and the urea level was 200 mmol/l?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 'J' stent drainage
  • Hydronephrosis with any size of ureteric stone: JJ stent is a suitable option.
  • JJ stent helps relieve obstruction and promote urine flow.
  • Percutaneous nephrostomy and ureteric stent are alternative options.
  • The JJ stent is a flexible tube inserted into the ureter to bypass the obstruction caused by the stone and allow urine to flow from the kidney to the bladder.

Fig: J stent insitu

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 281.

questions.text: What potential complications could there be if PCNL is performed through the eleventh intercostal space?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hydrothorax 
 
  • Hydrothorax is a potential complication that can occur when performing PCNL through the eleventh intercostal space.
  • Hydrothorax refers to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity, which can result from leakage of urine or irrigation fluid used during the procedure into the thoracic cavity.
  • It can lead to respiratory compromise and compression of the lungs, requiring appropriate management, such as thoracentesis or chest tube placement.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 2078.

questions.text: Which of the following stones can't be easily broken by ESWL?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Calcium oxalate monohydrate
ESWL (extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy) is a non-invasive procedure used to break down kidney stones into smaller fragments using shock waves.
  • Calcium oxalate monohydrate stones are the most challenging to break using ESWL.
  • Calcium oxalate monohydrate stones have a crystalline structure that makes them resistant to shock wave fragmentation.
  • On the other hand, calcium oxalate dihydrate, uric acid, and struvite stones are relatively easier to break using ESWL due to their composition and structure.
  • ESWL may still be attempted for calcium oxalate monohydrate stones, but alternative treatment options like ureteroscopic removal or percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) may be considered if ESWL fails to effectively break down the stones.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1471.

questions.text: Which of the following renal vascular anomalies occurs most frequently?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Supernumerary renal arteries 
 
  • Supernumerary renal arteries are the most frequently encountered renal vascular anomaly.
  • They refer to additional arteries originating from the abdominal aorta and supplying the kidneys in addition to the normal renal arteries.
  • Recognition of these vascular anomalies is crucial for surgical procedures involving the kidneys to ensure adequate blood supply and minimize the risk of inadvertent injury to these vessels.

Other options:
 
  • B. Supernumerary renal veins: This refers to the presence of additional veins draining the kidneys.
  • C. Double renal arteries: This is the presence of two separate arteries supplying a single kidney.
  • Double renal veins: This refers to the presence of two separate veins draining a single kidney.
They all occur less frequently compared to supernumerary renal arteries.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 2068.

questions.text: The first autologous kidney transplant was performed by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hardy
 
  • Renal auto-transplantation was first performed by James Hardy in 1963 to repair a high ureteral injury.


Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 357.

questions.text: The ideal time period to operate on an undescended testis is before:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 12 months of age
  • Surgical intervention for an undescended testis is ideally performed before the child reaches 12 months of age.
  • Orchidopexy is the treatment of choice for incompletely palpable unilateral undescended testis. Orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age.
  • Delayed or untreated undescended testis can lead to various complications: Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication) Torsion Seminoma (Increased risk) Epididymorchitis Trauma (Increased risk) Sterility.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 258.

questions.text: The Gray-hack shunt can be found between:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Corpora cavernosa and saphenous vein 
 
  • The Gray-hack shunt is a surgical procedure used for the treatment of priapism, a persistent penile erection unrelated to sexual arousal.
  • The shunt involves creating a connection between the corpora cavernosa (cylindrical chambers in the penis) and the saphenous vein.
  • This connection allows the excessive blood trapped in the corpora cavernosa to drain out, relieving the prolonged erection.
  • The shunt is typically created by anastomosing the corpora cavernosa to the saphenous vein using surgical techniques.
Reference: van der Horst, Christof & Stuebinger, Henrik & Seif, Christoph & Melchior, Diethild & Martínez-Portillo, F.J. & Juenemann, Klaus-Peter. (2003). Priapism: Etiology, pathophysiology and management. International braz j urol : official journal of the Brazilian Society of Urology. 29. 391-400. 10.1590/S1677-55382003000500002.

questions.text: Which is the most common site of urethral carcinoma in men?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bulbomembranous urethra 
 
  • The bulbomembranous urethra (60%) is the most common site of urethral carcinoma in men.
  • Urethral carcinoma typically presents with symptoms such as hematuria (blood in the urine), obstructive voiding, and urinary tract infections.
  • Other sites of urethral carcinoma include the penile urethra (30%), prostatic urethra (10%), and fossa navicularis.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1766.

questions.text: In otherwise healthy 40 yr old man Management of a RCC less than 4 cm in size?
questions.solution:
Renal cell carcinoma staging is based on the size, position and lymph node involvement of a tumor.

  • Stage I indicates a tumor that is less than 7 cm in the largest dimension and localized to the kidney.
  • Stage II is larger than 7 cm and localized to the kidney.
  • Stage III is when the tumor has extended beyond the Gerota's fascia, or regional lymph nodes are involved.
  • Partial nephrectomy is indicated for patients with T1 tumors (less than 7 cm confined to the kidney, stage I).
  • Classic radical nephrectomy involves removing the entire kidney, perineal fat, adrenal gland and regional lymph nodes. However, when the tumor is smaller than 5 cm and located at the inferior pole, the adrenal gland can be preserved, as well as the regional lymph node dissection in cases of clinically positive nodes detected on CT.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1482.

choices.text: Immediate exploration and operate opposite side if symptomatic
Delay exploration and operate opposite side if symptomatic
Immediate exploration and operate opposite side even asymptomatic
Delayed exploration and operate opposite side even if asymptomatic

questions.text: Which test will you do in a 10 years old boy who came with a complain of pain in right side of scrotum for past 1 hr. and you suspect torsion of testes.?
questions.solution:
Torsion in testis
  • Most prevalent in adolescents aged 10 to 25.
  • An unexpected onset of testicular pain.
  • Just after strenuous exercises. (Example sexual activity).
  • "Bell Clapper deformity" is a significant risk factor.
  • The investigation of choice: Color Doppler detects the reduced blood flow to the testis in torsion
  • Manipulation can be used to correct torsion in the first hour, but afterwards surgery is required to fix the testis.
  • If the problem cannot be resolved by manipulation or if more than an hour has passed, surgery must be performed. The procedure MUST be completed in 4 hours or else the testis will undergo infarction. 
  • Because the anatomical variation causing the torsion is probably bilateral, orchidopexy should be performed on both the affected and unaffected testicles to prevent further torsion in the other testis. 
  • Differential diagnosis:  epididym-orchitis 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 254.

questions.text: In a single-core prostate needle biopsy, poorly formed glands arranged in cribriform pattern is seen. What will be the Gleason pattern in this patient?
questions.solution:
Gleason Pattern-

Pattern 1 and 2- Not defined according to modified Gleason

Pattern 3- Well formed glands

Pattern 4- Cribriform glands/glomeruloid glands/poorly formed

Pattern 5- Comedo-necrosis, individual cells or tumor sheets



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1534.

questions.text: A young girl complains that her urine is dribbling continuously. She does, however, urinate normally. Since her birth, her parents claim, she has never been completely dry. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Case of ectopic ureter as the patient has continuous dribbling of urine.
IVU can be used for investigation
Re-implantation of the ectopic ureter is the definitive treatment.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1498.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS)?
questions.solution:
Lower Urinary Tracy Symptom ( LUTS ) refer to a group of urinary problems related to storage, voiding, and post-voiding issues and occur due to Bladder, Prostate & Urethral disorders. These include

1. Voiding Symptoms

  • Hesitancy 
  • Poor Stream 
  • Intermittent Flow 
  • Incomplete emptying 
  • Post Void Dribbling 
  • Overflow incontinence
     

2. Storage Symptoms

  • Frequency 
  • Nocturnal 
  • Urgency
  • Urge Incontinence.
Incontinence during intercourse (option 1), though it can be a symptom of pelvic floor dysfunction, is not a classical lower urinary tract symptom.
 

Reference:  Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1448.

questions.text: A patient complains of hematuria and visits the OP. High grade transitional cell carcinoma is found in the urine, and a 2x2 cm bladder tumour is visible on a CT scan. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Bladder cancer is of 3 types—

  • 1. Transitional Cell Cancer (Most Common)
  • 2. Squamous Cell Cancer 
  • 3. Adenocarcinoma

It clinically presents with gross painless hematuria. NAT2 and GSTM1 are consistent germline markers for bladder cancer.

For Superficial Bladder Cancer (not invading muscle layer) : Transurethral resection of bladder tumor and Intravesical chemotherapy is done. Intravesical immunotherapy (BCG) is also done in high grade tumors.

Neo adjuvant chemo followed by TURB is done for for T3 AND T4 stage tumor with local invasion.
For advanced deep layer bladder cancer (Invasive bladder Cancer)—Radical Cystectomy is done followed by radiotherapy.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1517.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man who had a 2x3 cm prostate lesion presented to the OPD. PSA is 8. Gleason rating is six. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
• Gleason sums for well-differentiated cancers range from 2-4, moderately differentiated tumors from 5-6, and poorly differentiated tumors from 8-10.
  • The initial T stage, Gleason score, and baseline PSA are used in combination to more accurately predict risk and direct treatment choices.
  • Yet, given that the patient is 80 years old, comorbidities are a possibility here. As a result, we will continue to actively monitor the patient.
 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1534.

choices.text: Wait for bladder to fill and urge to urinate

questions.text:
A little child with a perineal injury visited the emergency room. Examination reveals blood at the meatus and no recent urination; the bladder is not palpable.
What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
The bulbar urethra has ruptured, which is the most likely diagnosis.
  • The next course of action in management is to wait and observe as the bladder is not full.
  • Doing suprapubic aspiration after the bladder is full is advised.
  • This lessens urine extravasation and makes it possible to determine the severity of the urethral damage by investigations.
  • Using water-soluble contrast, urethrography is used to make the diagnosis.
  • A catheter should be inserted using a Seldinger technique through a percutaneous suprapubic puncture to empty a full bladder. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1766.

questions.text: A patient came in with a firm, painless testicular tumor and high LDH. What is the ideal course of action moving forward?
questions.solution:
• A testicular tumor case is suspected based on the provided clinical situation. The patient typically arrives with a lump in the testes that doesn't hurt. 
  • The testis may feel heavy if it is two or three times its normal size, but only a small percentage of people report pain. An ultrasound scan of the testis is used to confirm the diagnosis. Staging is a crucial step in treatment planning for confirmed patients. 
  • Before an orchidectomy, blood is drawn to check the levels of tumour markers, which are elevated in about 50% of cases. 
  • An inguinal incision is used to perform the orchidectomy. The external oblique aponeurosis is divided to reveal the spermatic cord, and a soft clamp is placed across the cord to prevent the spread of cancerous cells as the testis is removed.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1571.

questions.text: A patient with CKD is having a pyeloplasty. Which of the following post-operative analgesics is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
The medication that is frequently suggested for sporadic usage in people with renal disease is acetaminophen. It is safe in case of CKD. 
In comparison to intravenous paracetamol 1 gr and tramadol 0.7 mg/kg for patients undergoing renal surgery, various studies have shown that the combination of intravenous paracetamol 1 gr and ketamine 0.5 mg/kg resulted in a general reduction in pain scores, decreased postoperative analgesic requirements, and lower agitation score.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 2120.

questions.text: Single core prostate needle biopsy results With a cribriform pattern, acinar adenocarcinoma predominates, followed by crowded but distinct glands and a small (5%) amount of single cell infiltration. What grade does it belong in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Grade 4
The cribriform pattern and the presence of crowded but distinct glands along with some single-cell infiltration suggest a more aggressive form, likely to be Gleason 4.





Reference:
Ali Hasan Md. Linkon, Md. Mahir Labib, Tarik Hasan, Mozammal Hossain, Marium-E- Jannat,
Deep learning in prostate cancer diagnosis and Gleason grading in histopathology images: An extensive study, Informatics in Medicine Unlocked, Volume 24, 2021, 100582, ISSN 2352-9148,
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.imu.2021.100582.
(https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352914821000721)

choices.text: Medially vas deferens, laterally gonadal vessel, inferiorly peritoneum
Laterally vas deferens, medially gonadal vessel, inferiorly peritoneum
Laterally medial umbilical ligament, medially gonadal vessel, Lateral inferiorly peritoneum
Laterally gonadal vessels and medially lateral umbilical ligament, inferiorly peritoneum

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Triangle of Doom's limits is accurate?
questions.solution:
The triangle of doom is bounded on medial side by the vas deferens and on the lateral side by the vessels of the spermatic cord. The floor of the triangle is made up of the peritoneum.
The area contains the external iliac vessels, deep circumflex iliac vein, femoral nerve, and genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.


Fig: Triangle of DOOM

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1605.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man reports painless firm testicular swelling. AFP testing revealed a level of 3080 ng/mL. No mediastinal lymph nodes, paraaortic nodes, or iliac nodes were discovered. Small regions of necrosis and homogeneous echotexture are visible on USG. The nearby structures are normal. What should we do next?
questions.solution:
• An individual suffering from hard and painless swelling in the testicles, a raised AFP and history of testicular tumors is best treated through an initial high inguinal orchiectomy. 
  • Biopsy or orchiectomy procedures of the scrotum should not be carried out due to the associated lymph drainage which can upstage the disease. 
  • Following the radical inguinal orchiectomy, further imaging is vital.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1569.

questions.text: A Kasai portoenterostomy was performed on a toddler to treat extra-hepatic biliary atresia. Which of the following is not related to this condition in addition to the relationships shown in the provided image?
questions.solution:
• Biliary atresia, a rare disease affecting newborns is characterized by inflammatory obturation of intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts. This affliction is estimated to occur in 1 in 5000 to 12,000 infants in various regions.
  • It is often associated with congenital malformations such as a double spleen and/or asplenia, absence of the inferior vena cava, and intestinal malformation.
  • In some cases, patients have additional malformations including polysplenia, preduodenal portal vein, and intrahepatic vena cava. Without treatment, progressive cirrhosis and death may occur by two years of age. 
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 383.

questions.text: How can a radiotherapy-treated 70-year-old man's prostate cancer recurrence be biochemically monitored?
questions.solution:
The recurrence of the prostate cancer in a patient who has been given radiotherapy is biochemically measured by prostate specific antigen only.

The current standard definition of biochemical failure (the Phoenix definition) is a rise in PSA by >2 ng/ml higher than the lowest PSA achieved.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1536.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the urine collection in the urethral rupture above the deep perineal pouch is true in light of our understanding of the anatomy of the pelvis and perineum?
questions.solution:
True regarding collection of urine in urethral rupture above deep perineal pouch is c)it is collected in true pelvis only

Men are more likely than women to sustain urethral injuries, which are typically occur due to pelvic fractures or straddle falls.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1766.

questions.text: Which of the following carcinomas has historically used the Gleason score as a grading system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Prostatic carcinoma
 
  • The Gleason score is primarily used for grading prostatic carcinoma. It assesses the architectural patterns of prostate cancer cells and assigns a score based on their differentiation.
  • The Gleason score helps predict the aggressiveness and prognosis of prostate cancer, with higher scores indicating a higher grade and more aggressive tumor.

Patterns 1 and 2 are no longer defined in the 2014 WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score system.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1535.

choices.text: Smoking is the most important risk factor
Most common histological variant is transitional cell carcinoma
Muscle invasion is seen in T2 stage
Treatment of choice for stage-T2 cancer is intravesical chemotherapy

questions.text: The following is not true regarding urinary bladder carcinoma:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Treatment of choice for stage-T2 cancer is intravesical chemotherapy 
 
  • Smoking is the most important risk factor (option A) for developing urinary bladder carcinoma. Risk factors:
      • Smoking
      • Exposure to aniline dyes
      • Cyclophosphamide
      • Pelvic irradiation
  • The most common histological variant of urinary bladder carcinoma is transitional cell carcinoma (option B).
  • Muscle invasion is seen in T2 stage (option C), which indicates infiltration into the muscular layer of the bladder wall.
  • Intravesical chemotherapy is not the treatment of choice for stage T2 cancer; radical cystectomy (surgical removal of the bladder) is usually recommended.

* T staging:




Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1517.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital defects is related with exstrophy of the bladder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Epispadias
 
  • Exstrophy of the bladder is associated with epispadias, a congenital defect where the urinary meatus is located on the dorsal surface of the penis.
  • In extrophy of bladder, the bladder mucosa is exposed to the surface
  • Hypospadias refers to a condition where the urethral opening is located on the ventral surface of the penis.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 279.

questions.text:
Which of the following four types of figures can be found most frequently?
1. 
2. 
3. 
4.
questions.solution:
Correct option 1:Vaginal hydrocoele
  • Congenital Vaginal hydrocoele is the most common type of hydrocoele.
  • Vaginal hydrocoele results when the processus vaginalis remains patent, allowing fluid from the peritoneum to accumulate in the scrotum. 
Other options given :
1-Vaginal hydrocoele (very common)
2-Infantile hydrocoele
3-Communicating hydrocoele
4-Encysted hydrocoele of the cord

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 257.

questions.text: What is the medical term for the triad of renal colic, which causes a swelling in the loin that goes away after passing urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Dietel's crisis
 
  • The medical term for the triad of renal colic, which causes a swelling in the loin that goes away after passing urine, is Dietel's crisis. It occurs due to obstruction by kidney stone. 
  • Renal colic refers to severe pain in the flank area (loin) caused by the passage of kidney stones through the urinary tract.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1469.

choices.text: Superimposed on Vertebral column on Lateral X-Ray

questions.text: Which of the following prefers a gallstones diagnosis to a Renal Calculi?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Usually Radiolucent
 
  • Gallstones are typically radiolucent, meaning they do not appear clearly on X-ray imaging due to their composition, which is usually cholesterol or mixed cholesterol and pigment stones.
  • On the other hand, renal calculi are often radiopaque and can be visualized on X-ray due to their mineral composition, such as calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate.
  • Therefore, if a patient presents with a radiolucent stone, it is more likely to be a gallstone rather than a renal calculus.
  • None of the stones move with respiration.
  • Other diagnostic modalities, such as ultrasound or CT scan, are commonly used to evaluate and confirm the presence of gallstones or renal calculi, as they provide better visualization and characterization of the stones.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1403.

questions.text: Which Renal Calculi is associated with proteus infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Triple phosphate 
 
  • Proteus infection is commonly associated with the formation of struvite stones, which are also called triple phosphate stones.
  • Struvite stones are composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate and are associated with alkaline urine and urinary tract infections, particularly with Proteus species
  • It causes Staghorn calculus. 

Other options:
  • Uric acid stones (option A) are formed due to the precipitation of uric acid in acidic urine.
  • Calcium oxalate stones (option C) are the most common type of kidney stones and can be caused by various factors.
  • Xanthine stones (option D) are rare and typically occur in individuals with an inborn error of purine metabolism.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1474.

questions.text: After TURP, which of the following is the most common cause of delayed urinary obstructive symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Bladder neck stenosis 
 
  • After a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which is a surgical procedure to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), the most common cause of delayed urinary obstructive symptoms is bladder neck stenosis
  • TURP is a surgical procedure performed to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and it involves removing the obstructing prostate tissue.
  • However, in some cases, scar tissue or fibrosis can develop at the bladder neck, leading to narrowing or stenosis.
  • This can result in urinary flow obstruction and symptoms such as weak urinary stream, difficulty initiating urination, or urinary retention.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1530.

questions.text: During TURP, to prevent injury to which of the following structures does the surgeon dissects above the verumontanum :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  External Urethral Sphincter 
 
  • During TURP, the surgeon dissects above the verumontanum.
  • TURP is a surgical procedure performed to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and it involves removing the obstructing prostate tissue.
  • The verumontanum is a ridge located in the prostatic urethra. Dissecting above the verumontanum helps prevent injury to the external urethral sphincter.
  • By avoiding injury to the external urethral sphincter, the surgeon minimizes the risk of postoperative urinary incontinence.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1530.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations should be performed to evaluate the suspected diagnosis in case of a 55 year old smoker presented with history of five episodes of macroscopic hematuria each lasting for about 4-5 days in the past five years.?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Urine microscopy and cytology 
 
  • In a case of a 55-year-old smoker with a history of recurrent macroscopic hematuria, the suspected diagnosis is urinary tract malignancy.
  • To evaluate this suspected diagnosis, the recommended investigation is urine microscopy and cytology.
  • Urine microscopy and cytology involve examining the urine sample under a microscope to look for abnormal cells and other indicators of urinary tract malignancy.
  • This investigation helps identify any abnormal cells or evidence of malignancy in the urinary tract.
Ultrasound is a non-invasive and commonly used investigation to evaluate the kidneys, ureters, and bladder, especially to rule out stones or structural abnormalities. However, it may miss small or early-stage bladder tumors and is less sensitive for detecting upper urinary tract malignancies (e.g., renal or ureteral cancers). While useful, it is not definitive for ruling out urothelial malignancies.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1450.

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the best recommended management option for a 40 year old patient with a single kidney presented with a solitary exophytic mass of 4 cm localized at its lower pole.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Partial Nephrectomy 
 
  • For tumors less than or equal to 4 cm in size and limited to the kidney (T1a), partial nephrectomy is performed.
  • Partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed in tumors >4cm in size but less than or equal to 7 cms, and limited to the kidney (T1b). If partial nephrectomy is not feasible in T1b tumors, then a radical nephrectomy is done.
  • Other indications for partial nephrectomy are bilateral renal cell carcinoma and carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1483.

questions.text: An old male presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of pain in the scrotum, fever and cellulitis of scrotal skin. Clinical image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario along with image findings of gangrenous scrotal wall goes in favour of Fournier's gangrene. 
  • It is a polymicrobial infection involving the subcutaneous tissue leading to obliterative arteritis and gangrene. 
  • Management is emergency surgical debridement. 
  • Testis are usually spared in Fournier's gangrene due to dual blood supply. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1553.

questions.text: A 5 years old child presented with history of recurrent urinary tract infections. A mass was palpable in the loin as well. Micturating cystourethrogram was done, which is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of recurrent urinary tract obstruction with the micturating cystourethrogram showing reflux of contrast into ureters which are dilated along with blunting of fornices and loss of renal papillary impression is diagnostic of Vesicoureteric reflux. 
  • It is more common in females as compared to males. 
  • Micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is the investigation of choice for VUR.
  • It can also be graded based on the MCU appearance into 5 grades. 

Grading of VUR:





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1404, 1436-1437, 1440.

questions.text: Study the image given below and make a clinical diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The above image is suggestive of ectopia vesicae or bladder exostrophy.

It occurs due to improper formation of lower anterior abdominal wall leaving the bladder open and exposed. 

Clinical features:
 
  • Appearance: The bladder is exposed outside the body, often appearing as a red, raw, and moist tissue mass. The bladder is open and not covered by skin.
 
  • Associated defects: Bladder exstrophy is often associated with other congenital anomalies, such as:
    • Epispadias (a malformation of the urethra, where the urethral opening is located on the upper side of the penis in males or on the clitoris in females).
    • Pubic symphysis separation (the bone structures of the pelvis may not be fully joined).
    • Cloacal exstrophy (a more severe variant involving defects in the bladder, intestines, and genitalia)


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1424, 1425.

questions.text: Study the delayed intravenous urogram shown below and make a clinical diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Delayed intravenous pyelogram of the patient shows left hydronephrosis with absence of contrast opacification of ispilateral ureter. This is most likely to be pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction on left side. 
 
  • Option 3- Putty kidney is characterized by dense renal parenchymal ( not pelvi-calyceal system ) calcifications visualized on a plain X-Ray KUB ( and not IVP )


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1402, 1405-1406, 1410-1412.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and presented to the Emergency department with inability to pass urine. Vitals were stable. On examination, there was blood at the tip of urethral meatus. A retrograde urethrogram was done as shown below. Most likely site of urethral rupture:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a patient with road traffic accident, inability to pass urine with blood at the tip pf meatus, the retrograde urethrogram shows significant contrast extravasation in the region of membranous urethra. 
 
  • The investigation of choice in a patient with suspected urethral trauma is to perform a retrograde urethrography.
  • Loss of smooth contour of the urethra with extravasation of dye is diagnostic of urethral rupture. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1479-1481.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male came with a blunt injury to the abdomen. There was no blood at the tip of the penile meatus, and no urine output after Folley's catheter insertion. The cystography image of the patient is given below. What is the next best management?
questions.solution:
Retrograde Cystogram shows extravasation of urine with intraperitoneal bladder rupture - Management for the same is Exploratory laparotomy with peritoneal lavage(since extravasated urine will cause peritoneal irritation and peritonitis)

Reference: SRB Mannual of Surgery, 6th Edition , Page no 234 .

questions.text: A patient developed loss of sensation in the root of penis after a laparoscopic hernia repair surgery. Which of the following nerve is damaged?
questions.solution:
In males, fibers of the ilioinguinal nerve carry sensation from:
  • the skin of the upper and medial part of the thigh
  • the skin over the root of the penis
  • the upper part of the scrotum

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 1094,1095,1096 .

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient with pain in the left flank has presented to the OPD. CT scan was done and is given below. Whats the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple disseminated intra-abdominal fluid density cysts, some of them show focal areas of calcification, septations, and daughter cysts suggestive of Hydatid cyst.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page no 1460.

questions.text: 5-alpha reductase inhibitor is indicated to?
questions.solution:
• A 5-alpha reductase inhibitor is indicated to reduce intracellular Dihydrotestosterone (DHT).
  • The enzyme 5-alpha reductase converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent form of testosterone. By inhibiting this enzyme, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors reduce the conversion of testosterone to DHT, leading to lower levels of intracellular DHT.
  • Lowering intracellular DHT is the primary therapeutic effect of 5-alpha reductase inhibitors, and it is utilized in the treatment of certain conditions such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and androgenetic alopecia (male pattern baldness).
 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 494,840-842 .

choices.text: It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.text: Patient presented with a clinical picture as shown. Surgical debridement is done for the patient. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient with a necrotizing soft tissue infection of the perineal region ( Fournier’s gangrene) has undergone surgical debridement.
Diabetes mellitus and immunosuppression are associated risk factors.
It is a surgical emergency.
Treatment involves a combination of:
  1. Extensive surgical debridement: for source control, as already done in this patient. It is the cornerstone of treatment.

  2. Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics: Initiated as soon as possible. intent of covering gram positives (including MRSA), gram negatives, and anaerobic organisms, since, most commonly it is caused by a polymicrobial flora including gram positive cocci, gram-negative rods, and anaerobic bacteria including Escherichia coli, Bacteroides spp, Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus.

Since the blood supply of the testicles is from the testicular artery and independent of the overlying tissue it is usually not infected. Thus bilateral orchiectomy is generally not required. (option B)
Urinary or fecal diversion may be necessary depending on the location and degree of tissue loss but is seldom necessary at the initial debridement, and will not be the next step in the management of this patient. (option C)
Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is of historical importance in the treatment of gas gangrene and is no longer used. (option D)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 1510.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing abdominoperineal resection. Which of the following is likely to be seen after the ligation of the first vessel of the surgery?
questions.solution:
The patient is undergoing an abdominal perineal resection (APR), also called the Miles procedure, which includes the resection of the sigmoid colon, rectum, and anus and the construction of a permanent end colostomy.
In the abdominal part of the procedure, the inferior mesenteric artery is the first vessel to be ligated.
The pelvic sympathetic nerves are prone to get injured at their origin from the aortic plexus; during high ligation of the IMA leading to:
  • In men: Retrograde ejaculation (option D)
  • Urinary dysfunction: Sympathetic innervation to the bladder neck, trigone, and urethra.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1329, 1385.

questions.text: The following growth is seen on the retraction of prepuce of the patient. Inguinal lymph nodes are not palpable. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a warty growth that is visible on retraction of the prepuce, representing penile carcinoma involving the glans with no inguinal lymphadenopathy on clinical examination.
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type and it most commonly originates from the glans. 
  • Lesions involving glans or distal shaft require partial penectomy with 2 cm margin.
  • This may be accompanied by bilateral ilioinguinal LN dissection in case the patient has metastatic lymph nodes.
  • Small non-invasive lesions (penile intraepithelial neoplasia) involving prepuce can be managed by 5-fluorouracil cream, CO2 laser ablation, Nd-YAG laser and radiotherapy but require close follow-up. Wide excision or circumcision may also be required. (option A, option B)
  • If the lesion involves proximal shaft or a 2 cm margin is not achievable, total penectomy with perineal urethrostomy is done. (option D)
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 1553.

questions.text: All of the following tumor markers are elevated in Seminoma Except?
questions.solution:
Seminoma would be positive for Placental Alkaline Phosphatase- PLAP ,Octamer Binding Transcription factor 4- OCT4, KIT- AKA NANOG
Hcg-is positve in other types of germ cell tumors such as Choriocarcinoma and yolk sac tumors and nonseminomatous Testicular tumors.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 336.

questions.text: Liver transplanation can be done in which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Liver transplantation is relatively not Contraindicated in Testicular Cancer. Testicular Cancer has low risk of recurrence following transplantation, hence it can be advised in patients with history of testicular Ca.

Reference: Varma V, Mehta N, Kumaran V, Nundy S. Indications and contraindications for liver transplantation. Int J Hepatol. 2011;2011:121862. doi: 10.4061/2011/121862. Epub 2011 Oct 5. PMID: 22007310; PMCID: PMC3189562.

questions.text: The most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in a male child is
questions.solution:
Bladder outlet obstruction (BOO) in male children is most commonly caused by posterior urethral valves, which are congenital membranous folds in the posterior urethra.

Key points:

  • Occurs only in males, usually detected in neonates or infants.

  • Can present with poor urinary stream, urinary tract infections, hydronephrosis, or renal insufficiency.

  • Diagnosis: Ultrasound showing thick-walled bladder, dilated posterior urethra, confirmed by voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

  • Management: Endoscopic ablation of the valve; sometimes requires diversion if severe.

    Other options:

  • Urethral atresia: Extremely rare; incompatible with life without prenatal intervention.

  • Anterior urethral valve: Very uncommon; less frequent cause of BOO.

  • Ureterocele: Causes obstruction at ureterovesical junction, not primary bladder outlet obstruction.

questions.text: Identify the lesion depicted in the image given below
questions.solution:
The image provided demonstrates a retrograde cystourethrogram with findings indicative of a penile urethral stricture.

The male urethra is typically visualized using retrograde urethrography (RGU) or a voiding cystourethrogram (VCU), also known as a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). In RGU, contrast material is introduced into the anterior urethra (which includes the penile and bulbar urethra), allowing for the detailed visualization of the urethra and facilitating the diagnosis of anterior urethral abnormalities, such as strictures.

questions.text: The following image on a background of alkaline ph is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
• Coffin lid shaped crystals are suggestive of triple phosphate stones.
  • They are also known as staghorn or struvite stones. It is usually caused due to infection with urea-splitting organisms, such as Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, or Enterobacter species.
  • Urea metabolism by these organisms lead to formation of an alkaline urine and precipitation of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate - resulting in the formation of struvite stones.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 1474-75.

choices.text: Neuroblastoma is the second most common primary abdominal tumour of childhood
Most common presentation of Wilms tumour is an abdominal mass
Mean age of presentation of Wilms tumour is five years of age

questions.text: Which of the following is false?
questions.solution:
• Neuroblastoma is the most common primary abdominal malignancy in children followed by Wilm's tumor, while Wilm's tumor itself is the most common primary malignant renal tumor children less than 5 years of age.
  • Wilms tumor commonly presents as an asymptomatic abdominal mass.
  • Other findings of Wilm's tumor include hypertension, abdominal pain, gross painless hematuria, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and weight loss.
  • CECT abdomen is used to identify the extent of the tumor, integrity of the other kidney, and metastasis.
  • Wilms tumor is metabolically active and can concentrate fluorodeoxyglucose therefore PET/CT is also helpful to identify regional spread and metastatic lesions.
  • Radical nephrectomy is the standard surgical procedure done as treatment for Wilm's tumor. Nephron-sparing nephrectomy is done for children with bilateral disease or with a solitary kidney.
  • Chemotherapeutic agents used are vincristine and dactinomycin with the addition of Adriamycin(Doxorubicin).
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 262.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is done before performing an A-V fistula procedure? The image of the test is given below.
questions.solution:
The image appears to represent the Allen's Test, a procedure commonly performed before radial artery cannulation or arteriovenous (A-V) fistula creation to evaluate the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand.

In this test, both the radial and ulnar arteries are compressed while the patient is instructed to clench their fist tightly to drain blood from the palm. Once the hand is opened, the pressure on the ulnar artery is released, and the color of the palm is observed. Normally, the palm should regain color within 5 to 6 seconds. If it remains pale for more than 6 to 10 seconds, it suggests impaired ulnar collateral circulation. The modified Allen's test uses a time range of 5 to 15 seconds as the threshold for normal blood flow restoration.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2112 .

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of the following is used to manage the urinary symptoms in the initial stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tamsulosin is used to manage urinary symptoms in the early stages of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH). It works by inhibiting smooth muscle contraction in the prostate, reducing resistance at the bladder neck, and improving urinary flow.

Symptoms of BPH:
BPH is marked by lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) such as:

Increased urinary frequency and urgency
Nocturia (frequent urination at night)
Incontinence
Slow urinary stream
Hesitancy, urinary intermittency, or straining during urination
Splitting of the voiding stream and terminal dribbling
On physical examination, BPH is often associated with a smooth, enlarged, and non-tender prostate. PSA (prostate-specific antigen) levels are typically normal, distinguishing BPH from prostate malignancies. Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and the exclusion of malignancy (e.g., elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely necessary.

Treatment Approach:
Conservative management is recommended for patients with mild symptoms, a urine flow rate >10 ml/s, and post-void residual urine <100 ml.
Medical management includes the use of alpha-adrenergic blockers, which reduce smooth muscle contraction in the prostate. Tamsulosin, an alpha-1A adrenergic receptor antagonist, is commonly prescribed for BPH to improve urinary flow and alleviate symptoms.
By targeting the smooth muscle in the prostate, tamsulosin helps relieve the obstruction, providing symptomatic relief for those with BPH.

questions.text: Which of the following will not have bilateral hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
A retrocaval ureter does not typically result in bilateral hydronephrosis.

The circumcaval or retrocaval ureter is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC) caused by abnormal development of the right supracardinal system. In this condition, a persistent right posterior cardinal vein passes in front of the ureter, leading to its characteristic positioning. This anomaly is always found on the right side, corresponding to the location of the normal IVC.

Imaging Characteristics
The provided image illustrates a right-sided fish hook or S-shaped ureter, which represents the appearance of a retrocaval ureter as the right ureter curves behind the IVC. This characteristic configuration can help in diagnosing the condition, but it does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis.

Other options:

  • Posterior urethral valves → congenital obstruction at the level of posterior urethra → bilateral hydronephrosis.

  • Phimosis → difficulty in micturition, chronic obstruction → can cause bilateral hydronephrosis.

  • Urethral strictures → obstruction at urethra → can lead to bilateral hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with painless hematuria. He is diagnosed with bladder cancer involving the muscle layer. What is the next best step in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Radical cystectomy is the preferred treatment for patients with bladder cancer that has invaded the muscle layer.

Risk Factors: Smoking and chemical exposure are strongly linked to the development of bladder cancer.

Genetic Factors: The formation of bladder cancer is associated with the activation of oncogenes such as ras, c-erbB, and E2F3, as well as the inactivation of tumor suppressor genes including p53, p21, p16, and the Rb gene.

Clinical Features of Bladder Carcinoma:
Painless gross hematuria: The most common symptom and often indicative of bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise.
Urinary retention
Constant pelvic pain
Increased urinary frequency
Dysuria (discomfort while urinating)
Nerve involvement: May cause referred pain in the suprapubic region, groins, perineum, and thighs.

Investigations for Bladder Cancer:
Urine cytology: Low sensitivity.
Intravenous urography, non-contrast CT, and MRI: May show a filling defect.
Cystourethroscopy and biopsy: The mainstay for diagnosis.
Prognostic Factors:
The most significant prognostic factor in bladder carcinoma is the depth of invasion.

Management Strategies:
Non-Muscle Invasive Bladder Cancer:
Intravesical instillations of chemotherapeutic agents like mitomycin C or epirubicin.
Regular cystoscopic check-ups and repeat biopsy as needed.
Immunotherapy with intravesical Bacille Calmette Guerin (BCG).

Muscle Invasive Bladder Cancer:
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy: Systemic chemotherapy with combinations such as cisplatin, methotrexate, doxorubicin, and vinblastine (M-VAC) or cisplatin plus gemcitabine.
Radical cystectomy: Accompanied by urinary diversion and lymph node dissection, with or without neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
Radiotherapy: Radical beam external radiotherapy may also be utilized for invasive bladder cancer.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infection. You notice the following finding in his CECT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a horseshoe kidney, which is susceptible to obstruction, reflux, and stone formation.



Horseshoe Kidney: This is the most prevalent congenital anomaly of the kidneys and falls under the category of renal fusion anomalies. It occurs when the lower poles of the two kidneys fuse during organ development, forming an isthmus. Due to the size of the inferior mesenteric artery, which interferes with the ascent of the kidneys, they are typically positioned lower than normal.

Clinical Presentation: A horseshoe kidney typically presents as a fixed, non-mobile, firm mass located in the midline at the level of the fourth lumbar vertebra and may be resonant on percussion.

Associated Risks: Individuals with a horseshoe kidney have an increased risk of infections, stone formation, hydronephrosis, and renal tuberculosis.

Epidemiology: There is a male-to-female ratio of 2:1, indicating a higher prevalence in males. Individuals with this condition are at a greater risk for complications such as reflux, obstruction, and stone formation.

choices.text: Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is reported as a super scan with increased uptake in the bones and reduced activity in the spleen. What is the reason for this super scan appearance?
questions.solution:
The "super scan" appearance on bone scans indicates increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis.



Diffuse osteoblastic metastatic diseases, such as breast and prostate carcinomas, result in a generalized rise in skeletal uptake compared to soft tissue, along with absent or faint renal activity on a bone scan—this phenomenon is referred to as a "super scan." It can also be observed in systemic bone disorders, such as hyperparathyroidism.

Prostate carcinoma is the most prevalent malignant tumor among men over 65 years of age. Many of these cancers remain asymptomatic and are often identified through routine rectal examinations or PSA testing. Pathologically, malignant tissue is gritty and firm, contrasting with the softer, spongy appearance of benign tissue, making it easier to detect during digital rectal examination. These tumors typically develop in the gland's peripheral zone.

In terms of local extension, the disease commonly invades periprostatic tissue, seminal vesicles, and the base of the urinary bladder. Metastatic spread occurs primarily via lymphatics to the obturator and para-aortic nodes. Hematogenous dissemination predominantly affects the bones, specifically the axial skeleton, while involvement of the viscera is rare. The metastatic bone lesions are blastic and often affect the lumbar spine, proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs, in that order of frequency.
Regarding prognosis and staging, the Gleason grading system is utilized to correlate with the pathological stage, extent of spread, and prognosis of prostate cancer. Additionally, serum PSA levels are valuable for aiding in diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The provided X-ray image indicates the presence of a lower or distal ureteric stone. For stones measuring less than 6 mm, especially those located in the distal ureter, ureteroscopic removal is typically the preferred approach.

Ureteroscopic Removal Process
