1. Visualization: Ureteric stones are directly visualized using semi-rigid ureteroscopes.
2. Fragmentation and Extraction: Once identified, the stones can be fragmented and extracted with a dormia basket.

Complications:
-Ureteric perforation
-Extravasation of urine
-Avulsion of the ureter
-Ureteric stricture

questions.text: A 44-year-old lady presents to the hospital with a flank mass that is ballotable. On CT imaging, the mass measures 4cm. Urine examination shows malignant cells. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
Partial nephrectomy, also referred to as nephron-sparing surgery, is indicated for renal cell carcinoma (RCC) tumors that are less than 4 cm in size. Additionally, it is performed under the following conditions:

Indications for Partial Nephrectomy:
Tumors < 4 cm: The primary indication for nephron-sparing surgery.
Well-selected tumors between 4-7 cm: In certain cases, this size range may still be suitable for partial nephrectomy.
Bilateral tumors: When tumors are present in both kidneys.
Tumor in solitary kidneys: In cases where the patient has only one functioning kidney.
Patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction: To preserve as much renal function as possible.

Recent Trends:
There is a growing trend toward performing partial nephrectomy for stage T1b tumors, which can be larger than previously recommended thresholds, provided the tumors are well-selected. This reflects an evolving understanding of the benefits of preserving kidney function in patients with RCC.

questions.text: Which lymph node is most commonly involved in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
The most common site for metastatic disease in prostate cancer is the pelvic lymph nodes consisting Of the internal iliac and obturator nodes.

Epidemiology: Carcinoma of the prostate is the most prevalent malignant tumor in men over 65 years. It often remains asymptomatic and is typically detected during routine rectal examinations or through prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing.

Histopathology: Malignant prostate tissue has a gritty and firm consistency, contrasting with the softer, spongy texture of benign tissue, making it more palpable during digital rectal examinations. Tumors usually originate in the peripheral zone of the prostate gland.

Local and Distant Spread:
Local Extension: Prostate cancer commonly invades the periprostatic tissues, seminal vesicles, and the base of the urinary bladder.
Lymphatic Metastasis: Cancer spreads via lymphatics to the pelvic, obturator, and retroperitoneal lymph nodes.
Hematogenous Metastasis: Metastasis primarily occurs in the bones, particularly affecting the axial skeleton. The pattern of bony metastasis is typically blastic, with the lumbar spine, proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs being the most frequently involved sites.

Prognosis and Staging:
Gleason Grading System: This system correlates with the tumor's pathological stage, extent of spread, and overall prognosis.
PSA Measurement: Serum PSA levels are useful in diagnosing and managing prostate cancer, providing insight into the disease's progression and response to treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the following image?
questions.solution:
The image indicates that the patient is suffering from Fournier's gangrene, a severe and rapidly progressing necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal region. This condition is typically caused by a mixed infection involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

Risk Factors:
Concurrent conditions such as diabetes mellitus and alcoholism significantly increase the risk of developing Fournier's gangrene.

Pathophysiology:
The sequence of events leading to Fournier's gangrene includes:

1. A mixed infection involving aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.
2. Fulminant inflammation of the subcutaneous tissue.
3. Obliterative arteritis affecting the arterioles that supply blood to the scrotal skin.
4. Progression to gangrene of the affected tissues.

Affected Structures:
Typically, the testes remain unaffected due to their blood supply originating from the intra-abdominal vasculature, which is less susceptible to the inflammatory changes occurring in Fournier's gangrene.

Urgency and Prognosis:
Fournier's gangrene is considered a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention. Despite aggressive treatment, the mortality rate remains high, at approximately 50%, highlighting the severity of this condition.

choices.text: The best test to evaluate the functioning of a kidney is through a Te99 DMSA scan
It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules.
It refers to the cystic dilation of proximal convoluting tubule

questions.text: A 20 year old male presented with renal colic , hematuria and a history of reccurent nephrolithiasis. Intravenous urogram showed the following image. Which of the following statement among the following is true?
questions.solution:
The given history and intravenous urogram is suggestive of medullary cystic kidney
Medullary sponge kidney is a benign congenital disorder characterized by dilatation of distal collecting tubules (medullary and papillary portions of the collecting ducts) in one or more renal papillae, affecting one or both kidneys. Most cases of medullary sponge kidney are sporadic. A rare, autosomal recessive form is associated with Caroli disease. Most common presenting complaints include hematuria, renal colic and history of reccurent nephrolithiasis. The diagnosis of medullary sponge kidney is usually confirmed by findings on excretory urography Cystic collections of contrast media in the ectatic collecting duct are seen which are referred to as "bunches of grapes" or "bouquets of flowers."

other options - 

Uretrocele has adder/cobra head appearance

Best way to assess differential renal function is via MAG3 scan. 

Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology 7th edition • Page no: 758

questions.text: Ga-68PSMA is used to diagnose which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Gallium attached to prostate specific membrane antigen can be helpful in detecting prostate cancer. Prostate specific membrane antigen is a specific epithelial cell membrane antigen showing increased expression in prostate cancers. Ref- Goodman and Gillman 13th edition Page 1224

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, diabetic patient presented with acute onset fever and chills. She also complains of pain in the right flank area. Urine examination revealed plenty of leukocytes with glycosuria. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation — acute fever, chills, right flank pain, diabetes mellitus, and pyuria with glycosuria — along with the CT image showing gas within the renal parenchyma and collecting system, is characteristic of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

Key diagnostic clues:

  • Predisposing factor: Diabetes mellitus

  • Symptoms: Fever, flank pain, chills

  • Urine findings: Pyuria, bacteriuria, glycosuria

  • Imaging: CT showing gas within the renal parenchyma, collecting system, or perinephric tissues

    Other options:

  • Volvulus: Presents with abdominal distension and obstruction, not flank pain or pyuria.

  • Cholecystitis: Right upper quadrant pain, not flank pain.

  • Small bowel obstruction: Multiple air-fluid levels, not gas in renal parenchyma.


Reference:Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology 6th edition page no 847

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency with a painless mass in his abdomen. Examination revealed a large, mobile abdomen mass that does not cross the midline. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 4-year-old child with a painless, palpable, smooth, firm, and mobile abdominal mass that does not cross the midline is characteristic of Wilms’ tumor (nephroblastoma) — a malignant renal tumor commonly seen in children between 2–5 years of age.

Other key points:

  • The mass typically arises from the kidney.

  • It may cause hematuria or hypertension due to renin secretion.

  • It remains confined to one side and does not cross the midline, which helps distinguish it from neuroblastoma.

  • Diagnosis is confirmed by ultrasound and CT/MRI, followed by surgical and histopathological evaluation.




Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 835

questions.text: A young male patient developed abdominal pain for which he was being evaluated. CT and IVU findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A horseshoe kidney is a congenital renal fusion anomaly where the lower poles of both kidneys are fused across the midline, typically by an isthmus of functioning renal tissue or fibrous band, lying anterior to the aorta and inferior vena cava.

Key radiological features (CT / IVU):

  • Both kidneys are located lower than normal (failed ascent due to inferior mesenteric artery obstruction).

  • The lower poles are fused in the midline.

  • The renal pelves face anteriorly (“malrotation”).

  • The isthmus can be seen crossing the midline, usually at L3–L5 level.

  • IVU shows a “flower vase” or “handcuff” appearance of the collecting system.

Clinical significance:

  • Often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally.

  • Can be associated with:

    • Ureteropelvic junction obstruction

    • Hydronephrosis

    • Stone formation

    • Increased risk of Wilms tumor or renal cell carcinoma



Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1399

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. On examination, a 2x2 cm bladder mass is noted. The gross specimen image is given below. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
• The patient is an elderly male with a small (2x2 cm) bladder mass presenting with hematuria.

  • First-line management for a localized, non-muscle invasive bladder tumor is TURBT. This allows:

    • Diagnosis: Provides tissue for histopathology and staging.

    • Treatment: Complete removal of superficial tumors.

  • Other options:

    • Partial cystectomy: Considered for select muscle-invasive tumors in specific locations, not for small superficial tumors.

    • Intravesical BCG: Used as adjuvant therapy after TURBT for high-risk non-muscle invasive tumors, not as initial management.

    • Radical cystectomy: Reserved for muscle-invasive or recurrent high-risk tumors.


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 28th edition page no 1515-9

choices.text: Cystoscopy and removal of the foreign body

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and flank pain. History revealed that he underwent kidney stone removal 4 years back. Imaging was done and a foreign body was detected. What is the appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with fever, flank pain, and a history of kidney stone removal, raising suspicion for a retained foreign body (e.g., a migrated stent, surgical material).

  • Imaging confirms a foreign body, which can serve as a nidus for infection or stone formation.

  • Cystoscopy is the least invasive and preferred approach to remove a foreign body from the urinary tract.

  • Other options:

    • Leave the foreign body inside: Not appropriate due to risk of infection, obstruction, and stone formation.

    • Retro-urethral approach: Rarely indicated; less practical than cystoscopy.

    • Laparotomy: Reserved for cases where endoscopic removal fails or the foreign body is not accessible via minimally invasive means.



Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 28th edition page no 1559

questions.text: A man was brought after he fell into a manhole and injured his perineum. He was unable to pass urine and blood was seen at the tip of the urethra. A diagnosis of bulbar urethral injury was made. Where do you expect the urine to get collected in this case?
questions.solution:
• Bulbar urethra injury (part of the anterior urethra) usually occurs due to straddle injuries or blunt perineal trauma.

  • In such injuries, urine leaks into the deep perineal pouch because the bulb of the penis lies within the superficial perineal space, but the urethra is surrounded by the urogenital diaphragm, which allows urine to track into the deep perineal space.

  • Other options:

    • Anterior abdominal wall: Seen in bladder rupture or intraperitoneal leaks.

    • Medial portion of thigh: Occurs in proximal spongiosal tears with Buck’s fascia disruption.

    • Ischiorectal fossa: Typically associated with posterior urethral injuries, e.g., membranous urethra in pelvic fracture.

Key point: Blood at the urethral meatus + inability to void strongly suggests urethral injury. Retrograde urethrogram is diagnostic before attempting catheterization.


Reference:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition Page no 1233

questions.text: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a young girl who has continuous urinary dribbling but can also void normally, the most likely cause is an ectopic ureter draining distal to the external urethral sphincter. This condition is more common in females, because ectopic ureters in girls can open into the vagina, vestibule, or urethra, bypassing voluntary control.

Key Features of Ectopic Ureter (in Females):

Feature Description
Urinary Dribbling Continuous, passive leak of urine
Voluntary Voiding Normal voiding possible if one ureter inserts normally
Dry Periods? Never totally dry since birth
Cause Ureter from duplicated collecting system drains ectopically
Diagnosis MRI Urography / Cystoscopy / DTPA scan
Treatment Surgical correction (e.g. ureteral reimplantation)


Other options: 

  • Ureterocele: Usually presents with UTI or obstruction, not continuous incontinence.

  • Congenital megaureter: Can cause infections or obstruction but not continuous dribbling with normal voiding.

  • Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR): Leads to recurrent UTIs, but not continuous dribbling.


Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition Page no 2584

questions.text: A 1-month-old child is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the next step of management in this child?
questions.solution:
In a 1-month-old male infant with bilateral undescended testes (palpable in the inguinal canal), the appropriate next step is observation. Most undescended testes descend spontaneously within the first 6 months of life.

Key Guidelines:

Age Management
< 6 months Wait and watch – spontaneous descent likely
6 months – 1 year If not descended, plan orchidopexy (ideally by 6–12 months of age)
> 1 year Spontaneous descent unlikely – perform surgical orchidopexy
Non-palpable testis May need diagnostic laparoscopy or imaging to locate testis
Suspicion of DSD (Disorder of Sex Development) Karyotyping indicated if scrotum is empty + ambiguous genitalia


Other options: 

  • Orchidopexy now (1 month): Too early. Guidelines recommend waiting until at least 6 months.

  • Surgical exploration within 2 weeks: Not necessary unless there are complications or suspicion of torsion.

  • Karyotyping: Not indicated routinely in a male infant with bilateral palpable testes and normal genitalia.


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1499

questions.text: The most common type of renal stones are:
questions.solution:
Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of renal (kidney) stones, accounting for approximately 70–80% of all cases. These stones can form in individuals with hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, low urinary citrate, or simply due to low fluid intake and concentrated urine.

Other options:

  • Cystine stones: Rare; seen in cystinuria, a genetic disorder of amino acid transport.

  • Triple phosphate stones (struvite stones): Composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate; occur in urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing organisms like Proteus.

  • Uric acid stones: Account for about 5–10% of stones; common in gout, high purine intake, or acidic urine.



Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1406

questions.text: Whitaker test is indicated for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The Whitaker test is a urodynamic study used to assess whether hydronephrosis is due to a functional obstruction in the upper urinary tract. Although not commonly performed today because of advanced imaging techniques, it still holds value in select cases with inconclusive findings.

In this test, the patient is positioned prone on a fluoroscopic table. A percutaneous nephrostomy catheter is introduced into the renal pelvis and connected to a pressure transducer. A second catheter is already placed in the bladder. A mixture of saline and contrast is infused into the renal pelvis at a fixed rate (typically 10 mL/min). As fluid flows from the pelvis to the bladder, the hydrostatic pressure in the renal pelvis is measured and compared to the bladder pressure.

If the renal pelvic pressure remains below 15 cm Hâ‚‚O, the system is considered non-obstructed. Readings between 15 and 22 cm Hâ‚‚O are interpreted as equivocal, while pressures above 22 cm Hâ‚‚O indicate significant obstruction.

The test is particularly useful in cases where:

  • The diuretic renogram is inconclusive,

  • There is persistent loin pain without demonstrable obstruction,

  • Intermittent obstruction is suspected,

  • The affected kidney is severely dilated or has reduced function, making radionuclide studies unreliable.

While no longer a first-line test, the Whitaker study remains a functional test that provides direct pressure measurements—especially valuable when other imaging fails to clarify the cause of hydronephrosis.


Reference:Brenners and Rectors The Kidney 10th edition page no 1268

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with scrotal swelling. On examination, one can feel the testis separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling shows transillumination. The fluid aspirated from the swelling resembles barley water in appearance. The most probable diagnosis Is
questions.solution:
Key clinical features:

Feature Interpretation
Scrotal swelling Suggests fluid or mass
Testis felt separately Indicates fluid collection, not involving testis
Transillumination positive Suggests clear fluid collection like in a hydrocele
Barley water–like fluid Classic description of hydrocele fluid

 
Diagnosis Key Features
Primary hydrocele Painless, transilluminant swelling, testis separate, barley water fluid
Secondary hydrocele Associated with underlying pathology (tumor, infection), may be painful
Epididymal cyst Arises from epididymis, cystic, usually smaller, clear fluid, testis separate
Spermatocele Arises from rete testis, sperm-containing fluid (milky), behind testis

Why primary hydrocoele?

  • Testis separate → typical for hydrocele

  • Transillumination → clear fluid

  • Barley water fluid → diagnostic for primary vaginal hydrocele

 

Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1504-1505

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A varicocele is an abnormal dilation of the pampiniform plexus of veins within the scrotum. It commonly presents as a painless or dull, throbbing scrotal pain and may be associated with infertility due to increased testicular temperature affecting spermatogenesis. On examination, a "bag of worms" consistency is felt, especially during a Valsalva maneuver (when the patient stands and bears down).

Varicoceles are most commonly left-sided, due to the drainage of the left testicular vein into the left renal vein at a right angle, which increases hydrostatic pressure. If a right-sided varicocele is found, especially in isolation, it raises concern for retroperitoneal or renal pathology, such as renal cell carcinoma, and further imaging is warranted.

Treatment is not always necessary. Asymptomatic patients or elderly individuals often do not require intervention and can be managed conservatively with NSAIDs and scrotal support.

In younger patients, especially those with infertility or discomfort, surgical treatment may be offered. This includes:

  • Inguinal (Ivanissevich) approach

  • Retroperitoneal (Palomo operation)

  • Laparoscopic or transluminal endoscopic surgery

An alternative to surgery is transvenous embolization by an interventional radiologist.


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1501

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma is found to have a tumor that is 10 cm in size, situated at the lower pole of the kidney with negative regional lymph nodes. Which of the following is the preferred management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a renal cell carcinoma (RCC) that is:

  • 10 cm in size → T2 tumor (T2a: 7–10 cm; T2b: >10 cm, still confined to kidney)

  • Confined to the kidney (no lymph node involvement or metastasis)

  • Located at the lower pole, but the large size makes partial nephrectomy less ideal.

    Management Approach (According to AUA & EAU Guidelines):

Feature Recommendation
Tumor ≤4 cm (T1a) Partial nephrectomy (nephron-sparing surgery) preferred
Tumor >4 cm and ≤7 cm (T1b) Partial or radical nephrectomy depending on location and surgical feasibility
Tumor >7 cm but confined to kidney (T2) Radical nephrectomy is standard of care
Involvement of lymph nodes or metastasis Consider systemic therapy (targeted therapy/immunotherapy)


Other options: 

  • Partial nephrectomy: Not suitable for large (10 cm) tumors due to limited renal preservation benefits and risk of positive margins.

  • Chemotherapy: RCC is chemoresistant.

  • Radiotherapy: Not effective for primary RCC (used only for palliation in metastasis, e.g., brain or bone).


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1419-1420

questions.text: A patient with a left-sided scrotal mass is being evaluated and on examination the mass is found to be hard in consistency with irregular margins with no reduction on lying down or on manipulation and no cough impulse but with fullness in para-aortic lymph nodes . What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A hard, irregular, non-reducible scrotal mass without cough impulse, not changing with position, and associated with para-aortic lymphadenopathy strongly suggests a testicular malignancy with metastasis.

Key Clinical Clues:

Feature Interpretation
Hard, irregular scrotal mass Suggests solid malignancy, not fluid (r/o hydrocele)
No reduction on lying down or manipulation Not hernia (which is often reducible)
No cough impulse Not hernia (hernia typically has cough impulse)
Para-aortic lymphadenopathy Common site of metastasis for testicular tumors via lymphatic drainage (especially on the left side)

Other options: 

  • Indirect Inguinal Hernia: Usually reducible, has a cough impulse, and follows the inguinal canal.

  • Direct Inguinal Hernia: Also reducible and has a cough impulse.

  • Hydrocele: Typically fluctuant, transilluminant, and not associated with lymphadenopathy.



Reference: Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1506

questions.text: A splenectomy was performed on a female with steroid-resistant ITP. On day 3 post-laparoscopy surgery, the patient had a fever. Which are the most likely scenarios to follow?
questions.solution:
Fever on postoperative day 3 after laparoscopic splenectomy suggests left lower lobe consolidation.
Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after OS; pleural effusion and pneumonia also can occur.

Hemorrhage can occur intraoperatively or postoperatively, presenting as subphrenic hematoma. Subphrenic abscess and wound infection are among the perioperative infectious complications.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 381.

questions.text: Which of these has the highest risk of developing pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
 
  • Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder STK 11 gene, characterized by the development of hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • Individuals with Peutz-Jegher's syndrome have an increased risk of developing various types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer.
  • The risk of developing pancreatic cancer in individuals with Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is estimated to be significantly higher compared to the general population.
  • It also has mucosal lentigens. 
  • Hereditary atypical multiple mole melanoma syndrome, hereditary pancreatitis, and familial adenomatous polyposis are associated with an increased risk of certain cancers but not specifically pancreatic cancer.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1309.

questions.text: Hematemesis and upper abdominal discomfort are reported by an adult. A growth near the stomach's pyloric antrum was discovered through endoscopy. The pyloric antrum was the site of growth on the CT scan, and there was no evidence of distant metastases, infiltration, or invasion. Neoplastic growth was seen during laparotomy to encompass the stomach's posterior wall and the pancreas, extending 6 cm up to the tail of the pancreas. What surgical treatment will be most suitable?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Partial gastrectomy + distal pancreatectomy
 
  • The most suitable surgical treatment in this case would be option C, which involves performing a partial gastrectomy and distal pancreatectomy.
  • Given the neoplastic growth involving the stomach's posterior wall and extending up to the tail of the pancreas, this approach would ensure adequate resection of the tumor while preserving as much organ function as possible.
  • The addition of a splenectomy (option D) may be considered if there is involvement of the spleen or suspicion of metastasis, but it is not mentioned in the given scenario.
  • Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following: Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail Tumors of size >2 cm Tumors located within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1284.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for annular pancreas in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Duodenoduodenostomy  
 
  • Annular pancreas is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal stenosis or atresia.
  • It occurs because of the failure of a complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development, so a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.
  • Duodenal obstruction typically causes vomiting in the neonate.
  • Treatment is duodenoduodenostomy, which involves creating a connection between two segments of the duodenum to bypass the obstruction caused by the annular pancreas.
  • Annular pancreas is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia or stenosis and is therefore more prevalent in children with Down syndrome.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1267.

questions.text: Since three months ago, a woman has experienced repeated bouts of giddiness and stomach pain. The endoscopy went well. Her insulin levels were high, and her fasting blood glucose level was 40 mg%. There were no other abdominal findings on the CT abdomen, only a well-defined 8 mm enhancing lesion at the head of the pancreas. What course of action should be taken with this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Enucleation 
 
  • The presence of an 8 mm enhancing lesion at the head of the pancreas in a patient with high insulin levels and low blood glucose suggests an insulinoma, which is a neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas. Whipples triad is seen. 
  • Insulinomas having diameter of <2 cm without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. Tumor enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.
* Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:
  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors located within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1481.

questions.text: The most typical spleen cysts are:
questions.solution:
The most typical spleen cysts are hydatid cysts, which are caused by the larvae of the Echinococcus tapeworm.
Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver.
Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice Dermatoid cysts (option B), pseudocysts (option C), and lymphangiomas (option D) can also occur in the spleen but are less common.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 73.

questions.text: Six hours after an RTA, a 27-year-old patient arrived at the emergency room complaining of left-sided stomach pain. He had steady hemodynamics and tested positive for FAST. Grade III splenic laceration was discovered by contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) imaging. What medical procedure is most suitable?
questions.solution:
Hemodynamically stable grade 1 to 3 injuries are managed conservatively.

Non-operative Management
  • When facilities are available, splenic injury can be managed conservatively by non-operative management (NOM). 80% of blunt splenic injuries can be managed non-operatively (success is more in children).
  • Clinically close observation, serial haematocrit evaluationand serial CT abdomen/US abdomen at regular intervals to assess the progress or regress of the bleeding spleen has to be done.
    It is often supported by angiographic selective embolisation using gelfoam,coils and stents to improve the splenic salvage rate.
    But it may cause pain, splenic abscess or infarction. Indications for non-operative treatment: (1) Only splenic injury-no other associated injuries. (2) Grade I, II and Ill injuries. (3) Haemodynamically stable patient
  • Absolute bed rest (for 2- 3 weeks), sedation(initially), antibiotic coverage and proper monitoring are needed.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 663.

questions.text: Six hours after an RTA, a 27-year-old patient arrives at the emergency room complaining of left-sided stomach pain. He had steady hemodynamics and tested positive for FAST. A grade III laceration and contrast flush are visible on a CECT scan. What type of management will be most effective?
questions.solution:
Contrast blush on CECT indicates active hemorrhage. A patient with stable hemodynamics should undergo endovascular intervention and embolisation should be attempted.

Non-operative Management
  • When facilities are available, splenic injury can be managed conservatively by non-operative management (NOM). 80% of blunt splenic injuries can be managed non-operatively (success is more in children).
  • Clinically close observation, serial haematocrit evaluation and serial CT abdomen/US abdomen at regular intervals to assess the progress or regress of the bleeding spleen has to be done.
  • Absolute bed rest (for 2- 3 weeks), sedation(initially), antibiotic coverage and proper monitoring are needed.
  • It is often supported by angiographic selective embolisation using gelfoam,coils and stents to improve the splenic salvage rate. But it may cause pain, splenic abscess or infarction.
  • Indications for non-operative treatment: (1) Only splenic injury-no other associated injuries. (2) Grade I, II and Ill injuries. (3) Haemodynamically stable patient.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 663.

choices.text: Injury to the left lobe to the diaphragm

questions.text: A woman with a stab wound to the left side of her abdomen visited the emergency room. She had stable hemodynamics, and a contrast-enhanced CT scan showed that her spleen had been lacerated. The patient was scheduled for a laparoscopy, but as soon as the pneumoperitoneum was formed, the patient's pO2 abruptly fell. What is the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Gaseous embolism through splenic vessels 
 
  • The abrupt fall in pO2 after pneumoperitoneum formation suggests a gaseous embolism.
  • When performing laparoscopy, creating a pneumoperitoneum involves insufflating carbon dioxide gas into the abdominal cavity.
  • While rare, a potential complication is the entry of gas into blood vessels, resulting in a gaseous embolism.
  • In this case, if carbon dioxide gas entered the splenic vessels, it could lead to a sudden decrease in pO2 as the embolism obstructs the flow of oxygenated blood.
This can cause a significant drop in oxygen levels.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1620.

questions.text: A patient says they've had a fever for three weeks. He is discovered to have splenomegaly upon evaluation. A hypoechoic shadow is visible on ultrasonography in the spleen close to the hilum. In blood culture, gram-negative bacteria are isolated. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Salmonella 

The clinical presentation of fever, splenomegaly, and a hypoechoic shadow in the spleen close to the hilum suggests the possibility of splenic abscess.
In cases of splenic abscess, gram-negative bacteria, especially Salmonella, are commonly isolated.

Causes of splenic abscess:
  • Infected splenic embolus, in association with typhoid and paratyphoid fever,
  • osteomyelitis,
  • otitis media
  • puerperal sepsis,
  • pancreatic necrosis
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1538.

questions.text: A splenectomy is being scheduled for a patient with ITP who has a platelet count of 50,000. When is the ideal time to administer platelets to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: After ligating the splenic artery 
 
  • In patients with ITP (immune thrombocytopenic purpura) undergoing splenectomy, administering platelets after ligating the splenic artery is the ideal timing.
  • Ligation of the splenic artery results in the isolation of the spleen from the circulation, reducing the risk of platelet sequestration and destruction, and maximizing platelet survival.
  • Administering platelets before surgery (options A and B) may result in rapid consumption and inadequate platelet count during the surgical procedure.
  • Administering platelets immediately after removal of the spleen (option D) is not as effective in preventing platelet sequestration and destruction during the surgical manipulation.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1535.

questions.text: Name the commonest pancreatic endocrine neoplasm
questions.solution:
Insulinoma
Insulinomas are the most common functioning pancreatic endocrine tumors.
  • They are rare (approximately 4 cases per million per year) but are the most common cause of hyper insulinemic hypoglycemia in adults.
  • It has a slight female predominance, and the median age at diagnosis is in the fifth decade of life. Insulinoma is a type of pancreatic tumor (endocrine neoplasm) that results in the overproduction of insulin.
  • This can lead to dangerously low levels of glucose in the blood (hypoglycemia).
  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia include weakness, sweating, tremor, tachycardia (rapid heart rate), anxiety, fatigue, dizziness, disorientation, and seizures.
  • Malignancy is typically not associated with insulinoma, with only 10% of cases being deemed malignant.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1480.

questions.text: Which of the following does not correlate with the severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Level of amylase does not correlate with severity of acute pancreatitis.
Severe pancreatitis is diagnosed if three or more of the Ranson's criteria are fulfilled.
All the other factors in the options are included in the criteria which are checked either at the time or 48 hours after admission.



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1445.

choices.text: Pathologic confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor
Absence of gross invasion of the superior mesenteric vessels and portal vein

questions.text: All of the following criteria must be met in order to perform a Whipple surgery except
questions.solution:
The correct answer is:

1. Pathologic confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor

  • Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy) is performed for resectable pancreatic head tumors, often without prior pathological confirmation because obtaining a biopsy can risk tumor seeding or delay surgery.
  • Instead, imaging (CT/MRI/PET) and clinical suspicion guide the decision for surgery.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1556.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely recommended surgical procedure of choice in a case where a fifty year old lady presents with two year history of recurrent abdominal pain with radiation to her back. Pain is severe in intensity and refractory, to simple analgesics. Ultrasound and contrast Enhanced CT scan (CECT) confirmed the diagnosis and showed a dilated pancreatic duct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Longitudinal Pancreatico jejunostomy 
 
  • In this case of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks, 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct, and intraductal calculi, longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (also known as Puestow procedure or lateral pancreaticojejunostomy) is the surgery of choice.
  • This procedure involves opening the pancreatic duct along its length and connecting it to a loop of the jejunum, which helps to drain the obstructed pancreatic duct and alleviate pain.


Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1473.

questions.text: All of the following vaccines against gram-negative organisms are taken before splenectomy except?
questions.solution:
• Pre-splenectomy - Vaccination is done at least 2 weeks prior to elective splenectomy for H. influenza, Meningococcus, Pneumococcus (All three being encapsulated organisms), and Influenza.
  • Vaccine against Typhoid is not recommended prior to splenectomy. 
 

Before splenectomy, vaccines against gram-negative organisms are crucial to protect against infections due to the loss of the spleen's immune function. The vaccines recommended include:

  • H. influenzae type b (Hib): Protection against Haemophilus influenzae type b, which is a gram-negative bacterium.
  • Meningococcal: Protection against Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative bacterium.
  • Pneumococcus: Protection against Streptococcus pneumoniae, which, while a gram-positive bacterium, is recommended before splenectomy due to the risk of severe infections.
 

Typhoid vaccine is not typically recommended before splenectomy, as Salmonella typhi (the causative organism of typhoid) is not as commonly associated with life-threatening infections in splenectomized individuals compared to the others listed. However, typhoid vaccination may still be recommended in certain geographic areas or depending on travel history.




Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 133, 223, 230, 333.

Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1230, 1231

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic obese male patient presented to the emergency department with severe pain abdomen radiating to the back. Blood investigations revealed increased serum amylase and lipase levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient is a 45-year-old alcoholic, obese male with sudden severe abdominal pain radiating to the back, which is classic for pancreatitis.

  • Laboratory findings: Elevated serum amylase and lipase confirm pancreatic inflammation.

  • Risk factors: Chronic alcohol intake and obesity are well-known predisposing factors for acute pancreatitis.

  • Other options:

    • Peptic ulcer disease: Causes epigastric pain but usually does not radiate to the back, and amylase/lipase are normal.

    • Acute cholecystitis: Pain is localized to right upper quadrant, often with Murphy’s sign; amylase/lipase may be mildly elevated but not typically diagnostic.

    • Pyogenic liver abscess: Causes fever, right upper quadrant tenderness, hepatomegaly, not back-radiating pain, and amylase/lipase are normal.

High-yield point: Severe epigastric pain radiating to the back + high amylase/lipase in an alcoholic patient → acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic obese male patient presented to the emergency department with severe pain abdomen radiating to the back. Blood investigations revealed increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has acute pancreatitis. Management focuses on fluid resuscitation, pain control, and pancreatic rest.

  • Nil per oral (NPO): Necessary initially to reduce pancreatic stimulation.

  • 5% dextrose: Should be avoided as the sole fluid because it is hypotonic and can worsen hypovolemia and cause hyperglycemia, especially in alcoholic or obese patients prone to insulin resistance. Isotonic fluids like Ringer’s lactate are preferred for volume resuscitation.

  • Early initiation of oral feedings: In mild pancreatitis, early enteral feeding (low-fat diet) can be started once pain improves and nausea subsides; it is not harmful in appropriately selected patients.

  • Parenteral nutrition: Only used if the patient cannot tolerate enteral feeding for a prolonged period; otherwise, enteral nutrition is preferred.

Key point:
For acute pancreatitis, isotonic fluids like Ringer’s lactate are recommended. 5% dextrose alone is inappropriate for initial fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea, dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Which of the following neuroendocrine tumors can be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario presented is indicative of VIPoma (vasoactive intestinal peptide secreting tumor).

VIPomas are a type of neuroendocrine tumor that excessively secretes vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). This condition is also referred to as Verner-Morrison syndrome or WDHA syndrome.

WDHA stands for:

Watery Diarrhea: Characterized by large-volume, watery diarrhea.
Hypokalemia: Low potassium levels in the blood due to diarrhea-induced losses.
Achlorhydria: Absence of hydrochloric acid in gastric secretions.
Diagnosis:

Confirmation can be achieved by measuring elevated levels of plasma VIP and obtaining a detailed history of large-volume diarrhea.

Treatment:

Initial management focuses on correcting dehydration, hypokalemia, and electrolyte imbalances through fluid and electrolyte replacement.
Long-acting somatostatin analogs, such as octreotide and lanreotide, are the preferred pharmacological treatments, as they help inhibit VIP secretion and reduce diarrhea.
 

Other options:

  • Glucagonoma: Causes necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes, anemia, glossitis.

  • Somatostatinoma: Causes diabetes, steatorrhea, gallstones (inhibition of insulin, CCK, secretin).

  • Insulinoma: Causes recurrent hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin secretion.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents to the emergency room with acute pain abdomen in the epigastric region radiating to the back with nausea, anorexia, and occasional vomiting. Investigations showed elevated amylase levels and total count. Likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A history of epigastric pain radiating to the back in a chronic alcoholic patient, along with elevated serum amylase levels, is most consistent with a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis.

Acute pancreatitis is often associated with risk factors such as heavy alcohol consumption, gallstones, and certain medications. The classic presentation includes severe abdominal pain, often described as a sudden onset of a persistent and severe epigastric pain that may radiate to the back, along with gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and vomiting. The elevation of pancreatic enzymes like amylase and lipase supports the diagnosis.

Other options:

  • Acute cholecystitis → RUQ pain, Murphy’s sign positive.

  • Acute hepatitis → hepatomegaly, jaundice, ↑ transaminases, not epigastric pain radiating to back.

  • Acute appendicitis → periumbilical → RLQ pain, not epigastric with back radiation.

questions.text: A male patient presented with severe abdominal pain. On examination, the patient's BP is 80/40 mm hg, and the following finding is noted. CT abdomen is normal. What ts the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with severe abdominal pain and hypotension (BP 80/40 mmHg), which may indicate systemic inflammatory response or hypovolemia.

  • CT abdomen is normal – in early acute pancreatitis, imaging may be normal because pancreatic changes develop after 48–72 hours.

  • Clinical features like sudden epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, vomiting, and hypotension are highly suggestive of acute pancreatitis.

  • Other options:

    • Chronic pancreatitis: Usually presents with recurrent abdominal pain, steatorrhea, and diabetes, not acute shock.

    • Acute appendicitis: Pain usually starts peri-umbilical and localizes to RIF; hypotension is uncommon unless perforation with sepsis occurs.

    • Fat necrosis: Usually a complication or histopathological finding, not an acute clinical diagnosis.



Reference:Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition Page no 1533-1536

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below which shows ‘colon cut-off sign”. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis: Acute Pancreatitis

  • Based on 2 out of 3 criteria:

    1. Epigastric pain radiating to back

    2. Elevated serum lipase/amylase >3× ULN

    3. Imaging (CT/MRI/USG) suggestive of pancreatitis

      Colon Cut-Off Sign (Classic Radiological Clue):

  • Seen on X-ray: Sudden stop of colonic gas at splenic flexure

  • Mechanism: Inflammation of pancreas irritates the phrenicocolic ligament, causing colonic spasm

  • Seen in: Severe or necrotizing pancreatitis

    Common Causes ("I GET SMASHED" Mnemonic):

Category Examples
Idiopathic ~15–20% cases
Gallstones Most common worldwide
Ethanol Most common in chronic alcoholics
Trauma Especially pediatric/seatbelt injuries
Steroids Drug-induced
Mumps / infections Mumps, Coxsackie B
Autoimmune IgG4-related disease
Scorpion sting Red scorpion sting (Trinidad)
Hypercalcemia & hyperparathyroidism
ERCP Post-procedural
Drugs Azathioprine, valproate, thiazides, etc.

Clinical Presentation

  • Pain: Sudden, severe epigastric, radiating to back

  • Relief: Leaning forward

  • Associated: Nausea, vomiting, hiccups

  • Systemic signs:

    • Fever, tachycardia, hypotension

    • Grey Turner sign: Flank ecchymosis

    • Cullen sign: Umbilical ecchymosis

    • Pleural effusion: More on left

      Key Lab Findings

Test Finding Significance
Serum amylase ↑ (early), less specific Rises in other GI conditions
Serum lipase ↑ (longer duration) More specific than amylase
Calcium ↓ (saponification) Severity marker
Glucose ↑ Islet cell dysfunction
WBC count ↑ Inflammatory response
ALT > 150 IU/L Suggestive of gallstone etiology
BUN/Creatinine May rise in necrotizing cases

Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1224

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has a slow onset soft, uncomfortable swelling on the back of her leg. Without any significant arterial feeder, colour Doppler revealed several venous channels. Except for________, all of the following are employed as liquid embolizing agents
questions.solution:
Except for absolute alcohol, all of the other options (polyvinyl alcohol, sodium tetradecyl sulfate, and cyanoacrylate) are employed as liquid embolizing agents for treating venous malformations or varices.
Absolute alcohol is used as a sclerosing agent rather than a liquid embolic agent in such cases.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 228.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old patient with a history of severe hemoptysis arrived at the emergency room. His usual exams and chest X-ray were clear.
Which of the following is not a method of hemoptysis prevention?
questions.solution:
In clinical practice, massive hemoptysis may be defined as greater than 400 mL of blood loss from the lungs in 24 hours, or bleeding at a rate of more than 100 mL/hr, regardless of whether abnormal gas exchange or hemodynamic instability exists.
The proximal airways may be occluded with only 150 mL of clotted blood, and even lower volume hemoptysis may be life-threatening.
Conservative management may consist of maintaining a functional and patent airway, bronchoscopy, clearing the airway of blood, cough suppression (with codeine), and monitoring until stabilized.
Angiographic catheterization for massive hemoptysis may be considered in patients with hemoptysis.
EACA has been used in numerous clinical situations to control bleeding and has been claimed to be an effective agent in subarachnoid hemorrhage, genitourinary bleeding from many causes, and in dental surgery in hemophiliacs.
It may also be effective in several less well studied situations such as prophylaxis of bleeding episodes in hemophiliacs, control of menorrhagia, gastrointestinal bleeding, obstetrical bleeding and in bleeding following cardiac and thoracic surgery.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1616.

questions.text: What recommendations will you provide a cardiac tamponade patient while testing his blood pressure?
questions.solution:
While measuring blood pressure of a cardiac tamponade patient, the patient should breath normally.

Moderate to severe cardiac tamponade, and occasionally constrictive pericarditis, induce hemodynamic changes that enhance the inspiratory fall in systolic blood pressure. This exaggerated drop in systemic blood pressure during inspiration is termed pulsus paradoxus.

Since the depth of respiration influences the severity of pulsus,  patient should not be instructed to change his/her breathing pattern during this evaluation.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 375.

questions.text: How can you tell the difference between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Raised JVP, pulse pressure and muffled heart sounds along with pulsus paradoxus are seen in both cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax.

These are differentiated by auscultation for breath sounds, which are normal in cardiac tamponade but absent in tension pneumothorax patients.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 375.

choices.text: Pneumatic compression stocking to prevent the DVT

questions.text: What is the device listed below:
questions.solution:
The given device is pneumatic compression stocking, used to prevent DVT.

Intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) devices are used to help prevent blood clots in the deep veins of the legs. The devices use cuffs around the legs that fill with air and squeeze your legs. This increases blood flow through the veins of your legs and helps prevent blood clots.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 998.

questions.text: Select the most common symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease.
questions.solution:
Most common symptom of aortoiliac disease is gluteal claudication.
  • “The site of claudication is distal to the location of the occlusive lesion.
  • For example, buttock, hip, thigh, and calf discomfort occurs in patients with aortoiliac disease, whereas calf claudication develops in patients with femoral- popliteal disease.” “Aortoiliac disease (30 per cent of cases) may cause thigh or buttock claudication.
  • Buttock claudication in association with sexual impotence resulting from arterial insufficiency is eponymously called Leriche’s syndrome. It is very rare.”


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1000.

questions.text: What is the mortality rate linked with emergency abdominal aortic surgery?
questions.solution:
Mortality associated with emergency abdominal aortic surgery is >50%.

The operational mortality rate is about 1-2% with adequate preoperative cardiac examination and after care. 

The mortality rate of an emergency procedure following an acute rupture is 45–50%. In Abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture Less than half of victims make it to the hospital. Death is practically certain if no surgery is done. More than 50% of patients survive if operation is done.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: What is the mortality rate associated with emergency abdominal aortic surgery for RAAA(Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms)?
questions.solution:
By providing adequate preoperative cardiac evaluation and close postoperative monitoring, the mortality rate for elective operative treatment is about 1-2%.

However, for those who experience an acute rupture, the fatality rate for emergency operations reaches 45-50%.

An alternative method of endovascular repair with stent placement is becoming more commonplace, however, it presently carries a mortality rate of approximately 40%.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: What is the mortality rate associated with emergency abdominal aortic surgery for ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: >50
 
  • Emergency abdominal aortic surgery for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm is a high-risk procedure associated with significant mortality.
  • The mortality rate for this procedure is generally greater than 50%.
  • Options A, B, and C underestimate the mortality rate associated with this surgical intervention.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: The optimal stent for femoropopliteal bypass is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Femoropopliteal bypass is used to treat stenosis or occlusion involving superficial femoral artery.
• Best graft material is autogenous saphenous vein.
• It can be used reversed or in situ after valve disruption.
• If no vein is available, a prosthetic poly tetrafluorothylene (PTFE) graft is used.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1005.

questions.text: Cutoff for surgery in abdominal aortic aneurysm in asymptomatic pts:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 5.5cm
 
  • The cutoff size for surgical intervention in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms is generally accepted to be 5.5cm.
  • Once the aneurysm reaches this size or larger, the risk of rupture increases significantly, and the benefit of surgical repair outweighs the risks associated with surgery.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

choices.text: USG monitoring till size of the aneurysm reaches 70 mm

questions.text: Select the correct management procedure of a patient with mild abdominal pain and an abdominal aortic aneurysm
questions.solution:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common type of large vessel aneurysm, found in 2% of the population. It usually remains asymptomatic, but may cause mild symptoms like back pain and abdominal discomfort.
However, rupture of an aneurysm produces severe pain in the back and abdomen, in addition to hypotension. The annual risk of rupture is low (1% or less) for aneurysms that are smaller than 55 mm in diameter, but increases significantly (up to 25%) for aneurysms with a diameter of 70 mm or more. Regular ultrasound assessments are indicated for asymptomatic aneurysms smaller than 55 mm in diameter, and repair of the aneurysm should be considered if the diameter is greater than 55 mm.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: Name the vessel involved in cramping gluteal pain of a 30 years old mom after walking 500 m.
questions.solution:
Claudication pain is a type of cramping pain that is felt after walking or exercising.
  • It is caused by a decrease in the blood supply to the muscles due to arterial insufficiency.
  • Claudication pain typically affects the muscle group one anatomical level below the area suffering from arterial insufficiency.
  • For instance, if claudication pain is felt in the calf, the likely cause is an issue with the superficial femoral artery, which is the most common artery affected in 70% of cases. In 30% of cases, aorto-iliac disease is the cause of the claudication pain, and this can also be associated with sexual impotence. This combination of claudication pain and impotence is referred to as Leriche's syndrome.
  • Claudication pain is a type of cramping pain that is felt after walking or exercising.
  • It is caused by a decrease in the blood supply to the muscles due to arterial insufficiency. Claudication pain typically affects the muscle group one anatomical level below the area suffering from arterial insufficiency.
  • For instance, if claudication pain is felt in the calf, the likely cause is an issue with the superficial femoral artery, which is the most common artery affected in 70% of cases. In 30% of cases, aorto-iliac disease is the cause of the claudication pain, and this can also be associated with sexual impotence. This combination of claudication pain and impotence is referred to as Leriche's syndrome.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 998.

questions.text: What is not a match with Thoracoscore?
questions.solution:
1. Lymphocyte Count: This is the number of lymphocytes in the patient’s circulatory system as measured by a complete blood count.
High lymphocyte counts are indicative of infection while low counts can point to lymphoma or HIV.

2. Age: Thoracoscore uses the age of the patient to calculate a risk score. Age is significant because certain conditions are more common among certain age groups.

3. Respiratory Rate: The respirations per minute of the patient are measured to gain an indication of his/her respiratory condition. Rapid respiratory rates may indicate problems such as pneumonia, while low rates could point to other conditions such as depression.

4. Oxygen Saturation: The oxygen saturation of arterial blood is monitored to gain an indication on the patient’s levels of hypoxemia, or lack of oxygen in the blood. Low levels of oxygen saturation, usually less than 90%, are usually seen in cases of pneumonia.

5. Heart Rate: The heart rate is monitored to gain an indication of the patient’s cardiovascular fitness and whether or not he/she is exhibiting signs of shock. High heart rates can point to problems such as anemia, while low heart rates can indicate hypovolemia or dehydration. 

6. PaO2: This is the partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood, measured through a blood gas. High PaO2 indicates good oxygenation, while a low PaO2 could indicate severe respiratory illness, such as pneumonia.

7. Bicarbonate: This is the concentration of bicarbonate in the patient’s blood. Low bicarbonate levels could point to acidosis due to poor ventilation.

8. Systolic Blood Pressure: This is the pressure of the arteries when the heart pumps blood. Low systolic blood pressure could point to sepsis or shock. High systolic blood pressure can indicate hypertension or other cardiovascular problems.

Reference: Pathy A, Kar P, Gopinath R, Gubba D, Soujanya Rani N, Kanimozhi A. Thoracoscore: Does it predict mortality in the Indian scenario? - A retrospective study. Indian J Anaesth. 2022 Aug;66(Suppl 5):S257-S263. doi: 10.4103/ija.ija_24_22. Epub 2022 Aug 12. PMID: 36262735; PMCID: PMC9575923.

questions.text:
What T stage does a 2.5 cm lung cancer with no involvement of the pleura have
1. T1a
2. T2
3. T1b
4. T1c
questions.solution:
In the AJCC classification system, a lung tumor that is less than 2.5 cm in size is classified as T1c. This stage indicates that the tumor is small and contained within the lung, and it has not yet spread to nearby lymph nodes or other organs. If a tumor is larger than 2.5 cm, it is classified as T2 or higher. 


Reference: AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, Eighth Edition, Page No 447.

choices.text: Wells scoring cannot be calculated as D-dimer levels not mentioned

questions.text: While on a flight, a 68-year-old man with a h/o bladder Ca., complained of leg pain and hemoptysis, o/e heartbeat was 102/min. He has been previously hospitalised with diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. He had a medical surgery three weeks prior. What is the Wells scoring's clinical likelihood of thrombotic risk
questions.solution:
The Wells criteria is a clinical scoring process used in the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). 

* Wells Criteria for DVT:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 324.

questions.text: A young man came in complaining of recurring calf pain. Upon examination, a sore ulcer at the big toe is seen, which is encircled by discoloured skin. Which of the options below would be the most effective as a first step in this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in the given question is Peripheral Vascular Disease.

Investigation for PVD:
 
  1. Initial : Duplex Scan
  2. IOC : CT angiography
  3. Best investigation : Digital Subtraction Angiography.
Duplex scan is non-invasive and relatively inexpensive, hence is used as an initial investigation. It combines both traditional and doppler ultrasound.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1001.

questions.text: Varicose veins were discovered in a bus driver. Eczema of the skin and lipodermatosclerosis were discovered during investigation. He would fall within the following categories in the CEAP classification scheme:
questions.solution:
CEAP: Clinical, Etiologic, Anatomical & Pathophysiologic manifestation classification is used for chronic venous disorders.

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary (skin eczema and Lipodermatosis) due to chronic venous disease (varicose vein) is classified as C4 as per CEAP classification.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1030.

questions.text: Which type of ulcer is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a punch out ulcer on the plantar aspect of foot along pressure points which is seen in neuropathic ulcer. 
  • callosity can be seen surrounding the ulcer margin.
  • Arterial ulcer will also have punched out appearance, but is seen in dorsum of foot. 
  • Venous ulcer has sloping edges with peripheral bluish discoloration, commonly seen in Gaiter's area above medial malleolus. 
  • Tubercular ulcer is characterized by undermined edges. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 577.

questions.text: A patient appears with dilated veins while having no complaints. What CEAP staging corresponds to the picture below?
questions.solution:
CEAP classification:
  • C0 - No visible or palpable varicose veins
  • C1 - Telangectasia Thread veins / Spider veins / Broken veins
  • C2A - Varicose veins without any symptoms (Asymptomatic)
  • C2S - Varicose veins with symptoms
  • C3 - Swollen ankle (oedema) due to varicose veins
  • C4A - Eczema
  • C4B- Atrophe blanche or lipodermatosclerosis
  • C4C- Corona phlebactesia 
  • C5 - Healed venous leg ulcer
  • C6 - Venous leg ulcer
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1030.

questions.text:
Right-leg claudication discomfort is reported by a male smoker.
This angiography is displayed. What comes after this in terms of management?
questions.solution:
As per the reconstructed plates, part of right SFA is completely occluded as compared to Left side.
If it is getting filled by collaterals and there is absence of any thrombus in detailed review of angiography then patient is a candidate for endo vascular stenting.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1004.

choices.text: Ankle brachial index < 0.4 indicates critical limb ischemia
Ankle brachial index is different at rest than that during exercise
L-arginine is useful for providing endothelium-dependent vasorelaxation
Smoking has a greater association with peripheral vascular disease than coronary vascular disease

questions.solution:
Smoking has greater association with coronary artery disease than peripheral vascular disease.
L-Arginine is a precursor of Nitric oxide so helps in vasodilation due to synthesis of NO by endothelium. Hence it is endothelium-dependent.
Ankle brachial index <0.5 indicates critical limb ischemia.
