questions.text: Which of the following is not done in a patient with varicose veins and saphenofemoral incompetence?
questions.solution:
Management options include all of the following except: b) sclerotherapy

Sodium tetradecyl sulphate destroys lipid membrane of endothelial cells and is most commonly used for treatment of telengiectasia not varicose veins.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1035.

choices.text: Only Ulnar artery and peroneal arteries involved

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Buerger's illness is correct?
questions.solution:
True about buerger's disease is b) neural involvement is present

buerger's disease is a segmental inflammatory disease affecting small and medium sized arteries and veins in upper and lower extremities and the inflammatory process involves neighbouring veins and nerves.

* Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger’s disease):
  • This is characterised by occlusive disease of small and medium-sized limb arteries, thrombophlebitis of superfcial or deep veins and Raynaud’s syndrome; it usually occurs in young male smokers.
  • Histologically, there are infammatory changes in the walls of arteries and veins, leading to thrombosis.
  • Treatment is total abstinence from smoking, which arrests, but does not reverse, the disease. Established arterial occlusions are treated as for atheromatous disease, but amputations may eventually be required.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1024.

questions.text: Chronic venous insufficiency has been documented in a patient over the age of 65. The patient is presenting the following leg lesion. what is the CEAP classification's clinical stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: C6
 
  • The CEAP classification system is used to describe the clinical severity of chronic venous insufficiency.
  • Stage C6 indicates the presence of venous ulcers, which are non-healing wounds associated with chronic venous hypertension and impaired venous return.
  • Other stages in the CEAP classification include C0 (no visible or palpable signs of venous disease) to C5 (advanced skin changes without ulceration).



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1030.

questions.text: Where is a Hunterian Ligature operation performed?
questions.solution:
• The Hunterian Ligature operation is a surgical procedure that involves tying off a blood vessel to control bleeding or to prevent blood flow to a specific area. This procedure is typically performed in cases of Cerebral aneurysms. 
  • The Hunterian Ligature operation is named after the famous Scottish surgeon, John Hunter, who first described the technique in the 18th century.
  • The procedure involves tying a ligature, which is a thread or suture, around the affected blood vessel to stop the flow of blood.
  • This can be done either directly on the vessel or by tying off the vessel's main branch.
In summary, the correct option for the location where the Hunterian Ligature operation is performed is option 3:Aneurysm. 

Reference: Schmalz P, Patel A, Hauck E. A Case Report on the Progressive Hunterian Ligation of an Intracranial Aneurysm by Flow Diversion: The Endovascular Selverstone Clamp. Cureus. 2022 Jan 13;14(1):e21218. doi: 10.7759/cureus.21218. PMID: 35174026; PMCID: PMC8840891.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of Thromboangiitis obliterans?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Absence of popliteal pulse
 
  • Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) is a non-atherosclerotic inflammatory disease that affects small, medium-sized arteries and veins.
  • Clinical features include :
    • Raynaud's phenomenon (episodic color changes of the fingers or toes in response to cold or stress).
    • Claudication of extremities (pain or discomfort in the legs or arms during physical activity).
    • Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (inflammation and blood clot formation in superficial veins, is also commonly seen in thromboangiitis obliterans)
  • However, the absence of a popliteal pulse is not a typical feature of thromboangiitis obliterans.
Thromboangiitis obliterans:



Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 172.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by the pressure on the artery proximal to an A-V fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Increase in heart rate
 
  • An arteriovenous (A-V) fistula is a direct connection between an artery and a vein, usually created surgically, to facilitate hemodialysis in patients with end-stage renal disease.
  • An increase in heart rate is not directly caused by the pressure on the artery proximal to the A-V fistula.
Pressure on the artery proximal to an A-V fistula can lead to certain changes and effects, known as Nicolandi-Branham sign,  including:



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1023.

questions.text: The Ankle Branchial Pressure Index indicating Imminent Necrosis is as follows:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: <0.3 
 
  • The Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is used to assess blood flow and perfusion in the lower extremities.
  • ABPI compares the BP in the ankle to the BP in the arm.
  • An ABPI <0.3 suggests severe arterial disease and a critical reduction in blood flow to the legs.
  • At this level, there is a high risk of tissue damage and the development of necrosis.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1003.

questions.text: What is the most common location for peripheral arterial aneurysms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Poplitealâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹
 
  • The most common location for peripheral arterial aneurysms is: Popliteal > Femoral > Axillary > Subclavian
  • Among the options provided, the most common location for peripheral arterial aneurysms is the popliteal artery (located behind the knee).
  • Femoral and popliteal artery aneurysms account for more than 90% of peripheral aneurysms, with popliteal artery aneurysms being the most common
  • Popliteal artery Aneurysms can lead to symptoms such as a pulsatile mass, pain, or limb ischemia.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1003.

questions.text: Cirsoid aneurysms of the scalp are most commonly caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Superficial temporal artery
 
  • Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling over the scalp or face that develops due to abnormal arteriovenous connections in the scalp and extremities.
  • They are usually congenital. 
  • However, in some cases, they may be traumatic.
  • The superficial temporal artery is commonly involved in cirsoid aneurysms of the scalp.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 209.

questions.text: The most prevalent DVT manifestation is:
questions.solution:
Most common presentation of DVT is pain and swelling.

Charley horse cramp - A sudden, involuntary contraction of one or more muscles (cramp), often in the legs.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 323.

questions.text: A patient presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of a swelling in the supraclavicular region on the right side. The swelling was smooth, compressible and pulsatile. Clinical image is given below. Next step in evaluating such a case:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a tender pulsatile mass at the base of the neck makes it more likely to be a vascular anomaly, arteriovenous fistula or a venous aneurysm, both of which can present with pulsatile swelling.
 
  • Therefore, ultrasound doppler should be the next step in this patient. 
  • USG Doppler study is a non-invasive method to assess the nature of the swelling, particularly if it's related to blood vessels (e.g., an aneurysm, arteriovenous fistula, or venous malformation).
  • It can help evaluate blood flow, identify any vascular anomalies, and provide insight into whether the swelling is due to arterial or venous causes.
  • This diagnostic tool is typically used to confirm the diagnosis before proceeding with further interventions or management.

Other options:
 
  1. CT angiography + intervention: While this can be useful for vascular lesions, it would typically be performed after initial assessment with ultrasound or Doppler study to further define the lesion and its vascular characteristics. It is not usually the first step.
  2. Needle biopsy: A biopsy is not typically indicated for pulsatile, vascular swellings, as it may be difficult to interpret and unnecessary without understanding the vascular nature of the swelling first.
  3. Excision: Surgical excision is a therapeutic approach, not a diagnostic one. This should only be considered after determining the nature of the swelling via non-invasive imaging.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1925.

questions.text: A male patient came to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of claudication in buttocks, thigh and calves on both the sides. Distal arterial pulses were absent. He is having impotence also. Clinical image is shown below. Most likely level of obstruction:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of claudication in buttocks, thigh and calves with impotence along with the image showing gangrenous toe is suggestive of Leriche's syndrome. It is characterized by occlusion at the aortoiliac bifurcation. 
 

Leriche's syndrome is a condition caused by the obstruction of the aorta at its bifurcation into the iliac arteries, leading to reduced blood flow to the lower extremities and pelvis. It is typically caused by atherosclerosis.

Clinical features:

  • Triad of symptoms:
    1. Claudication (leg pain on exertion)
    2. Impotence (erectile dysfunction)
    3. Lower limb atrophy (muscle wasting due to poor circulation)
  • Other signs: Decreased femoral pulses, cold or pale legs, and possibly a bruit.
Diagnosis:
  • Doppler ultrasound, CT angiography, or MRA can confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment:
  • Conservative: Lifestyle changes, medications.
  • Interventional: Angioplasty, stenting, or surgical bypass in severe cases.

Leriche's syndrome typically results from atherosclerosis, and early intervention can improve outcomes.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 943-948.

questions.text: Following stripping surgery for varicose veins, patient started complaining of numbness along the medial aspect of the thigh. This is because injury to:
questions.solution:
• The saphenous nerve runs in close proximity to the great saphenous vein and innervates the medial aspect of thigh, leg upto the ball of great toe. 
 
  • Hence, it is prone for injury during surgery for varicose veins and can result in loss of sensations along its distribution. 

Other options:
 

  • Sural nerve: The sural nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the foot and the lower part of the calf. It does not typically affect the medial thigh.

  • Deep peroneal nerve: This nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg and provides sensation between the first and second toes. It does not affect the medial thigh.

  • Superficial peroneal nerve: This nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot and the lateral aspect of the lower leg. It would not affect the medial thigh either.

Thus, the saphenous nerve is the most likely nerve injured following varicose vein stripping surgery, leading to numbness along the medial thigh.




Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 1399, 1415, 1416.

questions.text: A patient present with acute chest pain radiating to the back and interscapular area. On chest X-Ray, widening of mediastinum is seen. BP in the left arm is 160/ 100 mmHg and right arm is 100/60 mm Hg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has acute chest pain radiating to the interscapular area with a widened mediastinum and an inter-arm difference in blood pressure (IADBP) with left > right, alerting the possibility of aortic dissection.
Clinical features and diagnosis of aortic dissection:
  • Characteristics of pain:
    • Site: Localized to the front or back of the chest, often the interscapular region
    • Onset: Sudden
    • Character: Tearing
    • Radiation: Typically migrates with propagation of the dissection
    • Associations: Diaphoresis
    • Severity: Very severe
  • CXR findings
    • Ascending aorta: widened superior mediastinum.
    • Descending thoracic aorta: a widened mediastinum; the descending aorta appears wider than ascending aorta
  • Diagnosis: CT

Fig: De Bakey (left) and Stanford (right) aortic dissection classifications

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1752.

questions.text: A patient of varicose veins developed eczema around the veins. What is the CEAP classification of this patient?
questions.solution:
The Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification is a method to categorize chronic venous disorders for standardized reporting. The visible signs of chronic venous disorders are categorized as C0 to C6 depending on appearance
  • C1: Presence of telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2 classification refers to varicose veins: subcutaneous dilated, tortuous veins > 3 mm in diameter (option A)
  • C3 refers to edema: when associated with venous reflux, it is characterized by the development of dependent ankle edema (option B)
  • C4a refers to skin pigmentation/ dermatitis/ eczema: as seen in this patient (option 3)
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 974.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a feature of re-feeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Refeeding syndrome occurs when a malnourished patient is rapidly refed (especially with carbohydrates), leading to insulin surge.

  • This causes intracellular shift of electrolytes, resulting in:

    • Hypophosphatemia → hallmark feature

    • Hypokalemia

    • Hypomagnesemia

  • Clinical manifestations include:

    • Arrhythmias

    • Congestive heart failure (CHF)

    • Neurological symptoms (confusion, seizures)

  • Hyperphosphatemia is not a feature; in fact, phosphate drops in refeeding syndrome.

High-yield point: Always monitor phosphate, potassium, magnesium when refeeding malnourished patients.

choices.text: Chest Xray is the investigation of choice
Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about thymoma?
questions.solution:
Thymoma is the most common neoplasm of the thymus and the most frequently encountered tumor in the anterior mediastinum of adults, though it is rare in children. It is most commonly diagnosed in individuals aged 40 to 60 years. Many patients with thymoma are asymptomatic, but larger tumors may cause symptoms due to mass effect, such as cough, chest pain, shortness of breath (dyspnea), or superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. Additionally, 10% to 50% of thymoma patients may exhibit symptoms of myasthenia gravis or have circulating acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Other paraneoplastic syndromes, including pure red cell aplasia, hypogammaglobulinemia, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Cushing's syndrome, or syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), may also occur.

While mediastinal masses can be detected through screening chest X-rays, contrast-enhanced CT scans and MRIs play a key role in the characterization of such masses. Although the diagnosis of thymoma may be suspected based on history and imaging findings, these methods alone are not conclusive. The definitive diagnosis is typically made after surgical resection, as obtaining a needle biopsy is challenging. When imaging strongly suggests thymoma, biopsy is usually avoided. The Masaoka staging system is used to stage thymomas, assessing both gross and microscopic invasion of the tumor capsule, involvement of surrounding structures, and metastasis.

The primary treatment for thymoma is complete surgical resection. However, thymectomy results in improvement or resolution of myasthenia gravis symptoms in only about 25% of affected patients.

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 992 .

questions.text: A male patient presented with a sudden onset tearing type of chest pain radiating to the back, shortness of breath, and nausea. CT chest image is given. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described—a male patient experiencing tearing chest pain—is suggestive of aortic dissection.

Management:

Beta-blockers, such as Labetalol, are recommended for all patients with aortic dissection to help control blood pressure and heart rate.
Surgical repair of the dissection is performed after the patient has been stabilized.

Pathophysiology:

Aortic dissection occurs when there is a tear or flap in the intima (the innermost layer) or media of the aorta, leading to a progressive separation of the aortic layers.

Risk factors for aortic dissection include:

Smoking
Hypertension: Chronic high blood pressure is a significant contributing factor.
Atherosclerosis: Hardening and narrowing of the arteries can weaken the aortic wall.
Hypercholesterolemia: Elevated cholesterol levels can lead to atherosclerosis.
Aortopathy: Conditions affecting the aorta, such as aortitis or a bicuspid aortic valve.
Preexisting medial degenerative disease: Weakening of the aortic wall.
Iatrogenic causes: Aortic injury during procedures like cardiac catheterization, surgery, or endovascular aortic repair.
Substance abuse: Use of cocaine or amphetamines has been linked to an increased risk of dissection.

questions.text: Which is the least commonly used graft for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
The intercostal artery is the least likely to be used as a graft in coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is known to provide long-lasting results in CABG. It has the highest patency rate among conduits, with long-term patency rates exceeding 98%.

1. Venous Grafts:
The long saphenous vein is the most commonly used vein for grafting in CABG because it is easy to harvest, provides adequate length, and is manageable.
The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is approximately 50-60%.
2. Arterial Grafts:
The left internal mammary artery (LIMA), also known as the internal thoracic artery, is the preferred conduit for bypassing the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery.
The radial artery can be used as a secondary or alternative arterial bypass graft.
Other arterial graft options include the gastroepiploic artery and the inferior epigastric artery.

questions.text: A 73 old male smoker with a past history of coronary artery disease presents with blackening of the toes. An image of the foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an elderly smoker with a past history of coronary artery disease and gangrene of the first three toes is suggestive of atherosclerosis.

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by the accumulation of plaques within the arteries, predominantly occurring after the age of 50. These plaques are mainly composed of lipids, which trigger an inflammatory response that leads to turbulent blood flow and contributes to atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). Consequently, this results in the formation of atheromas that obstruct blood flow, causing ischemia.

Key risk factors for atherosclerosis include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, and elevated cholesterol levels. The common arteries affected include the infrarenal portion of the abdominal aorta, coronary arteries, iliofemoral vessels, carotid bifurcation, and popliteal arteries. The presence of atherosclerotic disease in one region indicates a potential for blockages elsewhere in the body.

Patients with chronic limb ischemia often experience rest pain and tissue loss, such as gangrene and ulceration. An ischemic ulcer typically presents as painful, pale, and cyanotic with absent pulsations. It may also be associated with other complications like transient ischemic attacks, chest pain, eye issues, mesenteric ischemia, and altered renal function.

Doppler ultrasound or angiography can be employed to locate blockages. Evaluating patients for concurrent cardiac disorders is crucial.

Management strategies should include smoking cessation and modifications to other risk factors like hypertension, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia. High-intensity statins should be administered regardless of baseline cholesterol levels in patients with ASCVD. Additional medications may include pentoxifylline, aspirin, clopidogrel, and cilostazol. Surgical interventions might involve thrombectomy, endarterectomy, bypass grafting, or amputation if gangrene is present.

choices.text: Tube thoracostomy at 6th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line
Needle decompression at 2nd intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line

questions.text: A 20 year old male with Marfanoid habitus presents with sudden onset breathlessness and right sided chest pain. On chest percussion patient had a hyper- resonant note in the right hemithorax with the following X-ray. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a spontaneous pneumothorax as the patient is hypotensive with tachypnea the treatment of choice would be needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line.
tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion should be carried out in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety. The boundaries of triangle of safety are
• Anteriorly - lateral border of the pectoralis major
• Posteriorly- latissimus dorsi
• Inferiorly- a line perpendicular to the nipple going to the back
For pediatric patients, needle decompression is done at the midclavicular line in the 2nd intercostal space.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition • Page no- 374

questions.text: An elderly man with a chronic history of IV drug use presented with a progressively increasing swelling in the groin on the right side. It is is non fluctuant but pulsatile on examination. He has diminished pulses on the same side distal to the swelling. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Due to multiple punctures while administrating intravenous drugs,the femoral artery is most likely to be injured, causing a pseudoaneurysm. In pseudoaneurysm, the intimal and medial layers are disrupted and the dilated segment is lined by adventitia however in a true aneurysm where all three layers are involved. Doppler ultrasound reveals a bidirectional, 'to-and-fro' flow of blood which is known as the yin-yang sign. Management includes the delineation of anatomy using CT-Angiography. Treatment options include open or endovascular surgery.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition • page no 798

questions.text: An intern is observing the procedure of thoracocentesis. What is the site of needle insertion in this procedure?
questions.solution:
During thoracentesis, the top border of the lower rib is typically the proper location for the needle to be inserted. The intercostal nerve and veins are shielded from harm in this area.

A posterior technique is favored for thoracocentesis. Leaning forward and placing their arms on a pillow resting on a bedside stand, the patient should be positioned on the edge of the bed. Before beginning the operation, it's critical to determine whether the patient can hold this position for ten minutes because they may have severe dyspnea.

The thoracocentesis entry point is located at the upper surface of the ribs.

By doing this, any harm to the intercostal nerve and arteries is avoided.

It is important to gradually move the needle into the pleural area while keeping a light negative pressure.



Reference:Bailey and love's short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 920

choices.text: Administer a hemostatic agent through the chest tube

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the ER after a road traffic accident. On examination, left-sided hydropneumothorax was noted. Thoracostomy was done and around 1800 ml was drained in 1 hour. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient's condition is serious due to a combination of pneumothorax, hydrothorax, and a rapid blood loss of 1800 ml in just 1 hour. This level of bleeding suggests a severe injury to blood vessels or vital structures within the chest.
The most appropriate management in this scenario would be an emergency thoracotomy. This is a surgical procedure in which an incision is made into the chest to access the thoracic cavity. It is performed in critical situations to control bleeding and repair injuries to the chest structures, including the lung and blood vessels.

Reference
Gray's Anatomy. The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition - Page no 1677.

questions.text: Select the ideal time for the repair of cleft palate.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 9-12 months
 
  • The ideal time for the repair of cleft palate is between 9-12 months of age (Option A).
  • Repairing the cleft palate at this age allows for optimal speech development.
  • By repairing the palate early, it promotes proper articulation and reduces the risk of speech abnormalities.
  • Additionally, early repair helps improve feeding and prevents complications such as recurrent otitis media.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 745.

questions.text: Pick the one that is not seen in tuberous sclerosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Ependymoma
 
  • Ependymoma (Option D) is not typically seen in tuberous sclerosis.
  • Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is an autosomal-dominant genetic disorder affecting the differentiation, proliferation, and migration of cells early in development, resulting in a variety of hamartomatous lesions that may affect virtually every organ system of the body. Occurs due to mutations in TSC1 (9q34) & TSC2 (16p13)
  • Common brain lesions seen in tuberous sclerosis include giant cell astrocytoma, subependymal nodules, and white matter lesions.
  • Ependymomas are not specifically associated with tuberous sclerosis but can occur independently.





Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1856.

questions.text: Which flap was used to accomplish chest wall closure in the patient depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap
 
  • Based on the provided image, the chest wall closure was achieved using a pectoralis major myocutaneous flap (Option C).
  • The pectoralis major myocutaneous flap is a versatile reconstructive option commonly used for chest wall defects, particularly following tumor resection or trauma.
  • The other options mentioned, such as transversely oriented rectus abdominis muscle flap (Option A), vertically oriented rectus abdominis muscle flap (Option B), and serratus anterior muscle flap (Option D), are different types of muscle flaps that can be used for various reconstructive purposes but are not specifically indicated for chest wall closure.


Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 651.

questions.text: A patient underwent thyroid surgery for hyperthyroidism. He manifested thyroid storm symptoms two days later. Which is the most likely cause
questions.solution:
Thyrotoxic Crisis (Storm)
This is an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism.
  • It occurs if a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy and is now extremely rare.
  • Very rarely, a thyrotoxic patient presents in a crisis and this may follow an unrelated operation.
  • Symptomatic and supportive treatment is for dehydration, hyperpyrexia, and restlessness.
  • This requires cooling the patient with ice packs, the administration of oxygen, diuretics for cardiac failure, digoxin for uncontrolled atrial fibrillation, sedation, and intravenous hydrocortisone.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 866.

questions.text: Which cyst in the jaw is precancerous?
questions.solution:
Odontogenic Keratocyst (OKC) is a type of cyst that usually develops in the jawbones.
  • It is generally considered a benign lesion, however, some studies indicate that OKC may be a premalignant condition.
  • This means that, while the cysts are not cancerous or malignant, they could potentially progress to become cancerous or malignant in some cases.
  • It is important to receive proper diagnosis and treatment to ensure that these cysts don't become cancerous or spread to other areas in the body.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 349.

questions.text: Hot spot on Tc-99 is observed in the following parotid tumor:
questions.solution:
• Hot spot on Tc-99 is seen in Adenolymphoma or Warthin's Tumor ( referred to as Papillary cystadenoma Lymphomatosum ).

  • It is second most common benign tumor of the parotid gland  characterized by both epithelial and lymphoid elements. It is more common in males in the 5th to 7th decade, with a possible association with smoking, and occurs exclusively in the parotid gland overlying the mandible angle.

  • It is usually bilateral (10%) and slow growing and while never malignant, it usually shows a 'hot' spot on 99m Te-pertechnate scan, which is a peculiar feature distinct from other parotid tumors which usually show a 'cold' spot.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: What do we call the highly vascular tumor of brain and spinal cord in adults?
questions.solution:
Hemangioblastoma is a highly vascular tumor of brain and spinal cord in adults.
Hemangioblastoma represents the most common primary intra-axial tumor in the adult posterior fossa.
It occur almost exclusively in the posterior fossa (cerebellum) as a solid or cystic with a mural nodule.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1896.

questions.text: A patient who is a 55-year- old man, has a 4 to 5 cm tumour in his right neck. It was determined to be a cancer by FNAC. There were no tumours found during the clinical examination of the larynx, pharynx, hypopharynx, and oral cavity. Except for the neck tumour, a full body PET scan did not reveal any enhanced uptake. An unidentified main diagnosis was made. The tumor's TNM status, as determined by the AJCC system of classification, would be:
questions.solution:
According to the American Joint Committee on Cancer Stages of Regional Lymph Node Involvement the TNM status would be - Tx: Unknown Primary (T status cannot be assessed) N2a: Metastasis in single ipsilateral LN, >3 cm but <6 cm in greatest dimension. Mx: Unknown presence or absence of metastasis.

Reference: AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, Eighth Edition, Page No 61.

questions.text: Which procedure is preferred for irradiation of the chordoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Protons
 
  • Proton irradiation is the preferred procedure for irradiating chordomas.
  • Proton therapy utilizes protons, which are charged particles, to deliver radiation to the tumor with high precision.
  • Proton beams have the advantage of depositing most of their energy within the tumor, minimizing radiation exposure to surrounding healthy tissues.
  • This targeted approach helps spare critical structures, such as the spinal cord and nearby organs, reducing the risk of complications and optimizing treatment outcomes.
  • Compared to other radiation techniques like electrons, gamma radiation, or 3D-CRT (three-dimensional conformal radiation therapy), proton therapy offers superior control and accuracy in treating chordomas.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 776.

questions.text: For parotid surgery, not a surgical landmark?
questions.solution:
• Identifying the facial nerve is done through a variety of methods, both antegrade and retrograde.
  • Antegrade methods involve tracing the nerve from posterior to anterior regions of the head and neck. These methods utilize the tragal pointer (Conley's Pointer), the squamotympanic fissure, the styloid process, and the mastoid process to identify the facial nerve and follow it to its origin deeper in the neck.
  • Retrograde methods involve identifying the buccal or cervical branches of the facial nerve and tracing them backwards. This is particularly useful in re-operative cases.

â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 408.

questions.text: Upon awakening following parotid surgery, a patient noticed paralysis of the lower lip. Which of the following has sustained the most damage?
questions.solution:
The more appropriate answer to the given Q will be cervical branch of facial nerve which provides some collateral innervation to muscles of lower lip. 

Injury to main trunk of facial nerve wont present with isolated paralysis of lower lip. 

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 408.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl has freckle-like markings on her face and trunk and a slow-growing, non-tender bulge on the left side of her neck. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Here, 15 year old girl with freckle like spots on face and trunk with slow growing bulge on left side of neck- likely neural tumor is indicative of neurofibromatosis type I. 

Neurofibromatosis Type I aka Von Recklinghausen Disease is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by 

(a) Intellectual disability or seizures
(b) Skeletal defects
(c) Pigmented nodules of the iris ( Lisch nodules )
(d) Cutaneous hyperpigmented macules (café au lait spots)
(e) Neurofibromas
(f) Optic nerve glioma

It is caused by mutations in the NF1 gene, which encodes the tumor suppressor protein neurofibromin and is located at chromosome 17q11.2.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 520.

questions.text:
Lymphadenopathy and dermatitis in a 7-year-old child. Skull X-ray below

Which of the following medications is most frequently used in this situation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the X-ray image showing punched out lytic lesion is s/o LCH. 

The current standard of care for patients with high-risk LCH is 1 year of therapy with vinblastine/prednisone/mercaptopurine, based on the LCH-III study.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presented to the OPD complaining of a mildly uncomfortable swelling on his scalp for the past three months.
She keeps a dog for a pet. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• A fungal ringworm infection of the scalp's hair follicles (and occasionally the beard) that may be accompanied by a subsequent bacterial infection can cause kerion, an acute inflammatory condition.
  • It is caused by Trichophyton verrucosum and Microsporum canis. 
  • Mainly caused by fungus infecting animals, in the question pet dog is also mentioned. 
  • It typically affects children and manifests as elevated, spongy lesions.
  • This honeycomb-shaped inflammatory reaction causes excruciating agony and causes deep suppurative sores on the scalp. Pupillating follicles may be noticed.
Reference: Nakagawa H, Nishihara M, Nakamura T. Kerion and tinea capitis. IDCases. 2018 Jun 28;14:e00418. doi: 10.1016/j.idcr.2018.e00418. PMID: 29988774; PMCID: PMC6031098.

questions.text: On a CT scan, a lesion around the foramen of Monroe and several periventricular calcific foci are visible in the youngster who has elevated ICT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Most probable diagnosis in a child with raised ICT, lesion around foramen of Monroe and multiple periventricular calcific foci on CT scan is subependymal giant cell astrocytoma.
  • It occurs in older children and young adults (<20 years) in the lateral wall of lateral ventricle overlying head of caudate nucleus near foramen of Monroe.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1088.

questions.text: For laryngeal cancer, a patient is receiving a modified radical neck dissection. The surgeon elevated the internal jugular vein for ligation while dissecting the vein's tributaries. The patient's EtCO2 suddenly plummeted from 38 to 12 mm Hg, and he or she also experienced cardiac arrhythmia and hypotension. What is the most likely reason for this?
questions.solution:
• A sudden plunge in the EtCO2 reading while a patient is undergoing mechanical ventilation is an indication for an embolism of venous air, which is an extremely serious medical condition.
  • Venous air embolism occurs when air bubbles enter the bloodstream and become trapped in the venous circulation, blocking the flow of oxygen-rich blood. It is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical treatment.
  • The most common cause of venous air embolism is a displaced central line, where the central line is pulled out of the vein and air enters the bloodstream. Other causes include trauma to the chest (such as during open-heart surgery), iatrogenic trauma (where a procedure or instrumentation causes air to enter the venous system), or a forced Valsalva maneuver.
  • Diving incidents can also lead to venous air embolism, when pressure changes cause an abrupt shift in gas pressures, filling the venous circulation with nitrogen or argon.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 188.

questions.text: What conditions is stereotactic surgery used to treat?
questions.solution:
Stereotactic surgery is used for treatment of brain tumor.

Stereotactic radiosurgery involves the delivery of a concentrated dose of radiation to a defined volume in the brain and is used for treatment of brain tumor.




Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 722.

questions.text: A young male, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented to the Surgery OPD with complaints of whitish patches in the oral cavity. The clinical image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis based on clinical scenario and the given image is leucoplakia. 
 
  • It is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity showing white patches or plaques which cannot be rubbed off. 
 
  • Speckled leucoplakia and proliferative verrucous leucoplakia are two important variants which carry higher risk of malignant transformation. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 761-763, 767.

questions.text: Study the intra-oral X-ray and make a diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Presence of radio-opaque substance in the region of floor of mouth, likely in the region of Wharton's duct goes in favor of sialolithiasis.
 
  • Clinically, it presents with acute painful swelling in the submandibular region which is aggravated with food intake and resolution of symptoms 1-2 hours after the meal is completed.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 780, 781, 787.

questions.text: A 50 years old female presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of single, smooth sweeling over the angle of mouth on the left side. It was firm and painless. Clinical image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical image demonstrates the classical curtain sign, which is elevation of overlying ear lobule, characteristic of a parotid tumor. 

Options:
 

  • Osteoma of the angle of mandible: An osteoma is a benign bone tumor, but it typically presents as a hard, bony mass rather than a smooth, soft swelling. Osteomas are uncommon in this area, and they usually cause local discomfort or asymmetry rather than being completely painless.

  • Parotid tumor: The parotid gland is located near the angle of the mandible. Tumors of the parotid gland, such as pleomorphic adenomas, commonly present as a smooth, firm, and painless swelling in this location. The absence of pain is characteristic of benign parotid tumors.

  • Bezold's abscess: This is a deep neck abscess usually related to a bacterial infection that affects the muscles of the neck, particularly in the region of the mandible. It is typically associated with fever, pain, and other signs of infection, which are not mentioned in this case.

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy: Lymph nodes can swell due to various causes, but the swelling in this case is described as "smooth" and located specifically at the angle of the mouth, which is more typical of a parotid mass. Lymph nodes, if enlarged, would likely be more mobile and tender, and would not usually present as a firm, smooth mass at this location unless it was secondary to an infection or malignancy.

Therefore, parotid tumor is the most likely diagnosis based on the presentation of a smooth, firm, and painless swelling at the angle of the mouth. Further investigations like ultrasound or fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) can help confirm this diagnosis.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 839, 840.

choices.text: Angiogram to find the site of aneurysm

questions.text: A female patient who is a hypertensive presented with a sudden onset headache. BP is 160/ 100 mmHg. CT shows SAH. What is the next initial step in the management?
questions.solution:
The hypertensive female with sudden headache, BP of 160/100 mmHg with no history of trauma was diagnosed with subarachnoid hemorrhage on non-contrast CT of the head.
This Spontaneous SAH likely indicates a case of aneurysmal SAH. 
Once a diagnosis of SAH has been made, the etiology of the hemorrhage must be determined with angiographic studies. This may be done using:
  1. Conventional digital subtraction angiography (DSA)
  2. Computed tomography angiography (CTA)
  3. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 367, 709.

questions.text: A 20-year old male presents with a midline neck swelling that moves with protrusion of tongue. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The young male patient presents with a midline cervical swelling which moves on protrusion of the tongue.
This is likely to be a thyroglossal duct cyst.
  • The normal development and subsequent obliteration of the thyroglossal duct are connected to that of the hyoid bone, which forms starting at the seventh week of gestation and functionally divides the thyroglossal tract into superior and inferior aspects.
  • When the thyroglossal duct does not completely obliterate and the epithelial duct cells remain, a thyroglossal duct cyst may arise from a persistent connection between the thyroid gland and the foramen cecum.
  • This scenario typically presents as a painless midline neck mass at or near the level of the hyoid, although it can be found near the base of the tongue or at the thyroid gland proper. Occasionally, these cysts can become infected from oral bacteria from the tongue, and can also form fistulous sinuses to the skin.

 * Management: 

The Sistrunk procedure, originally described in 1920, is the surgical treatment of choice for thyroglossal duct cysts that become chronically infected.
A number of modifications have been described, but the key component of the procedure involves excision of the entirety of the cyst and surrounding thyroglossal duct tract, including the central portion of the hyoid bone.
Resection of a small portion of the tongue is no longer thought to be necessary in the majority of cases.â€Š

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 875.

questions.text: A patient presented with a red, dense, mobile, nodular swelling with a variable consistency below the ear lobule from the last 2 years as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with a retromandibular swelling as shown in the image likely has a parotid neoplasm.
Most benign tumors will be smooth, relatively mobile and painless to palpate.
The patient complains of a mass behind the angle of their jaw in the retromandibular region, in front of the tragus or in the cheek.
Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands. 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 789.

questions.text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the lateral neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found in the neck as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, fluctuating mass located in the posterior part of the neck in a child is most likely a cystic hygroma.

Cystic Hygroma
Cystic hygroma is a lymph-filled sac caused by the obstruction of lymphatic vessels during development. It typically appears in the posterior triangle of the neck and may be present at birth or develop in early childhood due to lymph accumulation. The sac is usually soft, fluctuant, and demonstrates transillumination.
Commonly seen in females with Turner syndrome.

Treatment
1.Surgical Excision
2. Image-guided Sclerotherapy: 

Note Terms lymphangioma and cystic hygroma are older designations. They are now referred to as lymphatic malformations.

questions.text: The most common tumor of the parotid gland is
questions.solution:
• Parotid gland tumors: Most are benign (≈80%).

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid gland, accounting for ~60–70% of all parotid tumors.

  • Features:

    • Slow-growing, painless, firm mass

    • Usually mobile, located in the superficial lobe

    • Histology shows mixed epithelial and stromal (myxoid, chondroid) components

  • Other options:

    • Warthin’s tumor: Second most common, more in older males, smokers, often bilateral or cystic

    • Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Malignant, slow-growing, often causes pain due to perineural invasion

    • Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Malignant, can occur in parotid or minor salivary glands, variable behavior

High-yield point: Pleomorphic adenoma = most common parotid tumor (benign, mixed histology).

questions.text: A 35-year-old man sustained a spinal cord injury as a result of a road traffic accident. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg. The patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of hypotension associated with spinal cord injury is indicative of neurogenic shock.

Neurogenic shock occurs due to reduced tissue perfusion caused by a loss of vasomotor control to peripheral arteries. This condition is commonly secondary to spinal cord injuries resulting from fractures in the cervical or upper thoracic vertebrae, which impair the sympathetic nervous system's ability to regulate vascular tone. The loss of vasoconstrictive signals leads to increased vascular capacity, reduced venous return, and decreased cardiac output.

Primary injury in neurogenic shock results from direct damage to neuron axons and membranes, while secondary injury occurs due to vascular damage within hours to days after the initial trauma.

Clinical features include bradycardia, temperature dysregulation, hypotension, autonomic dysreflexia, and warm, flushed skin. Radiographic evidence of vertebral fractures may also be present.

Treatment focuses on securing the airway, ensuring proper ventilation, maintaining perfusion with fluids and blood products, and administering vasoconstrictors to restore vascular tone.

choices.text: Accessory nerve and Sternocleidomastoid, and internal jugular veins

questions.text: Structure(s) preserved in case of MRND 1 are:
questions.solution:
In Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND) Type 1, only the spinal accessory nerve is preserved. There are three types of MRND, each with different structures retained:

MRND 1: Preserves only the spinal accessory nerve.
MRND 2: Preserves both the accessory nerve and the internal jugular vein.
MRND 3 (functional neck dissection): Preserves the accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid muscle, and internal jugular vein.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with maxillofacial trauma and inability to open the mouth. To establish an airway, an emergency laryngotomy is performed. Where is the opening made?
questions.solution:
In emergency airway situations (e.g., severe maxillofacial trauma with inability to open the mouth), a cricothyrotomy (emergency laryngotomy) is performed.

  • The cricothyroid membrane lies between the thyroid cartilage and the cricoid cartilage.

  • A vertical or horizontal incision through this membrane provides rapid access to the airway when intubation is impossible. 

Other options — brief:

  1. Cricotracheal membrane: Between cricoid and first tracheal ring; used in tracheostomy, not emergent cricothyrotomy.

  2. Cricothyroid muscle: Muscle tissue; incision through muscle alone does not establish airway.

  3. Thyrohyoid membrane: Between thyroid cartilage and hyoid bone; not used for emergency airway.

Key point:

Emergency airway via cricothyrotomy → incision through cricothyroid membrane.

choices.text: Osmotic diuresis using Mannitol to decrease Intracranial pressure

questions.text: A young male presented with low GCS of 10 following a fall from height on evaluation found to have anisocoria with the following CT image. What is the best line of management?
questions.solution:
• With the history of fall from height, presenting with low GCS, anisocoria and CT finding of a lenticular hemorrhage showing a mid-line shift is characteristic of an extradural or epidural hemorrhage.
  • Urgent surgical evacuation of Hematoma by craniotomy is the management.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 365-66.

questions.text: Identify the following image:
questions.solution:
The scenario and image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are indicative of a ranula. A ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst originating from the sublingual gland, presenting as a translucent swelling resembling a frog's belly. It typically resolves on its own.

A plunging ranula, in contrast, is a mucus retention cyst where mucus accumulates beneath the gland and penetrates through the mylohyoid muscle.
Treatment generally involves the removal of the sublingual gland, as it has multiple ducts, and leaving the gland may result in recurrence of the ranula. Incision, drainage, and marsupialization have a lower success rate.


 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 834,805,1925 .

questions.text:
Match the features seen due to compression of the following structures in case of thyroid swelling.
Column I Column II
1 Trachea a Hoarseness
2 Esophagus b Horner’s Syndrome
3 Sympathetic chain. c Dyspnea
4 Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve d Dysphagia
questions.solution:
Thyroid swellings can present as a uniform enlargement of the gland, a solitary nodule, or a multinodulargoiter. When significantly enlarged, the thyroid may compress nearby structures, leading to various pressure-related symptoms:

Tracheal compression can result in respiratory issues such as dyspnea and stridor.

Esophageal pressure may cause dysphagia.

Compression of the sympathetic chain can lead to Horner‘s syndrome.

Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) compression causes hoarseness. Although vocal cord paralysis from RLN compression is extremely rare, it may indicate malignant transformation.

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 857,859 .

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient involved in a road traffic accident had headache, nausea and vomiting.She became unconscious and then regained consciousness. She again became unconscious 6hours later.She was brought unconscious to the emergency room. NCCT brain reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The provided history and the CT image displaying a typical biconvex hyperdense lesion are indicative of an extradural hemorrhage (EDH), which is most commonly caused by bleeding from the middle meningeal artery.

EDH refers to the accumulation of blood in the potential space between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater. This hematoma results from arterial disruption, particularly involving the middle meningeal artery, although the middle meningeal vein and diploic veins may also be involved.

Patients typically present with a head injury followed by a lucid interval, ipsilateral mydriasis, and ipsilateral hemiparesis. After an initial transient loss of consciousness, the patient's condition deteriorates 6-12 hours later. The period during which the patient appears normal is known as the lucid interval. Patients may exhibit signs of raised intracranial pressure, including high blood pressure, vomiting, bradycardia, and convulsions. Cushing's triad, characterised by bradycardia, respiratory irregularities, and hypertension, may also be present.

On a head CT scan, the blood clot appears biconvex or lentiform in shape with well-defined borders. An EDH is often associated with a fracture in the temporoparietal region.



Immediate surgical intervention is essential to save the patient's life. A craniotomy is indicated for the treatment of an EDH.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of superior mediastinal tumor.
questions.solution:
Thymoma is classified as an anterior mediastinal tumour, not a superior mediastinal tumour.



DIVISIONS OF MEDIASTINUM

choices.text: Sistrunks operation is performed to excise the cyst

questions.text: A 20-year-old male came to OPD with a complaint of midline neck swelling which has been persistent for many years. Recently, it has become painful and inflamed. There has been a clear watery discharge from the wound since last week. On examination, the swelling moves with protrusion of the tongue and also on deglutition. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst which has been complicated by a sinus fistula. A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. It represents the persistence of the thyroglossal tract. It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct, most common location being subhyoid region. The cyst moves on deglutition indicating attachment to hyoid bone. Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), non-tender, mobile, and often transilluminate.
The most common complication is infection. Malignant transformation is rare, and the most common type of cancer-associated is papillary. Sistrunk's operation is performed to excise the cyst. It involves the excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and the suprahyoid tract. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition • Page no: 755

questions.text: Following ventriculoperitoneal shunt for management of obstructive hydrocephalus due to tuberculous meningitis. Patient developed headache altered sensorium and multiple episodes of vomiting. Which is the most common cause of shunt malfunction?
questions.solution:
• Shunt obstruction is the most common cause of shunt malfunction and the most common site is the ventricular catheter.
• Obstruction occurs due to clogging of the shunt by blood, proteinaceous material, choroid plexus, glial adhesions or secondary to infection.
• The patient presents with features of raised intracranial pressure like headache, vomiting and eye fundoscopy will reveal papilloedema. Other complications of VP shunting include
• Shunt infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, most commonly from Staphylococcus epidermidis.
• Intracerebral or intraventricular haemorrhage
• Tip migration or malposition
• Shunt overdrainage (slit ventricle syndrome) - usually occurs after many years
• Shunt nephritis
• Shunt disconnection or breakage or kinking
• Inguinal hernia
• Seizures.
Handbook of Neurosurgery, 9th Edition • Page 434

choices.text: The given scenario is suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism
99Tc- Radiolabelled Sestamibi scan is used to localise the primary pathology
Conservative management is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A young male with previous history of reccurent renal calculi presented with abdominal cramps and bone aches. On investigating he was found to have increased calcium, phosphorus and PTH levels and an X-ray showing the following deformity of his hands . Which of the following is true
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma arising sporadically.
It is best localised using a 99Tc- Radiolabelled sestamibi scan.
Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e • Page no: 1101

choices.text: FFP and VIT K followed by neurosurgery consult

questions.text: A 55 year old male known case of mitral stenosis on warfarin and aspirin, came to the emergency with history of fall in the bathroom, CT scan showed showed SDH, what will be the line of management?
questions.solution: The given history of a SDH in a patient on warfarin and aspirin, the most likely diagnosis is a war for an induced coaguopathy. It should be treated by giving Vit K and FFP followed by neurosurgery consultation for the same . Ref - Bailey and love 27th edition Page 333-335

choices.text: 5 cm, and progressed to 5 cm in the last few months. What is the likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A young boy presented with a bluish-red cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. On examination, it showed fluctuation and transillumination. It was initially 1.5 cm, and progressed to 5 cm in the last few months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ranula: A mucous retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland in the floor of the mouth. Presents as a bluish, cystic swelling, fluctuant, and often transilluminates. It usually starts small and can progress in size over months, as described. 

    Other options:

  • Ludwig's angina: Rapidly spreading cellulitis of the floor of the mouth; usually painful, firm, and associated with systemic signs. Not cystic or fluctuant. 

  • Cystic hygroma: Congenital lymphatic malformation; commonly presents at birth or early childhood, usually posterior neck, and less common in the floor of the mouth. 

  • Ectopic thyroid: Usually midline, firm mass, not cystic, and rarely fluctuant or transilluminant. 


Reference:Bailey and love short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 754-756,779,936

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with a midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. CT confirms the diagnosis of a thyroglossal cyst. Which of the following procedures is used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has a midline neck swelling that moves with swallowing and tongue protrusion, which is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst.

  • Sistrunk procedure is the surgical treatment of choice. It involves:

    • Excision of the cyst along with the mid-portion of the hyoid bone and the tract up to the base of the tongue to reduce recurrence.

  • Other options:

    • Modified or radical neck dissection: Reserved for head and neck malignancies with lymph node involvement.

    • Total thyroidectomy: Done for thyroid malignancies, not for thyroglossal cysts.



Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 755

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with aortic dissection. He continuously complains of hiccups. Which of the following nerves is most likely compressed in this case?
questions.solution:
Irritation or stimulation of the phrenic nerve, which regulates the motions of the diaphragm, can result in tics.
The phrenic nerve is shown by the D shape.

The markings indicated in the picture are:
A. Vagus nerve on the right

B. Vagus nerve on the left

C. The laryngeal nerve recurrently

D. Phrenic nerve on the right

The cervical spine (C3–C5) is the phrenic nerve's original location. It passes through the chest and into the diaphragm.

Ruptures in the inner layer of the aorta cause aortic dissection, which can cause discomfort, altered blood flow, and involvement of nearby structures, among other symptoms, depending on where the rip occurs in the aorta.

Reference: Gray's Anatomy:The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 42nd edition page no 1040-1042

choices.text: Cystic hygroma is filled with clear lymph
Type 3 Branchial fistula has its internal orifice on cricopharynxgeus
Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion

questions.text: The false statement about cystic masses of the neck is: A. Type 3 Branchial fistula has its internal orifice on cricopharynxgeus(correct) B. Cystic hygroma is filled with clear lymph C. Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion D. Fluctuation Is positive in branchial cyst
questions.solution:
The false statement is:

Type 3 Branchial fistula has its internal orifice on cricopharyngeus

Why it's false:

  • The internal opening of a third branchial fistula is typically located at the piriform sinus, not at the cricopharyngeus muscle.

  • Cricopharyngeus is the upper esophageal sphincter, and while it's near the area, it is not the specific site of internal opening in third branchial fistulae.

    True statements:

  • Cystic hygroma is filled with clear lymph → True. It's a lymphatic malformation.

  • Fluctuation is positive in branchial cyst → True. Branchial cysts are fluid-filled and show fluctuation.

  • Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion → True. It’s attached to the foramen cecum via the tract.

    Clinical Tip:

  • In thyroglossal cysts, the upward movement on tongue protrusion (not just swallowing) helps distinguish them from other neck masses.


Reference:Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 753-755

questions.text: What procedure makes use of the instrument indicated in the diagram?
questions.solution:
Different kinds of bone marrow biopsy needles are depicted in the diagram.

questions.text: What is the name of the given instrument is used for harvesting the graft from healthy area in split thickness skin graft?
questions.solution:
• The name of the given instrument is Humby knife, which is used for harvesting the graft from healthy area in split thickness skin graft.
  • The Humby – Braithwaite Dermatome (Skin Graft Knife) is used to collect a slice of healthy skin from donor site to perform a skin graft on a site with tissue loss.
  • Donor sites for the harvest of skin graft include the lumbar and gluteal regions (thick skin), the thighs, and the arms (thin skin).

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 317.

questions.text: What is the name of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Name of the given instrument is chemoport, which is an implantable venous access device used to facilitate chemotherapy administration.

Chemoport is an implantable vascular access device lo provide repeated access to the vascular system for the delivery of medications, intravenous fluids, parenteral nutrition solutions and blood products.

Reference: Mittal GS, Sundriyal D, Naik NB, Sehrawat A. Totally Implantable Venous Access Device (Chemoport) in Oncology: Study of 168 Polyurethane Chemoport Catheter System. South Asian J Cancer. 2021 Dec 31;10(4):261-264. doi: 10.1055/s-0041-1739041. PMID: 34984207; PMCID: PMC8719977.

questions.solution:
It is a  procedure in which a thin, hollow needle is inserted into the lower part of the spine to collect a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
Lumbar puncture is done in L3-L4 level in adults.

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Laparoscopic port trocar
 
  • The instrument shown in the image is a laparoscopic port trocar.
  • A trocar is a sharp-pointed surgical instrument used to create access into body cavities during laparoscopic procedures.
  • It is inserted through a small incision in the abdominal wall, allowing the placement of laparoscopic instruments and camera for visualization.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 657.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male who arrived with rectal bleeding was found to have colon cancer. He had extensive right hemicolectomy. Below is a surgical tool that is being used. Name it -
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is used to perform Monopolar Cautery.

With the use of a specialised tool, electrosurgery uses high-frequency electrical current to cut, coagulate, desiccate, and fulgurate tissue.
It can be carried out using either monopolar or bipolar energy.

Reference: Cordero I. Electrosurgical units - how they work and how to use them safely. Community Eye Health. 2015;28(89):15-6. PMID: 26435589; PMCID: PMC4579996.

choices.text: No breath-holding is required for the procedure
Platelet count of less than 40,000 is a contraindication
It is useful is diagnosis of infiltrative and granulomatous disorders
It can be done in both prone and lateral positions

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the procedure in which this needle is used?
questions.solution:
• This is Bone marrow aspiration needle / Jamshedi's needle. So, PC < 40k is not a contraindication for this procedure. All other options are correct about BMA.
  • Absolute contraindications to bone marrow biopsy and aspiration include severe bleeding diatheses such as severe hemophilia or severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.
  • Thrombocytopenia is not a contraindication, and platelet transfusion can be performed if clinically warranted prior to the procedure, commonly performed if platelet counts are below 20,000 cells/microliter.
  • Thrombocytopenia is rather in indication for performing bone marrow biopsy. *  CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR BM BIOPSY:
  • Hemorrhagic disorders such DIC, concurrent anticoagulant usage, and congenital coagulation factor deficits (such as hemophilia).
  • The most frequent and dangerous occurrence is bleeding, especially in thrombocytopenic patients and those taking aspirin, warfarin, or heparin.
  • In these patients, a BMA or BMTB should only be performed if it is absolutely necessary. If this is the case, factor replacement or stopping anticoagulation should be considered before the surgery, and the patient should be thoroughly watched for 24 hours afterward. BMA is not contraindicated in cases of severe thrombocytopenia as long as the site is kept under pressure for an extended period of time to stop bleeding.
  •  When a bone marrow biopsy is recommended for obese individuals with severe thrombocytopenia, it is better to administer a platelet transfusion to increase the platelet count to > 15 x 10^9/L.
  • Other potential issues include persistent discomfort, a fracture (related to osteoporosis), and damage to nearby structures (such as damage to arteries).
  • At the sampling site, there may be skin infections or recent radiation therapy.
Reference: 
Rindy LJ, Chambers AR. Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy. [Updated 2023 May 29]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559232/

questions.text: Which is the structure visible in the X-ray below?

questions.text: The instrument depicted in the image is:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a Perkins self-retaining retractor.
  • It can be differentiated from other retractors by the presence of a flat plate on one blade and three prongs of equal size on the other blade.
  • Other retractors such as Mollison's retractor or Jansen Retractor have prongs on both the blades while the Joules self retractor contains circular blades.
  • The flat plate in Perkins' self-retaining retractor is used to retract the skin of the external auditory canal during mastoid and middle ear surgeries.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1149.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image
questions.solution:
The Mixter‘s right angle forceps is a surgical instrument used for passing ligatures and dissecting pedicles.

Adson‘s forceps, also known as Cerci-Adson:Brown forceps, feature a double grasping tip for enhanced stabilization. They are particularly suited for grasping cartilage during rhinoplasty, as their multi-teeth tip minimizes cartilage damage and prevents bounce.

Kocher forceps are designed with opposing teeth at the tip and serrations on the distal blades. They are used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. Additionally, they are useful for holding ribs during rib dissection and securing resected bowel.

Rampley‘s sponge-holding forceps have a fenestrated, serrated, and flat end. They are used for:

a)Mopping oozing areas

b)Holding the gallbladder and cervix during surgeries

c)Performing blunt dissections


Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page no 1150 ,1146,1147 .

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The linear stapler is a surgical instrument designed for the complete or partial closure of the bowel. 



Linear Stapler:
Purpose: Used primarily for gastrointestinal surgeries to close bowel sections efficiently.
Functionality: It creates a series of staples in a linear fashion, allowing for simultaneous cutting and stapling of tissue.
Benefits:
Ensures precise apposition of tissue edges.
Reduces operative time compared to traditional suturing methods.
Provides a secure closure that can accommodate the natural movements of the bowel.
Comparison with Cutaneous Staplers:
Cutaneous Staplers:
Function: Primarily used for closing skin incisions.
Advantages:
Faster and technically easier to apply compared to sutures.
Provides clean apposition of skin edges, which can help in minimizing scarring.
Disadvantages:
Removal requires a specific instrument.
Generally more expensive than traditional sutures.
Both instruments play essential roles in surgical practice, with their use depending on the specific requirements of the surgical procedure and the tissues involved.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The given image is that of Veress needle. In laparoscopic surgery, the Veress needle is used to create pneumoperitoneum.
 

Key points about the Veress needle:

  • Design:

    • Hollow needle with a spring-loaded blunt inner stylet.

    • When the needle tip encounters resistance (abdominal wall), the blunt inner stylet retracts; when it enters the peritoneal cavity, the stylet springs forward, preventing injury to intra-abdominal organs.

  • Purpose:

    • To safely access the peritoneal cavity for COâ‚‚ insufflation before inserting trocars.

  • Technique:

    1. Make a small incision at the desired entry point (commonly umbilicus).

    2. Insert the Veress needle perpendicularly with a gentle puncture.

    3. Confirm correct placement using tests:

      • Aspiration test: No blood or bowel content should come out.

      • Saline drop test: Saline flows freely into the cavity.

      • Hanging drop test: Drops of saline drawn inward by negative pressure.

    4. Connect to COâ‚‚ insufflator to establish pneumoperitoneum (usually 12–15 mmHg).

  • Advantages:

    • Reduces the risk of visceral or vascular injury compared to blind trocar insertion.

    • Widely used in laparoscopic cholecystectomy, appendectomy, gynecological procedures.

  • Complications (rare):

    • Bowel or vascular injury

    • Subcutaneous emphysema

    • Preperitoneal insufflation



Reference: Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition Page no 652

questions.text: Which gas is commonly used in pneumoperitoneum, which involves inflating the abdominal cavity during laparoscopic surgery?
questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide is the appropriate gas to utilize in pneumoperitoneum. In laparoscopic or minimally invasive surgery, the pheumoperitoneum technique is utilized to make a working area inside the abdominal cavity.

For this reason, CO2 is the ideal gas for a number of reasons:

1. Non-Flammable: Because CO2 doesn't catch fire, it's safer to employ during surgical procedures where there are electrical equipment around.

2. Minimal Absorption: Since CO2 absorbs very little from the body, it can be injected into the belly cavity without having a major physiological impact.

3. Rapid Absorption: CO2 is swiftly absorbed into the bloodstream and can be removed through respiration following the procedure, lowering the risk of post-operative problems.

4. Low Cost: CO2 is affordable and widely accessible.

Other gases like oxygen, nitrous oxide, or nitrogen are not preferred due to higher risk of combustion, gas embolism, or poor absorption.


Reference
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition - Page no: 1053-1056
